>again.  Any interest?  How many of you still consider yourselves ravers?

best post yet
props, apollo.

it's tough bein' a raver in the states these days.
i resorted to being a gypsy just to hump speakers to good t3kno.
the gas prices are killing me and the soundsystems are becoming more the 
size of mine.

i'm not sure what the hell happened, but i'm hearing it from everyone.
this doesn't even fit into the "old & jaded" category.

i've even started to go to salsa & swing clubs just to find some real 
dancers.
it's beautiful & all but their lasers,     well..........

now i guess we've all become what we were supposed to be,

consumers.
shall we drink at a club now????

-ras

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

Maybe the decline has more to do with the staggering economy (esp'ly)
in SF rather than 9/11. If u got half the city's hi-tech employees
getting pink-slips and have to flip burgers or wait tables just to get
by, it's kinda hard to find room for passion. The only spirit
remaining is mere survival.

I don't know if I still want to call myself a raver, I always hated
that term. It's been bastardized, commercialized and routinely
stereotyped. While I still believe in the spirit and will be forever,
it's a loaded label that I'm afraid to put on myself.

Much of our scene has been poisoned by posers and corporatism, so
nowadays I find myself gravitated to the BM crowd (though I'm
definitely a raver not a burner), where love is still pure and
universal like our old days (and I mean REALLY OLD days).

I rarely expect to find love and unity when I go out nowadays, it's
just not there (though I'm sure you have it better in SF). I go out
for my passion for music, and I feel reasonably satisfied most of the
time. Maybe I'm jaded, I don't know.

I do know that I can't change the scene nor the world. But I also know
that I do represent a philosophy, and I try to do my part and go out
and reprazent proper. I think that's the least anyone could do.

I'm sure the scene will thrive again, the love will be rediscovered.
The cycle will continue. Until the next summer of love, I'll just be
hibernating I guess.  LOL

- Jeff










On Thu, 30 Sep 2004 22:57:24 -0700, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> 
> I think it was Steph who remarked on this list right after 9/11
> that:  "...the world has changed forever."  Stuck in my mind.  She was
> absolutely right, of course.  Things change.  And the world changes us.
> 
> Sure, I would like the "old" sfraves back, but  before 9/11 there was a
> time when we were actually moderated:  lots of anarchy and disruption on
> the list in those days.  Much more interesting than now.  The list had some
> passion then.
> 
> What do we have now?  The only regular party reviews posted to sfraves are
> from Osby, and someone recently complained that he should combine his posts
> into one for whatever reason.  Aside from Osby, most of the posts tend to
> be one liners.  If there is any consistency here, it is that people
> complain about volume on a sadly low volume list.
> 
> Some people only post here when they are throwing a party, but contribute
> nothing otherwise.
> 
> The handful of collectives who actually throw undergrounds no longer post
> them here, but they do on BayRaves.  Why?  I was surprised to find that
> many good people I associated with sfraves post regularly there too.  But
> not here.  Why?
> 
> Yep, I would love to talk about the "philosophy of raving" here again.  Any
> interest?  How many of you still consider yourselves ravers?  When have we
> last discussed raving here?
> 
> Sfraves has changed, but it is not one of those changes that is outside of
> our collective control, like 9/11.  It seems we have decided to go in the
> direction of some other rave-related lists I could mention:  lots of
> silence.  But, then, you do save all that time deleting things and
> configuring people blockers.  Not that there are that many people left to
> block:)
> 
> Love,
>

Received: (qmail 82626 invoked from network); 1 Oct 2004 09:34:09 -0000
Date: Fri, 1 Oct 2004 02:34:09 -0700 (PDT)
From: Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
cc: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>, Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <20041001021705.I25254@taz3.hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] From moderator: please read

Apollo, Starchild, SFR-listers...

As the moderator of this list (actually I'm only the gnome on duty behind 
the curtain)...I appreciate your exchange. Your expressions are a classic 
debate, although coincidentally happening on the eve of our presidential 
debate...oops, political, bad moderator, bad. ;-)

However, you both bring up good points.

I'm sure Brian would have never believed that his simple attempt to find 
raves here in nor-cal back in '93, plus his adeptness at creating 
discussion lists would bring us here today. I joined this list back in '95 
also to find parties...and *boy* did I find parties =) A large percentage 
of us here found SFRaves the same way.

When I joined, I was impressed that this list was a single stream of 
consciousness, or an "organic community" as stated. It also had an amazing 
level of that "organic" organization in creating events and disseminating 
info on related events. I have learned so much from engaging this list 
from active discussion to personal relations. And the stories produced 
from my experiences due to this list will be retold in my grand-age.

I met Starchild in '96 at Bonnie Dunes at a daytime Harmony party. And 
while our exchanges have been brief, we were strangers by face but family 
as the SFR community. He was one of the PLURy characters on SFR that made 
me believe there was something more than my life at the time.

I met Apollo in '99 at Mission Rock, about a week after he posted to SFR 
about starting the Moksha Tribe. We had a interesting rave-scene 
discussion as strangers by face but more as family of the SFR community.

Perhaps it's just me, but I'm proud to be at the helm of a discussion 
today where these minds can meet, continuing this stream of consciousness.

Enough of my exposition from this point (thanks for listening =)...

While Starchild has returned to SFR charged with politicalism, I still 
read his posts, because while this is "rave" list, we are an "OLD-rave" 
list, and I find find it interesting in reading the political views of my 
peers. This list keeps me grounded in times of uncertainty. And while I 
may not agree with everything that is being said here, I refer here to the 
pulse of others that have gone through the same stuff as I have.

Apollo has passively suggested that our list has become complacent. Low 
signal to the noise, and less of all, which I also acknowledge. The old 
SFRaves dynamic is moving farther away every day, and has been for many 
years. I have no answer to this. We are who we are. This is what it is. 
Many of the people on this list are that same people that have been here 
for years.

SFRaves is a unique list, and it *has* changed, and it will continue to 
change. But I hope you all understand that this list, this discussion, and 
our tangible outcome is *yours*. I'm not here to tell you what to do, or 
what to think, or how to act, or how to learn. None of us are.

We're just here by chance, and *hopefully* have some sort of a shared 
consciousness that we can discuss, learn and grow, and maybe even take 
action...whether it be help us find some cool places to check out, or 
throw some really fun parties for ourselves, or talk about how electronic 
music or raves, or how it changed our lives...or perhaps discuss random 
thoughts, news & events, and yes even ::shudder:: politics...as it relates 
to ourselves.

I'm sure I have much more to say, but y'all do much better job in your 
collective discussion than I. Thanks for listening.

take care,

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

Things are hard. They require hard work, which makes them hard. But we have 
to do these hard things with resolve. We can't send mixed messages about the

they require resolve.

Thank you, and God bless America.

George W. Bush

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

On Fri, 01 Oct 2004 07:25:56 +0000, "time accelerator"
wrote:
 
> now i guess we've all become what we were supposed to
> be,
> 
> consumers.
> shall we drink at a club now????

you know... i couldn't agree anymore. i argued for
years with my family, who always asked, "when are you
going to grow out of this rave shit?" that as long as
there was a viable scene, i was going to be a part of
it.. 

but these days i'm not.  i haven't been to a "rave" in
god knows how long.. the closed thing i can think of
would be a full moon party on koh phangan this summer,
but even that really isn't the same...

perhaps viable is the key word.. the way this economy
is  with so many of us out of work or struggling on a
salary that hardly makes living in one of the most
expensive cities in the country easy, there is not as
much freedom as we once had.  it costs me $10 in gas
and bridge fare and a 45 minute drive just to go out to
the city for a night, nevermind ticket costs or cover
charges, or other expenses... 

i remember a time when i used to wonder why people
would drink at parties, then slowly i became one of
those people.. the people i threw parties with all
started to move towards club nights and other things...
the love of the music still there, but the drive and
determination to go out and search for underground
venues, to bust ass pulling a one-off together with a
group of friends, to party until 6am then cleaning up
together before heading off for breakfast.... it all
dwindled... we "grew-up" and out of the scene... got
older and started worrying more about the legal
reprucussions in a society more aware and more hostile
to our world... lost the ability and desire to stay up
until all hours of the night, and the idea of crawling
into bed sometime before the sun comes up took the
place of the idea of staying up to watch the sunrise...

i definitely cherrish all the memories, and especially
the friendships formed then, and still hanging on
now... but perhaps i have in a way, "grown out of all
that rave shit".  because i know there are still events
going on now, but maybe im too jaded for it... maybe
the years i had in this scene when it was so much more
alive and thriving ruined me for a scene that seems
struggling to hold on and recreate something that once
just existed.  

i will always hold those memories and experiences in a
special place in my heart, but like everything in life,
there comes a time to evolve... so maybe i'e evolved
with the  music and the friendships i've created and
moved onto other outlets and venues.... 

ok, enough babbling.. this is what happens when i try
to read email before having my morning tea.. ;)

love and hugs and kisses,
tina

http://moonchyld1.livejournal.com

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] From moderator: please read

Again, I'd like to point out that there are political discussion
lists that are more appropriate. Brian runs a very high-quality one
where a lot of you can *really* get your politics on.  Ask him about
it.

I'm not saying that politics don't ever belong here. We discussed a
LOT of politics in the debacles that eventually led to the formation
of the SFLNC and the SF Entertainment Commission. I consider that
entirely germane.

But I do think that most of the politics lately: "Hey *this* sucks",
"Hey *that* sucks", Bush, Bush, Bush, Bush, Bush, Bush, Iraq, Iraq,
Iraq, Moore, Moore, Bush, Bush, etc. are getting really tedious. And
most aren't really any discussion at all, but reposted URLs or media
stories that I'm already bombarded with. They're at a frequency of
posts that it's elevated to the level of spam. I've started putting
hard mail filters on people. I really hate to do that most of all.

There's no difference to me between Captain Stupid putting up 60
spams a day, and 20 people putting up three, each thinking they
won't make much difference.

Sigh, I'm pretty close to throwing my hands up and unsubbing. I can
barely find the wheat in the chaff.

Sean

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

Are we really in a decline?

In '93, people were saying the same thing, "rave is dead".
Same thing in '97.
Same thing in '00.

So, has it really declined?

I also wonder how the Entertainment Commission has affected things.
It's possible to get permits now, whereas in the mid 90s, it was not
possible to get one at all. Period.

I don't see that much difference in party activity, but maybe I'm
just not seeing it.

I dunno... what do you think?

Sean

From sfraves-return-116140-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Oct 01 17:32:35 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-116140-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 46749 invoked by uid 1103); 1 Oct 2004 17:32:34 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 46735 invoked from network); 1 Oct 2004 17:32:33 -0000
Message-ID: <20041001173231.18775.qmail@web60308.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 1 Oct 2004 10:32:31 -0700 (PDT)
From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20041001093626.3724.h013.c021.wm@mail.viberation.com.criticalpath.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Cmon!  Was: Re:  (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

--- tina <tina@viberation.com> wrote:
> i definitely cherrish all the memories, and especially
> the friendships formed then, and still hanging on
> now... but perhaps i have in a way, "grown out of all
> that rave shit".  because i know there are still events
> going on now, but maybe im too jaded for it... 

You people depress the heck out of me! ;)  The scene has become
complacent and events are not coming as rapid-fire as they once were,
but I must have had 10-20 awesome experiences at "raves" this summer
alone.  Sure, a good bit of that number was made up of campouts and
renegade outdoors, but hey, it's summer.

I'm not 21 or 22 and I still relish the sunrise.  I'm not just exiting
college, and I still feel the PLUR out there when the right event hits
at the right time with the right people.  I entered the scene around
'99 so I never really saw the heyday, so to speak, but much like a
favorite defunct band whose members are all still ALIVE and VIABLE, I
have to wonder why we aren't a little more motivated to do it all over
again?

The RAVE act sought to bury our culture and has had little impact
besides spooking some venue owners out of hosting parties.  What do the
"kids" do?  They break into fabled old venues and use unlikely spaces
that somehow squeak just under the radar.  One of the more giddy, "oh
my god, how the f*** are the cops not here right now :)" moments I had
this summer was at that Element party, where there were cracked-out
candy kids milling around in plain view of a major street.  Nothing
happened, except a fun party with a suprisingly with-it lineup.

The glimmer in all of this is thus:  The more understated we get and
the longer this sort of half-cocked hiatus lasts, the more underground
the scene goes- until, perhaps, the watchful post-9/11 eyes lose
interest and we can strike out and be a little bolder.  Moksha Tribe
has been having a tough time finding a venue of late, but you can bet
that once that gets squared away (and it seems to be about to be), we
will be throwing more sweaty, crazy, unifying "raves", because we
believe the area, and the world in general, needs it.  ..and let's face
it, we just like to have fun.

Does anybody else like to have fun?  :)

I gave BayRaves it's first shot last night after all the talk of it,
and I have to say, it's a pretty energizing place, for all of its
highschool drama.  I'll have to start paying attention.  In the
meantime I have become more of a clubber than I ever was before.  There
is not such a sense of decline in clubland, and there is PLUR to be
found on some of the better dancefloors out there.  Alcohol and its
abusers do not thrill me at all, and that is the major turnoff of the
clubs for me.  

I'm thinking of trying to find a space to host small afterparties for
club events so people that want to go all night and maybe get a little
crazier than they can in the clubs can do their thing.  It'd get some
new blood into the scene and it'd be a lot of fun.  Something sort of
like an afterhours version of "The Loft" in NYC that Apollo outlines in
House Music 101.  

Right, like I need another excuse to lose sleep ;)  These days I am
much more involved in making dance music than dancing to it, and that's
fine- but I would be really happy to the "the band get back together",
so to speak.  FnF, Cloudfactory, Viberation peoples- all of you are
very much alive, young, vibrant, and creative.  The campouts this year
were breathtaking.  Let's see some warehouses get defiled!  Let's see
some minds blown! 

Let's do this thang before it's way, way too late.

"Do not go gentle into that good night,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light."

AMEN. :)

Love,
-george c.
-newstylesound recordings
-djorigami.com
-newstylesound.com

  

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

to see and hear.

Hmmmm...
 
>From a Sacramento point of view, if that carries any weight at all, it has declined.  I remember 2 years ago there were random campouts almost every weekend throughout summer in the sierra foothills.  Hell, sometimes there were the occasional party up in the tahoe area.  I remember BFE some years ago that was busted up, then re-organized in placerville for a 2nd night. Good times.
 
I also always remember hearing here and there about modesto/stockton parties, and their success.  I haven't heard of any of these lately.
 
Anyone interested in orchestrating maybe a once-a-year hyperreal-member (sacraves/sfraves/whoever else) type campout? It's been a pipedream I've had for awhile, but I got generators to donate!!
 
Too much redbull...
Tofershizzle
 
Campouts are GRRRRATE!!

Sean Casey <sean@cloudfactory.org> wrote:
Are we really in a decline?

In '93, people were saying the same thing, "rave is dead".
Same thing in '97.
Same thing in '00.

So, has it really declined?

I also wonder how the Entertainment Commission has affected things.
It's possible to get permits now, whereas in the mid 90s, it was not
possible to get one at all. Period.

I don't see that much difference in party activity, but maybe I'm
just not seeing it.

I dunno... what do you think?

Sean

From sfraves-return-116153-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Oct 01 20:44:44 2004

Message-ID: <20041001204438.36133.qmail@web53202.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 1 Oct 2004 13:44:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: "michael, the red stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20041001173231.18775.qmail@web60308.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Cmon!  Was: Re:  (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

excellent post.

i think the trick is to constantly change, while at the same
time have fun.  i've been partying on and off since '89, but
not always in the same context.  god, how boring that'd be.

feel like you're stagnating?  help out at a party for a little
bit.  maybe get some records together and join the too-many-DJs
posse that is san francisco.  throw your own party.  poduce
your own tracks.  or do something completely different...

for me, it's always been about the music.  it's been a social
scene, yes, but the music is what drew me in, and keeps me
here.  i don't necessarily like all the music that's played in
SF, but i certainly love the stuff that i play out.

m

--- georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:

> --- tina <tina@viberation.com> wrote:
> > i definitely cherrish all the memories, and especially
> > the friendships formed then, and still hanging on
> > now... but perhaps i have in a way, "grown out of all
> > that rave shit".  because i know there are still events
> > going on now, but maybe im too jaded for it... 
> 
> You people depress the heck out of me! ;)  The scene has
> become
> complacent and events are not coming as rapid-fire as they
> once were,
> but I must have had 10-20 awesome experiences at "raves" this
> summer
> alone.  Sure, a good bit of that number was made up of
> campouts and
> renegade outdoors, but hey, it's summer.
> 
> I'm not 21 or 22 and I still relish the sunrise.  I'm not
> just exiting
> college, and I still feel the PLUR out there when the right
> event hits
> at the right time with the right people.  I entered the scene
> around
> '99 so I never really saw the heyday, so to speak, but much
> like a
> favorite defunct band whose members are all still ALIVE and
> VIABLE, I
> have to wonder why we aren't a little more motivated to do it
> all over
> again?
> 
> The RAVE act sought to bury our culture and has had little
> impact
> besides spooking some venue owners out of hosting parties. 
> What do the
> "kids" do?  They break into fabled old venues and use
> unlikely spaces
> that somehow squeak just under the radar.  One of the more
> giddy, "oh
> my god, how the f*** are the cops not here right now :)"
> moments I had
> this summer was at that Element party, where there were
> cracked-out
> candy kids milling around in plain view of a major street. 
> Nothing
> happened, except a fun party with a suprisingly with-it
> lineup.
> 
> The glimmer in all of this is thus:  The more understated we
> get and
> the longer this sort of half-cocked hiatus lasts, the more
> underground
> the scene goes- until, perhaps, the watchful post-9/11 eyes
> lose
> interest and we can strike out and be a little bolder. 
> Moksha Tribe
> has been having a tough time finding a venue of late, but you
> can bet
> that once that gets squared away (and it seems to be about to
> be), we
> will be throwing more sweaty, crazy, unifying "raves",
> because we
> believe the area, and the world in general, needs it.  ..and
> let's face
> it, we just like to have fun.
> 
> Does anybody else like to have fun?  :)
> 
> I gave BayRaves it's first shot last night after all the talk
> of it,
> and I have to say, it's a pretty energizing place, for all of
> its
> highschool drama.  I'll have to start paying attention.  In
> the
> meantime I have become more of a clubber than I ever was
> before.  There
> is not such a sense of decline in clubland, and there is PLUR
> to be
> found on some of the better dancefloors out there.  Alcohol
> and its
> abusers do not thrill me at all, and that is the major
> turnoff of the
> clubs for me.  
> 
> I'm thinking of trying to find a space to host small
> afterparties for
> club events so people that want to go all night and maybe get
> a little
> crazier than they can in the clubs can do their thing.  It'd
> get some
> new blood into the scene and it'd be a lot of fun.  Something
> sort of
> like an afterhours version of "The Loft" in NYC that Apollo
> outlines in
> House Music 101.  
> 
> Right, like I need another excuse to lose sleep ;)  These
> days I am
> much more involved in making dance music than dancing to it,
> and that's
> fine- but I would be really happy to the "the band get back
> together",
> so to speak.  FnF, Cloudfactory, Viberation peoples- all of
> you are
> very much alive, young, vibrant, and creative.  The campouts
> this year
> were breathtaking.  Let's see some warehouses get defiled! 
> Let's see
> some minds blown! 
> 
> Let's do this thang before it's way, way too late.
> 
> "Do not go gentle into that good night,
> Rage, rage against the dying of the light."
> 
> AMEN. :)
> 
> Love,
> -george c.
> -newstylesound recordings
> -djorigami.com
> -newstylesound.com
> 
>   
> 
>

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

wearing a big 'ol backpack all day.

(A Love Parade After Party)
In celebration of electronic music and arts
Brought to you by: Drum Machine Museum, 
Daly City Records, Concept, Trouble, and TeknotikaSF!

<http://www.drummachine.com/LMSF04.html>

Date: Saturday October 2, 2004 
Place: Please call the info line the day of 415.244.5507
Time: 7pm till next morning

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 10:28 AM 10/1/2004, Sean Casey wrote:
>Are we really in a decline?
>
>In '93, people were saying the same thing, "rave is dead".
>Same thing in '97.
>Same thing in '00.
>
>So, has it really declined?
>
>I also wonder how the Entertainment Commission has affected things.
>It's possible to get permits now, whereas in the mid 90s, it was not
>possible to get one at all. Period.
>
>I don't see that much difference in party activity, but maybe I'm
>just not seeing it.
>
>I dunno... what do you think?
>
>Sean

I've made the same argument, Sean, and still believe some aspects of raving 
are alive....and, of course, no one knows what the future may hold.  I'm 
still optimistic, but not to the degree I was even a year ago.

As for this list and politics, Sean, addressing your prior post:  yes there 
are numerous list for the discussion of politics.  I'm on more of them than 
I would like these days.  But there are also many lists devoted to music, 
EDM, and various genres.  There are discussion groups focused on music 
production.  Better lists for party information than sfraves these 
days.  What makes us different?

I was listening to Cornel West today on NPR.  The man's wisdom, 
intellectual achievement, and vast understanding of philosophy and history 
are remarkable.  But it is his "musical" approach to politics that makes my 
heart sing, as do the passion with which he invests his beliefs.  West said 
that to him "democracy" was a verb:  that is, a way of life; a belief 
system that is actionable in everyday life.

Early raving was like that.  It was not just "the music," or esoteric 
discussions of music making, or fun parties.  Yes, all these components 
somehow made up the whole of raving, but there was more behind it than just 
technique and getting high with friends one day a week.  One thing I admire 
about Starchild is that to me he is an example of a maturing raver who has 
taken what he learned in our community and actualized these beliefs in his 
life.  I don't agree with all of the Libertarian agenda, but I understand 
how integrating early rave ideals could be manifest in parts of that agenda.

So, what is/was raving?  What is different in our community twelve years later?

In the early nineties there were lots of clubs.  Good ones.  Much more free 
than now, with minimal security.  Why in the hell did the early ravers 
decided to throw underground, un permitted parties?  Makes no sense.  As 
Tina implied it's lots of trouble;  requires much tiring labor;  opens the 
promoter to great liability;  and for most of us then and now creates no 
monetary return.  Lots easier to throw a club night.

The early rave community was much older than the demographic in the late 
nineties.  So one  can't say they were a bunch of underage kids looking for 
ways to drink, smoke, take drugs and party all night long until they were 
old enough to get into clubs.  There were other motivations -- much more 
powerful -- in play then.  What were they?  Do they still exist?

I was thinking about all this at Catch 20-2 when the police came barging 
into our un permitted event.  At the very same time a guest who had 
swallowed a whole box of cough suppressant pills was freaking out and I had 
no idea what his physical condition was.  While waiting for the EMT's 
assessment I asked myself why am I doing these parties?  Worse case 
scenario the guest will need an ambulance, the police are right outside, 
and we all could be going to court:)  I must have stronger reasons for 
doing these events than making "fun" parties.  Perhaps Starchild remembers 
what these beliefs are.

Sure, there are lots of club nights these days.  Clubs seem to be doing 
OK.  Lots of booze again.  And there are the ubiquitous campouts during the 
summer.  The remnants of the old rave scene seemed to be defined by the 
campout now.  Lot safer and easier to do a couple of these a year. But for 
those of us unable or unwilling to do campouts ain't much out there but 
clubs and booze.  As far as I know there are two collectives who regularly 
do outdoor FMRs and the remarkable Modified people who actually still do 
break ins.  Telic is not, IMHO, and underground.  There is a house 
collective in SF that throws one of two ugs (usually terribly oversold and 
uncomfortable) a year.  And Moksha.  Our last event was in March.

Urban development has certainly reduced the number of reasonable 
underground venues available.  9/11 has, as Tina suggested, created more of 
a "police state" here and elsewhere.  Why bother with the big trouble of 
throwing an underground when you can rent a club?:)  Get into the business 
of selling booze?

The 18+ permits in SF, Sean, are fine for those who throw rather large 
parties, charge a hefty ticket price, and sell many things inside the 
venue, but the economics of finding a space that is not a bar yet still 
meets fire and other requirements is daunting and very expensive for those 
interested in throwing more intimate 3-400 person events.

I'm implying here, of course, that raving has something to do with 
underground, un permitted parties that provide a measure of freedom and 
liberation not found elsewhere.  If this is no longer true, then raving is 
dead.  Go to clubs.  Do club events.  I spent two thirds of my dance and 
music life in clubs, beginning with the Paradise Garage.  I had fun. But 
then, the PG didn't serve booze.  They provided LSD punch:)

Lots of questions in my mind these days.

As for this list and politics:  well, if raving is truly a way of life with 
a belief system, then everything is connected here.  One can't have 
temporary autonomous zones in a police state.  If life has become 24/7 
survival with no time for personal development, then that's a political, 
economic problem that affects raving.  If we are now just looking for a 
good club every couple of weeks to dance a little, drink, and leave at two 
when the bar closes then we are no longer ravers.  If we learned nothing 
about compassion, empathy, love and community from our raving experiences, 
then I think we were not raving.

Love,

Apollo






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"The truth is where the truth is, and it's sometimes in the candy store."
-Bob Dylan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

I could never understand why people COULDN'T find all the "connectiveness"
at clubs. Granted, it depends on where you're at, but the vast majority of
what I consider to be VERY "rave" moments were at  nightcluba in DC (namely
Buzz). I was raving long before going to Buzz, but that's where I forged
REAL bonds with people - and this wasn't until '99. I started raving in
'91 - you do the math.

I think it REALLY comes down to what people bring to the table. Are they
openminded, willing to meet new people, let themselves go, relax, lose the
'tude and not focus all their attention on being a scenester - or are you
just there to bitch about the music, the club the dj, the drink prices,
security, etc. ?

There're only two noticeable differences between undergrounds and clubs. A
bar and legality. Other than that, it's a dark spot, where dance music is
played over a huge soundsystem of some kind, where hopefully - people are
dancing.  It's the ravers that make the party what it is. I have been to
parties where there have been sick lineups - and the vibe sucked ass because
people were bitchy, or didn't feel like showing. I have been to crappy
little parties with no-name dj's that rocked socks - because the crowds vibe
was tangible.

*Each and every one of us can make or break that vibe. When you have people
who won't leave the city to go to the East Bay, and vice versa, DJ's who
won't go to parties they aren't playing at, people who are (insert genre
name here) fans that will ONLY go to that particular genre club and/or party
night...things aren't gonna be great. Things stagnate.

BTW - it's like this all over the country. Over-commercialization of the
scene, crackheads with no ability to moderate their drug use, archaic drug
laws and witch-hunts, coupled with a great deal of people "growing up" and
moving on (*and the aforementioned reasons) accounts for most of why things
are the way they are.

People are forced to go legit in order to keep the party going. Some of us
may not like that idea - but it's a necessary evil in my book.

For me - I just go where I like the beats the best. Could be a dirty
warehouse, could be a sparkling new club - it could even be someone's
apartment with 5 other people kickin' it. Rave - much like punk was to me
(and a lot of other folks) isn't what you wear, or what you say - it's who
you are, it's a state of mind.

Pardon my rambling...this thread has had me thinking.

-M

than
> I would like these days.  But there are also many lists devoted to music,
> EDM, and various genres.  There are discussion groups focused on music
> production.  Better lists for party information than sfraves these
> days.  What makes us different?
>
> I was listening to Cornel West today on NPR.  The man's wisdom,
> intellectual achievement, and vast understanding of philosophy and history
> are remarkable.  But it is his "musical" approach to politics that makes
my
> heart sing, as do the passion with which he invests his beliefs.  West
said
> that to him "democracy" was a verb:  that is, a way of life; a belief
> system that is actionable in everyday life.
>
> Early raving was like that.  It was not just "the music," or esoteric
> discussions of music making, or fun parties.  Yes, all these components
> somehow made up the whole of raving, but there was more behind it than
just
> technique and getting high with friends one day a week.  One thing I
admire
> about Starchild is that to me he is an example of a maturing raver who has
> taken what he learned in our community and actualized these beliefs in his
> life.  I don't agree with all of the Libertarian agenda, but I understand
> how integrating early rave ideals could be manifest in parts of that
agenda.
>
> So, what is/was raving?  What is different in our community twelve years
later?
>
> In the early nineties there were lots of clubs.  Good ones.  Much more
free
> than now, with minimal security.  Why in the hell did the early ravers
> decided to throw underground, un permitted parties?  Makes no sense.  As
> Tina implied it's lots of trouble;  requires much tiring labor;  opens the
> promoter to great liability;  and for most of us then and now creates no
> monetary return.  Lots easier to throw a club night.
>
> The early rave community was much older than the demographic in the late
> nineties.  So one  can't say they were a bunch of underage kids looking
for
> ways to drink, smoke, take drugs and party all night long until they were
> old enough to get into clubs.  There were other motivations -- much more
> powerful -- in play then.  What were they?  Do they still exist?
>
> I was thinking about all this at Catch 20-2 when the police came barging
> into our un permitted event.  At the very same time a guest who had
> swallowed a whole box of cough suppressant pills was freaking out and I
had
> no idea what his physical condition was.  While waiting for the EMT's
> assessment I asked myself why am I doing these parties?  Worse case
> scenario the guest will need an ambulance, the police are right outside,
> and we all could be going to court:)  I must have stronger reasons for
> doing these events than making "fun" parties.  Perhaps Starchild remembers
> what these beliefs are.
>
> Sure, there are lots of club nights these days.  Clubs seem to be doing
> OK.  Lots of booze again.  And there are the ubiquitous campouts during
the
> summer.  The remnants of the old rave scene seemed to be defined by the
> campout now.  Lot safer and easier to do a couple of these a year. But for
> those of us unable or unwilling to do campouts ain't much out there but
> clubs and booze.  As far as I know there are two collectives who regularly
> do outdoor FMRs and the remarkable Modified people who actually still do
> break ins.  Telic is not, IMHO, and underground.  There is a house
> collective in SF that throws one of two ugs (usually terribly oversold and
> uncomfortable) a year.  And Moksha.  Our last event was in March.
>
> Urban development has certainly reduced the number of reasonable
> underground venues available.  9/11 has, as Tina suggested, created more
of
> a "police state" here and elsewhere.  Why bother with the big trouble of
> throwing an underground when you can rent a club?:)  Get into the business
> of selling booze?
>
> The 18+ permits in SF, Sean, are fine for those who throw rather large
> parties, charge a hefty ticket price, and sell many things inside the
> venue, but the economics of finding a space that is not a bar yet still
> meets fire and other requirements is daunting and very expensive for those
> interested in throwing more intimate 3-400 person events.
>
> I'm implying here, of course, that raving has something to do with
> underground, un permitted parties that provide a measure of freedom and
> liberation not found elsewhere.  If this is no longer true, then raving is
> dead.  Go to clubs.  Do club events.  I spent two thirds of my dance and
> music life in clubs, beginning with the Paradise Garage.  I had fun. But
> then, the PG didn't serve booze.  They provided LSD punch:)
>
> Lots of questions in my mind these days.
>
> As for this list and politics:  well, if raving is truly a way of life
with
> a belief system, then everything is connected here.  One can't have
> temporary autonomous zones in a police state.  If life has become 24/7
> survival with no time for personal development, then that's a political,
> economic problem that affects raving.  If we are now just looking for a
> good club every couple of weeks to dance a little, drink, and leave at two
> when the bar closes then we are no longer ravers.  If we learned nothing
> about compassion, empathy, love and community from our raving experiences,
> then I think we were not raving.
>
> Love,
>
> Apollo
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
> Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein
>
> "The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands
> of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible
> empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
> -Woodrow Wilson
>
> "The truth is where the truth is, and it's sometimes in the candy store."
> -Bob Dylan
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>
>

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Received: (qmail 72455 invoked from network); 1 Oct 2004 22:22:15 -0000
Date: Fri, 1 Oct 2004 15:22:11 -0700
From: Sean Casey <sean@cloudfactory.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20041001222211.GL32566@cloudfactory.org>
Mail-Followup-To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <415C560C.4040704@netscape.net> <70C2D34D-132E-11D9-B895-003065DA480A@earthlink.net> <6.1.2.0.2.20040930223807.029adb38@localhost> <b7941d4c0410010101536d228d@mail.gmail.com> <20041001172815.GE32566@cloudfactory.org> <6.1.2.0.2.20041001135544.029b4c80@localhost>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <6.1.2.0.2.20041001135544.029b4c80@localhost>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

Thanks for the great post, Apollo!

I am not very enthused about the club scene, myself. Yeah there were
all the Wickeds and the Spundae's etc., a lot of them really going
off. But the legal spaces like the King St. Garage never really
appealed to me. The drinking vibe was all different. The club vibe
was all different.

Underground has a special energy... I'm not sure why. Is it the fact
that one is "getting away" with something? People flocked to our
Urban Wasteland parties despite the fact that we never had much
production at all and things were always just a little on the edge.
We got busted plenty of times, and more times, we weren't. People
came to expect that possiblity, and it was part of the adrenaline
ride. Lord I don't know how many times I've talked to the cops
myself, maybe 30 times???

Is the danger, the "undergound factor" a magic ingredient? I wonder.
I *know* if I threw a party in a "virgin" warehouse space, there'd
be a vibe I'd never see at a club.

I also wonder if the fact that permits are available eventually will
mean that enforcement will be harsher for those without one. This is
not an effect the people who founded the Entertainment Commission
would have wanted, I'm sure of that.

And you're totally right about the cost. It may be possible to get
permits now, but getting a space to meet all the fire code and other
requirements, even though it is factually safe to have the party
without improvements, can be outrageously expensive. I'd like to see
some sort of cost analysis to get an average space fully permitted.
I'd guess that unless it's dialed-in code-wise, the average cost is
in the tens of thousands of dollars.

That said, is the scene really dead? I'm one of the original Friends
and Family founders, and we just don't throw very many parties
anymore (nice analysis on the campout thing, btw). And yet there are
some spinoffs doing really well. Brass Tax always seems to rock the
house. I *very* much recommend going to their events. They've got
new energy whereas a lot of us FnFers have been going at it over a
decade.

(And by the way, even though I started in '93 at the age of 31 (!!),
I am *nowhere* near done. I only party like mad maybe 4 or 5 times a
year, and I love it, but I'm nowhere near done yet. :-P)

Who are the new tribes? That was always where the big energy was
coming from, once some people get fairly well organized, there
seemed a frenzy of energy. I think the older tribes have perhaps
stopped drawing in as much new people. Probably my biggest role (and
perhaps still) -- was meeting new people and connecting them with
others. The scene always needs new energy. It is an equilibrium, and
it is good.

But the ideas persist. Most of our society is still separationist.
There is a lot of conservative thought. And there is always the
resistance to that. I think that's where a lot of us come from.

And rave I think comes ultimately from the tribal drums. The group
experience of letting go and expression through beats and dance.
It's many tens of thousands of years old, and I don't think it will
just die away like that. We may be in a lull, but there is something
deep in us that responds, and the lull is probably temporary. It may
be rediscovered, it may take on new form, but there is something so
deep and primal that isn't just going to go away. Not until we're
wired differently. Perhaps we will evolve beyond it eventually. But
for now, the attraction to the beat way inside, and how that
connects us to ourselves and others, will persist for a long long
time. I'd bank on it.

Finally, again, people have always always always been saying the
scene is dead. It was dead when I started, and it's still dead. And
yet there's a Love Parade tomorrow and some afterparties that will
be utterly ballistic. This didn't all happen because people were
ready to give up. It happened because they really want to do this
thing, because it means *so much* to them. Enough to take risks
(monetary and otherwise). Enough to put forth a huge amount of
effort.

The rave scene isn't dead. It changes, and it's different for
everyone. As long as someone beats on drums and someone dances, it's
alive. Deep in the brain, you respond. You dance. And it's good.

Sean





---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: "manpurse"

I have this manpurse/fannypack hybrid. It's like a fanny pack that's
flat, or maybe u can see it as a manpurse with a waist belt. I't's as
practical as a genuine  fanny pack but with the contemporary styling
of a proper manurpse.  LMAO  :)

I used to never wear it cuz it's just, well.... a manpurse is a
manpurse (and I had it for 4 years). Then I started wearing it a lot
since I got an iPod: It carries the iPod, accessories, my PDA, my cell
phone, etc. All in one place. I no longer have to check all 6-7
cargo-pant pockets to find something.

Manpurses are grate, I'm a believer now. Let's embrace the fashion
victim in us all.  :)



- Jeff

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v619)

Message-Id: <C1FE6304-1401-11D9-AA03-00050209EDF8@yahoo.com>

Cc: "Sean Casey" <sean@cloudfactory.org>,
 "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>,
  <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 1 Oct 2004 16:29:36 -0700
To: "electrofunk138" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.619)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

Well, for me, that feeling of "connectiveness" is just entirely killed 
by the alcohol-fueled meat-market vibe of clubs.

Maybe I'm a hypocrite for being being negative about some drugs, while 
being positively disposed towards others.  Whatever.  I don't like 
alcohol.  To be more specific, I don't like being surrounded by large 
numbers of drunk people.  When I am, there are really only two options 
for me:

1) Get drunk myself.
2) Leave.

And, given the fact that BART and MUNI shut down overnight, my 
transportation situation usually makes #1 impossible.

Bitch about the irresponsibility.  Complain about the e-puddles 
crowding the dance floor.  Whatever.  The fact is... that wether I've 
decided to be sober, or indulge in some drug or another (even if it's 
alcohol... yah... maybe that makes me more of a hypocrite), I'd much 
rather be stuck in the midst of a thousand e-tards than just a hundred 
drunks.  Even if the "connectiveness" of those e-tards is more 
chemically induced than not, they're STILL a damn sight more pleasant 
than the drunks.  And let's not even GET into the belligerent drunks.  
The worst that can happen to you with an overbearing 'tard, after all, 
is that they'll tell you their life story and give you a big sweaty 
hug.

Then there's the meat-market thing.  I go out to have fun.  That's it.  
If I happen to meet someone, that's great.  But that's not my 
motivation behind going out.  The idea, that if you don't "hook up" on 
a given night you're a failure, is ludicrous in my mind.  There's more 
to life than empty sex.  Some time ago (Just after Blake's forced 
Ascension to end, actually.), I went through a stint of going to Faith 
fairly regularly with some friends (Nothing to do on thursdays now, and 
may as well give clubs a second chance, after all.).  And, often, by 
the time we'd make it through the crappy music and shady people in the 
front room to the (fairly decent, usually) main room, I'd have 
accumulated half a dozen free condoms.  And I could've easily had more 
if I actually picked them up myself, in addition to taking the ones 
actively given me.  Now, it's definitely good that this sort of thing 
is available.  But, for a while, the floor of my car was littered with 
so many free (unused) condoms that it was positively absurd.  And the 
intrinsic message behind that level of condom-saturation is obvious.

With raves, that meat-market vibe is not there.  I can go just to have 
fun.  And that's not a big deal because that's mostly why others are 
there too.  There's no pressure to "hook up" or otherwise be a failure. 
  And you can socialize and meet new people without those predatory 
undertones.  That freedom makes possible, to me, a level of 
"connectiveness" that is just not possible in a place where the main 
objective is just to "score".


cya,
john



On Oct 1, 2004, at 3:09 PM, electrofunk138 wrote:

> I could never understand why people COULDN'T find all the 
> "connectiveness"
> at clubs.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

I dunno - I can see that point, but maybe it's because the people I
surrounded myself with back east weren't like that, or maybe because any of
the nights I have gotten out around here haven't been like that - I don't
sweat the "meat market" thing. Typically the clubs where that vibe is thick
are clubs I wouldn't go to anyway - for numerous reasons.

As far as the alcohol good or bad thing...well, I like to drink, and most of
the people I know like to drink. The vast majority of those folks are not
belligerant drunks. They do exist tho - there's no denying that. And yes,
they do suck major ass. It's a double edged sword.

Still ,I have found the same vibe at clubs as I have at raves (underground
or otherwise). It just depends on the person. Some people are into the
"scene" and some are just along for the ride...the trick is figuring out who
is who.

> drunks.  Even if the "connectiveness" of those e-tards is more
> chemically induced than not, they're STILL a damn sight more pleasant
> than the drunks.  And let's not even GET into the belligerent drunks.
> The worst that can happen to you with an overbearing 'tard, after all,
> is that they'll tell you their life story and give you a big sweaty
> hug.
>
> Then there's the meat-market thing.  I go out to have fun.  That's it.
> If I happen to meet someone, that's great.  But that's not my
> motivation behind going out.  The idea, that if you don't "hook up" on
> a given night you're a failure, is ludicrous in my mind.  There's more
> to life than empty sex.  Some time ago (Just after Blake's forced
> Ascension to end, actually.), I went through a stint of going to Faith
> fairly regularly with some friends (Nothing to do on thursdays now, and
> may as well give clubs a second chance, after all.).  And, often, by
> the time we'd make it through the crappy music and shady people in the
> front room to the (fairly decent, usually) main room, I'd have
> accumulated half a dozen free condoms.  And I could've easily had more
> if I actually picked them up myself, in addition to taking the ones
> actively given me.  Now, it's definitely good that this sort of thing
> is available.  But, for a while, the floor of my car was littered with
> so many free (unused) condoms that it was positively absurd.  And the
> intrinsic message behind that level of condom-saturation is obvious.
>
> With raves, that meat-market vibe is not there.  I can go just to have
> fun.  And that's not a big deal because that's mostly why others are
> there too.  There's no pressure to "hook up" or otherwise be a failure.
>   And you can socialize and meet new people without those predatory
> undertones.  That freedom makes possible, to me, a level of
> "connectiveness" that is just not possible in a place where the main
> objective is just to "score".
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>
>
> On Oct 1, 2004, at 3:09 PM, electrofunk138 wrote:
>
> > I could never understand why people COULDN'T find all the
> > "connectiveness"
> > at clubs.
>
>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 03:09 PM 10/1/2004, electrofunk138 wrote:
>I could never understand why people COULDN'T find all the "connectiveness"
>at clubs. Granted, it depends on where you're at, but the vast majority of
>what I consider to be VERY "rave" moments were at  nightcluba in DC (namely
>Buzz). I was raving long before going to Buzz, but that's where I forged
>REAL bonds with people - and this wasn't until '99. I started raving in
>'91 - you do the math.

Of course people can find connectivity at a club.  I have written very 
passionately about the vibe and unity at the Paradise Garage and local 
events like Come-Unity and Wicked club events.

Some caveats, however.  The Paradise Garage was a membership only club and 
it was very difficult to get a card.  One had to be recommended by at least 
one current member.  The crowd here was self-selecting also:  comprised of 
gays, most of whom were African American and Hispanic, who had come 
together with a shared experience of oppression.  Very powerful.  Those who 
share a common bond on the dancefloor produce the best platform for a 
memorable, unifying dance experience.

Same with Come-Unity.  The Come-Unity crowd was comprised of the ravers, 
house heads, who started the whole rave scene here in the Bay.  The party 
originally had some barriers to entry: it was on Wednesday nights and one 
had to be a die hard to dance all night and go to work the next day.  When 
they moved to a Friday night the monthly started to unravel and now there 
is no more Come-Unity.

Wicked.  At Townsend the Wicked club night, usually a quarterly event, 
again attracted the old raver crowd.  When they moved to the DNA the event 
began a long, downward spiral.  More parties, but more clubbers and fewer 
ravers.  For me, Wicked at the DNA was an unmitigated disaster.  The house 
oversold the door, and the last party I attended there was one of the most 
horrible nights I've ever spent at a party.  I was assaulted twice by 
drunken patrons.

One problem with clubs vs raves -- a mass marketed party means that you get 
just that:  whoever has the admission price on the flier they discovered on 
their car comes.  Russian roulette.  Some nights can be good, others 
awful.  And, again, drunk folks can be happy or aggressive and sometimes 
violent.  At raves the promoter attempts to create some more focused 
invitations to an event and that tends to attract a more friends inviting 
friends environment.  Like the Paradise Garage, which I still see as a 
"rave" back in the day.

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"The truth is where the truth is, and it's sometimes in the candy store."
-Bob Dylan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

From: Rayn McCormick [mailto:rayn@anubismedia.net]=20
Sent: Friday, October 01, 2004 6:36 PM

My personal take is there is good clubs and bad clubs, good parties and
bad parties.  With anything you have to weed out what you don't want and
find places that you like and feel comfortable.  I go to many clubs and
rarely get that it=92s a meat market vibe more so than at a rave.  At =
some
raves I'd rather be at a club watching a beligerant drunk get escorted
out than listening to mediocre sets and watching 14 year olds take way
too many pills. =20

One of my favorite non-meat market clubs that plays really decent if not
great music every night with a crowd of people there for the music and a
few drinks is The Top.  I'm not a huge drum and bass fan but I try to
make it most Tuesday's to the Top for the happy hour to support my
roomie and Solution and sometimes stay for Phuturo.  DNB isin't really
my thing but what they play there is enough to get my booty shakin' for
a little while.  I also have nothing short of an amazing expierience
anytime I go to one of the Thump parties at 550.  It doesn't seem to
draw a meat market crowd but I can't say that for the rest of the things
thrown there.  It all depends on promoter, venue, style of music and how
easy it is to get to.  Make a club hard to get to and you'll most likely
only have people there who are there for the music, promoter and party.
Although that can also run a promoter into financial woes.  111 Minna is
kinda a cross.  Almost always a good vibe, even though you get a
distinct sort of meat market vibe at the same time, but the parties are
always really good for whatever you're there for.  And then I've always
enjoyed the atmosphere on Wednesday's at the Arrow Bar.  Lately though
I've been going to a lot more bars with pool tables, live music etc..
One club I've grown to hate is the Luna Lounge.  Even without a style of
music that=92s going to bring a meat market crowd, the bouncers and =
d=E9cor
make it seem more like Ruby Skye or 1015.

.025
-Rayn

-----Original Message-----
From: VanMundegaarde [mailto:ElectroFunk138@hotmail.com]=20
Sent: Friday, October 01, 2004 6:11 PM

I dunno - I can see that point, but maybe it's because the people I
surrounded myself with back east weren't like that, or maybe because any
of the nights I have gotten out around here haven't been like that - I
don't sweat the "meat market" thing. Typically the clubs where that vibe
is thick are clubs I wouldn't go to anyway - for numerous reasons.

As far as the alcohol good or bad thing...well, I like to drink, and
most of the people I know like to drink. The vast majority of those
folks are not belligerant drunks. They do exist tho - there's no denying
that. And yes, they do suck major ass. It's a double edged sword.

Still ,I have found the same vibe at clubs as I have at raves
(underground or otherwise). It just depends on the person. Some people
are into the "scene" and some are just along for the ride...the trick is
figuring out who is who.

At 03:22 PM 10/1/2004, Sean Casey wrote:
>Thanks for the great post, Apollo!

And for yours, Sean.  I've been genuinely trying to understand where raving 
is going these days and, quite frankly, whether the passion for the 
underground still exists.  If former ravers prefer clubs these days is it 
worth all the effort to throw undergrounds?


>Underground has a special energy... I'm not sure why. Is it the fact
>that one is "getting away" with something? People flocked to our
>Urban Wasteland parties despite the fact that we never had much
>production at all and things were always just a little on the edge.
>We got busted plenty of times, and more times, we weren't. People
>came to expect that possiblity, and it was part of the adrenaline
>ride. Lord I don't know how many times I've talked to the cops
>myself, maybe 30 times???

I think danger is a part of it:)  Another reason I think undergrounds have 
a consistently better vibe than clubs is, as I mentioned in my previous 
post, that the underground is not a mass market deal.  Rather, it was (and 
is) more about building community through word of mouth with, at its best, 
friends inviting friends.  You know this from your experiences with FnF.


>I also wonder if the fact that permits are available eventually will
>mean that enforcement will be harsher for those without one. This is
>not an effect the people who founded the Entertainment Commission
>would have wanted, I'm sure of that.

Yes, I feel this is what the effect will be.  In the end, it will be the 
big parties and commercial massives who will most benefit.


>And you're totally right about the cost. It may be possible to get
>permits now, but getting a space to meet all the fire code and other
>requirements, even though it is factually safe to have the party
>without improvements, can be outrageously expensive. I'd like to see
>some sort of cost analysis to get an average space fully permitted.
>I'd guess that unless it's dialed-in code-wise, the average cost is
>in the tens of thousands of dollars.

Which means, again, that to make a party economically viable it must be 
large and expensive.  And you also, as a promoter, are I think less able to 
showcase new local talent since your heart is focused on the bottom 
line.  Another good thing about the underground was that local talent had a 
chance to perform more frequently than they can in the more dollar driven 
commercial scene.

>  Brass Tax always seems to rock the
>house. I *very* much recommend going to their events. They've got
>new energy whereas a lot of us FnFers have been going at it over a
>decade.

I've been opening myself to more of the smaller events in town.  Had a very 
good time at Evil Breaks last week.  Lots of sfr people there and a good vibe.


>(And by the way, even though I started in '93 at the age of 31 (!!),
>I am *nowhere* near done. I only party like mad maybe 4 or 5 times a
>year, and I love it, but I'm nowhere near done yet. :-P)

LOL.  I'm older than you and the same goes for me.  I figure I'll prolly 
die on the dancefloor:)


>Who are the new tribes? That was always where the big energy was
>coming from, once some people get fairly well organized, there
>seemed a frenzy of energy. I think the older tribes have perhaps
>stopped drawing in as much new people. Probably my biggest role (and
>perhaps still) -- was meeting new people and connecting them with
>others. The scene always needs new energy. It is an equilibrium, and
>it is good.

Modified Productions is one.  And Moksha Tribe is always looking for people 
with new ideas and energy.  I have always been eager, personally, to train 
new blood, share resources, and do whatever I can to keep the underground 
alive.


>And rave I think comes ultimately from the tribal drums. The group
>experience of letting go and expression through beats and dance.
>It's many tens of thousands of years old, and I don't think it will
>just die away like that. We may be in a lull, but there is something
>deep in us that responds, and the lull is probably temporary. It may
>be rediscovered, it may take on new form, but there is something so
>deep and primal that isn't just going to go away. Not until we're
>wired differently. Perhaps we will evolve beyond it eventually. But
>for now, the attraction to the beat way inside, and how that
>connects us to ourselves and others, will persist for a long long
>time. I'd bank on it.

I agree.  After over thirty years of this I have seen much death and 
renewal, and that's the natural order of things.  This is an ancient rite 
and, I think, is as much a part of being human as sex and family:  the 
touching of the other through music and dance, and genuinely embracing the 
self through the orgiastic experience of the dancefloor.

Thanks for the thoughts, Sean.

Much love and respect,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"The truth is where the truth is, and it's sometimes in the candy store."
-Bob Dylan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <20041002012303.68835.qmail@web51803.mail.yahoo.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Love Parking (HELP)

Warren Shafor <daddy_g_dj@yahoo.com> said...
> i have a drive about 4 hr's to SF *Chico CA* i would like info on where would be a good place to park or who is doing free parking or if there is discounts or any good ideas please. thanks for the help.

This is going to be a big issue!

I'd suggest:

Park somewhere around 3rd St. and 20th St. (the "Dogpatch" area),
and take a "15" 3rd Street bus back north. The only problem is
getting there. I'd suggest getting off the freeway at Cezar Chavez,
head East towards the bay, and make a left on 3rd. Any other
way to 3rd street necessarily has to go very near the parade.

or 

Park near the Castro Muni Metro station (difficult) or the Forest
Hill station (easier) and take any inbound Muni train to Embarcadero
station.

or

Park at or near the Ashby BART station in Berkeley at Ashby and
Martin Luthor King Jr. Way, and take any SF train to Embarcadero
station. This is probably easiest of all.

Sean

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Dr. Souse is in the house....

for all the clubbers out there

>Dr. Souse is in the house
>
>1.
>Did you ever think about drinks you could drink?
>There=92s so many drinks if you only just think!
>Such wonderful drinks! Even drinks that are pink!
>Or yellow! Or purple! Even green, blue or brown.
>You can think of a drink for any color around!
>You can have scotch and soda. You could have gin and juice.
>You can have a wine spritzer if you=92re really a puss.
>Have a mint julep. Or Jameson=92s on ice.
>Perhaps a slippery nipple=92d be nice?
>Margaritas! Mimosas! How about a martini?
>Or bourbon? Perhaps you=92d prefer a bellini? A rusty nail just might hit=
=20
>the spot.
>Do you like tequila? Let=92s do a shot!
>Do you savor Sambuca? Pernod? Or Ouzo?
>Oh, the drinks you can drink if you just choose to do so!
>We could have Bailey=92s. Kahlua. Or Jager.
>But I=92m getting thirsty, so do me a favor.
>Make a selection and go place an order.
>And please pay for mine too, =91cause I just have a quarter.
>
>2.
>Perhaps it=92s a sign
>Of greater design
>Proof of the divine
>Or something sublime
>But the more I drink wine
>The more I feel fine!
>I thought it quite strange
>So I examined the range =AD
>The breadth of it all!
>So much alcohol!
>Tippling tequila, with one wedge of lime
>Leaves me feeling lovely
>The best of all time!
>A sip of Sambuca, or sometimes sangria,
>Supplies sense of self
>With which I=92m an agree=92n.
>And when I drink lots of beer
>I have much less to fear.
>When I relish my rum
>The voices go dumb.
>Vodka or gin can quiet the din.
>When wound up on whisky
>My worries grow dim!
>Bourbon or scotch =AD it just doesn=92t matter
>But get me some soon.
>The sooner the better.
>
>3.
>Sometimes I drink with friends
>Other times, an acquaintance
>Six or seven usually seems enough
>For adequate de-maintenance
>I like to drink on holidays
>And any celebration
>I drink to the deceased
>And to all of their relations
>Sometimes I sip at sunset
>Sometimes I drink at dawn
>Beer, wine, or spirits
>I beg you =AD bring it on!
>A toast to favorite memories
>To brain cells long forgotten
>Let=92s have another and another
>=91Til our livers turn rotten!
>I drink to every wedding
>And to every divorce
>Jim, Jack, and Johnny. And Jameson, of course
>I drink to every jest
>I toast to any joke
>I drink until I=92m drunk.
>Then I drink until I=92m broke.
>
>=ADMax Farr

Well that's why I always just go to afterhours instead on weekends,
and not get out of my house until 3am: Avoid all the drunk ppl.

During the week is not so bad, there's always a handful of good
weeklies during the week with exceptional music and very little bull
shit.

As for Faith... been there once. Twinky gay boys typically makes me
vomit. But then I look like a twinky gay boy anyways... **sigh**  I
was hoping the youg gay scene in SF would have a little more diverse
personalities, but it's overwhelmed by mass consumerism just like
everywhere else.

- Jeff 


On Fri, 1 Oct 2004 16:29:36 -0700, John B <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Well, for me, that feeling of "connectiveness" is just entirely killed
> by the alcohol-fueled meat-market vibe of clubs.
> 
> Maybe I'm a hypocrite for being being negative about some drugs, while
> being positively disposed towards others.  Whatever.  I don't like
> alcohol.  To be more specific, I don't like being surrounded by large
> numbers of drunk people.  When I am, there are really only two options
> for me:
> 
> 1) Get drunk myself.
> 2) Leave.
> 
> And, given the fact that BART and MUNI shut down overnight, my
> transportation situation usually makes #1 impossible.
> 
> Bitch about the irresponsibility.  Complain about the e-puddles
> crowding the dance floor.  Whatever.  The fact is... that wether I've
> decided to be sober, or indulge in some drug or another (even if it's
> alcohol... yah... maybe that makes me more of a hypocrite), I'd much
> rather be stuck in the midst of a thousand e-tards than just a hundred
> drunks.  Even if the "connectiveness" of those e-tards is more
> chemically induced than not, they're STILL a damn sight more pleasant
> than the drunks.  And let's not even GET into the belligerent drunks.
> The worst that can happen to you with an overbearing 'tard, after all,
> is that they'll tell you their life story and give you a big sweaty
> hug.
> 
> Then there's the meat-market thing.  I go out to have fun.  That's it.
> If I happen to meet someone, that's great.  But that's not my
> motivation behind going out.  The idea, that if you don't "hook up" on
> a given night you're a failure, is ludicrous in my mind.  There's more
> to life than empty sex.  Some time ago (Just after Blake's forced
> Ascension to end, actually.), I went through a stint of going to Faith
> fairly regularly with some friends (Nothing to do on thursdays now, and
> may as well give clubs a second chance, after all.).  And, often, by
> the time we'd make it through the crappy music and shady people in the
> front room to the (fairly decent, usually) main room, I'd have
> accumulated half a dozen free condoms.  And I could've easily had more
> if I actually picked them up myself, in addition to taking the ones
> actively given me.  Now, it's definitely good that this sort of thing
> is available.  But, for a while, the floor of my car was littered with
> so many free (unused) condoms that it was positively absurd.  And the
> intrinsic message behind that level of condom-saturation is obvious.
> 
> With raves, that meat-market vibe is not there.  I can go just to have
> fun.  And that's not a big deal because that's mostly why others are
> there too.  There's no pressure to "hook up" or otherwise be a failure.
>   And you can socialize and meet new people without those predatory
> undertones.  That freedom makes possible, to me, a level of
> "connectiveness" that is just not possible in a place where the main
> objective is just to "score".
> 
> cya,
> john
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On Oct 1, 2004, at 3:09 PM, electrofunk138 wrote:
> 
> > I could never understand why people COULDN'T find all the
> > "connectiveness"
> > at clubs.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

Yea - my experience is also limited to an environment where undergrounds
were all but extinct as early as '97. The promoters kind of had to switch to
a club atmosphere to continue what they were doing without going to prison.
So the core crowd were "ravers" as opposed to "clubbers" and until recently,
it remained that way.

SF still has relatively close ties to the real deal - and I can imagine
seeing it slip away, or change is disconcerting to folks. I can't say
whether or not it will ever fully happen here (the 110% switch from raves to
clubs ). But as long as there are warehouse collectives, and solid crews
that know how to successfully do a one-off type event - that mystical vibe
can still be found. Maybe fewer and farther between - but honestly, who can
devote 5 days a week to raving anymore??? (aside from Osby of course, lol)

I prefer them being quality over quantity anyway...a few good parties a
year, with some club nights in between to get my music fix on makes me a
happy camper. I guess I'm just weird like that...
----- Original Message -----
From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, October 01, 2004 6:22 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves


> At 03:09 PM 10/1/2004, electrofunk138 wrote:
> >I could never understand why people COULDN'T find all the
"connectiveness"
> >at clubs. Granted, it depends on where you're at, but the vast majority
of
> >what I consider to be VERY "rave" moments were at  nightcluba in DC
(namely
> >Buzz). I was raving long before going to Buzz, but that's where I forged
> >REAL bonds with people - and this wasn't until '99. I started raving in
> >'91 - you do the math.
>
> Of course people can find connectivity at a club.  I have written very
> passionately about the vibe and unity at the Paradise Garage and local
> events like Come-Unity and Wicked club events.
>
> Some caveats, however.  The Paradise Garage was a membership only club and
> it was very difficult to get a card.  One had to be recommended by at
least
> one current member.  The crowd here was self-selecting also:  comprised of
> gays, most of whom were African American and Hispanic, who had come
> together with a shared experience of oppression.  Very powerful.  Those
who
> share a common bond on the dancefloor produce the best platform for a
> memorable, unifying dance experience.
>
> Same with Come-Unity.  The Come-Unity crowd was comprised of the ravers,
> house heads, who started the whole rave scene here in the Bay.  The party
> originally had some barriers to entry: it was on Wednesday nights and one
> had to be a die hard to dance all night and go to work the next day.  When
> they moved to a Friday night the monthly started to unravel and now there
> is no more Come-Unity.
>
> Wicked.  At Townsend the Wicked club night, usually a quarterly event,
> again attracted the old raver crowd.  When they moved to the DNA the event
> began a long, downward spiral.  More parties, but more clubbers and fewer
> ravers.  For me, Wicked at the DNA was an unmitigated disaster.  The house
> oversold the door, and the last party I attended there was one of the most
> horrible nights I've ever spent at a party.  I was assaulted twice by
> drunken patrons.
>
> One problem with clubs vs raves -- a mass marketed party means that you
get
> just that:  whoever has the admission price on the flier they discovered
on
> their car comes.  Russian roulette.  Some nights can be good, others
> awful.  And, again, drunk folks can be happy or aggressive and sometimes
> violent.  At raves the promoter attempts to create some more focused
> invitations to an event and that tends to attract a more friends inviting
> friends environment.  Like the Paradise Garage, which I still see as a
> "rave" back in the day.
>
> Love,
>
> Apollo
>
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>

> Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein
