Blackstone is no longer doing Faith, although I guess it was twink 
heaven:)  I hear he has a party over at Mission Rock.  18+.  Don't know the 
details.  David Harness usually spins at gay parties with a good vibe.  If 
you see him on the DJ list give it a try.  He has a party called Loveworks 
at 111 Minna Gallery.  Next Saturday is "Superhero!," a birthday party for 
Jim (aka Astroboy aka Sharon Needles) an old, old friend from the Wicked 
FMR days, as well as the promoter for Club Universe and other gay events 
over the years.  David, Matt Valenz and Anita Lofton will be spinning.

Love,

Apollo



>On Fri, 1 Oct 2004 16:29:36 -0700, John B <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > Well, for me, that feeling of "connectiveness" is just entirely killed
> > by the alcohol-fueled meat-market vibe of clubs.
> >
> > Maybe I'm a hypocrite for being being negative about some drugs, while
> > being positively disposed towards others.  Whatever.  I don't like
> > alcohol.  To be more specific, I don't like being surrounded by large
> > numbers of drunk people.  When I am, there are really only two options
> > for me:
> >
> > 1) Get drunk myself.
> > 2) Leave.
> >
> > And, given the fact that BART and MUNI shut down overnight, my
> > transportation situation usually makes #1 impossible.
> >
> > Bitch about the irresponsibility.  Complain about the e-puddles
> > crowding the dance floor.  Whatever.  The fact is... that wether I've
> > decided to be sober, or indulge in some drug or another (even if it's
> > alcohol... yah... maybe that makes me more of a hypocrite), I'd much
> > rather be stuck in the midst of a thousand e-tards than just a hundred
> > drunks.  Even if the "connectiveness" of those e-tards is more
> > chemically induced than not, they're STILL a damn sight more pleasant
> > than the drunks.  And let's not even GET into the belligerent drunks.
> > The worst that can happen to you with an overbearing 'tard, after all,
> > is that they'll tell you their life story and give you a big sweaty
> > hug.
> >
> > Then there's the meat-market thing.  I go out to have fun.  That's it.
> > If I happen to meet someone, that's great.  But that's not my
> > motivation behind going out.  The idea, that if you don't "hook up" on
> > a given night you're a failure, is ludicrous in my mind.  There's more
> > to life than empty sex.  Some time ago (Just after Blake's forced
> > Ascension to end, actually.), I went through a stint of going to Faith
> > fairly regularly with some friends (Nothing to do on thursdays now, and
> > may as well give clubs a second chance, after all.).  And, often, by
> > the time we'd make it through the crappy music and shady people in the
> > front room to the (fairly decent, usually) main room, I'd have
> > accumulated half a dozen free condoms.  And I could've easily had more
> > if I actually picked them up myself, in addition to taking the ones
> > actively given me.  Now, it's definitely good that this sort of thing
> > is available.  But, for a while, the floor of my car was littered with
> > so many free (unused) condoms that it was positively absurd.  And the
> > intrinsic message behind that level of condom-saturation is obvious.
> >
> > With raves, that meat-market vibe is not there.  I can go just to have
> > fun.  And that's not a big deal because that's mostly why others are
> > there too.  There's no pressure to "hook up" or otherwise be a failure.
> >   And you can socialize and meet new people without those predatory
> > undertones.  That freedom makes possible, to me, a level of
> > "connectiveness" that is just not possible in a place where the main
> > objective is just to "score".
> >
> > cya,
> > john
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > On Oct 1, 2004, at 3:09 PM, electrofunk138 wrote:
> >
> > > I could never understand why people COULDN'T find all the
> > > "connectiveness"
> > > at clubs.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

Heh...  I'm with you there.  (Except for the Twinky gay boys inducing  
vomiting,)

I was lucky enough to already BE here in SF by the time I figured out  
that I like boys.  That saved me the hassle of dealing with the shit  
that would have come along with that if I had had to deal with it when  
I still lived in the fetid south.  The main problem being, that I find  
the "gay scene" to be appallingly tacky.

I just can't stand the cafe or the badlands.  In fact, the entire  
Castro strikes me as being a tacky and overrated parody.  It's like  
Disney came along, took all the stereotypes of what america thinks is  
"gay", wrapped it in shiny rainbow paper, and put it up for sale to  
tourists.  I just can't abide the place.  Even the Haight, which does  
the same thing only with "the '60s" instead of "gay", feels more real  
to me.

One of the main things I liked about Faith, was that it was *HUGE*.   
And I never saw a crowd that came close to filling it up.  So there was  
always room to dance, room to breathe, room to just get away from the  
crowd for a bit if you needed a break.  You can't say that about the  
cafe or the badlands.

Oh yeah...  the MUSIC is also much better in the rave scene than in the  
"gay scene".  WTF is up with THAT???  "Superior music" is... like...  
the one GOOD stereotype I always used to hear about the "gay scene".

muststopbeforeistarttorantmuststopbeforeistarttorantmuststopbeforeistart 
torant


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) New Plan To Turn Drivers Licenses Into

At 03:16 PM 9/30/04 -0700, Starchild wrote:
>it, though I really think most people will someday. Maybe not in my 
>lifetime, although I hope so. Someone recently said the problem with 
>libertarians is we are naive. Well, that's the type of criticism that was 
>sometimes directed at people who talked about PLUR, too.

That was me.  I am going around saying that a lot, so perhaps I ought to 
clarify this statement.

The analogy with PLUR is apt, actually.  PLUR is a nice slogan and all, but 
how many of those coming down from their E trip,
after they've been spouting PLUR all night, actually behave the same way at 
work or in their regular life the rest of week?  That's the
problem I had with the constant sloganeerring.  There's a difference 
between a slogan vs. living up to something and integrating
it into your life.  And to use PLUR as a blanket reason ignores the fact 
that true compassion sometimes requires kicking someone's
ass for their own good - PLUR was often tied to "it's all good" - the 
lassiez faire attitude to everything.  Just let everything slide....
So to say PLUR, PLUR, PLUR evinces a lack of understanding about the grey 
areas of life, much like the slogans "free love" and
"tune in, turn on, drop out".

In the same manner, Libertarianism, with a capital L, is like communism - 
it is too idealistic and ignores the nature of the world
and the nature of human psychology.  If humans were entirely rational and 
responsible, I'm sure it would work out fine.  But that day
is far into the future and will not come without a certain fundamental 
restructuring of human psychology and how humans view
the world.  I do see the beginnings of this with the ideals of the rave 
scene (it's only a scene) and the Burning Man culture that is
arising out of the rave scene.  When the Burning Man culture and its ethos 
becomes predominant, I think libertarianism may very
well arise naturally.

In the meantime, to try and even implement some of Libertarianism is to 
give an opening for the people, who akin to Stalin, will
take advantage of the loopholes and fuzziness in the political structures 
of society and implement something akin totalitarianism, but
which involves corporations - if Libertarianism was fully implemented, with 
the nature of American society today, the Enrons and
Worldcoms would FLOURISH.  And the government would be even more 
ineffectual than it is, and the social infrastructure would
crumble.  The world is not ready for Libertarianism.

Libertarians seem to have a blind spot when considering the nature of 
capitalism nowadays - responsible capitalism is certainly
possible (see the movie "The Corporation" for a glimmer of hope) but to 
think that the mechanisms of the free market can solve
everything is asinine.  In my mind, the neo-cons are trying to restructure 
society along certain lines akin to Libertarianism and
the negative effects are going to be felt for decades.

I'm not an idiot; some parts of libertarianism make perfect sense.  But to 
subscribe to it wholeheartedly and say it -is- THE solution
to be implemented as soon as possible ignores reality - just like when the 
faux PLURries spout off about how "it's all good".  No, it isn't.
To say "it's all good" expresses a shallow understanding of the Tao, just 
like Libertarianism.

doug

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

OK to all u other jaded hetero old skool ravers. If u think the rave
scene has gone all consumer-centric, u should look that the
progression of the gay scene for a sec.

The gays in the' 70s were leading modern arts and culture (think Andy
Warhol, etc.), they're responsible for disco and house. Then came
AIDS, rewound the gay civil right movement back to square one.
Throughout the '90s they fought hard for our civil rights and freedom.
Gay ppl usually had hard lives both at family and at work, so they
respected each other because they all knew what pain each other had to
go through on daily basis.

And where are we at now? We have our own TV shows, our own subgenre of
dance music, we have equal rights in most major cities, we have
domestic partnerships. but u know, the gay community is now just a
marketing demographic. Gay shows and magazines relentlessly selling us
this pre-packaged "gay lifestyle" U know, Diesel and Aberzombie and
Pottery Barn. And the frightening thing is the majority of gay ppl
actually subscribed to this lifestyle. A community that used to take
pride in diversity, now desperately imitate each other. Nobody take a
look at themselves and try to think for a min about who they really
are, they let TV and magazines (and gay porn) to tell them what they
should be.

Gays used to have great taste in music and fashion, in fact we were
pioneers back then. Now whenever I go to a gay club I see so much bad
taste and hear so much bad music that I need to vomit. (Hence my
previous comments.) What happened?

What's your take Apollo?

The rave culture is just another target for Corporate America, much
like any other alternative culture. From hip-hop to punk to goth to
rave, Corporate America has already discovered that these alternative
cultures are the best way to reach the other 30% of young teenagers
that Britney and Christina and Justin can't reach. They repackage
these underground culture into disposable bands and off-the-shelf
merchandises, where teenagers can conveniently purchase them @ their
local mall.

While there is a mainstream, consumer-centric rave culture for a
number of years now, it's my belief that there'll be those of us
who'll continue to support the underground and represent proper. Bare
in mind that every one of us began our journey much like all these
other clueless like kids. It's our responsibility to show them the
spirit of what this is **really** about.

Don't segregate, educate.

All this aside, I don't care about what y'all say but  I still love my
manpurse.  LOL


- Jeff

> to me.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves

I agree with you whole heartedly. I don't understand why many hardcore
ravers hate clubs. There are plenty of good weeklies to go to during
the week. The vibes at clubs are usually better during the week no
matter where u go (but of course, except the obvious ones that u
already know u should avoid).

Buzz is a **very** good example. I've never been there myself, but I
have to say all the Buzz kids I ever met are all hardcore,
passsionate, respecting, fun-loving individuals that leave a lasting
impression. I was told that the vibe @ Buzz is better than many of the
best raves, and I really have no doubt that's true.

So was Shadow lounge in Maimi. Sure there was a dress code (even bars
had dresscodes there) and the crowd looks all money. But if u see past
the handful of Versace/D&G fakesters and silicon bimbos, u'll find the
place was filled with music lovers for the most part, and there was a
great deal of passion. It was considered one of the best (if not
**the** best) trance clubs in the U.S.

Once upon a time, 1015 was a respectable venue too.

And that's some of the other benefits of clubs: It's always at the
same location, so u frequently run into some regular ppl, and can make
some connections. A clubs is safer in general, you can always count on
good ventilation, good lighting and sound system. The fact that a club
is at a fixed location also means it bring familiarity and a sense of
home, which can nurish a sense of family much like any underground
collective throwing one-offs.

BeatCamp in Miami (a d&b weekly @ the Mission) was such a family to
me. I made many great friends there and keep in touch with them still.
I'm sure that's how u feel about Buzz too.

- Jeff




On Fri, 1 Oct 2004 15:09:48 -0700, electrofunk138
<electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> I could never understand why people COULDN'T find all the "connectiveness"
> at clubs. Granted, it depends on where you're at, but the vast majority of
> what I consider to be VERY "rave" moments were at  nightcluba in DC (namely
> Buzz). I was raving long before going to Buzz, but that's where I forged
> REAL bonds with people - and this wasn't until '99. I started raving in
> '91 - you do the math.
> 
> I think it REALLY comes down to what people bring to the table. Are they
> openminded, willing to meet new people, let themselves go, relax, lose the
> 'tude and not focus all their attention on being a scenester - or are you
> just there to bitch about the music, the club the dj, the drink prices,
> security, etc. ?
> 
> There're only two noticeable differences between undergrounds and clubs. A
> bar and legality. Other than that, it's a dark spot, where dance music is
> played over a huge soundsystem of some kind, where hopefully - people are
> dancing.  It's the ravers that make the party what it is. I have been to
> parties where there have been sick lineups - and the vibe sucked ass because
> people were bitchy, or didn't feel like showing. I have been to crappy
> little parties with no-name dj's that rocked socks - because the crowds vibe
> was tangible.
> 
> *Each and every one of us can make or break that vibe. When you have people
> who won't leave the city to go to the East Bay, and vice versa, DJ's who
> won't go to parties they aren't playing at, people who are (insert genre
> name here) fans that will ONLY go to that particular genre club and/or party
> night...things aren't gonna be great. Things stagnate.
> 
> BTW - it's like this all over the country. Over-commercialization of the
> scene, crackheads with no ability to moderate their drug use, archaic drug
> laws and witch-hunts, coupled with a great deal of people "growing up" and
> moving on (*and the aforementioned reasons) accounts for most of why things
> are the way they are.
> 
> People are forced to go legit in order to keep the party going. Some of us
> may not like that idea - but it's a necessary evil in my book.
> 
> For me - I just go where I like the beats the best. Could be a dirty
> warehouse, could be a sparkling new club - it could even be someone's
> apartment with 5 other people kickin' it. Rave - much like punk was to me
> (and a lot of other folks) isn't what you wear, or what you say - it's who
> you are, it's a state of mind.
> 
> Pardon my rambling...this thread has had me thinking.
> 
> -M
> 
> 
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
> To: "Sean Casey" <sean@cloudfactory.org>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Friday, October 01, 2004 2:46 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) wasvNew Plan..Now sfraves
> 
> > At 10:28 AM 10/1/2004, Sean Casey wrote:
> > >Are we really in a decline?
> > >
> > >In '93, people were saying the same thing, "rave is dead".
> > >Same thing in '97.
> > >Same thing in '00.
> > >
> > >So, has it really declined?
> > >
> > >I also wonder how the Entertainment Commission has affected things.
> > >It's possible to get permits now, whereas in the mid 90s, it was not
> > >possible to get one at all. Period.
> > >
> > >I don't see that much difference in party activity, but maybe I'm
> > >just not seeing it.
> > >
> > >I dunno... what do you think?
> > >
> > >Sean
> >
> > I've made the same argument, Sean, and still believe some aspects of
> raving
> > are alive....and, of course, no one knows what the future may hold.  I'm
> > still optimistic, but not to the degree I was even a year ago.
> >
> > As for this list and politics, Sean, addressing your prior post:  yes
> there
> > are numerous list for the discussion of politics.  I'm on more of them
> than
> > I would like these days.  But there are also many lists devoted to music,
> > EDM, and various genres.  There are discussion groups focused on music
> > production.  Better lists for party information than sfraves these
> > days.  What makes us different?
> >
> > I was listening to Cornel West today on NPR.  The man's wisdom,
> > intellectual achievement, and vast understanding of philosophy and history
> > are remarkable.  But it is his "musical" approach to politics that makes
> my
> > heart sing, as do the passion with which he invests his beliefs.  West
> said
> > that to him "democracy" was a verb:  that is, a way of life; a belief
> > system that is actionable in everyday life.
> >
> > Early raving was like that.  It was not just "the music," or esoteric
> > discussions of music making, or fun parties.  Yes, all these components
> > somehow made up the whole of raving, but there was more behind it than
> just
> > technique and getting high with friends one day a week.  One thing I
> admire
> > about Starchild is that to me he is an example of a maturing raver who has
> > taken what he learned in our community and actualized these beliefs in his
> > life.  I don't agree with all of the Libertarian agenda, but I understand
> > how integrating early rave ideals could be manifest in parts of that
> agenda.
> >
> > So, what is/was raving?  What is different in our community twelve years
> later?
> >
> > In the early nineties there were lots of clubs.  Good ones.  Much more
> free
> > than now, with minimal security.  Why in the hell did the early ravers
> > decided to throw underground, un permitted parties?  Makes no sense.  As
> > Tina implied it's lots of trouble;  requires much tiring labor;  opens the
> > promoter to great liability;  and for most of us then and now creates no
> > monetary return.  Lots easier to throw a club night.
> >
> > The early rave community was much older than the demographic in the late
> > nineties.  So one  can't say they were a bunch of underage kids looking
> for
> > ways to drink, smoke, take drugs and party all night long until they were
> > old enough to get into clubs.  There were other motivations -- much more
> > powerful -- in play then.  What were they?  Do they still exist?
> >
> > I was thinking about all this at Catch 20-2 when the police came barging
> > into our un permitted event.  At the very same time a guest who had
> > swallowed a whole box of cough suppressant pills was freaking out and I
> had
> > no idea what his physical condition was.  While waiting for the EMT's
> > assessment I asked myself why am I doing these parties?  Worse case
> > scenario the guest will need an ambulance, the police are right outside,
> > and we all could be going to court:)  I must have stronger reasons for
> > doing these events than making "fun" parties.  Perhaps Starchild remembers
> > what these beliefs are.
> >
> > Sure, there are lots of club nights these days.  Clubs seem to be doing
> > OK.  Lots of booze again.  And there are the ubiquitous campouts during
> the
> > summer.  The remnants of the old rave scene seemed to be defined by the
> > campout now.  Lot safer and easier to do a couple of these a year. But for
> > those of us unable or unwilling to do campouts ain't much out there but
> > clubs and booze.  As far as I know there are two collectives who regularly
> > do outdoor FMRs and the remarkable Modified people who actually still do
> > break ins.  Telic is not, IMHO, and underground.  There is a house
> > collective in SF that throws one of two ugs (usually terribly oversold and
> > uncomfortable) a year.  And Moksha.  Our last event was in March.
> >
> > Urban development has certainly reduced the number of reasonable
> > underground venues available.  9/11 has, as Tina suggested, created more
> of
> > a "police state" here and elsewhere.  Why bother with the big trouble of
> > throwing an underground when you can rent a club?:)  Get into the business
> > of selling booze?
> >
> > The 18+ permits in SF, Sean, are fine for those who throw rather large
> > parties, charge a hefty ticket price, and sell many things inside the
> > venue, but the economics of finding a space that is not a bar yet still
> > meets fire and other requirements is daunting and very expensive for those
> > interested in throwing more intimate 3-400 person events.
> >
> > I'm implying here, of course, that raving has something to do with
> > underground, un permitted parties that provide a measure of freedom and
> > liberation not found elsewhere.  If this is no longer true, then raving is
> > dead.  Go to clubs.  Do club events.  I spent two thirds of my dance and
> > music life in clubs, beginning with the Paradise Garage.  I had fun. But
> > then, the PG didn't serve booze.  They provided LSD punch:)
> >
> > Lots of questions in my mind these days.
> >
> > As for this list and politics:  well, if raving is truly a way of life
> with
> > a belief system, then everything is connected here.  One can't have
> > temporary autonomous zones in a police state.  If life has become 24/7
> > survival with no time for personal development, then that's a political,
> > economic problem that affects raving.  If we are now just looking for a
> > good club every couple of weeks to dance a little, drink, and leave at two
> > when the bar closes then we are no longer ravers.  If we learned nothing
> > about compassion, empathy, love and community from our raving experiences,
> > then I think we were not raving.
> >
> > Love,
> >
> > Apollo
> >

Hey all,=20

most of you probably have heard something about this.=20
Just think of how many of you would be in iraq right now if this draft =
action was already active. . . something you definately need to pay =
attention to. Really, if you think about it. . .if there is a draft =
again, a lot of you won't be able to go about your fun party lives, but =
might have to take long breaks in the military which may or may not cost =
your life in one way or another.

The worst part about that is, I bet most of us are just totally NOT the =
types to go fight in the military for ideas we don't totally agree with =
under orders of someone else. . .and to be pulled from our normal lives =
for something that many of us just simply dont believe in. . .

I'm passing this on from a media buddy,
Mandatory draft for males and females (ages 18-26) starting June 15, =
2005, is something that everyone should know about. This literally =
effects everyone since we all have or know children that will have to go =
if this bill passes.

There is pending legislation in the house and senate (companion bills: =
S89 and HR 163) which will time the program's initiation so the draft =
can begin as early as spring, 2005, just after the 2004 presidential =
election. The administration is quietly trying to get these bills passed =
now, while the public's attention is on the elections, so our action on =
this is needed immediately. Details and links follow.

This plan, among other things, eliminates higher education as a shelter =
and incl reement with Canada which will no longer permit anyone =
attempting to dodge the draft to stay within it's borders. This bill =
also includes the extention of military service for all those that are =
currently active.

If you go to the select service web site and read their 2004 FYI Goals =
you will see that the reasoning for this is to increase the size of the =
military in case of terrorism. This is a critical piece of legislation, =
this will effect our undergradates, our children and our grandchildren.

Please take the time to write your congressman and let them know how you =
feel about this legislation. www.house.gov <http://www.house.gov/ =
www.senate.gov <http://www.senate.gov/

Please also write to your representatives and ask them why they aren't =
telling their constituents about these bills and write to newspapers and =
other media outlets to ask them why they're not covering this important =
story.

$28 million has been added to the 2004 selective ser 03, "to provide for =
the common defense by requiring that all young persons(age
18-26) in the United States, including women, perform a period of =
military service or a period of civilian service in furtherance of the =
national defense and homeland security, and for other purposes."

These active bills currently sit in the committee on armed services. =
Dodging the draft will be more difficult than those from the Vietnam =
era. College and Canada will not be options. In December, 2001, Canada =
and the U. S. signed a "smart border declaration," which could be used =
to keep would-be draft dodgers in. Signed by Canada's minister of =
foreign affairs, John Manley, an

hey there

ok an interesting situation.

I bid on a dutch (mulit-item auction) on ebay for one of the 12 =
Alienware Area51m Laptops @ $300. . . which first in itself is out of =
the ordinary.
The seller doesn't sell out of the US, but it supposed to be located in =
the UK.
The auction ended, and I lost to one of the other 74 bidders. And for =
some reason the sellers ebay registration isn't valid anymore.
The seller (or someone with their email) emails me saying I was 2nd and =
the winner was suspected by fraud. . .etc etc. . .( but there were 12 =
laptops, was that buyer buying all ? I was second ?)

So I was like YES. . . let me know.

She? emailed me back saying it would be $400 for the laptop, sent via =
western union money transfer to that persons address in Italy. . . I =
also sent an email thru ebay to the person that they haven't recieved.

Since then I've spoke to a couple other bidders who asked me if it =
seemed suspicious to me, they recieved the same email initially.

Now. . .the seller is still wanting to know if I want one. . .=20

So here, if you want to play, Give me $400, I'll buy the item. . . if =
it's legit and I recieve a laptop like in the auction, then I'll give =
you $600. . .if not and it is a scam, you lose your $400. . .  but if it =
is real, you make $200 . . . I'll write up some contract to be signed, =
one of the rules will be "no crying about losing" . . .

so did anyone want to play ?=20

: )

gotta let me know like today. . .=20

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "aK" <aK@hard-grooves.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Saturday, October 02, 2004 10:38 AM
Subject: [sfraves] nrr. . EBay scam ? wanna play ?


hey there

ok an interesting situation.

I bid on a dutch (mulit-item auction) on ebay for one of the 12 Alienware
Area51m Laptops @ $300. . . which first in itself is out of the ordinary.
The seller doesn't sell out of the US, but it supposed to be located in the
UK.
The auction ended, and I lost to one of the other 74 bidders. And for some
reason the sellers ebay registration isn't valid anymore.
The seller (or someone with their email) emails me saying I was 2nd and the
winner was suspected by fraud. . .etc etc. . .( but there were 12 laptops,
was that buyer buying all ? I was second ?)

So I was like YES. . . let me know.

She? emailed me back saying it would be $400 for the laptop, sent via
western union money transfer to that persons address in Italy. . . I also
sent an email thru ebay to the person that they haven't recieved.

Since then I've spoke to a couple other bidders who asked me if it seemed
suspicious to me, they recieved the same email initially.

Now. . .the seller is still wanting to know if I want one. . .

So here, if you want to play, Give me $400, I'll buy the item. . . if it's
legit and I recieve a laptop like in the auction, then I'll give you $600. .
.if not and it is a scam, you lose your $400. . .  but if it is real, you
make $200 . . . I'll write up some contract to be signed, one of the rules
will be "no crying about losing" . . .

so did anyone want to play ?

: )

gotta let me know like today. . .

aK



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: Loscocco@aol.com
Message-ID: <147.354fa267.2e9050f6@aol.com>
Date: Sat, 2 Oct 2004 14:44:06 EDT
To: ElectroFunk138@hotmail.com, aK@hard-grooves.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="-----------------------------1096742646"
X-Mailer: 9.0 for Windows sub 5000
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re: ANOTHER SCAM nrr. .  EBay scam ? wanna play ?

-------------------------------1096742646
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 
I do several grand a month on ebay (_eBay  Seller List: loscocco_ 
(http://cgi6.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewSellersOtherItems&userid=loscocco&include=0&sin
ce=-1&sort=3&rows=50) ) and  run into  scammers like this all  the time. You 
just gotta be really careful with transcaction and look at a  Ebayers history 
of feedback. If a deal sounds too good to be true... it is.  Laptops, cameras 
and such high ticket items are often where the scams are used  one. Here is an 
email i got regarding an item i was selling.   Its so  lame you would have to 
be really stupid to fall for it. 
Practice safe Ebaying
Erin
 
 Read this.
 
          Question about your item   

  Question for item #5722145347 - Faroudja  DV1000 High End Dvd Player
Dear  loscocco,

Hello, My client is interested in  buying your item and he wants to pay via 
Cashier check,he will issue  a cashier check which will include the money for 
the item,my  commission as an agent and also the shipping charges,Immediately 
you  get the check,you will go straight and cash it at a local check  cashing 
point in which you will send the excess funds through  western union money 
transfer to my client shipper in africa the same  day you get the check ,If you 
agree on this,kindly send me ur  contact mailing address to send the check to 
with ur phone number.  N.B ; He will be sending u a check of $3500 in which u 
will cash  instantly and send the excess funds thru western union to my client  
shipper the same day u get the check. I await ur reply. have a great  day. Pls 
if u agree end the auction imemdiately you can contact me  via my email ok i 
await your  reply
 

Dude - this is a CLASSIC scam, do NOT do it.
My Girlfriend was  supposed to get turntables in a scam just like this a
number of years back.  They'll get the money via Western Union, and that'll
be  that....

M-
----- Original Message -----
From: "aK"  <aK@hard-grooves.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent:  Saturday, October 02, 2004 10:38 AM
Subject: [sfraves] nrr. . EBay scam ?  wanna play ?


hey there

ok an interesting situation.

I  bid on a dutch (mulit-item auction) on ebay for one of the 12  Alienware
Area51m Laptops @ $300. . . which first in itself is out of the  ordinary.
The seller doesn't sell out of the US, but it supposed to be  located in the
UK.
The auction ended, and I lost to one of the other 74  bidders. And for some
reason the sellers ebay registration isn't valid  anymore.
The seller (or someone with their email) emails me saying I was  2nd and the
winner was suspected by fraud. . .etc etc. . .( but there were  12 laptops,
was that buyer buying all ? I was second ?)

So I was  like YES. . . let me know.

She? emailed me back saying it would be $400  for the laptop, sent via
western union money transfer to that persons  address in Italy. . . I also
sent an email thru ebay to the person that  they haven't recieved.

Since then I've spoke to a couple other bidders  who asked me if it seemed
suspicious to me, they recieved the same email  initially.

Now. . .the seller is still wanting to know if I want one. .  .

So here, if you want to play, Give me $400, I'll buy the item. . . if  it's
legit and I recieve a laptop like in the auction, then I'll give you  $600. .
if not and it is a scam, you lose your $400. . .  but if it is  real, you
make $200 . . . I'll write up some contract to be signed, one of  the rules
will be "no crying about losing" . . .

so did anyone want  to play ?

: )

gotta let me know like today. .  .

aK

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Asia Times:  The costs of the failed Iraqi transition 

From:
http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Middle_East/FJ02Ak04.html

  The costs of the failed Iraqi transition
October 2, 2004
Asia Times online

Key findings

  "A Failed Transition" is the most comprehensive accounting of the 
mounting costs of the Iraq war on the United States, Iraq and the 
world. Among its major findings are stark figures about the escalation 
of costs in these most recent three months of "transition" to Iraqi 
rule, a period that the Bush administration claimed would be 
characterized by falling human and economic costs.

1. US military casualties have been highest during the "transition": US 
military casualties (wounded and killed) stand at a monthly average of 
747 since the so-called "transition" to Iraqi rule on June 29. This 
contrasts with a monthly average of 482 US military casualties during 
the invasion (March 20-May 1, 2003) and a monthly average of 415 during 
the occupation (May 2, 2003-June 28, 2004).

  2. Non-Iraqi contractor deaths have also been highest during the 
"transition": There has also been a huge increase in the average 
monthly deaths of US and other non-Iraqi contractors since the 
"transition". On average, 17.5 contractors have died each month since 
the "transition", versus 7.6 contractor deaths per month during the 
previous 14 months of occupation.

3. Estimated strength of Iraqi resistance skyrockets: Because the US 
military occupation remains in place, the "transition" has failed to 
win Iraqi support or diminish Iraqi resistance to the occupation. 
According to Pentagon estimates, the number of Iraqi resistance 
fighters has quadrupled between November of 2003 and early September 
2004, from 5,000 to 20,000. The deputy commander of coalition forces in 
Iraq, British Major-General Andrew Graham, indicated to Time magazine 
in early September that he thinks the 20,000 estimate is too low; he 
estimates Iraqi resistance strength at 40,000-50,000. This rise is even 
starker when juxtaposed to Brookings Institution estimates that an 
additional 24,000 Iraqi resistance fighters have been detained or 
killed between May 2003 and August 2004.

4. US-led coalition shrinks further after "transition": The number of 
countries identified as members of the coalition backing the US-led war 
started with 30 on March 18, 2003, then grew in the early months of the 
war. Since then, eight countries have withdrawn their troops and Costa 
Rica has demanded to be taken off the coalition list. At the war's 
start, coalition countries represented 19.1% of the world's population; 
today, the remaining countries with forces in Iraq represent only 13.6% 
of the world's population.

HIGHLIGHTS

I. Costs to the United States

A. Human costs to the US and allies
US military deaths: Between the start of war on March 19, 2003 and 
September 22, 2004, 1,175 coalition forces were killed, including 1,040 
US military. Of the total, 925 were killed after President George W 
Bush declared the end of combat operations on May 1, 2003. Over 7,413 
US troops have been wounded since the war began, 6,953 (94%) since May 
1, 2003.

  Contractor deaths: As of September 22, there has been an estimated 154 
civilian contractors, missionaries and civilian worker deaths since May 
1, 2004. Of these, 52 have been identified as Americans.

  Journalist deaths: Forty-four international media workers have been 
killed in Iraq as of September 22, including 33 since Bush declared the 
end of combat operations. Eight of the dead worked for US companies.

B. Security costs
  Terrorist recruitment and action: According to the London-based 
International Institute for Strategic Studies, al-Qaeda's membership is 
now at 18,000, with 1,000 active in Iraq. The State Department's 2003 
"Patterns of Global Terrorism" documented 625 deaths and 3,646 injuries 
due to terrorist attacks in 2003. The report acknowledged that 
"significant incidents" increased from 60% of total attacks in 2002 to 
84% in 2003.

Low US credibility: Polls reveal that the war has damaged the US 
government's standing and credibility in the world. Surveys in eight 
European and Arab countries demonstrated broad public agreement that 
the war has hurt, rather than helped, the "war on terrorism". At home, 
52% of Americans polled by the Annenberg Election Survey disapprove of 
Bush's handling of Iraq.

  Military mistakes: A number of former military officials have 
criticized the war, including retired Marine General Anthony Zinni, who 
has charged that by manufacturing a false rationale for war, abandoning 
traditional allies, propping up and trusting Iraqi exiles, and failing 
to plan for post-war Iraq, the Bush administration made the US less 
secure.

  Low troop morale and lack of equipment: A March 2004 army survey found 
52% of soldiers reporting low morale, and three-fourths reporting they 
were poorly led by their officers. Lack of equipment has been an 
ongoing problem. The army did not fully equip soldiers with 
bullet-proof vests until June 2004, forcing many families to purchase 
them out of their own pockets.

  Loss of first responders: National Guard troops make up almost 
one-third of the US Army troops now in Iraq. Their deployment puts a 
particularly heavy burden on their home communities because many are 
"first responders", including police, firefighters and emergency 
medical personnel. For example, 44% of the country's police forces have 
lost officers to Iraq. In some states, the absence of so many Guard 
troops has raised concerns about the ability to handle natural 
disasters.

Use of private contractors: An estimated 20,000 private contractors are 
carrying out work in Iraq traditionally done by the military, despite 
the fact that they often lack sufficient training and are not 
accountable to the same guidelines and reviews as military personnel.

C. Economic costs
The bill so far: Congress has approved $151.1 billion for Iraq. 
Congressional leaders anticipate an additional supplemental 
appropriation of $60 billion after the election in November.

  Long-term impact on US economy: Economist Doug Henwood has estimated 
that the war bill will add up to an average of at least $3,415 for 
every US household. Another economist, James Galbraith of the 
University of Texas, predicts that while war spending may boost the 
economy initially, over the long term it is likely to bring a decade of 
economic troubles, including an expanded trade deficit and high 
inflation.

  Oil prices: US crude oil prices spiked at $48 per barrel on August 19, 
the highest level since 1983, a development that most analysts 
attribute at least in part to the deteriorating situation in Iraq. 
According to a mid-May CBS survey, 85% of Americans said they had been 
affected measurably by higher gas prices. According to one estimate, if 
crude oil prices stay around $40 a barrel for a year, US gross domestic 
product will decline by more than $50 billion.

  Economic impact on military families: Since the beginning of the wars 
in Iraq and Afghanistan, 364,000 reserve troops and National Guard 
soldiers have been called for military service, serving tours of duty 
that often last 20 months. Studies show that between 30% and 40% of 
reservists and National Guard members earn a lower salary when they 
leave civilian employment for military deployment. Army Emergency 
Relief has reported that requests from military families for food 
stamps and subsidized meals increased "several hundred percent" between 
2002 and 2003.

D. Social costs
  US budget and social programs: The Bush administration's combination 
of massive spending on the war and tax cuts for the wealthy means less 
money for social spending. The $151.1 billion expenditure for the war 
through this year could have paid for: close to 23 million housing 
vouchers; health care for over 27 million uninsured Americans; salaries 
for nearly 3 million elementary school teachers; 678,200 new fire 
engines; over 20 million Head Start slots for children; or health care 
coverage for 82 million children. A leaked memo from the White House to 
domestic agencies outlines major cuts following the election, including 
funding for education, Head Start, home ownership, job training, 
medical research and homeland security.

  Social costs to the military: To meet troop requirements in Iraq, the 
army has extended the tours of duty for soldiers. These extensions have 
been particularly difficult for reservists, many of whom never expected 
to face such long separations from their jobs and families. According 
to military policy, reservists are not supposed to be on assignment for 
more than 12 months every five-six years. To date, the average tour of 
duty for all soldiers in Iraq has been 320 days. A recent army survey 
revealed that more than half of soldiers said they would not re-enlist.

  Costs to veteran health care: About 64% of the more than 7,000 US 
soldiers injured in Iraq received wounds that prevented them from 
returning to duty. One trend has been an increase in amputees, the 
result of improved body armor that protects vital organs but not 
extremities. As in previous wars, many soldiers are likely to have 
received ailments that will not be detected for years to come. The 
Veterans Administration healthcare system is not prepared for the 
swelling number of claims. In May, the House of Representatives 
approved funding for FY 2005 that is $2.6 billion less than needed, 
according to veterans' groups.

  Mental health costs: The New England Journal of Medicine reported in 
July that one in six soldiers returning from war in Iraq showed signs 
of post-traumatic stress disorder, major depression, or severe anxiety. 
Only 23% to 40% of respondents in the study who showed signs of a 
mental disorder had sought mental health care.

II. Costs to Iraq

  A. Human costs
Iraqi deaths and injuries: As of September 22, between 12,800 and 
14,843 Iraqi civilians had been killed as a result of the US invasion 
and ensuing occupation, while an estimated 40,000 Iraqis injured. 
During "major combat" operations, between 4,895 and 6,370 Iraqi 
soldiers and insurgents were killed.

Effects of depleted uranium (DU): The health impacts of the use of 
depleted uranium weaponry in Iraq are yet to be known. The Pentagon 
estimates that US and British forces used 1,100 to 2,200 tons of 
weaponry made from the toxic and radioactive metal during the March 
2003 bombing campaign. Many scientists blame the far smaller amount of 
DU weapons used in the Persian Gulf War of 1991 for illnesses among US 
soldiers, as well as a sevenfold increase in child birth defects in 
Basra in southern Iraq.

B. Security costs
Rise in crime: Murder, rape and kidnapping have skyrocketed since March 
2003, forcing Iraqi children to stay home from school and women to stay 
off the streets at night. Violent deaths rose from an average of 14 per 
month in 2002 to 357 per month in 2003.

Psychological impact: Living under occupation without the most basic 
security has devastated the Iraqi population. A poll conducted by the 
Iraq Center for Research and Strategic Studies in June found that 80% 
of Iraqis believe that coalition forces should leave either immediately 
or directly after the election.

  C. Economic costs
  Unemployment: Iraqi joblessness doubled from 30% before the war to 60% 
in the summer of 2003. While the Bush administration now claims that 
unemployment has dropped, the US is only employing 120,000 Iraqis, of a 
workforce of 7 million, in reconstruction projects.

Corporate war profiteering: Most of Iraq's reconstruction has been 
contracted out to US companies, rather than experienced Iraqi firms. 
Top contractor Halliburton is being investigated for charging $160 
million for meals that were never served to troops and $61 million in 
cost overruns on fuel deliveries. Halliburton employees also took $6 
million in kickbacks from sub-contractors, while other employees have 
reported extensive waste, including the abandonment of $85,000 worth of 
trucks because they had flat tires.

Iraq's oil economy:  Anti-occupation violence has prevented Iraq from 
capitalizing on its oil assets. There have been an estimated 118 
attacks on Iraq's oil infrastructure since June 2003. By September, oil 
production still had not reached pre-war levels and major attacks 
caused oil exports to plummet to a 10-month low in August.

  D. Social costs
Health infrastructure: After more than a decade of crippling sanctions, 
Iraq's health facilities were further damaged during the war and 
post-invasion looting. Iraq's hospitals continue to suffer from lack of 
supplies and an overwhelming number of patients.

  Education: The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) estimates that 
more than 200 schools were destroyed in the conflict and thousands more 
were looted in the chaos following the fall of Saddam Hussein. The 
State Department reported on September 15 that "significant obstacles 
remain in maintaining security for civilian/military reconstruction, 
logistical support and distribution for donations, equipment, textbooks 
and supplies".

Environment: The US-led attack damaged water and sewage systems and the 
country's fragile desert ecosystem. It also resulted in oil well fires 
that spewed smoke across the country and left unexploded ordnance that 
continues to endanger the Iraqi people and environment. Mines and 
unexploded ordnance cause an estimated 20 casualties per month.

  E. Human-rights costs
Even with Saddam overthrown, Iraqis continue to face human-rights 
violations from occupying forces. In addition to the widely publicized 
humiliation and torture of prisoners, abuse has been widespread 
throughout the post-September 11 military operations, with over 300 
allegations of abuse in Afghanistan, Iraq and Guantanamo. As of 
mid-August, only 155 investigations into the existing 300 allegations 
had been completed.

F. Sovereignty costs
Despite the proclaimed "transfer of sovereignty" to Iraq, the country 
continues to be occupied by US and coalition troops and has severely 
limited political and economic independence. The interim government 
does not have the authority to reverse the nearly 100 orders by former 
Coalition Provisional Authority head L Paul Bremer that, among other 
things, allow for the privatization of Iraq's state-owned enterprises 
and prohibit preferences for domestic firms in reconstruction.

III. Costs to the world

A. Human costs
While Americans make up the vast majority of military and contractor 
personnel in Iraq, other US-allied "coalition" troops have suffered 135 
war casualties in Iraq. In addition, the focus on Iraq has diverted 
international resources and attention away from humanitarian crises 
such as in Sudan.

B. Disabling international law
The unilateral US decision to go to war in Iraq violated the United 
Nations charter, setting a dangerous precedent for other countries to 
seize any opportunity to respond militarily to claimed threats, whether 
real or contrived, that must be "preempted". The US military has also 
violated the Geneva Convention, making it more likely that in the 
future, other nations will ignore these protections in their treatment 
of civilian populations and detainees.

  C. Undermining the United Nations
  At every turn, the Bush administration has attacked the legitimacy and 
credibility of the UN, undermining the institution's capacity to act in 
the future as the centerpiece of global disarmament and conflict 
resolution. The efforts of the Bush administration to gain UN 
acceptance of an Iraqi government that was not elected but rather 
installed by occupying forces undermines the entire notion of national 
sovereignty as the basis for the UN charter. It was on this basis that 
secretary general Kofi Annan referred specifically to the vantage point 
of the UN charter in his September 2004 finding that the war was 
illegal.

D. Enforcing coalitions
Faced with opposition in the UN Security Council, the US government 
attempted to create the illusion of multilateral support for the war by 
pressuring other governments to join a so-called "coalition of the 
willing". This not only circumvented UN authority, but also undermined 
democracy in many coalition countries, where public opposition to the 
war was as high as 90%. As of the middle of September, only 29 members 
of the "coalition of the willing" had forces in Iraq, in addition to 
the US. These countries, combined with US, make up less than 14% of the 
world's population.

E. Costs to the global economy
The $151.1 billion spent by the US government on the war could have cut 
world hunger in half and covered HIV/AIDS medicine, childhood 
immunization and clean water and sanitation needs of the developing 
world for more than two years. As a factor in the oil price hike, the 
war has created concerns of a return to the "stagflation" of the 1970s. 
Already, the world's major airlines are expecting an increase in costs 
of $1 billion or more per month.

F. Undermining global security and disarmament
  The US-led war and occupation have galvanized international terrorist 
organizations, placing people not only in Iraq but around the world at 
greater risk of attack. The State Department's annual report on 
international terrorism reported that in 2003 there was the highest 
level of terror-related incidents deemed "significant" than at any time 
since the US began issuing these figures.

G. Global environmental costs
US-fired depleted uranium weapons have contributed to pollution of 
Iraq's land and water, with inevitable spillover effects in other 
countries. The heavily polluted Tigris River, for example, flows 
through Iraq, Iran and Kuwait.

  H. Human rights
The Justice Department memo assuring the White House that torture was 
legal stands in stark violation of the International Convention Against 
Torture (of which the US is a signatory). This, combined with the 
widely publicized mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners by US military and 
intelligence officials, gave new license for torture and mistreatment 
by governments around the world.

Press Release

2004-09-22

Press Release from Boycott For Equality

Gays to Withdraw Cash From Banks-Could Total Billions

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

Contact: Dale Duncan (757) 257-6215 dsd@boycottforequality.org

Gays to Withdraw Cash from Banks October 8 - Could Total Billions Atlanta, 
GA, September 22, 2004 - Organizers of the Boycott For Equality are 
expanding their nationwide walkout to include a coordinated cash withdrawal 
from the economy on October 8. To demonstrate the need for equality in 
marriage and the workplace, Straight and Gay supporters will each take out 
$80 from their local ATM.

Boycott For Equality expects the action will exhaust the cash in many ATMs, 
leaving a reminder of gay economic power to all who try to use them 
throughout the long bank weekend. To further drive home the lessons taught 
during the Boycott, participants should refer to the Boycott when 
communicating with their elected representatives, particularly when 
candidates ask for money to fund their campaigns. "Let them know you 
participated in the Boycott" explained Duncan. "Just take your ATM receipt, 
cross out your account number, circle your balance, write GAY MONEY on it 
and mail it to campaign headquarters in the postage paid envelope they 
provide. They'll get the message that nobody in America can be taken for 
granted." The amount represents the amount the average member of the 
Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) community contributes to the 
US economy each day, and could grow beyond the $1.4 billion that LGBT 
workers contribute each day - more than $500 billion each year according to 
computations by Washington D.C.-based public relations firm Witeck-Combs 
Communications.

The walkout combines several actions highlighting the various ways that 
Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) Citizens contribute to the 
economy on a regular basis. Other components of the Boycott include a 
one-day work stoppage or "pink flu" day to demonstrate solidarity to 
employers and colleagues; a moratorium on spending for goods and services 
such as gas, food and clothing, to show retailers what would happen if 7% 
of their revenue goes away; closures by sympathetic businesses to make 
their customers aware of how dependent Americans are upon each other; and a 
halt to cell phone use to spread the plea for equality throughout the 
participant's network.

Close to fifty businesses and 15,000 people have already pledged to 
participate using the online forms at the group's web site. Some major 
groups that have endorsed or encouraged Boycott For Equality Day include 
Don't Amend: The Equality Campaign, The Advocate magazine, Civil Marriage 
US, several local PFLAG chapters, DC Diversity, Equality Illinois and 
Wyoming Equality. In at least 36 states it is still legal to fire some one 
because of their sexuality - even if they never bring it into the 
workplace. And nowhere in the United States are these taxpayers able to 
file joint federal income tax, combine tax deductions, or access their 
partner's social security or disability benefits. ----------- Boycott For 
Equality is an Atlanta-based non-profit formed to promote the boycott, 
scheduled this year for October 8.

For that day, GLBT Americans and their straight allies are encouraged to 
withdraw from the economy in five specific areas: 1) Stay home from work. 
Do not generate payroll taxes, income taxes or add to the economy. If you 
run a business, let your customers know by closing for the day. 2) Withdraw 
$80 from your bank account at an ATM. 3) Don't shop. Do not generate sales 
tax or business revenue. 4) Hang up your cell phone. Your silence will 
affect your whole communications network. For more information, visit 
www.boycottforequality.org

> ok an interesting situation.

> The seller doesn't sell out of the US, but it supposed to be located in the UK.
> The auction ended, and I lost to one of the other 74 bidders. And for some reason the sellers ebay registration isn't valid anymore.
> The seller (or someone with their email) emails me saying I was 2nd and the winner was suspected by fraud. . .etc etc. . .( but there were 12 laptops, was that buyer buying all ? I was second ?)
> 
> So I was like YES. . . let me know.
> 
> She? emailed me back saying it would be $400 for the laptop, sent via western union money transfer to that persons address in Italy. . . I also sent an email thru ebay to the person that they haven't recieved.
> 
> Since then I've spoke to a couple other bidders who asked me if it seemed suspicious to me, they recieved the same email initially.
> 
> Now. . .the seller is still wanting to know if I want one. . .
> 
> So here, if you want to play, Give me $400, I'll buy the item. . . if it's legit and I recieve a laptop like in the auction, then I'll give you $600. . .if not and it is a scam, you lose your $400. . .  but if it is real, you make $200 . . . I'll write up some contract to be signed, one of the rules will be "no crying about losing" . . .

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr. .  EBay scam ? wanna play ?

Scam.

Any item like that you use an Ebay recommended escrow service. If
they insist on anything else, it's a scam.

I'd suggest drawing them out as much as possible, like they did
on the famous Slashdot "I scammed the scammer" article. Serve them
right.

Sean

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Love Parade

So now, instead of fighting off the beginnings of a cold with lots of 
green tea and vitamin C, I'm officially sick.  But it was worth it.

I thing Tigger said it best.  Love Parade was like a "ravers' class 
reunion".  I saw SOOOO many people that I haven't seen in ages.  The 
only difference was, unlike the people I went to high school with, I 
was glad to see everyone I found at Love Parade, and it reminded me how 
much I miss hanging with them, and how I'd really like to see more of 
them.  Fun times.

And the event itself was hella cool too.  More good music than you 
could shake a stick at; and many, Many, MANY people just having fun and 
doing their thing.  Only complaint I could come up with is the woefully 
inadequate number of port-o-lets they had on hand.  But presumably, 
they've learned from that for next years go around.  And damn am I 
looking forward to the next one!

Okay then.  Time to drink see if I can do anything else about this cold.


cya,
john

On Sat, 2 Oct 2004, aK wrote:

> Hey all,
>
> most of you probably have heard something about this.
> Just think of how many of you would be in iraq right now if this draft action was already active. . . something you definately need to pay attention to. Really, if you think about it. . .if there is a draft again, a lot of you won't be able to go about your fun party lives, but might have to take long breaks in the military which may or may not cost your life in one way or another.
>
> The worst part about that is, I bet most of us are just totally NOT the types to go fight in the military for ideas we don't totally agree with under orders of someone else. . .and to be pulled from our normal lives for something that many of us just simply dont believe in. . .
>
> I'm passing this on from a media buddy,
> Mandatory draft for males and females (ages 18-26) starting June 15, 2005, is something that everyone should know about. This literally effects everyone since we all have or know children that will have to go if this bill passes.
>
> There is pending legislation in the house and senate (companion bills: S89 and HR 163) which will time the program's initiation so the draft can begin as early as spring, 2005, just after the 2004 presidential election. The administration is quietly trying to get these bills passed now, while the public's attention is on the elections, so our action on this is needed immediately. Details and links follow.
>
> This plan, among other things, eliminates higher education as a shelter and incl reement with Canada which will no longer permit anyone attempting to dodge the draft to stay within it's borders. This bill also includes the extention of military service for all those that are currently active.
>
> If you go to the select service web site and read their 2004 FYI Goals you will see that the reasoning for this is to increase the size of the military in case of terrorism. This is a critical piece of legislation, this will effect our undergradates, our children and our grandchildren.
>
> Please take the time to write your congressman and let them know how you feel about this legislation. www.house.gov <http://www.house.gov/ www.senate.gov <http://www.senate.gov/
>
> Please also write to your representatives and ask them why they aren't telling their constituents about these bills and write to newspapers and other media outlets to ask them why they're not covering this important story.
>
> $28 million has been added to the 2004 selective ser 03, "to provide for the common defense by requiring that all young persons(age
> 18-26) in the United States, including women, perform a period of military service or a period of civilian service in furtherance of the national defense and homeland security, and for other purposes."
>
> These active bills currently sit in the committee on armed services. Dodging the draft will be more difficult than those from the Vietnam era. College and Canada will not be options. In December, 2001, Canada and the U. S. signed a "smart border declaration," which could be used to keep would-be draft dodgers in. Signed by Canada's minister of foreign affairs, John Manley, an

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Love Parade

I have to agree. For the 1st attempt at a Love Parade here, it was not bad
at all. Some of the floats were a little bland, but there was a ton of good
music - much happiness all around. People just gettin' down and having fun.
Very refreshing, and a helluva nice way to spend a Saturday afternoon. My
only complaint - not enough breaks! Although - someone on what looked like
the Skills float decided to abandon trance for long enough to drop "Alright
All Night" by the Lee Coombs/Christian J, and everyone around the float just
broke out dancing like maniacs in the middle of the street. That was
sweetness....

Next year (if they have it) can only get better. I'd go again...

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_17389104==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] How I Spent the Weekend of Love

--=====================_17389104==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

The Love Parade was an extraordinary event for a first-timer, and I hope it 
becomes a yearly celebration in the City of Love.

The high point of the weekend for me, however, was one of the after 
parties:  this one at Club 6.  Yes, I know I write about Club 6 a lot and I 
rarely see people from the list there.  But it really hit me in the groin 
and heart last night that Angel has achieved something at 6 that I have 
been looking for, and working towards myself, in San Francisco.

As some of you know from reading my House Music 101, I grew up in music and 
dance in primarily African American and Latino subcultures.  As a teenager 
in Pittsburgh, PA, I spent my weekends in the Hill District drinking, 
dancing and socializing in black bars and clubs that played Motown, R&B, 
and Blues.  My favorite radio station was WAMO.  Also made many trips to 
the Chicago scene with my black friends.

When I moved to New York it was the same.  The Loft had a good racial mix, 
and the Paradise Garage was a haven for gay African Americans and 
Latinos.  I was a part of the early rap and hip hop scene and used to 
regularly attend sound system battles in the Bronx.

Arriving in San Francisco with my Hispanic partner in the late eighties, 
the most striking thing we noticed about the gay club scene here and the 
music culture in general was the very small representation of African 
Americans and Hispanics.  It is a dirty little secret in the gay dance 
scene, perhaps not so secret lately, that people of color are discriminated 
against.  I think it's not so move overt, but covert.  One of the major 
promoters in the circuit party community here still brags that the brown 
skinned boys don't patronize his events.  One club event that was an oasis 
in this colorless desert was Page Hodel's Thursday night gay weekly at what 
is now the Justice League.

As time went by the Latino boys created their on gay club nights, and I've 
danced at some of these though I confess I can't deal with some of the Tex 
Mex stuff they spin at times.

The rave community is notable, for whatever reasons, for its lack of 
African Americans although one saw over time more Latinos and b-boys at the 
massives where hip hop, breaks, and jungle were featured.  It's 
encouraging, tho, that there is a growing Asian and Hispanic presence in 
the community.

What to do?  I really like dancing with African Americans.  They have a 
fluidity of style and movement on the dancefloor that inspires me to put 
more effort into my own moves.  And, obviously, I'm physically attracted to 
people of color.  I tried some of the commercial hip hop parties but didn't 
feel many of them were gay friendly.

Then Angle took over Club 6 a couple of years ago.  A man with a clear 
agenda:  to bring together an ethnically diverse dance crowd under one roof 
that was also sexually mixed.  He books quality underground hip hop parties 
regularly as well as house, breaks and other diverse genres.  As time went 
by one saw more and more b-boys coming down to the house floor from the hip 
hop room upstairs and visa versa:  the house heads experienced good hip hop 
and vibe.

Last night was an amazing example of the fruition of his efforts.  There 
were lots of parties last night, but we chose to go to Club 6 because our 
old friend Jesse was spinning, and following him was Roy Davis, Jr.  I 
wondered before we went who would show up to dance to classic, old school 
Chicago house.  Virtually no one I know from the house head crowd 
attended.  Rather -- and this is something I've dreamed about but never 
thought I would see -- the b-boy crowd was well represented with lots of 
people dancing hip hop fashion to soulful Chicago house.  Incredible.

As the evening was coming to an end there were three of us dancing 
energetically in front of the decks:  me, a Latino guy, and this b-boy who, 
in the fashion, was grabbing onto his crotch every four or five seconds, 
smiling at me, and dancing ever so fine.  I found this quite 
compelling.  Then Roy threw on an old house anthem about all the races 
dancing together -- the three of us putting everything into it at this 
point -- and I felt so completely happy and centered.  One of the best 
experiences I've had in ages.

I'm focused on having TrueSkool do a hip hop room at one of Moksha's 
parties.  I know that it took Angel a couple of years to do what he's 
done  at Club 6, but one takes one step at a time.  House and hip hop went 
there own ways at one point, but I think the circle is closing again.  I'd 
like to help make that happen.

Much love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"The truth is where the truth is, and it's sometimes in the candy store."
-Bob Dylan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] How I Spent the Weekend of Love

I sometimes wondered why that is, myself.  After all, you see plenty of 
white, Asian, and hispanic ravers of just about every persuasion you 
can think of.  And I can think of a not-insignificant number of ravers, 
I know, of Indian descent, and a good-sized middle-eastern contingent 
too.  And you see plenty of gay, lesbian, and bi ravers; and even the 
occasional transvestite.  So it's not like a case can be made that the 
rave scene wouldn't welcome a black kid in.  But, even if I wrack my 
brain, I can count on one hand the number of black ravers I've seen 
regularly.  And I can only honestly say I "know" one of them.

Curious.


cya,
john

Maria Kumjian, who didn't want to give her age but
said she has grandchildren, had been at the Ferry
Plaza Farmers' Market buying fruits and vegetables
when she saw the dancing people. She had to stop and

of these people dancing and the costumes, the feeling
that they're happy. It's a good feeling. We need a lot
of it."

The vibe was thick of love. All the people from all over the world. Smiles and hugs for all. Lots of people passing out free goodies & best of all was the music. 
 
The "Love Parade" was one of the ebst things i have ever went to as an event. There was so much love & positive people all around it was so friendly. All i can say is thank god for letting people use there video & digi cam's. 
 
So all and all this was a killer event once more in SF. Also i would like to say i wish the best of luck for this parade to happen a few more. The turn out was crazy. 
 
----On to drum machine's after partie. 
 
i would like to say thakns for the best aftr partie ever and thanks for the best damn UG set up ever 100% damn good. !!! musch love.. A++ event 
 
so i get to this after partie and it was 100% fun. I meet forset green dor the first time ever she was so nice and one of the most cheerfull dj's i meet ever. There was VJ , DJs and yes laptop dj's it was my first time seeing a VJ do his thing and it was such a mind trip.. The main room set up was killer with groovy black light props & posters, tons of chairs free water and beer . and the best thing was meeting all the people. i had a blast passing out suckers & glow sicks to all. and the drive back to chico at 1am was a pain in the ass but i did it. 
 
if anyone ells went to this evet let me know i got a few good pic's and some video tape of it. there was 3 rooms of pure BRG/Love and damn good home made music. 
 
well all and all Love was off the wall fun and i would love to come back to more.. 
 
-warren

asin, 1 of the guest who spun on our float, or was he a sponser, like total=
ly spun HAPPY HARDCORE.... I WAs in Hevean!!  Oh My Gosh man... LoL

 flava w/ their sets... Vicious was all about New School tracks & Future yu=
mmy stuff...Rabbi-E went on next spinning break beats & threw in some Yummy=
 house in there somewhere... OK... then i remember when lije John Stetler w=
ent on, he was all about like Future & Progressive Breakbeats... DMX went o=
n... PLayed a gang of like old school breakbeats then busted out wait... di=
d he???  He like doin' alota his scratching tricks on the decks.. hmmmmmm..=

I swear man.. like i said.. sensory fuckin' Overload.. if u weren't there..=
 I'm totally mondo sorry 2 say that U totally missed out!!

OK... I know alota y'all took pixes of me when i was driving & I wanna C th=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Origami bounced Friday at Anu (thump)

Thanks much for coming out, Peter and all the rest of y'all freaks! 
That was the most fun I've had throwing a club night, hands down.  This
party is now a monthly affair, every first friday @ Anu (on 6th st
between Market & Mission in SF), and we're going to have some nifty
lineups coming up in the months ahead.

On the 1s and 2s was my live performance and production partner Andrew
Phelan (www.djandrewphelan.com), a badass man on the decks and behind
the console.  On keys was local phenom Ryan Manley, known for his work
with band Loquat.

Starting off the night was our old pal Justin Hale, housin' the thang
right, and closing it off was AndyW, playing a set unlike anything I've
ever heard from him, absolutely off the hook. :)

To say we were happy with the turnout and the music would be a big
understatement.  Thanks again, all y'all, that was too much fun.

..and Peter, let's get together soon and get some sounds and rhymes
flowing!  Wh0000p!

Love,
-george c.
-newstylesound recordings
-djorigami.com
-newstylesound.com

From sfraves-return-116231-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Oct 05 00:48:53 2004
