Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary=Apple-Mail-2-518698919
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v553)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org,
 Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org>
From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
In-Reply-To: <20041001021705.I25254@taz3.hyperreal.org>
Message-Id: <B77DA8FE-1668-11D9-9A32-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] From moderator: please read

--Apple-Mail-2-518698919
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed

Hi Terry,

	Thanks for the kind words. You have a good memory to recollect the 
party we met at. I wish my own recollection were sharper about all the 
wonderful people I met at so many blissful events. I hope it's true 
that when you die, your life flashes in front of you -- I'm just afraid 
it may happen too fast for me to take notes.

	Anyway, I'm glad we're having this conversation about... what is this 
conversation about? I'm not exactly sure. I'm not even sure what I'm 
doing on this list, or whether I'm a raver any more, or whether there 
is such a thing as a rave "scene" in San Francisco (or anywhere else?) 
now. Maybe this will help me figure it out.

	For me, the magic that happens at a good rave will always be in a 
place by itself. But here I use the term "rave" broadly, to encompass 
any kind of experience of communal love bonding/tribal dancing/altered 
state experience. I have personally found that more strongly in the 
all-night electronic dance community than anywhere else, but I think it 
has happened many times and places throughout history.

	And I think it's important to have a sense of that. Back in the day, I 
often shared the sense, talking with other ravers whether in person or 
online, that we were part of something historic. Something that had 
changed our lives, an exciting social and technological phenomenon. I 
always wanted the scene to be more consciously about changing the 
world. I applauded the elements that made raves distinctly raves -- the 
illicit nature of the rave, the colorful clothing and accessories, the 
love puddles, the things like bouncy castles and brainwave machines 
that no one had thought of bringing to dance parties before. No one 
talked about "candy ravers" at the start, because that perspective was 
so mainstream within the rave culture that it didn't need a special 
category to describe it.

	I remember getting into an argument with one of the guys who worked at 
Ameba on upper Haight. Not Amoeba Records, but the small clothing and 
ephemera store that used to be across the street. That store had more 
of the flavor of the scene than any other store I'm aware of, except 
perhaps for "Raver Books" in Seattle (Groovin' Kim, you in the house?). 
Anyway, they had a display of rave hats -- you know, now that I think 
about it, maybe the display was at Villains down the street. Whatever, 
they had a display where they had taken a bunch of rave-type headgear 
and put them on top of very dark looking skulls. I found this deeply 
unfortunate, even offensive. Although I'd previously embraced a lot of 
goth culture myself, and still loved dark fantasy, cemeteries, the Cure 
and so on, I felt that to mix this kind of thing with the positive vibe 
of the rave scene was a complete corruption of what the spirit of 
raving was about. The guy made the counterargument of pointing to the 
Grateful Dead, perhaps the seminal band of the '60s era, and their use 
of skeletons in their artwork, not to mention the band's name itself. 
But it felt different to me. I didn't know that much about the Dead and 
still don't really, but their artwork has generally seemed to me to 
have more of a cheerful quality, as if they were laughing at death, 
trying to remind people of the transience of life, but in a 
non-threatening, playful kind of way. The evil-looking plastic skulls 
wearing the rave hats didn't give me that feeling. Around this time or 
perhaps a bit later I also remember a few parties that tried to promote 
the idea of "gravers" -- a mixing of goth and rave culture. Fortunately 
this ungodly concept never quite caught on -- no big surprise there! 
But I saw this type of thing, and many other influences, perhaps most 
notably the continuing mainstreaming of rave in all its manifestations, 
slowly diluting the energy of the scene, chipping away at the sense of 
what it meant to be a raver.

	Like I said, I always wanted ravers to be more conscious of the scene 
as a kind of project to change the world. But many never wanted that -- 
they wanted to have fun partying, and nothing more. Some people thought 
(probably still think) that what happened was a result of the music, 
and that the spirit of raving was uniquely tied to electronic dance 
music, perhaps even particular forms of electronic dance music. While I 
think electronic dance music is very well suited to orgiastic communal 
bonding experiences of the type we seek, I think other forms could 
potentially work just as well in the right place and time -- Sufi 
music, the Grateful Dead (whom I've never enjoyed all that much 
musically, but I love their fans), etc.

	Hmm... this message is rambling all over the place again. I don't know 
exactly what I want to say. It would be nice to have a sense of who's 
out there. How many people are on SFRaves now? How many of you have 
taken Ecstasy? How many of you consider yourself idealists? I think 
idealism is incredibly important to our scene. Anyone who dares to 
imagine the world much better than it is, after all, is an idealist. 
And if we can't (or won't) imagine a better world, how are we ever 
going to get there? It's been said that the only constant is change, 
and this is true. So why do people sort of settle for the idea that 
things aren't going to change that much -- that really wonderful, 
positive change is out of the question? I don't think I'm unrealistic 
about it, but maybe I have a rare gift for being able to maintain an 
optimistic outlook alongside a clear-headed view of reality. I don't 
think history is preordained to end in 2012, or that humanity is going 
to undergo some kind of marvelous transformation at that time. But if 
you can believe in something like that without fear of becoming 
disillusioned if it *doesn't* come to pass, then by all means believe! 
If enough people believe, it may happen. Or perhaps the expected good 
will not come about, but something else positive and unexpected will 
manifest.

	In 1967, Jerry Rubin and the Yippies led an anti-war protest in 
Washington D.C. to the Pentagon, where they sat down and attempted to 
use their minds to levitate the building away into space. I was at a 
lecture where this event was being talked about by someone who had been 
there, and he said that many of the people present actually expected 
the effort to *work*. Some, he said, even claimed to have seen the 
Pentagon rise a couple inches off the ground. Nuts? In a literal sense, 
certainly. Well, I'm 99.9% certain. But there was something beautiful 
about making the effort, even if from a political standpoint I wish 
they would have taken less of a knee-jerk anti-American posture and 
also gone after the Viet-Cong and international communism, which really 
were much worse than the U.S. government, even if the administration 
had horribly botched the war in Vietnam.

	Well, I guess what I'd like to see, what I believe would really make a 
difference, is to have a renaissance within the rave scene to reclaim 
the true spirit of raving as a conscious, idealistic project to change 
the world. Because without that kind of focus on larger goals and 
vision, it's too easy to get sidetracked. "If you don't stand for 
something, you'll go for anything" -- words of wisdom.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>


BOSS DRUM (The Shamen)
Written by Angus/West Published by Warner Chappell Music

Activate the Rhythm, the Rhythm that has always been Within you

On Friday, October 1, 2004, at 02:34  AM, Terry Estioko wrote:

> Apollo, Starchild, SFR-listers...
>
> As the moderator of this list (actually I'm only the gnome on duty 
> behind the curtain)...I appreciate your exchange. Your expressions are 
> a classic debate, although coincidentally happening on the eve of our 
> presidential debate...oops, political, bad moderator, bad. ;-)
>
> However, you both bring up good points.
>
> I'm sure Brian would have never believed that his simple attempt to 
> find raves here in nor-cal back in '93, plus his adeptness at creating 
> discussion lists would bring us here today. I joined this list back in 
> '95 also to find parties...and *boy* did I find parties =) A large 
> percentage of us here found SFRaves the same way.
>
> When I joined, I was impressed that this list was a single stream of 
> consciousness, or an "organic community" as stated. It also had an 
> amazing level of that "organic" organization in creating events and 
> disseminating info on related events. I have learned so much from 
> engaging this list from active discussion to personal relations. And 
> the stories produced from my experiences due to this list will be 
> retold in my grand-age.
>
> I met Starchild in '96 at Bonnie Dunes at a daytime Harmony party. And 
> while our exchanges have been brief, we were strangers by face but 
> family as the SFR community. He was one of the PLURy characters on SFR 
> that made me believe there was something more than my life at the > time.
>
> I met Apollo in '99 at Mission Rock, about a week after he posted to 
> SFR about starting the Moksha Tribe. We had a interesting rave-scene 
> discussion as strangers by face but more as family of the SFR 
> community.
>
> Perhaps it's just me, but I'm proud to be at the helm of a discussion 
> today where these minds can meet, continuing this stream of 
> consciousness.
>
> Enough of my exposition from this point (thanks for listening =)...
>
> While Starchild has returned to SFR charged with politicalism, I still 
> read his posts, because while this is "rave" list, we are an 
> "OLD-rave" list, and I find find it interesting in reading the 
> political views of my peers. This list keeps me grounded in times of 
> uncertainty. And while I may not agree with everything that is being 
> said here, I refer here to the pulse of others that have gone through 
> the same stuff as I have.
>
> Apollo has passively suggested that our list has become complacent. 
> Low signal to the noise, and less of all, which I also acknowledge. 
> The old SFRaves dynamic is moving farther away every day, and has been 
> for many years. I have no answer to this. We are who we are. This is 
> what it is. Many of the people on this list are that same people that 
> have been here for years.
>
> SFRaves is a unique list, and it *has* changed, and it will continue 
> to change. But I hope you all understand that this list, this 
> discussion, and our tangible outcome is *yours*. I'm not here to tell 
> you what to do, or what to think, or how to act, or how to learn. None 
> of us are.
>
> We're just here by chance, and *hopefully* have some sort of a shared 
> consciousness that we can discuss, learn and grow, and maybe even take 
> action...whether it be help us find some cool places to check out, or 
> throw some really fun parties for ourselves, or talk about how 
> electronic music or raves, or how it changed our lives...or perhaps 
> discuss random thoughts, news & events, and yes even ::shudder:: 
> politics...as it relates to ourselves.
>
> I'm sure I have much more to say, but y'all do much better job in your 
> collective discussion than I. Thanks for listening.
>
> take care,
>
> -terry


--Apple-Mail-2-518698919--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] How I Spent the Weekend of Love

quoth Apollo:
> The Love Parade was an extraordinary event for a first-timer, and I
> hope it becomes a yearly celebration in the City of Love.

I certainly hope so too. It was so great to see people from all facets
of the EDM community out here united in a single cause. Next year should
be even bigger and crazier!

Friday night was a great way to wind things up. George and Andrew: great
job getting all those peeps out for a night of housey goodness.
Unfortunately I missed the bi-curious makeout session, but I had to
catch Stewart Walker at Rx. I have to say though, that place is really
wierd. Maybe it's the crappy sound; maybe it's the disproportionately
male clientelle; maybe it's the lack of a full bar. Whatever it is, this
place just never seems to go off, despite all the amazing talent they
bring in. Needless to say, after a while we were on our way back to Anu
to catch the remainder of Andy's painfully entertaining 90's house set.

Then, the parade. Melissa and I got there at noon to help out, but it
was pretty poorly organized so we just ended up mulling around watching
people set up. One thing I would stress, now that you all know what it's
about, is for more people to VOLUNTEER next year. It's pretty amazing
that things went as well as they did, given that there were less than 20
volunteers this year (aside from dedicated parade staff). But with more
people from our community involved next year, it can only get better.

Now, for those of you with future float aspirations, I have some
recommendations:

1) talk to people that did floats this year; there's much to be learned
   in the art of securing turntables and sound systems on a flatbed full
   of dancing people.
2) if you go, save your shit (costumes, art car decorations, etc.) from
   Burning Man. You will save a TON money.
3) start planning now!

The festival afterwards was kind of lame, IMO--like a massive with
several really small, relatively underwhelming sound setups. I guess
it was a lot easier to organize than an "official" stage featuring
talent booked separately by all of the float staff though. Anyway, at
that point I was a bit tired and my brownie was kicking in, so I had to
get home and catch some sleep before my door shift at...

LOVE MACHINE! With the exception of some issues with bathrooms and water
(seemingly unavoidable at that venue), everything went smoothly and
people appeared to be having a great time. The only DJ I was able to
catch a good deal of was Forest Green, on point as usual with the
totally seamless dancefloor techno mixing skills. I caught bits of
Mochipet and Brizzle's merciless live performances, and an excellent
electro/breaks set by Saru. Cheers to those of you that stuck around
late enough to catch me (and Amber) winding things down upstairs. I
think the playlist speaks for itself:

Terence FM - Feelin' Kinda High (Cajual)
Ricardo Villalobos - What You Say Is More Than I Can Say (Playhouse)
John Shananigans - Charlie's On the Dancefloor (Cynosure)
Ricardo vs. Jay - Cactus Love (Contexterrior)
John Tejada & Arian Leviste - Ghetto Platypus (Palette)
Copacabannark - Garden Parade (Perlon)
Ectomorph - Ritmo Sinestro (Interdimensional Transmissions)
L'usine - Push (Ghostly International)
Unai - Night Fell (And So Did We) (Sub Static)
2 Dollar Egg - Implantat (Klang Elektronik)

Good times. Let's do it again!

Toodles,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving (or E vs LSD)

It just striked me recently that the phase "the spirit of raving"
implied something very fundamental about what I missed from our scene:
spirituality.

Whether PLUR is a good slogan or if kids these that actually live by
the motto is besides the point. The slogan entirely omitted the
spiritual aspect of our scene.

Before E became the drug of choice, acid ruled the scene. Our
objective of the night wasn't getting blissfully E'ed out and jump
into hug puddles at every corner. Instead, we were trying to preceive
the world in a new light and raise ourselves collectively to a higher
consciousness.

Yes, "higher state of consciousness". It used to be a catch phase.
Spitituality was a major focus in our scene, now the idea all but
disappeared. Coincidentally, it's when PLUR and E became popular (in
the mid '90s).

Have we all been consumed by the need of artificial, chemically
induced empathy and compassion? Have we fogotten that what connect us
together is more than just music and philosophy, but our collective,
singular existence beyond our physical reality?

Just thinking our loud.


Love,

- Jeff


-- 
"I don't go out to be seen,
 I don't go out to show off,
 I go out to be a part of something I believe in."

Subject: [sfraves] interactive music machine available

hi list -

i've been lurking for ages but i'm stepping out of the shadows to say -
i'm part of an arts collective that has built an interactive
sound sculpture that allows up to four players to do live
remixing/performance of original (and some plundered) electronic music,
ambient and dance.  we've had our improbable orchestra at burning man for
the last three years, and especially this last year, people reacted really
positively.  so, any promoter on this list who would like to break down
the dancer/dj divide at your event - this is you chance, we are
available.

IO consists of four speakers on stands, pointing inwards,
arranged in a circle around a central control podium which lights up at
night.  This podium has on it four control stations with a number of knobs
and buttons that allow non-musician players easy but thorough control over
the music that is playing.  please see:

http://xiphoidprocess.com/io/

for detailed description, photos, and video (i've found that it's much
easier for people to grasp what this thing does after watching the
videos).

we can tailor the music our machine makes to your event - for example, if
you're going to have detroit techno party, we'll sample a bunch of detroit
techno records - then you can have people dancing to techno djs in one
room, and people being their own techno djs in another room with our
machine.

please email me if you're interested.  also, if you saw us at burning man
i'd be curious to know what you thought...

jacob

My email is all jacked up so I don't know if this has already been sent
but if it hasn't:

=20

EVERY TUESDAY at LIT LOUNGE!!!!

=20

H U G G E R - M U G G E R

brought to you by tech-on

http://www.tech-on.com <http://www.tech-on.com/>=20

at Lit Lounge (101 6th street @ Mission) 9pm - 2am

21+

FREE admission!!!

.techno .electro .idm .minimal .micro .breaks

=20

This week's guest:

=20

Tom Wax (Phuture Wax, Frankfurt)

DJ Pat (Teknique, Sacramento)

=20

For those of you that are sitting there thinking "I know that name" but
just can't remember where u heard it, Tom Wax pretty much invented the
German techno sound.  In addition to putting out literally hundreds of
records over the last 15 years under names like Arpeggiators, Microbots,
DJ Tom + Norman, AWeX, etc., he's also remixed just about everybody on
the planet from Erasure and Depeche Mode to Hardfloor.  And if producing
the longest discography in all of EDM over the years wasn't enough, Tom
has spent the last 15 years personally shaping the sound of underground
music.  His most notable work in this department was working as A&R
manager for Harthouse where he pushed new artists like Cari Lekebush.
He's worked for a number of other labels over the years but none more
important than his own Phuture Wax label, where he launched the careers
of numerous artists like Timo Maas, Terry Lee Brown Jr. Jean Frank
Cochois, and so on.  Whether you like hard minimal techno, deep house,
tech-house or trance, Tom has had a hand in shaping that sound.  So for
those of you that wouldn't normally come out to a "Techno" oriented
club, tonight is the night you will want to check it out! =20

=20

residents spinning tonight:

>>>Clairity<<< and >>>Forest Green<<<

=20

Resident DJ's

Andy W

Li

Forest Green

Clairity

Juan Segovia

=20

----- Message from Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> on Sat, 02 Oct 2004
17:49:42 -0700 -----
                                                            
      To: sfraves@hyperreal.org                             
                                                            
 Subject: NRR: Gays to Withdraw Cash From Banks-Could Total 
          Billions                                          
                                                            



Press Release

2004-09-22

Press Release from Boycott For Equality

Gays to Withdraw Cash From Banks-Could Total Billions

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

Contact: Dale Duncan (757) 257-6215 dsd@boycottforequality.org

Gays to Withdraw Cash from Banks October 8 - Could Total Billions Atlan=
ta,
GA, September 22, 2004 - Organizers of the Boycott For Equality are
expanding their nationwide walkout to include a coordinated cash withdr=
awal

from the economy on October 8. To demonstrate the need for equality in
marriage and the workplace, Straight and Gay supporters will each take =
out
$80 from their local ATM.

Boycott For Equality expects the action will exhaust the cash in many A=
TMs,

leaving a reminder of gay economic power to all who try to use them
throughout the long bank weekend. To further drive home the lessons tau=
ght
during the Boycott, participants should refer to the Boycott when
communicating with their elected representatives, particularly when
candidates ask for money to fund their campaigns. "Let them know you
participated in the Boycott" explained Duncan. "Just take your ATM rece=
ipt,

cross out your account number, circle your balance, write GAY MONEY on =
it
and mail it to campaign headquarters in the postage paid envelope they
provide. They'll get the message that nobody in America can be taken fo=
r
granted." The amount represents the amount the average member of the
Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) community contributes to =
the
US economy each day, and could grow beyond the $1.4 billion that LGBT
workers contribute each day - more than $500 billion each year accordin=
g to

computations by Washington D.C.-based public relations firm Witeck-Comb=
s
Communications.

The walkout combines several actions highlighting the various ways that=

Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) Citizens contribute to th=
e
economy on a regular basis. Other components of the Boycott include a
one-day work stoppage or "pink flu" day to demonstrate solidarity to
employers and colleagues; a moratorium on spending for goods and servic=
es
such as gas, food and clothing, to show retailers what would happen if =
7%
of their revenue goes away; closures by sympathetic businesses to make
their customers aware of how dependent Americans are upon each other; a=
nd a

halt to cell phone use to spread the plea for equality throughout the
participant's network.

Close to fifty businesses and 15,000 people have already pledged to
participate using the online forms at the group's web site. Some major
groups that have endorsed or encouraged Boycott For Equality Day includ=
e
Don't Amend: The Equality Campaign, The Advocate magazine, Civil Marria=
ge
US, several local PFLAG chapters, DC Diversity, Equality Illinois and
Wyoming Equality. In at least 36 states it is still legal to fire some =
one
because of their sexuality - even if they never bring it into the
workplace. And nowhere in the United States are these taxpayers able to=

file joint federal income tax, combine tax deductions, or access their
partner's social security or disability benefits. ----------- Boycott F=
or
Equality is an Atlanta-based non-profit formed to promote the boycott,
scheduled this year for October 8.

For that day, GLBT Americans and their straight allies are encouraged t=
o
withdraw from the economy in five specific areas: 1) Stay home from wor=
k.
Do not generate payroll taxes, income taxes or add to the economy. If y=
ou
run a business, let your customers know by closing for the day. 2) With=
draw

$80 from your bank account at an ATM. 3) Don't shop. Do not generate sa=
les
tax or business revenue. 4) Hang up your cell phone. Your silence will
affect your whole communications network. For more information, visit
www.boycottforequality.org





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.ht=
m

"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the ha=
nds
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible=

empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"The truth is where the truth is, and it's sometimes in the candy store=
."
-Bob Dylan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of th=
e
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually bec=
ome
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

database of gay americans. The banks will turn over pics/videos of
every ATM customers who withdraw $80 that day to the Dept of Homeland
Security, along with their detailed personal information, their
lifetime bank statements, etc. The Bush Adminstration plan to draft
every gay person who make under $25,000 a year into the military and
send them to Iraq. Since they have little contribution to the economy,
and typically have no legal spouses nor children, ttheir casualities
will result in little financial consequences to the gorvernment.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving (or E vs LSD)

> 
> Have we all been consumed by the need of artificial, chemically
> induced empathy and compassion? 

Instead of the need for artificial, chemically induced enlightment?

I am not anti-drug, but I don't think it is fair to say that acid=good
for scene, e=bad.  Whats enlightment without love?  Whats love without
enlightment?   I think the key is to take the lessons learned from 
these substances and apply them to your everyday, non-chemical life,
and know when you have learned all there is to learn.  True love,
red wine and a hottub is just as good as the phatest hit of e.  A computer
loaded with the latest music software is more fun than acid.  Or is that
a computer loaded with Acid is as good as acid?  

Man, if I owned a hot tub, I would never ever need drugs.

-troy

> ----- Message from Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> on Sat, 02
> Oct 2004
> 17:49:42 -0700 -----
> 
>       To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> 
>  Subject: NRR: Gays to Withdraw Cash From Banks-Could Total
>           Billions
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Press Release
> 
> 2004-09-22
> 
> Press Release from Boycott For Equality
> 
> Gays to Withdraw Cash From Banks-Could Total Billions
> 
> FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
> 
> Contact: Dale Duncan (757) 257-6215
> dsd@boycottforequality.org
> 
> Gays to Withdraw Cash from Banks October 8 - Could Total
> Billions Atlanta,
> GA, September 22, 2004 - Organizers of the Boycott For
> Equality are
> expanding their nationwide walkout to include a coordinated
> cash withdrawal
> 
> from the economy on October 8. To demonstrate the need for
> equality in
> marriage and the workplace, Straight and Gay supporters will
> each take out
> $80 from their local ATM.
> 
> Boycott For Equality expects the action will exhaust the cash
> in many ATMs,
> 
> leaving a reminder of gay economic power to all who try to
> use them
> throughout the long bank weekend. To further drive home the
> lessons taught
> during the Boycott, participants should refer to the Boycott
> when
> communicating with their elected representatives,
> particularly when
> candidates ask for money to fund their campaigns. "Let them
> know you
> participated in the Boycott" explained Duncan. "Just take
> your ATM receipt,
> 
> cross out your account number, circle your balance, write GAY
> MONEY on it
> and mail it to campaign headquarters in the postage paid
> envelope they
> provide. They'll get the message that nobody in America can
> be taken for
> granted." The amount represents the amount the average member
> of the
> Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) community
> contributes to the
> US economy each day, and could grow beyond the $1.4 billion
> that LGBT
> workers contribute each day - more than $500 billion each
> year according to
> 
> computations by Washington D.C.-based public relations firm
> Witeck-Combs
> Communications.
> 
> The walkout combines several actions highlighting the various
> ways that
> Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) Citizens
> contribute to the
> economy on a regular basis. Other components of the Boycott
> include a
> one-day work stoppage or "pink flu" day to demonstrate
> solidarity to
> employers and colleagues; a moratorium on spending for goods
> and services
> such as gas, food and clothing, to show retailers what would
> happen if 7%
> of their revenue goes away; closures by sympathetic
> businesses to make
> their customers aware of how dependent Americans are upon
> each other; and a
> 
> halt to cell phone use to spread the plea for equality
> throughout the
> participant's network.
> 
> Close to fifty businesses and 15,000 people have already
> pledged to
> participate using the online forms at the group's web site.
> Some major
> groups that have endorsed or encouraged Boycott For Equality
> Day include
> Don't Amend: The Equality Campaign, The Advocate magazine,
> Civil Marriage
> US, several local PFLAG chapters, DC Diversity, Equality
> Illinois and
> Wyoming Equality. In at least 36 states it is still legal to
> fire some one
> because of their sexuality - even if they never bring it into
> the
> workplace. And nowhere in the United States are these
> taxpayers able to
> file joint federal income tax, combine tax deductions, or
> access their
> partner's social security or disability benefits. -----------
> Boycott For
> Equality is an Atlanta-based non-profit formed to promote the
> boycott,
> scheduled this year for October 8.
> 
> For that day, GLBT Americans and their straight allies are
> encouraged to
> withdraw from the economy in five specific areas: 1) Stay
> home from work.
> Do not generate payroll taxes, income taxes or add to the
> economy. If you
> run a business, let your customers know by closing for the
> day. 2) Withdraw
> 
> $80 from your bank account at an ATM. 3) Don't shop. Do not
> generate sales
> tax or business revenue. 4) Hang up your cell phone. Your
> silence will
> affect your whole communications network. For more
> information, visit
> www.boycottforequality.org
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>

> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

> >
> > Have we all been consumed by the need of artificial, chemically
> > induced empathy and compassion?
> 
> Instead of the need for artificial, chemically induced enlightment?
> 

The key word is "consumed", not "arrificial". Physical euphoria is
more instantly gratifying than spiritual enlightment.

> I am not anti-drug, but I don't think it is fair to say that acid=good
> for scene, e=bad.  Whats enlightment without love?  Whats love without
> enlightment?   I think the key is to take the lessons learned from
> these substances and apply them to your everyday, non-chemical life,
> and know when you have learned all there is to learn.  True love,
> red wine and a hottub is just as good as the phatest hit of e.  A computer
> loaded with the latest music software is more fun than acid.  Or is that
> a computer loaded with Acid is as good as acid?
> 

It never fails that whenever an arguement mewntions drugs, someone
will reducie it to the drugs alone.

I was speaking mostly in terms of how the scene used to be spirituality-driven.

> Man, if I owned a hot tub, I would never ever need drugs.
> 


Maybe u can sell more drugs to afford that hot tub.  LMAO

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving (or E vs LSD)

 
> I was speaking mostly in terms of how the scene used to be 
> spirituality-driven.

I think the last scene to really have true spirtuality was goa/psy-trance,
but lately it has succumb to being simply harder and darker.

Truth is, most people don't like sprituality in their scene.  They want
to party, not go to church.

There is such a fine line between true spirituality and hippie mumbo-jumbo..
or worse, true spiritualty and cult-like cliques.

Its out there, people still do spiritual-oriented parties.  I think much
of what goes on at Cell Space falls into the catagory.  

Lots of people think Goa Gill parties are pretty spiritual...

http://www.goagil.com/

> Maybe u can sell more drugs to afford that hot tub.  LMAO

I am going to start selling hot tubs to afford drugs.

-troy

  	Actually Edwards' got rich in his career as a trial lawyer by =
suing =20
doctors over medical outcomes that they could not have reasonably =20
prevented in cases where he had reason to expect a large fee.  See =20
article below.

			<<< Starchild >>>


http://www.cnsnews.com//=20
ViewCulture.asp?Page=3D\Culture\archive\200402\CUL20040210a.html
=A0
John Edwards 'Increased the Cost of Medicine', Former Associate Says
By Marc Morano
CNSNews.com Senior Staff Writer
February 10, 2004

(CNSNews.com) - A former North Carolina obstetrician-gynecologist who =20=

served as an expert witness and consultant to Sen. John Edwards during =20=

his days as a trial lawyer, now accuses the Democratic presidential =20
candidate of increasing the cost of medicine and forcing doctors into =20=

retirement in the senator's home state.

"What he has done with those lawsuits is increased the cost of =20
medicine, and he has not changed the practice of medicine in a way that =20=

you can see that there are fewer cases of cerebral palsy," William =20
Brannan said in an interview with CNSNews.com.

As CNSNews.com first reported on Jan. 20, Edwards won record jury =20
verdicts and settlements by arguing that in certain cases, =20
obstetricians and the hospitals where they practiced had been =20
responsible for botching the treatment of women in labor and the =20
delivery of their babies.

It was that botched treatment, Edwards argued, that resulted in the =20
infants sustaining either brain damage or developing cerebral palsy, a =20=

brain disorder that causes motor function impairment and lifelong =20
disability.

Brannan, the chief medical officer of Mission Hospitals in Asheville, =20=

N.C., said he was forced to end his medical practice this year because =20=

of skyrocketing medical insurance premiums. Brannan said he consulted =20=

for Edwards in an attempt to "bring only the valid cases into the legal =20=

system."

Edwards' campaign metaphors about standing up for the poor and =20
underprivileged in the battle between the "two Americas" does not =20
resonate with Brannan.

"I have some argument with [Edwards's] idea that he's out there to help =20=

the poor person and that he's out there helping all. No, he was very =20
selective in his cases, and went for those that were going to go for =20
large judgments," Brannan said.

"He was not an individual that would go out and help the poor person =20
who needed help in a low-dollar amount. If you look at his cases, they =20=

were all high-dollar amount and he didn't work for low-dollar =20
settlements," he added.

Brannan's role as a consultant and sometimes expert witness for Edwards =20=

and his legal firm allowed him to see Edwards's career up close.

"He was an expert at getting [cerebral palsy cases] settled without =20
going into the courtroom," Brannan said.

Brannan is very skeptical of Edwards' and other trial lawyers' =20
accomplishments in seeking to blame infant cerebral palsy cases on =20
botched labor and deliveries.

"I don't think that there is a correlation between bad medical practice =20=

and the incidence of cerebral palsy," Brannan said.

"Studies that we have done have found no changes in the incidences of =20=

cerebral palsy occurring either with increased vigilance...or the =20
increase in C-section rates that have occurred," he said.

Despite the scientific evidence, Brannan is not optimistic that medical =20=

malpractice cerebral palsy cases will fade from the courtroom anytime =20=

soon.

"Most juries have a live person in the room that they feel sympathy =20
for, and it's very hard to make the cold statistics of a scientific =20
study cancel out the sympathy that they feel," Brannan said.

"So most of juries, knowing that there are insurance policies behind =20
all of these [cases], will then want this family to have something to =20=

be able to provide care for the child," he added.

Edwards defends legal career

Edwards has conceded that infant cerebral palsy usually is not the =20
fault of the doctors who deliver the baby -- even though he argued =20
otherwise in his days as a trial lawyer.

According to an article in the New York Times on January 31, "...Mr. =20
Edwards did not dispute the contention...that few cases of cerebral =20
palsy are caused by mishandled deliveries." Edwards did say that during =20=

his legal career, he represented only the few cases that were the =20
exceptions to the rule.

Edwards was responding to allegations first reported by CNSNews.com on =20=

Jan. 20. The CNSNews.com report noted that a large part of Edwards' =20
legal career was based on "junk science," which he used to win hugely =20=

lucrative legal judgments or settlements against the medical profession.

The outcome of those cases, many of them dealing with the debatable =20
cause of cerebral palsy in infants, made Edwards a rich man, allowing =20=

him to self-finance a 1998 run for the U.S. Senate from North Carolina =20=

and position himself as a presidential candidate in 2004.

The CNSNews.com report pointed to medical studies, dating back to at =20
least the 1980s, which asserted that doctors could do very little to =20
cause cerebral palsy during the birthing process. Two new studies in =20
2003 further undermined the scientific premise of the high-profile =20
court cases won by Edwards.

Edwards now insists that the cerebral cases he represented were the =20
exceptions.

"I took very seriously our responsibility to determine if our cases =20
were merited," Edwards told the New York Times in the January 30 =20
interview, just days after refusing to answer CNSNews.com's questions =20=

on the same topic.

"Before I ever accepted a brain-injured child case, we would spend =20
months investigating it," Edwards added.

The Times article noted that between 1985 and 1995, "Edwards filed at =20=

least 20 similar lawsuits against doctors and hospitals in deliveries =20=

gone wrong, winning verdicts and settlements of more than $60 million, =20=

typically keeping about a third."

'Crisis'

Brannan believes that Edwards did his part to contribute to the =20
American Medical Association's listing of North Carolina as one of the =20=

"crisis states" for rising liability insurance.

Many physicians in the state are opting to quit their practices because =20=

they cannot afford the insurance premiums, according to Brannan.

The hospital that Brannan now serves as the chief medical officer also =20=

has been the target of Edwards and his law firm.

"Our hospital (Mission Hospitals, formerly St Joseph's) had two major =20=

suits brought by [Edwards's] law firm -- one of which he was able to =20
prevail and got a judgment, and another one his firm lost," Brannan =20
noted.

Brannan said he personally was forced to stop his Ob/Gyn practice when =20=

his insurance premiums shot up.

"My premium two years ago was $44,000 a year, and my insurance carrier =20=

notified me that if I wished to continue practicing, it was going up to =20=

$68,000 for this year," Brannan said.

"I chose to discontinue my Ob privileges, because I would have to =20
deliver 68 babies just to pay the premium before being able to pay any =20=

office expenses." He also said that his premiums were lower than those =20=

of many other doctors because of his affiliation with a hospital.

The small practitioners are hit the hardest by rising insurance, =20
Brannan said.

"Liability premiums are the same whether you deliver one baby a year or =20=

300 babies a year," he explained.

"The town of Franklin, North Carolina, lost their sole Ob/Gyn =20
practitioner, so now the women in that town are having to travel over a =20=

mountain pass to a neighboring city in order to get obstetrical care," =20=

Brannan said.


See Related Articles:
John Edwards Responds to 'Junk Science' Allegations (2/2/2004)
Did 'Junk Science' Make John Edwards Rich? (1/20/2004)

Subject: [sfraves] Rooms for rent

I saw a post on here not to long ago about someone with a room in sf.

At 12:33 PM 10/5/2004, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
>Man - almost any SERIOUS house club IS like going to church. What more 
>spirituality do you need than jackin' yer body with a few hundred other 
>folks, all blissed out on the beautiful beats??? That tribal feeling, the 
>primal feeling - that's what it's all about.
>
>I think you can get your "spirituality" on with any kind of EDM, if that's 
>what moves your soul....
>
>M-


"Not everyone understands House music; it's a spiritual thing; a body 
thing; a soul thing."

I've written lots on this subject in House Music 101 and elsewhere.  I 
think one has to define the term "spirituality":  it means different things 
to different people.  I've never been to a party that is 
"religion-based,"  but I've been to many where I've touched the sun, meshed 
with the flesh, and moved outside my own, often dismal little world.

As for religion I guess I'm more a pagan who practices Buddhism as a 
personal discipline.  I used to be an atheist.  Then I thought that it was 
much more fun to "believe" in a world of magic:  a place where Pan with 
hooves and a big dick runs amok;  where the sun is actually a "god" with a 
chariot who manifests truth and music.  LOL.  What difference does it 
make?  I'm not going to spend my time these days waiting for Godot and 
dealing with existentialist dilemmas.

As for goofrider's comment on LSD vs MDMA -- 'tis true that many in the 
rave community and in the dance scene as a whole from the seventies onward 
used acid and magic mushrooms to enhance perception and embark on personal, 
often epic, journeys of the body and soul.  Then MDMA was added to the mix, 
which introduced some empathy into the stew.

What I see these days are folks either numbing themselves with booze (or 
worse heroin) or burning themselves up with performance drugs like cocaine 
(the choice of executives even now) or speed.

Then I guess there are hot tubs and juice:)

People do what they will to make this arduous journey of life a bit easier 
and more meaningful.  I prefer a place where I can play with the wood 
nymphs, dance with Dionysus, and talk with some shamans once in 
awhile.  Magic.  I'm so burned out on cynicism and darkness.

Love,

Apollo

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Gays to Withdraw Cash From Banks-Could Total Billions

yo, Mary,

Babs and i are both doing this as a show of solidarity, and I'm about
as straight as you can get.

I posted this on the the DC Craigslist Rants and Raves section, and
one guy wrote back calling me gay because I used the word 'breeder' in
a sentence, and he also called this almost as dumb as the FMA itself.

sigh.

I stopped short of calling him a 'Capo,' which was my first gut
instinct, when i posted back, but i did say that there were some black
folk in Montgomery that did ride the busses, and there were white
people that joined that boycott, and that one of the reasons that I'm
going to do this is to take up their slack.

I also got a chilly response when I walked into a few local stores
that had Rainbow flags on them to let the people working there now
about this and what keywords to use to find out about it on google.

Took me by surprise, since this is such a simple idea.

Also surprised that i'm not seeing this all over the different cities
that Craigslists has in the personals, rants and raves and forum
sections, that strikes me as the most obvious place to virally market
this idea, give the explosive, exponential growth he's seen on there
in the last year.

And finally, Nick, my guess is is that number is much higher, think
overall gay population, in any given country on earth, is somewhere in
the 7-10% range of population.

Figure the USA is somewhere around 270 million people and key off of
that and the number gets much higher.

This is a process, be interesting how much play it gets in the
mainstream press this weekend, and it would be even crazier if it
actually had an effect that rippled out from the banks to Wall Street.

btw, speaking of which, since the Stock Market is essentially at the
same spot today, the lower 10,000 range, to where it was on September
10th, 2001, why is Wall Street still giving Bush the time of day and
why isn't Kerry all over that?

It's the Economy, Sweetheart.

nwa

Raindance Presents
The 10th Annual Halloween

Freaker's Ball !!!
Saturday October 30th
Yes it will be held on the 30th this year and not the 31st.

this will give people an opportunity to recuperate before Voting day which is
on Tuesday November 2nd ,so please get out and vote

We are very proud to announce the phenomenal lineup of this years event

Live acts will include
Hamsa Lila (world trance groove) , Foxgluv (this will be a cd release 
celebration for them)
our very own LUX aka (Rodman) playing all originals, Timonkey also playing 
originals

Goddess of Funk Santa Cruz's all star all female drum ensemble performing with
the talented and beautiful dancers of Hipnautica performing a special midnight
dance ritual honoring the onset of Halloween

Rick Walker's Loop Pool, will be keeping things properly weird on the lawn
  story telling and more surprises to be found

annual Costume Contest with prises

Now as for the Freakin' DJ Lineup

Lorin (Bassnactar) ,Jeno (Wicked) ,Carlos (the old school master has come 
out of hiding for this ocasion)
Tracy (Raindance ,end up), Little John( Raindance), Subal (13 Moon Tribe), 
CB (yoga Tai chi)
Tom L-G (Raindance), (13 Moon Tribe) Taina (13 Moon Tribe) + a few surprises

there will be four rooms of madness, outdoor lounge, organic snacks from 
Convergence
Sambzon Acai drinks

Trick or treat smell my feet give us some big phat beats

this event will be held at The Veterans Memorial Building 846 Front St in 
Santa Cruz
the doors open at 8pm


Tickets
the first 200 tickets will be sold for $15 each these will not last long
then they will be $20 until the night of the event they will be $22 at the door

you can buy them online right now for $15
click on this http://www.inhousetickets.com/evinfo.php?eventid=6050
if that does not work go to http://www.inhousetickets.com and type in 
Freakers Ball

walk up tickets will be available by this Friday at the following locations
Streetlight Records  939 Pacific Ave. in Santa Cruz
Solid Grooves in Santa Calara
BPM on the corner of Hayes and Laguna in San Francisco

Please pass this along to your friends
if you have been sent this by a friend and you wish to join our mailing list
go to http://www.raindanceproductions.com/ to join

PEACE




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_28803397==.ALT--

From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: NRR: Re: [sfraves] What to watch out for from Edwards tonight (humor)

	I wish CNSNews was a libertarian news service -- we could use one. If  
you're commenting on the fact that the article has an apparent point of  
view, it is clearly labeled as "commentary," which means it's an  
opinion piece representing the view of the author.

	As to fair and transparent elections, no one has more of an interest  
in ensuring the integrity of the vote than alternative parties like the  
Libertarians. Those not in control of the vote-counting process always  
have more to worry about in terms of potential fraud than those who do  
control that process. The more election monitors the better, as far as  
I'm concerned, and I hope that lots of monitors from other countries  
are watching the U.S. elections, not just a handful invited by  
left-wing members of Congress or left-wing groups like Global Exchange.

	I have personally made several calls to Jon Arntz, the head of the  
Elections Department in San Francisco, over the past couple weeks to  
urge that the department immediately release all the raw data on vote  
totals on election night, instead of only the first-ranked results for  
the races using ranked-choice voting, as they are apparently planning  
to do.

	Anyone who wants the vote results to be as transparent and free from  
potential malfeasance as possible should be in favor of all voting  
results immediately being released to the public and to the media as  
soon as they are tallied, and I encourage people to call the SF DOE at  
(415) 554-4375 to request that this be done.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: Re: NRR: Re: [sfraves] What to watch out for from Edwards tonight
 (humor)

On 6 October 2004, Starchild wrote:

> 	I wish CNSNews was a libertarian news service -- we could use one. If
> you're commenting on the fact that the article has an apparent point of
> view, it is clearly labeled as "commentary," which means it's an
> opinion piece representing the view of the author.

Seemed that it was coming from the libertarian slant to me.  As was a
fair # of the other articles available on that site.

>
> 	As to fair and transparent elections, no one has more of an interest
> in ensuring the integrity of the vote than alternative parties like the
> Libertarians. Those not in control of the vote-counting process always
> have more to worry about in terms of potential fraud than those who do
> control that process. The more election monitors the better, as far as
> I'm concerned, and I hope that lots of monitors from other countries
> are watching the U.S. elections, not just a handful invited by
> left-wing members of Congress or left-wing groups like Global Exchange.

Are you implying that they might not be honest in their judgements?

>
> 	I have personally made several calls to Jon Arntz, the head of the
> Elections Department in San Francisco, over the past couple weeks to
> urge that the department immediately release all the raw data on vote
> totals on election night, instead of only the first-ranked results for
> the races using ranked-choice voting, as they are apparently planning
> to do.

I had heard that they were planning on doing just that.  Either that, or
I was having a hallucination. :)

>
> 	Anyone who wants the vote results to be as transparent and free from
> potential malfeasance as possible should be in favor of all voting
> results immediately being released to the public and to the media as
> soon as they are tallied, and I encourage people to call the SF DOE at
> (415) 554-4375 to request that this be done.

Even better yet is to continue the tradition of (generally highly
accurate) exit polls.  Which unfortunately seem to have been dropped,
since the recent voting machines don't seem to be so accurate for
whatever reasons.

>
> Peace, love & liberty,
> 					<<< Starchild >>>
>


http://www.jcthedj.com
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

-- 
Imagine if FDR responded to a Japanese attack by quickly invading the
Alutien Islands, not finding Hirohito, and decided to bomb China
instead, because they're Asian too.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

From sfraves-return-116274-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Oct 06 11:03:47 2004

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Voter registration

SO, I'm trying to figure out the most likely reasons why someone might
be removed from the voting polls.  And about all I can come up with are
either of the following two reasons:
1. You've not voted in any of the previous 4 elections.
2. You've submitted a change of address form with the U.S.P.S. (does a
'vacation' request count?  What if mail accidently got returned for an
extended period of time.)

Does anyone know the qualifications actually written into the statutes?
I've heard that as many as 30% of folks who think they're registered may
actually not be.  And that scares me.  Who knows the truth??

message to us from Dale Duncan, boycott organizer:

< Anytime our issues are on the front burner, we win.

There are 17 million of us (Forbes.com).  We spend $1.4 Billion per day.
If just 25% of us do this (about 4 million) and take one straight ally
with us, we will have about 8 million participants.  If the cynics drop
the negativity and unify, that will send a powerful message.

Cynics have never been on the forefront of great change.  We have an
opportunity to send a clear message....if we seize the moment.

Please forward this to your circle of friends who are cynical....

Thanks,

Dale Duncan >


so please don't be cynical!

let's seize the moment!  :)

c'mon!  it'll be the greatest if we do this and it works!

respectfully,
mary m  :)


originally posted by Apollo on sfraves:

2004-09-22

Press Release from Boycott For Equality

Gays to Withdraw Cash From Banks-Could Total Billions

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

Contact: Dale Duncan (757) 257-6215 dsd@boycottforequality.org

Gays to Withdraw Cash from Banks October 8 - Could Total Billions Atlanta,
GA, September 22, 2004 - Organizers of the Boycott For Equality are
expanding their nationwide walkout to include a coordinated cash withdrawal

from the economy on October 8. To demonstrate the need for equality in
marriage and the workplace, Straight and Gay supporters will each take out
$80 from their local ATM.

Boycott For Equality expects the action will exhaust the cash in many ATMs,

leaving a reminder of gay economic power to all who try to use them
throughout the long bank weekend. To further drive home the lessons taught
during the Boycott, participants should refer to the Boycott when
communicating with their elected representatives, particularly when
candidates ask for money to fund their campaigns. "Let them know you
participated in the Boycott" explained Duncan. "Just take your ATM receipt,

cross out your account number, circle your balance, write GAY MONEY on it
and mail it to campaign headquarters in the postage paid envelope they
provide. They'll get the message that nobody in America can be taken for
granted." The amount represents the amount the average member of the
Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) community contributes to the
US economy each day, and could grow beyond the $1.4 billion that LGBT
workers contribute each day - more than $500 billion each year according to

computations by Washington D.C.-based public relations firm Witeck-Combs
Communications.

The walkout combines several actions highlighting the various ways that
Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) Citizens contribute to the
economy on a regular basis. Other components of the Boycott include a
one-day work stoppage or "pink flu" day to demonstrate solidarity to
employers and colleagues; a moratorium on spending for goods and services
such as gas, food and clothing, to show retailers what would happen if 7%
of their revenue goes away; closures by sympathetic businesses to make
their customers aware of how dependent Americans are upon each other; and a

halt to cell phone use to spread the plea for equality throughout the
participant's network.

Close to fifty businesses and 15,000 people have already pledged to
participate using the online forms at the group's web site. Some major
groups that have endorsed or encouraged Boycott For Equality Day include
Don't Amend: The Equality Campaign, The Advocate magazine, Civil Marriage
US, several local PFLAG chapters, DC Diversity, Equality Illinois and
Wyoming Equality. In at least 36 states it is still legal to fire some one
because of their sexuality - even if they never bring it into the
workplace. And nowhere in the United States are these taxpayers able to
file joint federal income tax, combine tax deductions, or access their
partner's social security or disability benefits. ----------- Boycott For
Equality is an Atlanta-based non-profit formed to promote the boycott,
scheduled this year for October 8.

For that day, GLBT Americans and their straight allies are encouraged to
withdraw from the economy in five specific areas: 1) Stay home from work.
Do not generate payroll taxes, income taxes or add to the economy. If you
run a business, let your customers know by closing for the day. 2) Withdraw

$80 from your bank account at an ATM. 3) Don't shop. Do not generate sales
tax or business revenue. 4) Hang up your cell phone. Your silence will
affect your whole communications network. For more information, visit
www.boycottforequality.org


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: RE: [sfraves] BSP: Freaker's Ball

You know I have been to the freakers ball several times and I am done with 
it.  For one, all the Santa Cruz djs (moontribe 13) will be playing the same 
tribal breaks they have always played for the same group of people that they 
always play to.   The freakers ball is the one party that they throw every 
year where they invite other dj's from elsewhere to come and play with them. 
  You almost cannot find a more clicky group of party kids in Cali. I am 
very surprised that they have Tom L-G playing, he is a great techno dj and a 
wonderful guy.  He and Jeno will tear shit up, that is if these two actually 
got decent set times to play.  Maybe cuz they only have a set 15 dj's who 
always play there parties they thought it would be a good idea.  Not only 
that, the Civic auditorium is a shitty venue for a party.

wow, I am talking shit, crazy...
D

Subject: [sfraves] Fall and new leaves?

So what the heck is it about fall that people start getting their shit in
order? I've noticed a bit of a trend -- in my circle of friends and
acquaintances, at least -- of people coming to harsh realizations and
getting their butts into gear once summer totally shits itself and the
long winter haul draws near. People seem to start cutting back on or
terminating their drug intake; slow down on parties; start thinking more
seriously about work and school and their lives.

Anyone else taken notice of this?

S

From: ALTRDVISON@aol.com

Date: Wed, 6 Oct 2004 16:28:38 EDT
To: velouria83@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="-----------------------------1097094518"
X-Mailer: 9.0 for Windows sub 5032

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: looking for a career change for music

-------------------------------1097094518
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Delia,
I would consider going back to school.  More specifically, a tech college to 
get your feet wet with the gear (soundboards, micing, wiring etc.)  I could 
recommend the Recording Workshop (some in CA) which has a quick six week course 
not to bad on the $$.
This will show any employer that you mean business.  Or better, Fullsail 
which has numerous degrees.  Look into it.  I dont want to burst bubbles but if 
you have no other music industry experience, you will be the last in a very long 
line to 
"get to play with the goodies".  But of course if you can book a PA 
(production assistant)
gig, you will learn more in a year than some do with four years of college.  
Start calling all studios, and dont forget media/video production facilities 
in your area and ask if they are hiring PAs.  Most likely you will come across 
one or two cuz a lot of these outfits go through PAs like toilet paper.  You 
will work like a dog till all hours and get treated like shit and pay>?!  HA>!  
Dont expect much.  But after a year you will know more about the industry 
than you want to.  And you will have somthing to boast about on your resume and 
next interview.  Then decide if its for you.  I would say that its not all 
glitz and glamour.
No matter what industry your in you still have to deal with overbearing 
bosses, bullshit tightwad clients and all the politics that come along with it.  
There are so many nich
Good luck

Jon


fullsail dot com
recordingworkshop dot com

-------------------------------1097094518--

>From: ALTRDVISON@aol.com
>To: velouria83@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: looking for a career change for music
>Date: Wed, 6 Oct 2004 16:28:38 EDT
>
>Delia,
>I would consider going back to school.  More specifically, a tech college 
>to
>get your feet wet with the gear (soundboards, micing, wiring etc.)  I could
>recommend the Recording Workshop (some in CA) which has a quick six week 
>course
>not to bad on the $$.
>This will show any employer that you mean business.  Or better, Fullsail
>which has numerous degrees.  Look into it.  I dont want to burst bubbles 
>but if
>you have no other music industry experience, you will be the last in a very 
>long
>line to
>"get to play with the goodies".  But of course if you can book a PA
>(production assistant)
>gig, you will learn more in a year than some do with four years of college.
>Start calling all studios, and dont forget media/video production 
>facilities
>in your area and ask if they are hiring PAs.  Most likely you will come 
>across
>one or two cuz a lot of these outfits go through PAs like toilet paper.  
>You
>will work like a dog till all hours and get treated like shit and pay>?!  
>HA>!
>Dont expect much.  But after a year you will know more about the industry
>than you want to.  And you will have somthing to boast about on your resume 
>and
>next interview.  Then decide if its for you.  I would say that its not all
>glitz and glamour.
>No matter what industry your in you still have to deal with overbearing
>bosses, bullshit tightwad clients and all the politics that come along with 
>it.
>There are so many nich
>Good luck
>
>Jon
>
>
>fullsail dot com
>recordingworkshop dot com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fall and new leaves?

And thank goodness for that. I'm damn ready for the summer madness to end 
about now. At least here that is. Too many of the same circles treaded and 
time to switch that up. Thailand it is to start. From there it's off to 
other warm spots until Europe gets out of the winter nasties. Maybe I'll 
endup in Tahoe for boarding season. I'm kissing the well paying corporate 
job goodbye. Turning my back on everything that's my safety blanket and 
finally doing what I need to. I guess that's getting your shit together. I 
can't wait either way. Just need more $$ and I'm set. I also think with the 
coming elections and the general uncertainty in the world that people are 
going for the things that are secure and safe. They're thinking long and 
hard about what THEY need to be happy. Also toss in an age factor and people 
are just growing up man and taking their lives seriously...

Message-ID: <20041006234357.4874.qmail@web60306.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 6 Oct 2004 16:43:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: velouria83@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-F95ux1Zcn8TtEv0001a034@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: looking for a career change for music

If you're looking to get in on the administrative/business side of
things, a business degree program and as much industry schmoozing as
you can stand would be a good course of action.  If you want to be a
recording engineer, producer, or artist, you will probably be better
served by sinking that big recording school dough into a home recording
setup you can really start doing your thing with.

The big recording schools will acquaint you with lots of high-end
equipment, and prepare you well to intern at a major studio, but ~$25k
will buy you a top-flight project studio setup these days.  Most folks
I've talked to in the industry consider heavy hands-on experience in
engineering fundamentals to be more valuable than a certificate or
degree.

I used to advocate recording schools for my friends that wanted a fast
track way to learn, but in the end most of them have told me they'd
rather have invested in their own setups and had something functional
to work with, in the end.  It's nice to have your hands on
multi-million-dollar gear, but engineering is a skill that scales
exceptionally well.  A person who is familiar with a well-equipped home
setup and reads a few textbooks will generally be able to work in a
large studio with a minor leap of thought.

Case in point: I've had only cursory experience with large consoles, as
my background is in digital audio workstations and small-to-mid size
project studios.  A few weeks ago I showed up to a big studio and
needed to operate an SSL console- a 20-foot-wide, $750,000 beast.  I
looked at the board for a few minutes as the other engineer did some
tasks, asked about 3 questions, let go of my fear, and I was rockin'
with little incident.  

Also, if one *really* wants to get in at the ground floor of the
mainstream music business and make it their living, it's almost
imperative that one lives in a major music market - LA, Nashville and
NYC all come to mind and one's choice between them hinges mainly on
what kind of music and/or work you're interested in.  I do a lot of
music stuff but my interest is not in commercial music or engineering
as a profession, so the bay area suits me fine.

YMMV, just my thoughts.  Not that you won't learn a lot and gain some
great experience/contacts through these schools- they just seem to have
become an outdated concept.  Large studios (and the job paths within
them) are, sadly, a dying breed.

Cheers,
-george c.
-newstylesound recordings
-newstylesound.com
-djorigami.com

At 01:05 PM 10/6/2004, Sean G wrote:
>So what the heck is it about fall that people start getting their shit in
>order? I've noticed a bit of a trend -- in my circle of friends and
>acquaintances, at least -- of people coming to harsh realizations and
>getting their butts into gear once summer totally shits itself and the
>long winter haul draws near. People seem to start cutting back on or
>terminating their drug intake; slow down on parties; start thinking more
>seriously about work and school and their lives.
>
>Anyone else taken notice of this?
>
>S

I think fall tends to be a reflective time.  Harvest.  The summing up of 
the past year and life.  Most of us probably haven't reaped as much as we 
would have liked and the "death" of winter is right around the corner:)

However, the celebratory season will soon be upon us with hopes in the new 
year and anticipation of rebirth in the spring.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: [sfraves] nrr: My encounter with Mealy-Mouthed Big Dick Cheney's Evil Twin today

Oh My Fucking God.....

I think I just had one of the Greatest Fucking Moments Of My Entire
Life, like, ever.

like, just fucking now.

Holy Fuck.

I had just gotten off werk and was leaving the Metro in Bethesda with
my bike and as I was heading towards the elevator I saw this fat,
bald, old guy in front of me that looked **exactly** like your
favorite arch-enemy and mines.....

Mealy-Mouthed Big Dick Cheney's Evil Twin.

Holy Shit, Batman!

I'm talking spitting image here, right down to the bright bald pate,
bad teeth, glasses, tacky pin-striped suit, bad teeth, lapel pin,
shoes, gut, the
dismissive Executive attitude, and the eyes, those horrible,
not-quite-able focus, sharklike, soul sucking eyes.

in other werds, the whole, complete, kit 'n' kaboodle, motherfucking package.

What a loser.

Just the kind of guy the resident, modern-day Eva Braun's of Modern
Day DC go for in a big way.

After all, guys like him pay **really** well.

I knew what I had to do and besides, I felt the Hand of God on my back
@ werk here, so I stepped up my pace just a tad, not that I had too,
this elevator is notoriously slow, but, hey, why take chances?

Now, bear in mind, this elevator, historically, for me, is one of the
great nexuses of evil on the planet, the shit I get into on there, you
would not believe, a while back I had a Rosa Park look-a-like
literally tell me to 'get on the back of the bus,' and I'm a
white-boy, but that's another story, for another time, babs has heard
them all.

Usually I'm on the receiving end of that energy and it feels pretty
shitty, but it totally felt like it was going to be my turn.

(Full disclosure: I *was* just a little tipsy, a buddy at werk passed
me one of those new funny labeled fruit drinks and after i got off
werk I drank it, and unbeknownst to me it was spiked with the rot-gut
vodka, good thing I waited too, because I never drink and drive, bear
with, there is a payoff to this).

I caught up to cocksucking Mealy-Mouth at the elevator waiting area
and since I was wearing my Kerry-Edwards button atop my www.alt.com
outsourcing parting gift T-Shirt, (i wore it today because it's got
Halloween orange and black colors, but more so in solidarity with the
prisoners of Abu Ghraib for the short shrift they've been getting in
the debates),  it was kinda hard to play off my affiliation, but I
wanted to make nice until we got into the elevator, so I made a point
of being cordial until I knew we were going to share that confined
space.

Asked him who he thought 'won' the debate and I played along, said
some things that i knew would be catnip to him, these guys just roll
over when one mentions Wall Street in a positive fashion, and build up
some levels of, you know, trust.

hubba hubba hubba.

Then as soon as the doors closed I lit into him like we all wish
Edwards woulda, coulda, shoulda last night.

(See: RudePundit link below, and I made damned sure I threw in a
little Joe Welch for good measure, I'm DONE playing with these
people.)

Nothing like a captive audience, let me tell you.

And that's one long fucking elevator ride.

Finally he pulled out his 'Big Guns,' (turns out, in my case at least,
the 'leaves you breathless' line is just another bullshit, urban
legend, piece of Madison Avenue PR), he smelled the vodka and made a
snarky comment about it, along the lines of

'I might take you seriously if you weren't so drunk.'

right.

I laughed right in his motherfucking face and said:

'Y'know what, you're right, I'm little tipsy right now, and that's all
well and good, and nothing I need to be ashamed of, but you're
PSYCHOTIC and, guess what, I can sober up.'

Then of course, the doors opened up and it was time to go our separate ways.

the sheer sense of satisfaction I'm feeling right now is pretty
fucking indescribable.

Right this very instant, I feel like I've been fucking a harem of 72
decided non-virgin super-models, non-stop, for a solid month, with a
getting mad lit in a Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, New Years, Best
Birthday Party in the History of Earth aspect thrown in.

What's not to like?

feel free to forward this out to all and sundry if you happen to like it.

If not, then, hey.....

kick it.

nwa

>>>You know I have been to the freakers ball several times and I am done 
>>>with it.  For one, all the Santa Cruz djs (moontribe 13) will be playing 
>>>the same tribal breaks they have always played for the same group of 
>>>people that they always play to.   The freakers ball is the one party 
>>>that they throw every year where they invite other dj's from elsewhere to 
>>>come and play with them.  You almost cannot find a more clicky group of 
>>>party kids in Cali. I am very surprised that they have Tom L-G playing, 
>>>he is a great techno dj and a wonderful guy.  He and Jeno will tear shit 
>>>up, that is if these two actually got decent set times to play.  Maybe 
>>>cuz they only have a set 15 dj's who always play there parties they

>>>>From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>

>>>>Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Freaker's Ball
>>>>Date: Tue, 05 Oct 2004 23:49:13 -0700
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>Raindance Presents
>>>>The 10th Annual Halloween
>>>>
>>>>Freaker's Ball !!!
>>>>Saturday October 30th
>>>>Yes it will be held on the 30th this year and not the 31st.
>>>>
>>>>this will give people an opportunity to recuperate before Voting day 
>>>>which is
>>>>on Tuesday November 2nd ,so please get out and vote
>>>>
>>>>We are very proud to announce the phenomenal lineup of this years event
>>>>
>>>>Live acts will include
>>>>Hamsa Lila (world trance groove) , Foxgluv (this will be a cd release 
>>>>celebration for them)
>>>>our very own LUX aka (Rodman) playing all originals, Timonkey also 
>>>>playing originals
>>>>
>>>>Goddess of Funk Santa Cruz's all star all female drum ensemble 
>>>>performing with
>>>>the talented and beautiful dancers of Hipnautica performing a special 
>>>>midnight
>>>>dance ritual honoring the onset of Halloween
>>>>
>>>>Rick Walker's Loop Pool, will be keeping things properly weird on the 
>>>>lawn
>>>>  story telling and more surprises to be found
>>>>
>>>>annual Costume Contest with prises
>>>>
>>>>Now as for the Freakin' DJ Lineup
>>>>
>>>>Lorin (Bassnactar) ,Jeno (Wicked) ,Carlos (the old school master has 
>>>>come out of hiding for this ocasion)
>>>>Tracy (Raindance ,end up), Little John( Raindance), Subal (13 Moon 
>>>>Tribe), CB (yoga Tai chi)
>>>>Tom L-G (Raindance), (13 Moon Tribe) Taina (13 Moon Tribe) + a few 
>>>>surprises
>>>>
>>>>there will be four rooms of madness, outdoor lounge, organic snacks from 
>>>>Convergence
>>>>Sambzon Acai drinks
>>>>
>>>>Trick or treat smell my feet give us some big phat beats
>>>>
>>>>this event will be held at The Veterans Memorial Building 846 Front St 
>>>>in Santa Cruz
>>>>the doors open at 8pm
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>Tickets
>>>>the first 200 tickets will be sold for $15 each these will not last long
>>>>then they will be $20 until the night of the event they will be $22 at 
>>>>the door
>>>>
>>>>you can buy them online right now for $15
>>>>click on this http://www.inhousetickets.com/evinfo.php?eventid=6050
>>>>if that does not work go to http://www.inhousetickets.com and type in 
>>>>Freakers Ball
>>>>
>>>>walk up tickets will be available by this Friday at the following 
>>>>locations
>>>>Streetlight Records  939 Pacific Ave. in Santa Cruz
>>>>Solid Grooves in Santa Calara
>>>>BPM on the corner of Hayes and Laguna in San Francisco
>>>>
>>>>Please pass this along to your friends
>>>>if you have been sent this by a friend and you wish to join our mailing 
>>>>list
>>>>go to http://www.raindanceproductions.com/ to join
>>>>
>>>>PEACE

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: My encounter with Mealy-Mouthed Big Dick Cheney's Evil Twin today

uh, this *wasn't* dick cheney.

why harass someone who looks like someone you don't agree with?

what would happen if i went around and kicked everyone's ass
who looked like the dude who raped my ex-ex-ex-ex-girlfriend?

yeah, you feel like a million bucks, but what the fuck.  if
someone pulled that shit on me, you can bet i wouldn't be as
gentle on him as this dude was to you.  props to him for
keeping it together, regardless of his political affiliations
or likeness to dick cheney.

and thinking someone is a "loser" based on the way they look is
pretty fucking lame.  you'll learn.  you'll meet the makers and
shakers of this little community and you'll be amazed at how
these "losers" made this community into what it is today.

if i'd seen you pull that little stunt, i'd have told you to
get on the back of the bus as well.  the short bus, no less.

learn to live with everyone, learn to love.  learn to accept
people.  we don't all have the same opinions, and that's okay.

m

From: "nwa" <nwa420@gmail.com>
