Sent: Wednesday, October 06, 2004 10:21 PM
Subject: [sfraves] nrr: My encounter with Mealy-Mouthed Big Dick Cheney's Evil Twin today


> Oh My Fucking God.....
> 
> I think I just had one of the Greatest Fucking Moments Of My Entire
> Life, like, ever.
> 
> like, just fucking now.
> 
> Holy Fuck.
> 
> I had just gotten off werk and was leaving the Metro in Bethesda with
> my bike and as I was heading towards the elevator I saw this fat,
> bald, old guy in front of me that looked **exactly** like your
> favorite arch-enemy and mines.....
> 
> Mealy-Mouthed Big Dick Cheney's Evil Twin.
> 
> Holy Shit, Batman!
> 
> I'm talking spitting image here, right down to the bright bald pate,
> bad teeth, glasses, tacky pin-striped suit, bad teeth, lapel pin,
> shoes, gut, the
> dismissive Executive attitude, and the eyes, those horrible,
> not-quite-able focus, sharklike, soul sucking eyes.
> 
> in other werds, the whole, complete, kit 'n' kaboodle, motherfucking package.
> 
> What a loser.
> 
> Just the kind of guy the resident, modern-day Eva Braun's of Modern
> Day DC go for in a big way.
> 
> After all, guys like him pay **really** well.
> 
> I knew what I had to do and besides, I felt the Hand of God on my back
> @ werk here, so I stepped up my pace just a tad, not that I had too,
> this elevator is notoriously slow, but, hey, why take chances?
> 
> Now, bear in mind, this elevator, historically, for me, is one of the
> great nexuses of evil on the planet, the shit I get into on there, you
> would not believe, a while back I had a Rosa Park look-a-like
> literally tell me to 'get on the back of the bus,' and I'm a
> white-boy, but that's another story, for another time, babs has heard
> them all.
> 
> Usually I'm on the receiving end of that energy and it feels pretty
> shitty, but it totally felt like it was going to be my turn.
> 
> (Full disclosure: I *was* just a little tipsy, a buddy at werk passed
> me one of those new funny labeled fruit drinks and after i got off
> werk I drank it, and unbeknownst to me it was spiked with the rot-gut
> vodka, good thing I waited too, because I never drink and drive, bear
> with, there is a payoff to this).
> 
> I caught up to cocksucking Mealy-Mouth at the elevator waiting area
> and since I was wearing my Kerry-Edwards button atop my www.alt.com
> outsourcing parting gift T-Shirt, (i wore it today because it's got
> Halloween orange and black colors, but more so in solidarity with the
> prisoners of Abu Ghraib for the short shrift they've been getting in
> the debates),  it was kinda hard to play off my affiliation, but I
> wanted to make nice until we got into the elevator, so I made a point
> of being cordial until I knew we were going to share that confined
> space.
> 
> Asked him who he thought 'won' the debate and I played along, said
> some things that i knew would be catnip to him, these guys just roll
> over when one mentions Wall Street in a positive fashion, and build up
> some levels of, you know, trust.
> 
> hubba hubba hubba.
> 
> Then as soon as the doors closed I lit into him like we all wish
> Edwards woulda, coulda, shoulda last night.
> 
> (See: RudePundit link below, and I made damned sure I threw in a
> little Joe Welch for good measure, I'm DONE playing with these
> people.)
> 
> Nothing like a captive audience, let me tell you.
> 
> And that's one long fucking elevator ride.
> 
> Finally he pulled out his 'Big Guns,' (turns out, in my case at least,
> the 'leaves you breathless' line is just another bullshit, urban
> legend, piece of Madison Avenue PR), he smelled the vodka and made a
> snarky comment about it, along the lines of
> 
> 'I might take you seriously if you weren't so drunk.'
> 
> right.
> 
> I laughed right in his motherfucking face and said:
> 
> 'Y'know what, you're right, I'm little tipsy right now, and that's all
> well and good, and nothing I need to be ashamed of, but you're
> PSYCHOTIC and, guess what, I can sober up.'
> 
> Then of course, the doors opened up and it was time to go our separate ways.
> 
> the sheer sense of satisfaction I'm feeling right now is pretty
> fucking indescribable.
> 
> Right this very instant, I feel like I've been fucking a harem of 72
> decided non-virgin super-models, non-stop, for a solid month, with a
> getting mad lit in a Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, New Years, Best
> Birthday Party in the History of Earth aspect thrown in.
> 
> What's not to like?
> 
> feel free to forward this out to all and sundry if you happen to like it.
> 
> If not, then, hey.....

From sfraves-return-116313-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Oct 07 18:37:58 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-116313-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 20727 invoked by uid 1103); 7 Oct 2004 18:37:57 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 20714 invoked from network); 7 Oct 2004 18:37:56 -0000
Message-ID: <20041007183707.13098.qmail@web50305.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Oct 2004 11:37:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: Monikat <technoslut303@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] a mixed review of the love and fuck parades

Ive got mixed feelings about the love parade, but I
was glad to see it happen, and hope it continues to
happen and grow over the years.  however, I think it
may only get better if San Francisco's musical taste
gets better.  I only got into the music for about 10
minutes total, and I was there for a while.  maybe I'm
just picky (yes), but...what can I say?  I did hear
some good techno on the DEFSF float, but it was one of
the smallest and worst sounding sound systems there. 
And I heard KJ play some decent acid as he went by on
the Thump system, and a bit of decent house from a
woman on I think the Sunset system.  I didn't have
high expectations, but I guess I expected to wander
among the systems at the end the parade, and get
turned on to some new electronic music.  Oh well.  

Another problem was the fact that all the systems were
jammed in so close together at the end.  Sound clash
hell.  I know there's always sound clash at events
like this, but it was overwhelming and ridiculous. 
Also, nowhere to sit down, hardly any curb areas.   

On the plus side, I did enjoy being out and about,
smiling at people, and all the dancing in the streets.
It was no Reclaim the Streets, but still, it was fun.
And I appreciated peoples creativity in dressing up
(particularly the clowns.)  Well, some people I wanted
to photograph for "Donts" for a Disco Dos and Donts
spread, but luckily I didnt have my camera.  There
was some of cheesiness, like I would look at some
floats and ask myself, "Are they from Vegas?" but
overall it was ok.  I wasnt too happy about the
corporate sponsorship, and the high price for getting
a float in, but I was willing to overlook it and have
some fun.   

But I began to get a bit melancholy while there.  
Partly it was the onset of autumn (along with the
frigid, frigid wind), and partly because I got
nostalgic for my time in Barcelona earlier this year,
when I went to a free, 3-day long techno party in the
city, outside SONAR, an international techno festival.
 SONAR was great, and the "alterni-SONAR" outdoors was
amazing as well.  It was overwhelmingly hard acid
techno, not my favorite genre, but with about 10
systems there, there was some diversity, and some
really good music.  And thousands of people dancing,
all free, unsanctioned, renegade-style.  Fucking
amazing.  I thought of it Saturday because it was in a
similar kind of outdoor space as the SF Love Parade,
an industrial district near the docks, with corporate
office parks, in the east of the city with the hills
rising to the west.  I remember standing at the
festival in Barcelona, looking west, and thinking of
how much this mini-"teknival" was like what my friends
do here at home, and appreciating them and their
efforts.  But there were thousands of people dancing
at this renegade thing in Barcelona, and here, well,
renegade things, if they happen at all, are a lot
smaller, and it seems like not as many people dance. 
And I can't imagine anything like the above happening
in the u.s., without severe police repression.  I
know, I shouldnt compare  the Catalan (Catalunyan?)
people seem to love their techno, whereas in the U.S.,
I just dont think that many people understand dancing
yet.   

Anyway, on to the fuck parade.  No police repression
that I witnessed (though maybe they were diverted from
an original location, I dont know), but hardly any
people either.  The fuck parade was the renegade,
non-commercial, "hardcore" alternative to the love
parade, and I was looking forward to it.  Not my
favorite genres of music (I expected mainly hardcore
and drum and bass, based on the flyers), but I
appreciate the spirit.  Unfortunately, it was rather
difficult to find the location, and by the time I got
there the wind was blasting and I was ready to get
inside.  And it was tiny.  When I was there, there
were maybe 30 people and four sound systems.  Granted,
I did go a little late.  

So, I do hope the Love Parade continues, and brings
more events and afterparties to SF that week.  (I was
glad to see Stewart Walker in town on Friday night,
though I left when I saw the "No Patron Dancing" signs
at Rx Gallery.  WTF?  Guess it's the usual bullshit,
cabaret permit, whatever...Should have stayed,
though.)  And cheesy as it was, I feel kind of proud
that the first Love Parade in the U.S. was in San
Francisco.   I also hope the Fuck Parade continues as
well, though hopefully with a few more people.

> jammed in so close together at the end.  Sound clash

At future love parades, just like at Burning Man, I would love to see
fewer, but higher-quality sound systems.  

Love Parade could do this by increasing the float entry price.  It would
force more groups to work together and colaborate.

Love Parade could also allow smaller, non-sound floats to participate for 
free.

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_1337092==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR:  F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network

--=====================_1337092==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network

Mark Pesce Lecturer, Interactive Media, AFTRS
markp@aftrs.edu.au www.playfulworld.com


Preamble

The worldwide consolidation of media industries has led
to a consequent closure of the public airwaves with
respect to matters of public interest. As control of
this public resource becomes more centralized, the
messages transmitted by global media purveyors become
progressively less relevant, less diverse, and less
reflective of ground truth.

At present, individuals and organizations work to break
the stranglehold of these anti-market-media-mega-
corporations through the application of the courts and
the law. However, because of the inherent monopoly that
anti-market media maintain on the public mindset,
legislators have been understandably reluctant to make
moves toward media diversification. We are thus
confronted with a situation where many people have
interesting things to say, but there are progressively
fewer outlets where these views can be shared.

The public airwaves, because they are a limited
resource, are managed by public bodies for the public
interest. While honorable, the net effect of this
philosophy of resource management has been negative: a
public resource has become the equivalent of a
beachfront property, its sale generating enormous
license revenues, but its transfer to the private
domain denying the community access to the sea of
ideas.

If a well-informed public is the necessary prerequisite
to the democratic process, then we must frankly admit
that any private ownership of public airwaves
represents a potential threat to the free exchange of
ideas. Now that private property has mostly
collectivized the electromagnetic spectrum, and with
little hope that this will soon change, we must look
elsewhere to find a common ground for the public
discourse.

We are fortunate that such ground already exists.


For more:  <http://www.hyperreal.org/~mpesce/fbm.html>



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_1337092==.ALT--

Ben Fulton, David Adams, Salt Lake City Weekly

drug MDMA back to its psychotherapeutic roots by using it
in therapy sessions (and yes, it's still illegal).

empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."

i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:

> F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network
> 
> Mark Pesce Lecturer, Interactive Media, AFTRS
> markp@aftrs.edu.au www.playfulworld.com
> 
> 
> Preamble
> 
> The worldwide consolidation of media industries has
> led
> to a consequent closure of the public airwaves with
> respect to matters of public interest. As control of
> this public resource becomes more centralized, the
> messages transmitted by global media purveyors
> become
> progressively less relevant, less diverse, and less
> reflective of ground truth.
> 
> At present, individuals and organizations work to
> break
> the stranglehold of these anti-market-media-mega-
> corporations through the application of the courts
> and
> the law. However, because of the inherent monopoly
> that
> anti-market media maintain on the public mindset,
> legislators have been understandably reluctant to
> make
> moves toward media diversification. We are thus
> confronted with a situation where many people have
> interesting things to say, but there are
> progressively
> fewer outlets where these views can be shared.
> 
> The public airwaves, because they are a limited
> resource, are managed by public bodies for the
> public
> interest. While honorable, the net effect of this
> philosophy of resource management has been negative:
> a
> public resource has become the equivalent of a
> beachfront property, its sale generating enormous
> license revenues, but its transfer to the private
> domain denying the community access to the sea of
> ideas.
> 
> If a well-informed public is the necessary
> prerequisite
> to the democratic process, then we must frankly
> admit
> that any private ownership of public airwaves
> represents a potential threat to the free exchange
> of
> ideas. Now that private property has mostly
> collectivized the electromagnetic spectrum, and with
> little hope that this will soon change, we must look
> elsewhere to find a common ground for the public
> discourse.
> 
> We are fortunate that such ground already exists.
> 
> 
> For more: 
> <http://www.hyperreal.org/~mpesce/fbm.html>
> 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> 
> House Music 101: 
>
http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> 
> "The government, which was designed for the people,
> has got into the hands 
> of the bosses and their employers, the special
> interests.  An invisible 
> empire has been set up above the forms of
> democracy."
> -Woodrow Wilson
> 
> "There are times when you have to obey a call which
> is the highest of all, 
> i.e. the voice of conscience even though such
> obedience may cost many a 
> bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends,
> from family, from the 
> state to which you may belong, from all that you
> have held as dear as life 
> itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
>    Gandhi
> 
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic
> organization are ahead of the 
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that
> will gradually become 
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> 
>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Internships available

--=====================_10352015==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Asphodel Ltd. is an eleven year old independent record label located in San
Francisco.   We are looking for interns to assist staff in both the label's
office, multimedia functions and it's recording studio, the Bloody Angle
Compound.

Asphodel is an ideal place to obtain work experiance in the setting of an
artist-driven indie label.  Below is a discription of the intern positions
available.  If you are interested in one of these positions please contact
Brian O'Reilly at brian@asphodel.com


Office:  Assist staff in mail orders and shipping, packaging promos, filing,
inventory and other office duties as needed.   Must commit to a regular
schedule of two days per week with a set start time.  Hours may vary depending
on work load.

Retail:  Assist manager in obtaining distribution information from independent
record stores in the United States and Canada.  Phone skills required.  Must
commit to a regular schedule of two days per week with a set start time.
Hours may vary depending on work load.

Audio & Video:   Projects will vary according to studio manager.  Basic
experiance with digital audio work stations (Macintosh) is required.  Must be
reliable and self-motivated.


All internship positions are on a volunteer basis.  However, bonuses in the
the form of "free stuff" will be provided based on job performance.  We will
be happy to provide and letters of recommendations needed for future
employment or college credit.







Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: My encounter with Mealy-Mouthed Big Dick Cheney's Evil Twin today

oh, you'd never take me for a crack-head weirdo if you passed me on
the street, I'm pretty clean cut, even on days when I wear my black
dot.com.bomb T-Shirts.

Don't get me wrong though, I'm extremely grateful for those days. 

For had I not stumbled down that path, after years of complete
abstinence, (try it sometime, it does have some pretty cool rewards),
while I served in our US Marines, as a volunteer, and did a few year's
stint on Wall Street and SF's Financial District across the street
from the Transamerica Pyramid as a stockbroker, I would still be one
of 'them' to this day and you probably wouldn't like me very much.

Then again, we wouldn't be having this conversation, I'd probably be
chilling in my crib up on Skyline Drive right now.

I'm glad I chose this path of music, dancing, drugging and otherwise
having a good time, instead.

Aren't you?

Hella more fun, ain't it?

both your points are well taken.

My Mom's, who grew up in a commie, totalitarian, country and my
left-of-Karl Marx raver girl are of the same mind, so you're in good
company.

however, this really felt like 'if not now, then when? and 'if not me,
then who?' situation.

there's a famous quote about people not speaking up 75 years ago and
what the results were of that.

is that a lesson of history that we can afford to blithefully ignore
because we want to be all loving and understanding and tolerant?

Please bear in mind just who we're dealing with here.

There is a war on, and has been going in this country for many, many
years and it's been declared on YOU and I, and if you want, or need to
keep rolling over and taking it, suit yourself.

For starters, they're just champing at the bit to lock people like you
and I up in a Federal Gulag for a minimum of ten years, and they're
hard at werk writing even more hostile laws against us which carry
much stiffer penalties.

you *do* remember the RAVE Act that they passed a year ago April?

That hasn't gone away, y'know.

They're pretty hell-bent on putting lights out on our little parties,
and excuse me for taking that at face value and matching them
tit-for-tat instead of sticking my head in the sand and playing the
game of it'll go away if I just stick my head in the sand and pretend
this bad shit isn't happening and that these people that are doing it
aren't bad people.

It's a choice, and they're choosing to do what they do each and every
day, and so I'm just responding to that.

It's not like that or the Patriot Act are simply going to vanish.

They're the LAW of the Land now.

Watch for enforcement of those pieces of legisaltion to begin in
earnest after the election.

I'll put money on it that by this time next year you will personally
know of at least one person facing persecution under that law, if you
don't already.

Even to begin the process of challenging the Rave Act, someone is
going to have to get arrested first, and then argue it all the way up
to the Supreme Court, which is a very costly endeavor, no matter how
you slice it.

Once a government starts writing and passing laws like that, it's only
a matter of time before they start lining folks up against the wall
and shooting them.

That's the reality of it, OK?

on the flip-side, being polite and civil has kind of gotten us into
this situation to begin with and we really took our eyes off the ball
and let our guard down when Nixon left office and we're now reaping
the benefits of falling asleep at the switch today.

This didn't happen in a vacuum, or overnight, and people like myself
who stood by and didn't do a damn thing, though we knew better, are as
equally complicit in this as they are.

A thousand pardons for doing my best for making up for lost time, in a
better late than never way.

Now, just because I said 'What a loser' in that post doesn't mean I
said it to him directly

I just chucked that in there because I was listening to the beastie
boys's new CD, 'To The 5 Boroughs, and I got that line from there,
it's an interstitial throw away that seemed to fit what i was writing.

if it's good enough for the Beasties, then by god, it's good enough for me.

:P

But yes, that's totally my opinion of an individual like that, and
given the laws they've passed against me and mines they take a much
dimmer view of the likes of me, so this is just a matter of showing
the same kind of respect to them that they do me.

Now I didn't jump his shit on sight. 

I made damn sure who I was dealing with first by asking him a few
questions, had he answered differently it may have gone another
direction.

The first thing I asked him was the same thing I asked at least 50-75
other people that day, who 'won' the debate?

Since I saw it as a draw, as did most people I spoke with earlier, it
was pretty revealing how strongly he came down in Cheney's camp, which
tells me that it wouldn't have mattered one iota what to him when the
flat out bald face lies Cheney told during the course of the evening.

I moved on from their, and i admit I deliberately played dumb with the
next series of questions which went along the lines of....

'See, sir, here's what I don't understand and maybe you can help me with this? 

I follow the markets and one thing I know is that the Dow Jones opened
this morning, 3 years later, at almost the same exact spot it did on
September TENTH, 2001.

What's up with that?

The man's had a SOLID three years to get it right, and at this
juncture his policies are not only werking, but they're costing you
and everybody else the usual 10% per year gains the market usually
sees.

How can rationalize the blind support you've been giving him, given
the miserable job he's done so far?

Just because he says 'we've turned the corner' 23 times over the
course of a weekend in his speeches, doesn't necessarily make it so,
now does it, sir?'

'And why aren't the Principals behind Enron and MCI, to name two just
companies, being prosecuted as vociferously as an inner city crack
dealer?

They've certainly wreaked just as much damage to Americans that placed
their trust in them?

Which is worse, sir?'

of course he had nothing to say to that, nor the spiral that millions
of people have had into poverty in this country during the same
period, I mentioned that too before the elevator showed up.

When we got into the thing after the usual interminable wait, I
shifted into a little discussion of foreign policy, centering around
the lies around the non-existent WMD's, the 10,000+ dead Iraqi
civilians, 1,000 dead and climbing US troops, (it took until 1967 that
we saw that many dead in Vietnam, just for point of comparison, so the
pace here is radically higherand the fact that if the Arab world was
ambivalent about the US before Abu Ghraib, they REALLY hate us now.

Bring out the Gimp. 

(On a side note, good thing we caught it then, because it's a given,
left unchecked, it would be sooner before later that we started making
lamp-shades and soap out of people).

What's making Abu Ghraib infinitely worse is the complete lack of any
sort of contrition our leadership is showing.

Try and blow it off all you want, but this will haunt the US for many,
many years to come.

That's pretty much the gist of what I got off to Mr. Mealy-Mouth Bush
Cheney supporter, and if you feel that that was out of line, good for
you.

And as far as sprinkling a few 'fucks' in there as i spoke, well, I
was only showing the same amount of respect that Mr. Cheney showed in
what I consider the Hallowed, Holy, Halls of our US Congress, when he

'said what needed to be said, and I'm glad I did it' 

when a member of the Senate confronted him earlier this year.

I'm not the one setting the example here, now am I?

The difference between a man like him and a person like me is that
I'll go so far to use harsh language when I see something I don't
like.

These people use force, guns and jails to get their point across.

If you can't tell the two apart, I can't help you.

I've been living in our Nation's Capitol for 2 years now, a place that
has been in the running for 'Murder Capitol USA' for the last ten
years now, some years coming in first.

About 2 weeks ago, in this sort of environment, Congress voted to
repeal a long-standing hand guns ban here in DC, which if it passes
the Senate, and Bush signs it into law, will not only make it legal to
own a Saturday Night Special again, but you won't even have to
register it with the cops.

Guess which one of our two parties led the charge to push that bill
through the House?

Just in point of contrast, I ride a bicycle here and it's the law that
if I own and operate it I not only have to register it with the cops,
but I have to have a receipt on me as well.

Failure to comply means I risk having my property siezed.

I need to register my bike, but not my gun?

Doesn't that strike you as a little nuts?

20 years ago, a punk band called The Clash wrote a song where they
described an urban environment where poor people stood on steam grates
in the winter because they had no other means to stay warm.

My first February here in the year 2003 went down in DC history as the
coldest one ever sionce they started keeping records in the 1860's

Now, not only did I see this tableau of human misery, up close and
personal, my girl is an attorney and the Courthouse she works at is at
3rd and Constitution, and I saw this every single day I went by there.

What made it really special, is at that this particular locus the most
dominant feature in the landscape is the Capitol Building.

Quite the view, can't miss it, it's right in line of sight of those
people freezing to death on the sidewalk.

See, I'm not just mad about all this, I'm livid, and I've got to
wonder what's going on with people that don't feel this way?

It's not like it's hidden or anything.

Then again, you probably don't have any childhood friends like I do
that have had their left leg blown off beneath the knee by an RPG in
Fallujah like I do.

He's finally getting out of rehab this week to go home to his wife and kid.

Multiply that by 10,000 young people, many of whom he's luckier than,
since they're much more maimed for life than he is.

What really got me started on all this was the Reagan Funeral this past June.

Day after day of this pushing bad news off the TV in celebration of
his 'Legacy.'

Quite the spectacle wasn't it?

I'll tell you what his 'Legacy' is, I pass it on every damned corner
of this city.

See, I remember an America that WAS a Shining City On The Hill, the
one that these people went out of their way to destroy.

When I was coming up there were no 'homeless' littering our streets
like they do today.

It was Reagan who tossed them out into the streets to fend for
themselves, and when this first happened 20 years ago, there were 10
times of them around as you'll see today.

Question, where'd the 90% of them disappear to?

Did we re-open the hospitals?

No we didn't.

Did they return to their families?

No, in most cases, they didn't.

They're dead because we're too MEAN and CHEAP to do the right thing.

What these people's 'Legacy' is that no one talks about is that that
simple act killed in cold blood just about as many of our own people
as Hitler killed Jews.

Just because we didn't use a gas oven to accomplish this doesn't make
us one bit better.

At least they could defend themselves, to a point, the Americans we
killed on the streets were the weakest, frailest, most vulnerable
human beings in our society.

I am so ashamed.

Heads up, we ran out of those people, and now we're going after our
elderly, infirm, ailing, black and brown people and they've already
made it quite clear that they don't like us free-spirit, gypsy, hippy,
raver types either.

In Soviet Era Russia, 30 **million** people starved to death in the
Ukraine, the greatest source of food on the planet.

That's just what happens when you have a bankrupt, corrupt system in place.

<shrug>

Here in the United States, we have the greatest health care system the
world has ever seen, yet we are rapidly approaching the point where
one out of three people can't get access because they lack the
ability-to-pay.

What do you think is going to happen to **millions**  them?

That's just what happens when you have a bankrupt, corrupt system in place.

<shrug>

These people have the gall to speak of corruption of others?

I love my country with a deep and abiding passion and i'm now at the
point where I see whoever wins this election being irrelevant.

No matter who wins, we're either going to do one of two things after
this election.

Either we're going to collectively come to our senses and start
working in earnest on these issues that are staring us in the face, or
we're going to take this as far as we can and many, many many people
will be hurt, for nothing.

At the end of it, the United States that we live in today will cease
to exist in its present form.

You may think what I did was speaking out of turn, so be it, pardon me
if I feel that to not speak is completely abdicating and shirking my
responsibilities and my Patriotic Duty as a Citizen of this once great
and proud Republic.

I used to be such a nice guy, too.

Those that know me personally once knew me to be the plurriest person
on the planet, and if you catch me on a good day, some of that does
shine through, still, and honestly i'd rather nurture that than feed
this, but again, this IS a war we're in and I just know that sitting
on the sidelines and letting things happen and going out to the party,
party, party is not only lazy and weak, but will have grave
consequences, not just for me, but all those I love and care about.

There's an added degree of difficulty because I'm not one to raise
anything more than my voice in anger, and that's decidely not these
people's approach, they freak over a black women's nearly exposed
nipple during a nothing football game, but boy, oh boy don't they
positively drool over an aerial view of a Daisy-Cutter Bomb dropped
from a great height?

That's a little backwards, and so I will continue to speak to them
like they are backwards children, since they exhibit the same
behavior.

Once they start acting like the adults that they physically are, sure,
sure I'll tone down my rhetoric.

Gladly.

Nothing will make me prouder and my language will reflect that instead
of the shame that I am feeling about all this.

There's more, as you can tell, but that would be gratuitous, I think
you see where I'm coming from, so I'll leave you with this....

My Father's last job before he retired was at the World Trade Center
and fortunately he died on the Father's Day 3 months before 9.11, he'd
been predicting a catatrophic event like this for years prior, and I'm
glad he wasn't around to see his worst thoughts confirmed.

Undoubtedly, he knew someone that perished there that day.

Want to prevent another event like that ever happening again?

Good.

So do I.

Everybody wants that.

How about, instead of using the approach we've got going on now, we
double what we pay the Vietnamese Nike sneaker assemblers?

Think that might cost a whole lot less than the $200 billion dollars
we just spent that's not going into our schools, roads, healthcare and
crumbling domestic infrastructure?

Who knows, it might even restore some goodwill that we used to have in
this world.

btw, where's Osama?

Love,

nwa

On Wed, 6 Oct 2004 23:59:13 -0700 (PDT), michael, the red stickman
<red_stickman@yahoo.com> wrote:

I just registered for the first time in my voting career as a Democrat
and still haven't got my registration card back in the mail, got so
caught up in that last post here I spaced calling The Board before
they closed for the evening.

Damn, I don't like cutting things this close.

Oh, a brief synopsis of my voting history of all years since 1972,
this included who I would have voted for prior to coming of legal age
as well

1972:      it would have been:     Nixon        (R)

1976:      "                          "    Ford         (R)

1980       volunteered on the      Anderson  (3rd Party effort)

1984       my first ever vote:       Reagan      (R)

1988       wrote in:                    Nixon         (R) (was
appalled by the Willie Horton ad no way
                                                                     
was I going to vote for Bush cuz of that)
1992       volunteer/voted 4:       Perot

1996       sat this one out, didn't 'get' Clinton until 1998 and Dole
is too mean-spirited a
              "human" being for me to be comfortable with him as my Prez.

2000        also sat this one out because (a) I was in California
dinn't think it mattered and (b)            the gravity of what was at
stake eluded me, but I was already on my way towards converting.

Woulda tossed a coin in the booth 'tween Nader or Gore.

You should see our yard, we sit on a corner where a HS Football field
faces our backyard and right now there's about half a dozen KE signs
that I put up this afternoon, as well as a liberal sprinkling of local
Dem Congresman and US Senator signs.

We're getting a dozen more tomorrow because the HS is having their
annual Homecoming Parade and they're going to be marching right past
so we wanted to make it as visually stunning as possible.

It's really cool, maybe I've got a future in party decor planning after all. :-)

Kick-off is at 6:30pm, so this is an Anti-Karl Rove Counter-Measure
since Rove picked this date and hour because they knew half the
country was going to be at a game like this and the other half was
going to be lit like a Xmas Tree.

ratbastids.

It's a highly trafficked street otherwise so their use will go on
right until Election Day.

nwa

> and I up in a Federal Gulag for a minimum of ten years, and

> hard at werk writing even more hostile laws against us which
> carry
> much stiffer penalties.
> 
> you *do* remember the RAVE Act that they passed a year ago
> April?
> 
> That hasn't gone away, y'know.
> 
> They're pretty hell-bent on putting lights out on our little
> parties,
> and excuse me for taking that at face value and matching them
> tit-for-tat instead of sticking my head in the sand and
> playing the
> game of it'll go away if I just stick my head in the sand and
> pretend
> this bad shit isn't happening and that these people that are
> doing it
> aren't bad people.
> 
> It's a choice, and they're choosing to do what they do each
> and every
> day, and so I'm just responding to that.
> 
> It's not like that or the Patriot Act are simply going to
> vanish.
> 
> They're the LAW of the Land now.
> 
> Watch for enforcement of those pieces of legisaltion to begin
> in
> earnest after the election.
> 
> I'll put money on it that by this time next year you will
> personally
> know of at least one person facing persecution under that
> law, if you
> don't already.
> 
> Even to begin the process of challenging the Rave Act,
> someone is
> going to have to get arrested first, and then argue it all
> the way up
> to the Supreme Court, which is a very costly endeavor, no
> matter how
> you slice it.
> 
> Once a government starts writing and passing laws like that,
> it's only
> a matter of time before they start lining folks up against
> the wall
> and shooting them.
> 
> That's the reality of it, OK?
> 
> on the flip-side, being polite and civil has kind of gotten
> us into
> this situation to begin with and we really took our eyes off
> the ball
> and let our guard down when Nixon left office and we're now
> reaping
> the benefits of falling asleep at the switch today.
> 
> This didn't happen in a vacuum, or overnight, and people like
> myself
> who stood by and didn't do a damn thing, though we knew
> better, are as
> equally complicit in this as they are.
> 
> A thousand pardons for doing my best for making up for lost
> time, in a
> better late than never way.
> 
> Now, just because I said 'What a loser' in that post doesn't
> mean I
> said it to him directly
> 
> I just chucked that in there because I was listening to the
> beastie
> boys's new CD, 'To The 5 Boroughs, and I got that line from
> there,
> it's an interstitial throw away that seemed to fit what i was
> writing.
> 
> if it's good enough for the Beasties, then by god, it's good
> enough for me.
> 
> :P
> 
> But yes, that's totally my opinion of an individual like
> that, and
> given the laws they've passed against me and mines they take
> a much
> dimmer view of the likes of me, so this is just a matter of
> showing
> the same kind of respect to them that they do me.
> 
> Now I didn't jump his shit on sight. 
> 
> I made damn sure who I was dealing with first by asking him a
> few
> questions, had he answered differently it may have gone
> another
> direction.
> 
> The first thing I asked him was the same thing I asked at
> least 50-75
> other people that day, who 'won' the debate?
> 
> Since I saw it as a draw, as did most people I spoke with
> earlier, it
> was pretty revealing how strongly he came down in Cheney's
> camp, which
> tells me that it wouldn't have mattered one iota what to him
> when the
> flat out bald face lies Cheney told during the course of the
> evening.
> 
> I moved on from their, and i admit I deliberately played dumb
> with the
> next series of questions which went along the lines of....
> 
> 'See, sir, here's what I don't understand and maybe you can
> help me with this? 
> 
> I follow the markets and one thing I know is that the Dow
> Jones opened
> this morning, 3 years later, at almost the same exact spot it
> did on
> September TENTH, 2001.
> 
> What's up with that?
> 
> The man's had a SOLID three years to get it right, and at
> this
> juncture his policies are not only werking, but they're
> costing you
> and everybody else the usual 10% per year gains the market
> usually
> sees.
> 
> How can rationalize the blind support you've been giving him,
> given
> the miserable job he's done so far?
> 
> Just because he says 'we've turned the corner' 23 times over
> the
> course of a weekend in his speeches, doesn't necessarily make
> it so,
> now does it, sir?'
> 
> 'And why aren't the Principals behind Enron and MCI, to name
> two just
> companies, being prosecuted as vociferously as an inner city
> crack
> dealer?
> 
> They've certainly wreaked just as much damage to Americans
> that placed
> their trust in them?
> 
> Which is worse, sir?'
> 
> of course he had nothing to say to that, nor the spiral that
> millions
> of people have had into poverty in this country during the
> same
> period, I mentioned that too before the elevator showed up.
> 
> When we got into the thing after the usual interminable wait,
> I
> shifted into a little discussion of foreign policy, centering
> around
> the lies around the non-existent WMD's, the 10,000+ dead
> Iraqi
> civilians, 1,000 dead and climbing US troops, (it took until
> 1967 that
> we saw that many dead in Vietnam, just for point of
> comparison, so the
> pace here is radically higherand the fact that if the Arab
> world was
> ambivalent about the US before Abu Ghraib, they REALLY hate
> us now.
> 
> Bring out the Gimp. 
> 
> (On a side note, good thing we caught it then, because it's a
> given,
> left unchecked, it would be sooner before later that we
> started making
> lamp-shades and soap out of people).
> 
> What's making Abu Ghraib infinitely worse is the complete
> lack of any
> sort of contrition our leadership is showing.
> 
> Try and blow it off all you want, but this will haunt the US
> for many,
> many years to come.
> 
> That's pretty much the gist of what I got off to Mr.
> Mealy-Mouth Bush
> Cheney supporter, and if you feel that that was out of line,
> good for
> you.
> 
> And as far as sprinkling a few 'fucks' in there as i spoke,
> well, I
> was only showing the same amount of respect that Mr. Cheney
> showed in
> what I consider the Hallowed, Holy, Halls of our US Congress,
> when he
> 
> 'said what needed to be said, and I'm glad I did it' 
> 
> when a member of the Senate confronted him earlier this year.
> 
> I'm not the one setting the example here, now am I?
> 
> The difference between a man like him and a person like me is
> that
> I'll go so far to use harsh language when I see something I
> don't
> like.
> 
> These people use force, guns and jails to get their point
> across.
> 
> If you can't tell the two apart, I can't help you.
> 
> I've been living in our Nation's Capitol for 2 years now, a
> place that
> has been in the running for 'Murder Capitol USA' for the last
> ten
> years now, some years coming in first.
> 
> About 2 weeks ago, in this sort of environment, Congress
> voted to
> repeal a long-standing hand guns ban here in DC, which if it
> passes
> the Senate, and Bush signs it into law, will not only make it
> legal to
> own a Saturday Night Special again, but you won't even have
> to
> register it with the cops.
> 
> Guess which one of our two parties led the charge to push
> that bill
> through the House?
> 
> Just in point of contrast, I ride a bicycle here and it's the
> law that
> if I own and operate it I not only have to register it with
> the cops,
> but I have to have a receipt on me as well.
> 
> Failure to comply means I risk having my property siezed.
> 
> I need to register my bike, but not my gun?
> 
> Doesn't that strike you as a little nuts?
> 
> 20 years ago, a punk band called The Clash wrote a song where
> they
> described an urban environment where poor people stood on
> steam grates
> in the winter because they had no other means to stay warm.
> 
> My first February here in the year 2003 went down in DC
> history as the
> coldest one ever sionce they started keeping records in the
> 1860's
> 
> Now, not only did I see this tableau of human misery, up
> close and
> personal, my girl is an attorney and the Courthouse she works
> at is at
> 3rd and Constitution, and I saw this every single day I went
> by there.
> 
> What made it really special, is at that this particular locus
> the most
> dominant feature in the landscape is the Capitol Building.
> 
> Quite the view, can't miss it, it's right in line of sight of
> those
> people freezing to death on the sidewalk.
> 
> See, I'm not just mad about all this, I'm livid, and I've got
> to
> wonder what's going on with people that don't feel this way?
> 
> It's not like it's hidden or anything.
> 
> Then again, you probably don't have any childhood friends
> like I do
> that have had their left leg blown off beneath the knee by an
> RPG in
> Fallujah like I do.
> 
> He's finally getting out of rehab this week to go home to his
> wife and kid.
> 
> Multiply that by 10,000 young people, many of whom he's
> luckier than,
> since they're much more maimed for life than he is.
> 
> What really got me started on all this was the Reagan Funeral
> this past June.
> 
> Day after day of this pushing bad news off the TV in
> celebration of
> his 'Legacy.'
> 
> Quite the spectacle wasn't it?
> 
> I'll tell you what his 'Legacy' is, I pass it on every damned
> corner
> of this city.
> 
> See, I remember an America that WAS a Shining City On The
> Hill, the
> one that these people went out of their way to destroy.
> 
> When I was coming up there were no 'homeless' littering our
> streets
> like they do today.
> 
> It was Reagan who tossed them out into the streets to fend
> for
> themselves, and when this first happened 20 years ago, there
> were 10
> times of them around as you'll see today.
> 
> Question, where'd the 90% of them disappear to?
> 
> Did we re-open the hospitals?
> 
> No we didn't.
> 
> Did they return to their families?
> 
> No, in most cases, they didn't.
> 
> They're dead because we're too MEAN and CHEAP to do the right
> thing.
> 
> What these people's 'Legacy' is that no one talks about is
> that that
> simple act killed in cold blood just about as many of our own
> people
> as Hitler killed Jews.
> 
> Just because we didn't use a gas oven to accomplish this
> doesn't make
> us one bit better.
> 
> At least they could defend themselves, to a point, the
> Americans we
> killed on the streets were the weakest, frailest, most
> vulnerable
> human beings in our society.
> 
> I am so ashamed.
> 
> Heads up, we ran out of those people, and now we're going
> after our
> elderly, infirm, ailing, black and brown people and they've
> already
> made it quite clear that they don't like us free-spirit,
> gypsy, hippy,
> raver types either.
> 
> In Soviet Era Russia, 30 **million** people starved to death
> in the
> Ukraine, the greatest source of food on the planet.
> 
> That's just what happens when you have a bankrupt, corrupt
> system in place.
> 
> <shrug>
> 
> Here in the United States, we have the greatest health care
> system the
> world has ever seen, yet we are rapidly approaching the point
> where
> one out of three people can't get access because they lack
> the
> ability-to-pay.
> 
> What do you think is going to happen to **millions**  them?
> 
> That's just what happens when you have a bankrupt, corrupt
> system in place.
> 
> <shrug>
> 
> These people have the gall to speak of corruption of others?
> 
> I love my country with a deep and abiding passion and i'm now
> at the
> point where I see whoever wins this election being
> irrelevant.
> 
> No matter who wins, we're either going to do one of two
> things after
> this election.
> 
> Either we're going to collectively come to our senses and
> start
> working in earnest on these issues that are staring us in the
> face, or
> we're going to take this as far as we can and many, many many
> people
> will be hurt, for nothing.
> 
> At the end of it, the United States that we live in today
> will cease
> to exist in its present form.
> 
> You may think what I did was speaking out of turn, so be it,
> pardon me
> if I feel that to not speak is completely abdicating and
> shirking my
> responsibilities and my Patriotic Duty as a Citizen of this
> once great
> and proud Republic.
> 
> I used to be such a nice guy, too.
> 
> Those that know me personally once knew me to be the
> plurriest person
> on the planet, and if you catch me on a good day, some of
> that does
> shine through, still, and honestly i'd rather nurture that
> than feed
> this, but again, this IS a war we're in and I just know that
> sitting
> on the sidelines and letting things happen and going out to
> the party,
> party, party is not only lazy and weak, but will have grave
> consequences, not just for me, but all those I love and care
> about.
> 
> There's an added degree of difficulty because I'm not one to
> raise
> anything more than my voice in anger, and that's decidely not
> these
> people's approach, they freak over a black women's nearly
> exposed
> nipple during a nothing football game, but boy, oh boy don't
> they
> positively drool over an aerial view of a Daisy-Cutter Bomb
> dropped
> from a great height?
> 
> That's a little backwards, and so I will continue to speak to
> them
> like they are backwards children, since they exhibit the same
> behavior.
> 
> Once they start acting like the adults that they physically
> are, sure,
> sure I'll tone down my rhetoric.
> 
> Gladly.
> 
> Nothing will make me prouder and my language will reflect
> that instead
> of the shame that I am feeling about all this.
> 
> There's more, as you can tell, but that would be gratuitous,
> I think
> you see where I'm coming from, so I'll leave you with
> this....
> 
> My Father's last job before he retired was at the World Trade
> Center
> and fortunately he died on the Father's Day 3 months before
> 9.11, he'd
> been predicting a catatrophic event like this for years
> prior, and I'm
> glad he wasn't around to see his worst thoughts confirmed.
> 
> Undoubtedly, he knew someone that perished there that day.
> 
> Want to prevent another event like that ever happening again?
> 
> Good.
> 
> So do I.
> 
> Everybody wants that.
> 
> How about, instead of using the approach we've got going on
> now, we
> double what we pay the Vietnamese Nike sneaker assemblers?
> 
> Think that might cost a whole lot less than the $200 billion
> dollars
> we just spent that's not going into our schools, roads,
> healthcare and
> crumbling domestic infrastructure?
> 
> Who knows, it might even restore some goodwill that we used
> to have in
> this world.
> 
> btw, where's Osama?
> 
> Love,
> 
> nwa
> 
> On Wed, 6 Oct 2004 23:59:13 -0700 (PDT), michael, the red
> stickman
> <red_stickman@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > uh, this *wasn't* dick cheney.
> >

> >

> > someone pulled that shit on me, you can bet i wouldn't be
> as
> > gentle on him as this dude was to you.  props to him for
> > keeping it together, regardless of his political
> affiliations
> > or likeness to dick cheney.
> > 
> > and thinking someone is a "loser" based on the way they
> look is
> > pretty fucking lame.  you'll learn.  you'll meet the makers
> and
> > shakers of this little community and you'll be amazed at
> how
> > these "losers" made this community into what it is today.
> > 
> > if i'd seen you pull that little stunt, i'd have told you

> > get on the back of the bus as well.  the short bus, no

> >

> accept
> > people.  we don't all have the same opinions, and that's
> okay.
> > 
> > m

Subject: Re: [sfraves] a mixed review of the love and fuck parades

> Ive got mixed feelings about the love parade, but I
> was glad to see it happen, and hope it continues to
> happen and grow over the years.  however, I think it
> may only get better if San Francisco's musical taste
> gets better.


i'm from seattle, so it's not like i'm an expert on this ;) but i didn't
get the impression that it was about sf's music taste. i thought it was
more about who could afford to operate a float.

it seemed to me like most of the floats were using it as an opportunity to
advertise their upcoming club/party.


>I didn't have high expectations, but I guess I expected to wander
> among the systems at the end the parade, and get turned on to some new
electronic music.  Oh well.


well, in all fairness, i'm not certain that love parade in any country is 
particularly experimental in terms of the music that gets played. most of
the people that played in berlin seemed to be on the 'mainstream' side of
the electronic spectrum, regardless of genre.

i'm fine with that. i just wanted to run around in the street and party.
if i want innovative sounds i attend that sort of event or dj 'em meself
;)


> Another problem was the fact that all the systems were
> jammed in so close together at the end.  Sound clash
> hell.  I know there's always sound clash at events
> like this, but it was overwhelming and ridiculous.
> Also, nowhere to sit down, hardly any curb areas.


very true. i didn't get the impression that they were expecting that size
turnout. i wonder how many of the attendees were tourists like myself who
had flown in for the event.


> But I began to get a bit melancholy while there.
> Partly it was the onset of autumn (along with the
> frigid, frigid wind), and partly because I got
> nostalgic for my time in Barcelona earlier this year,
> when I went to a free, 3-day long techno party in the
> city, outside SONAR, an international techno festival.
>  SONAR was great, and the "alterni-SONAR" outdoors was
> amazing as well.


strongly agree with you. i was at barcelona last year and adored the
renegade events nearby. (and sonar and barcelona in general, but that's
another topic.)


> But there were thousands of people dancing at this renegade thing in
Barcelona, and here, well, renegade things, if they happen at all, are a
lot
> smaller, and it seems like not as many people dance. And I can't imagine
anything like the above happening in the u.s., without severe police
repression.


don't decide that until you've gone to detroit for demf/movement. ;)

i suspect that if someone in the states threw a 'renegade' event directly
outside a permitted event they also might be able to get away with it.
officials would most likely assume that the two events were connected.
whether the organizers of the u.s. event would be willing to tolerate it,
though, is another story.

there have been relatively large renegade events in the northwest over the
years. i'd be surprised if attendance was any less in the bay or elsewhere
in cali. weren't/aren't the moontribes illegal? or did that end long ago
with the increase in popularity?


> So, I do hope the Love Parade continues, and brings more events and
afterparties to SF that week.  (I was glad to see Stewart Walker in town
on Friday night, though I left when I saw the "No Patron Dancing" signs
> at Rx Gallery.


aww, too bad you left. no one obeyed! though i must admit that i was
deterred by it initially too and went around asking locals if sf had
metamorphosed into new york when i wasn't looking ;)

although i'm not sure if you'd call what i was doing dancing as it tends
to resemble a schizophrenic grandma on crack. whatever it was, it occurred
with great enthusiasm near the left speaker and no one tapped me and
begged me to stop.

kim

> So, I do hope the Love Parade continues, and brings more events and
afterparties to SF that week.  (I was glad to see Stewart Walker in town
on Friday night, though I left when I saw the "No Patron Dancing" signs
> at Rx Gallery.


aww, too bad you left. no one obeyed! though i must admit that i was
deterred by it initially too and went around asking locals if sf had
metamorphosed into new york when i wasn't looking ;)

although i'm not sure if you'd call what i was doing dancing as it tends
to resemble a schizophrenic grandma on crack. whatever it was, it occurred
with great enthusiasm near the left speaker and no one tapped me and
begged me to stop.

kim
http://www.to-evolve.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Chicago record stores?

I was just in Chicago last month.

Gramaphone seems to be the game in town. It's by Lincoln Park on Clark
St, south of Diversey I think. Across the street from BestBuy on Clark
St.

Mostly house (it's Chicago after all), and some good techno (probably
for its proximity to Detroit). Very little trance and d&b, breaks is
non-existence.

- Jeff

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network

Since the Internet emerged, the real barrier to a grassroot media
outlet is no longer the limited airwaves, but the unreasonably
restrictive copyright laws (and the media industries' army of
ligitation-happy lawyers).

Unless you can come up with all-original footage, you'll bound to run
into the big guys when u try to get permissions to air some of their
clips. U know how that'll turn out.

Fight fair use.

- Jeff

On Thu, 07 Oct 2004 12:25:59 -0700, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network
>=20
> Mark Pesce Lecturer, Interactive Media, AFTRS
> markp@aftrs.edu.au www.playfulworld.com
>=20
> Preamble
>=20
> The worldwide consolidation of media industries has led
> to a consequent closure of the public airwaves with
> respect to matters of public interest. As control of
> this public resource becomes more centralized, the
> messages transmitted by global media purveyors become
> progressively less relevant, less diverse, and less
> reflective of ground truth.
>=20
> At present, individuals and organizations work to break
> the stranglehold of these anti-market-media-mega-
> corporations through the application of the courts and
> the law. However, because of the inherent monopoly that
> anti-market media maintain on the public mindset,
> legislators have been understandably reluctant to make
> moves toward media diversification. We are thus
> confronted with a situation where many people have
> interesting things to say, but there are progressively
> fewer outlets where these views can be shared.
>=20
> The public airwaves, because they are a limited
> resource, are managed by public bodies for the public
> interest. While honorable, the net effect of this
> philosophy of resource management has been negative: a
> public resource has become the equivalent of a
> beachfront property, its sale generating enormous
> license revenues, but its transfer to the private
> domain denying the community access to the sea of
> ideas.
>=20
> If a well-informed public is the necessary prerequisite
> to the democratic process, then we must frankly admit
> that any private ownership of public airwaves
> represents a potential threat to the free exchange of
> ideas. Now that private property has mostly
> collectivized the electromagnetic spectrum, and with
> little hope that this will soon change, we must look
> elsewhere to find a common ground for the public
> discourse.
>=20
> We are fortunate that such ground already exists.
>=20
> For more:  <http://www.hyperreal.org/~mpesce/fbm.html>
>=20
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>=20
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>=20
> "The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hand=
s
> of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible
> empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
> -Woodrow Wilson
>=20
> "There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all=
,
> i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a
> bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from th=
e
> state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as lif=
e
> itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
>   =E2=80=93 Gandhi
>=20
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually becom=
e
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>=20
>

Message-ID: <20041008013801.16550.qmail@web21528.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Oct 2004 18:38:01 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <b7941d4c041007182319bc64bb@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network

Take to the streets and shoot your own video.  Then
you own the rights.  Unless your shots include images
of trademarked products, company logos, or images of
somewhat famous people, etc.

One of my great disappointments with Internet radio is
that no street level grassroots reporting ever
emerged.  (It would be relatively simple to do "live
in the street" reporting from any WiFi hot spot)  In
fact to this day there is very little trully original
content on Internet radio.

Contrast this with the wealth of original content out
there in blogs.  The breadth of original content in
the blogosphere is completely staggering.  Sure some
of it is crap, but this amazing wealth of triviality
is one of the reasons that blogs are a social
phenomena while Internet radio still really isn't.

Regards,

Peter

--- groovinkim

in the spirit of keeping it real, we pretty much have
refrained from participating in discussions since this
is a collectively shared address, and since no one
here has time to respond or follow it all with any
sort of consistancy, but being that it is my turn
today, and being that you said something so
interesting, i felt moved to reply. hopefully , no one
will mind, and will just take pleasure..continue
reading.  i am responding to something in your post.

> although i'm not sure if you'd call what i was doing
> dancing as it tends
> to resemble a schizophrenic grandma on crack.

my point is, we could all hope that the schizophrenia
is either  assisted by the crack, or better yet,
caused by the crack, then there'd be an easy remedy. 
not to rag on your dancing.  I was just interested in
the mental disease. :)

	 <20041007065913.65015.qmail@web53203.mail.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Project for The New American Century back alley rendevouzay, baby

> 
> and thinking someone is a "loser" based on the way they look is
> pretty fucking lame.  you'll learn.  you'll meet the makers and
> shakers of this little community and you'll be amazed at how
> these "losers" made this community into what it is today.
> 

Funny you should mention that.

See just about 45 minutes prior to my demonstrating that lapse of
judgement on my part with that Republican in that elevator, I was in
the alley directly behind the DC offices of Project For A New American
Century, (an actual client of the people I contract with and I've set
foot in their offices on bizness more than once) finishing off my
morning's paperwork.

I go there to unwind a bit because my werk is a bit demanding and I
need a break.

Anyhow, there was this other person in there just chilling, as many
street people do, and I we wouldn't have spoken had he not asked me
for a cigarette.

He was listening to the radio and as I passed him the smoke I asked
him what he was listening to.

turns out it was Rush Limbaugh's show.

Dude looked like he was in his 50's and had spent a few months living
in his clothes, which were quite dirty, ripped, and he coulda used a
shave and I bet if I got close enough, a shower.

In other words your typical, unconnected, DC crackhead weirdo, and I'm
pretty clear on just how far he'da got if he showed up at one of our
UG's one night and tried to get in.

Intrigued, I asked him why on earth he would spend a second listening
to that junkie.

Turns out he was a regualar listener, not because he aspired to
'better his situation in life,' but because he wanted to know exactly
what people like him were up against.

We spoke for a bit after that and it turns out that he, like many
others in the service sector here that I've been speaking with, was
just as up to speed on the news of the day as any one on these lists.

For example, he knew more about the Wal-Mart/Gillette RFID tag story than I did.

Who knew?

If Tyler Durden were to suddenly spring to life today, he'd have no
shortage of people to help him out, it turns out.

:P

nwa

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network

On Thu, 7 Oct 2004 18:38:01 -0700 (PDT), Peter Rothman
<dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Take to the streets and shoot your own video.  Then
> you own the rights.=20

That was my point. But it's easier said than done . Costs alone is a
problem, not to mention how easily your can wander into copyrighted
terrority even if you think u have all-original footage.

> Unless your shots include images
> of trademarked products, company logos, or images of
> somewhat famous people, etc.
>=20

Fun+games #1: Whip our your camera phone and take a picture of your
bedroom. Count the trademarked logos.

And make sure you didn't get a shot of "The Simpsons" playing on your TV.=
=20
- http://www.sslug.dk/~chlor/lessig/freeculture/recorders.html


> One of my great disappointments with Internet radio is
> that no street level grassroots reporting ever
> emerged.  (It would be relatively simple to do "live
> in the street" reporting from any WiFi hot spot)  In
> fact to this day there is very little trully original
> content on Internet radio.
>=20

Internet radio never takes of because it cannot be consumed like
over-the-air radio: you can't listen to it in the car (drivers are the
majority of OTA radio listeners). Podcasting sounds like a good
concept though. The availabilty of DNC/RNC speeches and presidential
debates on iTMS is also a sign of other things to come.


> Contrast this with the wealth of original content out
> there in blogs.  The breadth of original content in
> the blogosphere is completely staggering.  Sure some
> of it is crap, but this amazing wealth of triviality
> is one of the reasons that blogs are a social
> phenomena while Internet radio still really isn't.
>=20


Blogspace is ture democracy at work. However trivial each blog is,
collectively they become a powerful voice.

The truth is, grassroot media do not operate as well in the
traditional mass media's asymetrical, one-way-only,
stuff-your-head-with-marketing-and-propaganda broadcast model. It
operates better in a 2-way format, where we don't simply "consume"
ideas, we exchange them. Isn't it why you subcribe to this mailing
list in the first place?

Don't let the media giants box you in. Just that they do it one way
doesn't mean it's effective for us to do it the same way.

The Internet is our war against the mega-corp propaganda. The
revolution has already begun.

And, yeah, fight for fair use and stuff.

Love,

- Jeff

> > On Thu, 07 Oct 2004 12:25:59 -0700, Apollo
> > <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> > > F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network
> > >
> > > Mark Pesce Lecturer, Interactive Media, AFTRS
> > > markp@aftrs.edu.au www.playfulworld.com
> > >
> > > Preamble
> > >
> > > The worldwide consolidation of media industries
> > has led
> > > to a consequent closure of the public airwaves
> > with
> > > respect to matters of public interest. As control
> > of
> > > this public resource becomes more centralized, the
> > > messages transmitted by global media purveyors
> > become
> > > progressively less relevant, less diverse, and
> > less
> > > reflective of ground truth.
> > >
> > > At present, individuals and organizations work to
> > break
> > > the stranglehold of these anti-market-media-mega-
> > > corporations through the application of the courts
> > and
> > > the law. However, because of the inherent monopoly
> > that
> > > anti-market media maintain on the public mindset,
> > > legislators have been understandably reluctant to
> > make
> > > moves toward media diversification. We are thus
> > > confronted with a situation where many people have
> > > interesting things to say, but there are
> > progressively
> > > fewer outlets where these views can be shared.
> > >
> > > The public airwaves, because they are a limited
> > > resource, are managed by public bodies for the
> > public
> > > interest. While honorable, the net effect of this
> > > philosophy of resource management has been
> > negative: a
> > > public resource has become the equivalent of a
> > > beachfront property, its sale generating enormous
> > > license revenues, but its transfer to the private
> > > domain denying the community access to the sea of
> > > ideas.
> > >
> > > If a well-informed public is the necessary
> > prerequisite
> > > to the democratic process, then we must frankly
> > admit
> > > that any private ownership of public airwaves
> > > represents a potential threat to the free exchange
> > of
> > > ideas. Now that private property has mostly
> > > collectivized the electromagnetic spectrum, and
> > with
> > > little hope that this will soon change, we must
> > look
> > > elsewhere to find a common ground for the public
> > > discourse.
> > >
> > > We are fortunate that such ground already exists.
> > >
> > > For more:
> > <http://www.hyperreal.org/~mpesce/fbm.html>
> > >
> > > Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> > >
> > > House Music 101:
> >
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> > >
> > > "The government, which was designed for the
> > people, has got into the hands
> > > of the bosses and their employers, the special
> > interests.  An invisible
> > > empire has been set up above the forms of
> > democracy."
> > > -Woodrow Wilson
> > >
> > > "There are times when you have to obey a call
> > which is the highest of all,
> > > i.e. the voice of conscience even though such
> > obedience may cost many a
> > > bitter tear, and even more, separation from
> > friends, from family, from the
> > > state to which you may belong, from all that you

Subject: [NWR] Seattle 10/9 - J Majik, Hive Infiltrata, + more..All Ages + Bar! 
Content-Length: 2604


 
Kaos Theory Seattle brings you...
 
MORE KAOS

Saturday October 9th 2004
 
Featuring....
 

J MAJIK 
Infrared, Metalheadz - - U.K.
www.Metalheadz.co.uk
According to Goldie J Majik is the Luke Skywalker of
drum & bass. J Majik's has been a household name in
drum and bass and electronic music as a whole for over
ten years. His label, Infrared Recordings is one of
the longest running and most successfull labels in
drum and bass today. The man's tunes are always hot on
the dubplate circuit. Tracks like, "Love Is Not A
Game" and "Spaced Invaders" hit top the UK top 40 and
once again show why J Majik is one of the top dogs in
drum and bass today.
 

HIVE 
Violence Recordings, Renegade Hardware - S.F.
www.ViolenceRecordings.com www.TOVmusic.com
Celebrated on worldwide, Hive is Americas biggest
accomplishment in drum and bass. His tracks are rinsed
by nearly every DnB legend and his label, Violence,
has registered sales comparable with Ram, Renegade
Hardware, and Valve. He remixed some of DnB's biggest
tunes, "The Shadow" and "Hysteria" and produced
anthems such as "Neo", "Bring it On", "The Plague",
and "UltraSonic Sound" wich was featured on the
soundtrack for The Matrix . Hive is the man.
 

INFILTRATA 
Payload UK, Cartel Recordings, Phuturo - L.A.
www.Phuturo.com 
Infiltrata has gained massive respect from the
worldwide drum and bass massive from tunes being
released on over a half a dozen different labels
worldwide. His tunes "Against All Odds" on Stakka's
label Payload and his remix of Craze and Juju's
"Souldshine have been being cained all over the UK by
many of DnB's top DJs such as DJ Fresh, Photek,
Teebee, John B and many more. Seattle witnessed his
skills as a DJ in July as he stopped for a few dates
off of his North American tour. An excellent DJ and
producer with a huge bag of A-list dub plates. What
more could you ask for?
 

MC JOHN DADA 
Phuturo - L.A.
www.Phuturo.com
An L.A. ruffneck lyrical assasin callin the reloads
proper every time. John Dada has shared the mic with
MC greats from Skibbadee to Rymetyme and called shots
for DJ legends from Andy C to Grooverider. Being a
resident at Juju's Phuturo night has helped propel
John Dada to one of the premier west coast drum and
bass MC's. Dont sleep on this mans mic control!
 
NITSUJ - www.360bpm.com www.greylife.com
THE DOWLZ - Kaos Theory
ROB NOBLE - KVT
AARON SIMPSON - Tytan Studios, www.AaronSimpson.com
 
 
BREAKS & HOUSE ROOM:
------------------------

VIZE -  Vizion Records - Portland
ELECTROKID - Hyve, Virus Breaks - Portland
ILL EEZE ONE - Homegrown / NBA
HYPERFUNK - Next Level, Housewreckin
RYLE - Next Level
SOULDKID - NBA, F-8, Baszic Elements
KIPPY - NBA, Dragon Ent.
 
 
::: Free breakbeat mix CD "Gettin U Open" by Vize to
the first 100 people! :::

::: Free Drum and Bass mix CD "DNBMIX03" by Aaron
Simpson to the first 200 people! :::

::: Additional bass brought in by Metsys. 30,000 total
wats of sound! :::
 

^^^^We will be bringing in another sound system in by
Metsys in addition to the Aristocrats stock sound.
That means we'll have 10, 18" subs downstairs powered
with extra amps and eqs. The upstairs will also have
additions to the sound. Better EQing and what not. Its
going to be alittle overkill on the sound but its drum
and bass and thats how we like. Loud and clean. Oh
yea!!! 
 
 
TWO FLOORS ALL AGES

FULL BAR FOR 21+ (with view of stage upstairs)

Drink specials for 21+ before 11pm:

$3 Wells
$3 Beers
$5 Long Islands
 
9pm - 5am
(come early for cheap drinks, the free CDs, stickers
and ensured entry. This event may sell out.)
 
$17 Advance
$20 @ Door

$5 off @ Door with Oregon, Idaho, or British Columbia
identification. ID must be current and valid.
 
Adavance tickets available through Sunday Oct 3rd only
at:
SEATTLE: 35th Ave. Skateshop North - 12th & Pike on
Capitol Hill (206)320-1252

South and Main St. two blocks East of Poinier Square.)
