Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Let Them Eat Democracy

--=====================_4024286==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I read widely, and one of the publications I study each month is the 
"Proceedings of the U. S. Naval Institute:  Independent Forum on 
Defense."  I'm also a long-time member of the Institute.

This month's "Proceedings" covered Iraq in perspective.  Included were 
thoughtful articles about the need for more understanding of 
cultures:  "...it is more important to understand motivation, intend, 
method, and culture than to have a few more meters of precision, knots of 
speed, or bits of bandwidth..." in the war on terror;  the military's 
responsibility in losing the media war in Iraq;  and an editorial on pork 
in military appropriations.

I trust many of you know that the military is not comprised of automatons 
who obey orders without question.  Yes,  they may execute the orders of the 
Commander in Chief for that is their sworn duty;  but that doesn't mean 
that these people, often with excellent educations and training, are 
without ideas and values that may be contrary to current national political 
agendas.

I thought I'd pass on this excellent history-based critique of the United 
States' desire to impose democracy (a code word for corporate capitalism) 
on Iraq and other third-world nations.  Please forgive any errors:  scanned 
and OCRed the piece.

Love,

Apollo




Let Them Eat Democracy


By Stephen Pressfield
Commentary
Proceedings of the U.S. Naval Institute, October, 2004


"We are here to help the Vietnamese. Because inside every gook is an 
American trying to get out."

The quote above-from Stanley Kubrick's film, Full Metal Jacket-was of 
course played for satire. Unfortunately, if you revise the nationality, it 
is a pretty accurate summation of current U.S. policy in Iraq. If we give 
our Iraqi friends a taste of American-style democracy and freedom, they 
will take to it like Moscow did to McDonald's.

Will they? Is individual liberty compatible with Islam? Can democracy work 
in a society that is essentially tribal? Inside every Iraqi, is there an 
American struggling to get out? A precedent from the past may be 
illuminating. Let's flash back to Athens during the golden age of Pericles.

Athens in the 5th century B.C. was a democracy and an empire, much like the 
United States. Athens was an enlightened empire. Its power produced peace. 
Trade flourished. Its subject states (nearly 200, from Sicily to the Black 
Sea) got rich. The Athenian drachma was as universal as the Yankee dollar; 
its law courts facilitated prosperity by adjudicating trade disputes. Like 
the United States, Athens was the reigning superpower.

Athens did not have Disneyland or Hollywood movies, but it had the 
Parthenon and the plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides. It was so 
dominant militarily, culturally, and commercially that it simply held the 
world in thrall. The energy of its people seemed irresistible and very, 
well, American.

An Athenian is always an innovator, quick to form a resolution and quick at 
carrying it out.... they are always abroad; for they think that the farther 
they go, the more they will get.... they prefer hardship and activity to 
peace and quiet. In a word, they are by nature incapable of either living a 
quiet life or of allowing anyone else to do so.'(1)

Athens had a tactic for keeping its subject states in line. It compelled 
them to become democracies. For their own good. And for a while it worked. 
But a funny thing happened on the way to hegemony by imposed democracy.

The shadow side of Athens's benevolence began to show. The subject states' 
people saw that their democracies could vote for any measure except 
autonomy. They could pass any bill except self-determination. Athens's law 
courts fleeced them. The states began to hate the Athenian drachma. They 
hated the sight of Athenian warships in their harbors and Athenian marines 
in their towns. They sought a champion and found it in Sparta; the 
Peloponnesian War began. The ol' democracy trick had back fired on Athens. 
Its tributaries perceived this "democracy" as a device for their 
subjugation. It was hollow, puppet democracy. So intense had the states' 
hatred for Athens grown, they now willingly sided with the sternest of 
oligarchies, Sparta, and an alien empire, Persia-all in the cause of 
shedding Athens's yoke.

Does any of this sound familiar? Are those who forget the past condemned to 
repeat it? The Iraqis are not stupid. They can read Ambassador J. Paul 
Bremer's "100 Orders," which, in effect, tie up their economy for years and 
hand it on a plate to U.S. corporations. They see through our altruistic 
aspirations for them, as the ancient states saw through those of Athens.

If we think we can impose democracies abroad and people will like us for it 
(when democracy is a code word for corporate capitalism, which is itself a 
code word for American domination), we are deluding ourselves and scorning 
the lessons of history. If the past teaches anything, it is that a 
people-any people-will gladly take bad rule they can call their own over 
the most enlightened governance by an alien occupier.

In the end, Athens lost. The very democracies it had established to secure 
its dominance ganged up and brought it down. In 403 B.C., Lysander's 
Spartan fleet entered the port of Piraeus and "to the music of flute girls, 
tore down the city's Long Walls." The day was hailed, said Xenophon "as 
beginning of freedom for Greece.'(2)



1.  Thucydides:   History of the Peloponnesian War (translation by Rex 
Warner) (Lon­don: Penguin Books 1954) 1.70.

2.  Xenophon:   A History of My Tines (translation by Rex Warner) (London: 
Penguin Books, 1966)  2.23

Steven Pressfield is author of Gates of Fire and the upcoming The Virtues 
of War:  A novel of Alexander the Great (New York: Doubleday,  2004).

<http://www.navalinstitute.org/>www.navalinstitute.org






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_4024286==.ALT--

a similar thing happened years ago in my home state of
Maine, when locals in a little seaside cove decided
they didn't want them queers coming to buy antiques
and titter over their fancy tea like it was the new
Fire Island.

The following tourist season, them gay interlopers
stamped "Queer money" on every bill they spent in 
town, and needless to say, us locals got the picture. 
 Them fuckers was rich!

Season after that, seems old Mayor Jenkins took to the
buggery himself.  Town meetings ain't been the same
since.    This is mostly a true story, leastways how I
recall.

ayup,
boomerang
...................
a m b i e n t    m a f i a
We put the tit back in Constitution

From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Michael Badnarik arrested trying to serve legal papers at debate

	The presidential debates -- democracy, or lack thereof, in =
action...

On Rational Review...
"NEWS FLASH: Badnarik arrested trying to crash debate"
http://www.rationalreview.com/announcements/10092004.html
-----------

Libertarian Presidential candidate Michael Badnarik
and Green Party Presidential candidate David Cobb were
arrested Friday evening when they crossed police lines
in an attempt to gain entry to the presidential debate
they had been excluded from at Washington University
in St. Louis, MO.

Reached by mobile phone at approximately 11:30PM
Central time Friday, Badnarik campaign Communications
Director Stephen Gordon reported being in a hectic
rush to gather, verify and distribute information on
the situation.

=93Michael Badnarik is currently imprisoned at an
undisclosed location in the St. Louis area. I've
gotten a report from our man John Airheart out in the
field saying that law enforcement officials are unable
to provide info on his exact whereabouts, but he is
believed to probably be in a St. Louis municipal
lockup. We intend to get him out as soon as we can
find out more, as he has campaign appearances
scheduled in St. Louis, Champagne-Urbana and Kansas
City on Saturday.=94

Gordon went on to stress that Badnarik was doing far
more than merely protesting his exclusion from the
debates when arrested. He was attempting to serve
process papers on Commission on Presidential Debates
officials.

=93Michael had process papers in his pocket related to
our suit in Arizona against the CPD. Two previous
attempts this afternoon to serve papers to the CPD at
their facility in Washington, DC were thwarted by
guards they recently set up. We expect to be releasing
more information on that as it becomes available=94

The Badnarik campaign said they also made attempts to
serve process via email and facsimile to the
Commission on Presidential Debates and others involved
in the suit, which may soon take a turn for the
dramatic.

=93We will be in court Tuesday morning to stop the third
debate. Public money is being used illegally to
promote only certain candidates=94 said Gordon, who also
mentioned that photos and audio of process papers
being served to Arizona State University officials for
their role in the upcoming third debate will be made
available by the Badnarik campaign shortly.

Asked about the mainstream media blackout of Badnarik
and Cobb's arrest, Gordon was undaunted. =93Americans
know now they can not trust the mainstream media to
cover real events in real time. The Internet is taking
over because it has to. Americans have no place to go
for the truth anymore but the Internet.=94=

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

At 11:20 PM 10/8/2004, Starchild wrote:
>         The presidential debates -- democracy, or lack thereof, in action...


Yes, I agree.  Ever since the debates were taken out of the hands of the 
League of Women Voters these staged media events have become a tool of the 
Democratic and Republican parties.  There is no democracy in action 
here.  We are, really, moving swiftly to a one party system -- and you know 
what that means.  There is no room for dissent;  no place for a dialectic.

Love,

Apollo

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Message-ID: <b7941d4c04100911535b2e5c9d@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Sat, 9 Oct 2004 11:53:41 -0700
From: goofrider <goofrider@gmail.com>
Reply-To: goofrider <goofrider@gmail.com>
To: sfr <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] 10 DJ mixes on my iPod

......aka: "what's been rocking in my pants"

Sorry, I just have this strange impulse to tell everyone what I've
been listening to lately. I tried to tell ppl on the bus but nobody
cared. Maybe some of u would actually give a fuck.

Here I picked 10 of the recent DJ mixes I listen to the most in the
past 3 months:


1. GU024 Reykjavik - Mixed by Nick Warren

- Say what you will about Global Underground. The first disc here is
phenominal. It's all downtempo/ambient cuts and builds up to some
atmospheric breaks at the end, very atypical of the series, and a real
masterpiece. Reminds me of Nick's Back To Mine release, only better.
Check it out even if u HATE Global Underground.


2. GU025 Toronto - Mixed by Deep Dish

- You already know what it is. Deep, sexy progressive house, choice
cuts with that usual Deep Dish trademark pop sensibilty and smooth as
silk construction.


3. Bedrock Breaks - Mixed by Meat Katie
4. Wired - Mixed by DJ Hyper
5. Frabriclive 08 - Mixed by Plump DJs

- Funky-ass nu-skool breaks. Makes me bounce around like an
Energenzier Bunny all night long.


6. DJ World Series: Breaks from Australia - Mixed by Phil K
7. Fabriclive 16 - Mixed by Adam Freeland

- Mostly amtospheric breaks. Nice chill-out stuff for breaksheads.
Can't listen to K&D Sessions all the time u know.


8. Subliminal Sessions 5 - Mixed by Erick Morillo

- I don't even like house music all that much, but this rocks. Disc 1
is more funky and soulful (it even opens with the disco classic
"Relight My FIre"), groovy and playful. Disc 2 is the darker
progressive stuff. But overall it retains a New York house sound. FUCK
Mark Farina, FUCK Miguel Migs, FUCK Ben Watt. ***This is house
music****.  Flame on.  :)


9. Balance 005 - Mixed by James Holden

- Trance is dead, right? This is the only trance DJ mix I actually
liked in the last... um... 2 years? Deep, progressive and techy, what
you expect of James.


10. Nite:Life 06 - Mixed by Ian Pooley

- OK this one is oldest (2001). But this is some damn sexy, jazzy,
soulful, groovy deep house.


There, I feel better now.  :)


So what's on YOUR iPod? 

- Jeff


-- 
"I don't go out to be seen,
 I don't go out to show off,
 I go out to be a part of something I believe in."

From: nwa <nwa420@gmail.com>

To: The_List <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Beastie Boys are always on vacation!!!

I'm actually writing a review of the new Beastie Boys CD myself right
now that I might post a link to here when i'm done, and I'm trying not
to repeat anything anyone else is doing so i'm looking at what other
people are saying and I found this:

http://www.joyzine.co.uk/bboy.htm

too funny, and it would be great if this as a review style catches on, ya'think?

What's the real kick in the teeth for me, is that last week when I
de-lurked here after like a 2 year layoff with those really long
political posts out of nowhere, (that someone told me off-list are
better off going into my Live Journal, which sounds about right),  I
came to the realization that had I just posted a link to it, like I am
here:

http://www.beastieboys.com/ 

(doesn't that artwerk on the cover with the Towers standing like 9.11
never happened give you goosebumps? It does me. What a bold, visionary
artistic statement),

it would have been a lot better way to present some of the ideas I was
putting out, just to use shorthand and recommend this CD to people,
since they're sying the same things I am, save that they're so much
better at it than I am.

On repeated listenings what i'm hearing is that they're performing a
political miracle.....

They're showing us a way to take the rancor out of politics.

I now believe that we're going to be able to move the caliber of
political discussion in this country *back* to being a dialogue and
away from being in this crazed polemical state it's in today.

It WILL happen.

Holy shit, that's so huge i don't even have werds for it, except to say

a) sorry for dragging ya'll through those long posts, when this woulda
been a much better way to do it, so I'm doing it now.

:P

b) i have a much different sense of direction than I've had in a long
time, a lot of negativity and sense of overall despair that I've had
over things has moved out of my body and I'm now seeing a way out of
all this that i just couldn't see before.

It's a rush.

For the past few days I've been floating on air, feels like I took a
hit of pharm grade mdma, except that I haven't.

If you're not feeling it, let me share this with you......

Even if Bush wins the election, as bad as it will be for the country,
it won't matter because he and his crew are in the process of
self-destructing, and more importantly, the Democratic Party, as well
as other groups that share some of that ideological mindset, are in
the strongest position they has been in the last two decades, even
though it doesn't look like it this very second.

The tide *is* turning, I'm sure of it, I can feel it in my bones, and
that, my friends, has sucked the fight, or the desire to fight out of
me.

Even if this process takes 20 years to get to, and i, for one, am
prepared to wait for it, now that i know that we as a people are going
to get there, it changes everything for me.

man, if only i could bottle this feeling up and put it into a pill.

;-)

m'kay, now back 2 the music!

nwa

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network

I just read the full article, I should have soner. What's most
interesting in it was BBC's "Flexible TV", a video-on-demand service
for PC using BitTorrent at its distribution mechanism.

That can really be a blueprint for grassroot internet media. Using a
P2P model takes away the enormous bandwith requirement of streaming
video. Not to mention that this can also be used as strong evidence of
P2P's "substantial non-infriging use" if INDUCE Act ever become law
and we have to strike it down in Supreme Court.

Sorry, this is getting hella NRR. I'm kind of a copyright/media reformist. =
LOL


- Jeff


On Thu, 07 Oct 2004 12:25:59 -0700, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> F*ck Big Media: Rolling Your Own Network
>=20
> Mark Pesce Lecturer, Interactive Media, AFTRS
> markp@aftrs.edu.au www.playfulworld.com
>=20
> Preamble
>=20
> The worldwide consolidation of media industries has led
> to a consequent closure of the public airwaves with
> respect to matters of public interest. As control of
> this public resource becomes more centralized, the
> messages transmitted by global media purveyors become
> progressively less relevant, less diverse, and less
> reflective of ground truth.
>=20
> At present, individuals and organizations work to break
> the stranglehold of these anti-market-media-mega-
> corporations through the application of the courts and
> the law. However, because of the inherent monopoly that
> anti-market media maintain on the public mindset,
> legislators have been understandably reluctant to make
> moves toward media diversification. We are thus
> confronted with a situation where many people have
> interesting things to say, but there are progressively
> fewer outlets where these views can be shared.
>=20
> The public airwaves, because they are a limited
> resource, are managed by public bodies for the public
> interest. While honorable, the net effect of this
> philosophy of resource management has been negative: a
> public resource has become the equivalent of a
> beachfront property, its sale generating enormous
> license revenues, but its transfer to the private
> domain denying the community access to the sea of
> ideas.
>=20
> If a well-informed public is the necessary prerequisite
> to the democratic process, then we must frankly admit
> that any private ownership of public airwaves
> represents a potential threat to the free exchange of
> ideas. Now that private property has mostly
> collectivized the electromagnetic spectrum, and with
> little hope that this will soon change, we must look
> elsewhere to find a common ground for the public
> discourse.
>=20
> We are fortunate that such ground already exists.
>=20
> For more:  <http://www.hyperreal.org/~mpesce/fbm.html>
>=20
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>=20
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>=20
> "The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hand=
s
> of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible
> empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
> -Woodrow Wilson
>=20
> "There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all=
,
> i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a
> bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from th=
e
> state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as lif=
e
> itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
>   =E2=80=93 Gandhi
>=20
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually becom=
e
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>=20
>=20


--=20
"I don't go out to be seen,
 I don't go out to show off,
 I go out to be a part of something I believe in."

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:
 
supa got bored with dealing with ig. as great as ig is, supa is a little bit more independent, and longing for an independent journey to the east coast. supa knows that everyone "thinks" they are on east coast time, but no one is a slick as the east coast variety, plus, it is time to hit up his favorite aunt for import candy to bring home to ig. :)

Subject: [sfraves] Notice: Subscription moderation turned off, new configuration

Hi All-

Last week Brian and I modified the SFRaves list configuration so we 
could keep the list open with subscriptions but have some level of 
security against those who want to abuse it.

So far seems to be working great, so I'm letting you guys know. For 
everyone on the list now it's back to business-as-usual, the only 
difference is new subscribers might experience a delay in their first few 
posts.

Any questions, just let me know =)

-terry

itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

Howdy Boys and gurls..

The time has come again when I have a room for rent and im looking for a 
cool down to earth roomate here is the skinny on my place:

2 Bedrom 2 1/2 Bath Townhouse located centrally in Milpitas (southbay)
Near all Major freeways (101,237,680,280 etc) Close to the great mall and 
McCarthy ranch.
Room for rent: Dimensions 11W x 13L Nice Mid size room two good sized 
sliding Mirrored closets
Private Balcony,Private Bathroom and exclusive access to one car garage.
Rent $650 Plus half Utilities.
Perks (Me as a roomate)!! Well that ain't really a perk but im laid back and 
cool so I guess in a way it can be.

House specifics. Central A/C and Heat. Satellite TV in every room. Nice 
living room entertainment center with 50 Inch TV for you die hard TV addicts 
such as myself.  Wireless DSL etc..

I will have pics up soon after I paint the room.

minor roomie requirements:
Male or female 21+  (Male prefered)
Non Smoker (Or smoke outside)
420 Friendly but it pretty much stops there with the occasional others.
Stable income, don't have to be a "Techie" but at least be able to support 
yourself.
Snowboarder or mountain biker (You get ++ points)
DJ,Artist or all around cool person (++ points again.)

If you read this far.. thanks  ;-)

If your interested or know someone that is hit me up privately and I can go 
over it some more.

Macadio

_________________________________________________________________
On the road to retirement? Check out MSN Life Events for advice on how to 
get there! http://lifeevents.msn.com/category.aspx?cid=Retirement

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beastie Boys are always on vacation!!!

Points taken, but I wasn't talking about that.

I'm talking about a **real** vacation, not one of those empty
self-indulgent cruises to nowhere, or one that's all about  living in
the land of posture like George does in Crawford TX every year, but
one for his soul.

The path he and his associates have been on cannot possibly be a
healthy one for the spirit.

Have George go to Esalen, Harbin Hot Springs, or Taos, NM, and do a
few workshops and get in touch with his humanity.

Mebbe a re-birthing werkshop would be just the thing for where George's at.

Get some healing going on. 

I'm only saying this because I care about George as another human
being, just like me and everyone else, I really and truly deeply do.

No matter what.

I'm no longer going to get sucked into the hate on hate on hate hate
on hate on hate game, no matter how easy, seductive that is.

That's over for me.

Somehow i managed to break the spell of that, and I now see a way out.

Everything I'll be saying or doing from this point on is a result of that.

you've been warned, & I mean that in the nicest way possible.

:-)

either plur is an all-inclusive concept, or it isn't.

And if it isn't, then I've been fooling myself about who I am & what
I'm about for a very long time.

if plurs something I say I believe in, then I better start acting like
it if I want to sleep well at night.

the real litmus test of plur is not at some party with the most
awesome vibe ver, but comes when dealing with someone that you don't
necessarily agree with, or better yet, this person made it quite
clear, (see: rave act), that they don't like you at all

you know George won't like the idea of trying a different approach at
first, especially if his mindset is that he's beyond redemption, but
he'll thank us later for suggesting it.

I know this.

It's either that, or him going out & getting blinding drunk. 

(which, 12 step opinions to the contrary, (btw, i'm living
motherfucking proof that those guys don't have all the answers they
fucking think they do), may not be the 'bad' thing it looks like at
first blush.
God, if his Dad could chow down on Pork Rinds for the cameras, George
can certainly pop open a tall cool Bud, and not suffer for it in the
least, ya think? After all, given his history with alcohol he'd be
doing nothing more than following his bliss.)

Getting unutterably hammered is fun, as we all know, and is great for
the pressure release I'm talking about, which George so obviously
needs, as well, but doesn't have lasting effects that carry into one's
life, so I'd suggest he goes on a retreat of some sort after the
election, whetehr or not he wins, or doesn't.

nic

Tuesday options:
	a) Laundry
	b) Catch the next episode of "One Tree Hill"
	c) Hugger-Mugger at Lit!  <------

You can do laundry tomorrow, and I have no comment on option "b." So it's
simple...stop by and have a drink at Lit.  Admission is free!

Special guests for 10/12 include SF electrofunkbreaks authority, Audioel
(Cybrid), and Tech-On favorite, Tari (Frog&Lobster Show).  Also, introducing
recent SF transplant, DJ Paradox (Ill Beats) who will be cutting up the decks
with some fresh hip hop tracks.

Trust me, you won't want to miss this one!!!

H U G G E R - M U G G E R - every friggin' Tuesday

  Audioel (Cybrid)
  Paradox (Ill Beats)

Christopher Reeve (Sept. 25, 1952 - Oct. 11, 2004)

"Look, I've flown, I've become evil, loved, stopped and turned the
world backward, I've faced my peers, I've befriended children and small
animals and I've rescued cats from trees," Reeve told the Los Angeles
Times in 1983, just before the release of the third "Superman" movie.
"What else is there left for Superman to do that hasn't been done?"

"I refuse to allow a disability to determine how I live my life. I
don't mean to be reckless, but setting a goal that seems a bit daunting
actually is very helpful toward recovery," Reeve said after his 1995
horse-riding accident that caused his paralysis.

--- Christopher Reeve's inspiration is beyond words.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beastie Boys are always on vacation!!!

totally natural, and it's been like this for going on a week now.

nice thing is, is that it doesn't wear off, and there's no come down,
at least not yet.

it's like touring around the Nation while being on a permanent vacation.

you can have it too, if you like. 

catch is, to get to this point, I had to lose the anger first. 

which I did.

this is so great to feel this way, esecially in these, oh, so polemical times.

mad props to Mike & Dave for putting me in check for ragging on the
Cheney look-a-like dude in the elevator, (yup he's God's kid too, and
if I bump into him again I will tell him that I was out of line,
unless, of course, he cleans my clock first), last week, it kinda
triggered this line of thinking.

Here's the short version of how to get get here.

Know, not think or feel, but KNOW that the Democratic Party today is
in the strongest position it's been in a long, long, long time, the
wife says at least since 1992.

This is a direct result of being woken up by people like Dr. Dean, and
Michael Moore, who also, SuperDuperSpecialExtra added bonus,  proved
the point beyond any reasonable doubt that it IS true that just one
person can make a difference.

Know that the poor Republicans, who seem to have it all at this point,
(like the friggin' House, Senate, WH & SC), are on their way out, even
as we speak.

Won't happen in this election cycle, and maybe not even in the next
one, but they are not only finished, but they won't be coming back in
their present form because in one of the greatest acts of political
self-sabotage, ever, they've undermined their long-term prospects by
not cultivating a back bench.

Outside of a man like John McCain, there's no there there.

they present leadership of the Republican Party has  driven away many,
many good and decent Republicans, myself included.

I just now got werd, Hello 2day, that my voter registration and party
affiliation switch just went through.

I just turned 40 this year, and for the first time, ever, in my voting
life i'm no longer a Republican, but a Democrat, and I won't be going
back, which really stung at first, but what choice did I have?

I didn't do this lightly, at all.

To borrow a phrase, I didn't leave them, they left me, and I know that
there are hundreds of thousands of Americans that feel the same way,
and we are the fucking future of this country.

OK, and this is really important, and if you can dial into this, KNOW
these people that are 'large and in charge' are very sick people and
you don't get mad at sick people, that's not the right way to go about
it.

Would you lay into your Mom because she has cancer?

Same thing.

No point in getting angry or mad or upset because a new society is
coming up on the horizon, one that you and I and everyone we know will
build.

It's gonna be a **lot** of hard werk to get there from here, and Bush
may even have to win this time to make it happen.

which may not be a bad thing, over time, because the upside of that is
is that the lessons we're in the process of learning today as a people
will really stick.

We'll know better than to go back down that path again.

It takes time to build.

you gotz to chillllllll....

:-)

peaceout motherfucker,

nwa

ps: even with all this 'A Bitter Pill' is still very much a GO, I
haven't completely gone off the deep end with this.

Semiotic deconstructionist Jacques Derrida died today as well and his
passing has not gotten near the same amount of play in the Press,
'natch.

I wrote this below to another list in response to that.....


Holy fuck, this is bigger than the passing of Reeves.

weird that they'd check out within the same 24 hour time period.

without a fucking doubt both these men were Supermen, in their
respective, chosen, fields

I wore my star-spangled 'S' t-shirt to werk today, & will again tmw, as a s=
how
of respect 4 Mr. Reeves, and the Kinks 'Superman' has been on mtv
level heavy rotation  here in the old homestead since day-break as well.

i werked with Mr. Reeves back in 1986 on his (& Morgan Freeman's
breakthrough, Academy Award nominated, role, in 'Street Smart),' it's
always a blow when that happens to someone you've been in the same
vicinity with.

Odd how that is.

I never got to have that w/Mr. Derrida, but since I've traveled in the
high country of the mind, for a spell, I feel his loss just as acutely.

It's going to take a lot more effort on my part to acknowledge him &
his passing than throwing on some ratty ass t-shirt & playing
some tunes.

then again, "Superman" is a fitting tribute to him as well & it would
werk great as a d'n'b or House remix.

if nothing else, it's good that it was you that broke the news to me.

thanks.

i'm gonna go light a few candles now.

peaceout mothrfucker

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Supressing the black vote.  (Don't let it happen.)

SUPPRESSING THE BLACK VOTE
http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/9660865.htm

BOB HEBERT, NY TIMES - More than 80 percent of the population of Detroit
is black. This is very well understood by John Pappageorge, who is white
and a Republican state legislator in Michigan. "If we do not suppress
the Detroit vote," said Pappageorge, "we're going to have a tough time
in this election."

Oops! Republicans aren't supposed to actually say they want to suppress
black votes. That's so retro. It's so Jim Crow. This is the 21st
century, and the thing now is to do the dastardly deed, but never ever
acknowledge it. That's where our friend Pappageorge went wrong.

After his startling quote was published several weeks ago in the Detroit
Free Press, Pappageorge, who is 73, apologized and said he certainly
never meant to suggest that anything racist or illegal take place. But
he reiterated to me in a phone conversation last Friday that he did
indeed mean that the vote in Detroit needed to be kept down.

A lot of other Republicans have similar views about the vote in areas
with large black populations. Most blacks vote Democratic. If those
votes can be suppressed, Republicans benefit. And there is increasing
evidence that a big effort to suppress the vote among blacks and some
other heavily Democratic voting groups is under way, which is why it is
important to keep the following phone number handy:

1-866-OUR VOTE.

That's a hot line set up by the Election Protection Coalition, a group
that was formed to identify and stamp out attempts to disenfranchise
voters, especially in predominantly black and Latino precincts around
the country.

On Election Day in November, the coalition expects to have as many as
25,000 volunteers, including 5,000 lawyers, available to provide
assistance to voters who encounter irregularities or feel they are not
being treated fairly at the polls. Voters who call the hot line will
immediately be put in touch with volunteers in their local area. The
coalition is also urging people to call the hot line now if they are
aware of efforts to discourage or prevent people from voting.


http://www.jcthedj.com
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

-- 
Imagine if FDR responded to a Japanese attack by quickly invading the
Alutien Islands, not finding Hirohito, and decided to bomb China
instead, because they're Asian too.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR - Santa Cruz raises its Limits for Medical Users =)

Just a little late on sending this out, but i thought a few people on
here may still be interested to here about this...

http://safeaccessnow.org/article.php?id=1470

-------------------

Medical pot limit raised in Santa Cruz

by Maria Alicia Gaura, San Francisco Chronicle
October 7th, 2004
 
 
Santa Cruz County medical marijuana users may now legally possess as
much as 3 pounds of pot -- at least as far as the local authorities
are concerned.

The county Board of Supervisors voted unanimously Tuesday to set the
3- pound limit at the urging of medical marijuana advocates, who
argued that the sickest patients frequently use upwards of an ounce of
marijuana per week to ease their symptoms. The board also voted to
allow medical users to grow a home garden plot of the herb measuring
100 square feet.

Marijuana is an annual crop, so the 3-pound limit will allow users to
obtain a single supply that can last them an entire year.

"Three pounds sounds like a lot, but it's just a few marijuana
cigarettes per day, when you break it down," said Valerie Corral, one
of the founders of the Wo/Men's Alliance for Medical Marijuana, a
Santa Cruz marijuana-growing collective.

Corral uses marijuana several times daily to suppress seizures caused
by injuries she suffered in a car accident.

"About 15 percent of our patients use in excess of 5 pounds per year,"
Corral said. "They suffer from everything from chronic pain to cancer
and AIDS, chemotherapy and wasting."

While the new county ordinance will protect marijuana users from
prosecution by local law enforcement, it won't do much to dissuade
federal agents. The federal government does not recognize California's
rules allowing medical marijuana use, which voters enacted in 1996 by
passing Proposition 215.

"The federal government still insists that there is no such thing as
medicinal marijuana," said Glenn Backes, director of the Sacramento
office of the Drug Policy Alliance, a national advocacy group
organized to reform drug laws.

"Unfortunately, these state and local guidelines still leave patients
vulnerable to attack from the feds," Backes said.

Last October, outgoing Gov. Gray Davis signed a bill by state Sen.
John Vasconcellos, D-San Jose, that attempted to standardize the
jumble of local medical marijuana legislation passed after Prop. 215
took effect.

The bill, SB420, set a statewide possession limit of 8 ounces of
medical marijuana for patients with a doctor's recommendation, but
encouraged individual communities to set higher limits if they saw
fit. The legislation also allows medical users to possess six mature
marijuana plants or 12 immature plants for personal use.

(The bill number was an inside joke referring to 4:20 p.m. -- the time
that many recreational users like to take a smoke break and some refer
to as "Miller time for stoners.")

Santa Cruz County is among a growing number of communities that have
adopted higher limits, according to NORML, the National Organization
for Reform of Marijuana Laws.

Humboldt and Sonoma counties have limits similar to Santa Cruz's.
Calaveras County allows possession of six plants and 2 pounds of dried
marijuana. Yuba County allows five plants and 1.5 pounds, and the city
of Berkeley allows 10 plants and 2.5 pounds.

Santa Cruz attorney Ben Rice, who represents the Wo/Men's Alliance for
Medical Marijuana, says that the new limits are a positive step, but
that more refinements to the law are needed.

"It is kind of a bare-bones ordinance," Rice said. "One question that
remains is, what should law enforcement do when it comes across what
is alleged to be a medical marijuana garden?

"Historically they cut down the plants and resolve the issue later --
and in the meantime the medicine is lost," Rice said. "I've had a
couple of pounds of (seized marijuana) returned that was nothing more
than green mush."

He cited a city of Santa Cruz guideline that directs police to take a
sample of the suspect marijuana as well as photographs, but to leave
the plants standing until the district attorney decides whether to
file charges.

Subject: [sfraves] DJ/COLLECTIVE question...

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 61282 invoked from network); 12 Oct 2004 22:03:41 -0000
Message-ID: <20041012220338.89221.qmail@web53207.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 12 Oct 2004 15:03:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: "michael, the red stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>
To: Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-F15pmy20h08xWI00016fa8@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJ/COLLECTIVE question...

1) you have to be decently good.  not absolutely top-notch, but
pretty good for what you do.

2) commitment and willingness to help.  if you don't help, you
don't get the bookings.

3) we all get along.  ie:  if you're harassing all the females
in the collective, then you're gone.

4) meet an unmet need.  ie:  you're good at decorations, you
have sound, a generator, etc.  this is not necessarily
essential, but is nice to have.

:)
m

Received: (qmail 63140 invoked from network); 12 Oct 2004 22:05:29 -0000
Message-ID: <20041012220527.67259.qmail@web21528.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 12 Oct 2004 15:05:27 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Marginal Groove: The Politics of Raves in Richmond

Something I accidentally found today...


Everyone knows how it feels to be out of place.
However, not everyone knows explicitly what that
means. To be out of place is to fall outside of
certain "expectations about behavior that relate a
position in a social structure to actions in space"
(Cresswell, 1996, p. 3). Ideological norms are
determined by those highest in the social hierarchy to
further and perpetuate their dominance. In this
complex web of power relations, places are inscribed
with and convey meanings; these are ordinarily
implicit, requiring a disruptive event to expose them.

Raves may be and have been examples of transgression
in many places they have occurred. A rave is typically
an all-night social gathering, featuring electronic
music and dancing. Common but not essential to these
events is a variety of psychedelic stimuli, including
visual effects and the consumption of recreational
drugs by some participants (see Brown, 1995; Rietveld,
1993; RollerGirl, 2000). As a culture, rave has its
roots in the United Kingdom's acid house movement of
1988 and 1989, which was set off by the combination of
house music from the United States, New Age hippy
values, and the empathogenic drug ecstasy (Silcott,
1999). Loosely described as a subculture or
counterculture, rave made its way to North America,
first establishing itself in New York, and slowly
spreading across the United States and Canada during
the 1990s.



http://www.aquapulse.net//knowledge/rave

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

At 02:35 PM 10/12/2004, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
>Just curiously - how do you folks out there in crews/collectives decide 
>who is and isn't "material" for your crew/collective?
>
>Is it a strictly friends type of thing, or are there more qualifications 
>necessary than that?

In Moksha the procedure involves a current member sponsoring someone he/she 
knows for new membership.  The current member then becomes a mentor for the 
newbie and is responsible for bringing him/her up to speed on collective 
responsibilities and procedures.  The newbie is then required to work 
successfully at one party before he/she becomes a permanent member.


>I realize style/genre, etc. play into it as well - but what do you all 
>truly look for in your DJ's?

Depends on the event, that is, what themes and genres are the 
focus.  Overall we look for very competent DJs who can get people to dance 
on the dancefloors;  when we offer a chill room, we look for innovative DJs 
in the ambient genres.  We are much interested in giving new talent 
opportunities to perform.

Moksha has a music team comprised of permanent and volunteer members who 
make DJ selections and then offer their recommendations to the collective 
as a whole for approval.  The team listens to promotional CDs we have been 
sent as part of the selection process.

That's a brief response, Marc(O):)  If you have more questions, give me a 
hit off line.

Much love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: any financially challenged and mechanically inclined people out there?

Ok, sorry about the NRR but I'm having major problems finding a
mechanic. Actually, it's kind of rave-related, I need to get her fixed
so I can haul other people's sound systems again! nyuk nyuk.

If you, or anyone you know is a mechanic and is looking to make a few
bucks, I need someone to cruise by my place on Friday to replace the
starter and a few other items in my pickup. CL is proving to have no
one competent or reliable and the only friend i have that's halfway
mechanically competent is in Fresno.

I will pay cash. Or do the work for free and I'll haul your sound
system anytime you want :o) Please email me if you can help. Peace
y'all.

tala

Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJ/COLLECTIVE question...

Nice to see a potentially great thread deprecate into peanut gallery 
humor....um ok not really ;-)

Looks like a loaded post to me.

imho, a superstar collective DJ should:

Spin a rockin' set, schlep gear up and down the beach (or in/out the 
warehouse), bring personality, hang with the locals, treat a booking as an 
"adventure", fix EQ'ing for sound people correctly, know how to re-fill a 
generator (or assist in the breakers blowing), know how to talk to the 
cops, spin a rockin' set....no, not the same one you did last weekend, 
pick up trash, come to breakfast, have a bloody mary/mimosa at breakfast, 
talk shit at breakfast, and all for no money and be willing to do it again 
next weekend =) Grilling a tri-tip in the afternoon a plus.

Wow, that sounds cool, doesn't it =)

-t
------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Judge orders hearing on lawsuit to stop 3rd Bush-Kerry debate

--Apple-Mail-38--931058216
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed

Libertarians Win a Hearing in Debate Case

BY JOSH GERSTEIN - Staff Reporter of the New York Sun
October 11, 2004
URL: http://www.nysun.com/article/2962

The third and final debate between President Bush and Senator Kerry has 
been thrown into doubt after a state judge in Arizona ordered a hearing 
on whether the event, scheduled for Wednesday, should be halted because 
the Libertarian Party's nominee for president has not been invited.

Judge F. Pendleton Gaines III instructed the debate's hosts, Arizona 
State University and the Commission on Presidential Debates, to appear 
in his courtroom in Phoenix tomorrow to respond to a lawsuit filed last 
week by the Libertarians.

"I'm happy so far with the way things are going," an attorney for the 
Libertarian Party, David Euchner, said in an interview yesterday. "He 
did not have to sign that order. The fact that he did is a good sign."

The suit argues that the university is illegally donating state 
resources to the Republican and Democratic Parties by serving as host 
for a debate that showcases Messrs. Bush and Kerry but excludes their 
Libertarian counterpart, Michael Badnarik, who is on the ballot in 
Arizona and 47 other states.

"They can't have debates that make public expenditures for private 
benefit," Mr. Euchner said. "A.S.U. is spending its money in violation 
of the state constitution."

A spokeswoman for the university, Nancy Neff, said she was unaware of 
the hearing tomorrow. "If that's the judge's order, then we'll be there 
for sure," Ms. Neff said.

While the university is constructing a massive press filing center and 
has incurred large expenses for security, Ms. Neff insisted the debate 
will take place at no cost to taxpayers.

"We are not spending public money on the debate. We have underwritten 
it using private donations, in-kind gifts, and private foundation 
funds," the university spokeswoman said. "The price we've been working 
with is $2.5 million, and that's what we've been trying to raise," Ms. 
Neff said.

Major sponsors for the third debate include a heavy equipment maker, 
Caterpillar Inc.; a local utility company, APS, and an Indian tribal 
group that owns two casinos near Scottsdale, the Salt River 
Pima-Maricopa Indian Community.

Ms. Neff acknowledged, however, that the university has yet to raise 
all the funds required for the event, which is scheduled to take place 
at an auditorium on the school's Tempe campus, just east of Phoenix. 
"We're still raising money even as we work on it," she said, adding 
that at the last tally about $2.3 million had been pledged.

Mr. Euchner said the university's claim that no public money is 
involved is laughable. "The fact they've got their hat in hand helps 
us," he said. "The evidence is pretty clear that if there's a shortfall 
here that A.S.U. is holding the bag. They made, essentially, an 
interest free loan."

Mr. Euchner said the state's involvement in the debate is part of what 
many Libertarians see as a pattern of improper use of government funds 
to promote the two major parties. "Taxpayers foot the bill for the 
Democratic and Republican national conventions," he complained. 
"Anything they can get the taxpayers to pay for that way, they do it."

Several legal experts said the Libertarians face an uphill battle in 
attempting to use the so-called gift clause of the Arizona Constitution 
to block Wednesday's debate.

"It doesn't strike me as a very strong ground," an author of a book on 
the Arizona Constitution, Toni McClory, said. "It's not a violation of 
the gift clause if the state is getting something of real value." While 
state universities have been hosts to presidential debates in the past, 
Arizona State is the only one to do so this year.

Ms. McClory, who teaches at a community college near Phoenix, said the 
publicity surrounding the debate might be considered a substantial 
benefit to the university. "It's giving the university a great deal of 
public exposure," she said.

A law professor at the University of Arizona, Robert Glennon, said the 
court dispute is likely to turn on whether Arizona State is seen as 
discriminating against the Libertarians. He said offering the 
Libertarians the use of a similar facility on campus would probably be 
enough to fulfill the state's obligations.

"So long as the state has a nondiscriminatory policy, the fact that one 
particular party or one religion uses it is of no consequence," Mr. 
Glennon said. The professor noted that the requirements to bring a case 
for abuse of taxpayer funds are often lower in state courts than in the 
federal system, but he said he was surprised that the judge granted the 
Libertarians a hearing.

Judge Gaines was appointed to the bench in 1999 by Gov. Jane Hull, a 
Republican. In his show-cause order issued Friday morning, the judge 
also required that the university and the debate commission be served 
with the lawsuit by Friday afternoon. An attorney for the university 
accepted service, but security guards at the commission's headquarters 
in Washington ordered process-servers to leave the building, Mr. 
Euchner said.

Indeed, Mr. Badnarik and the Green Party nominee, David Cobb, were 
arrested Friday night after they crossed a police line at the 
presidential debate in St. Louis. Mr. Badnarik said he was trying to 
serve the lawsuit on a representative of the debate commission. The two 
candidates were released after being given tickets for trespassing and 
refusing a reasonable order from a policeman.

The commission, which is a nonprofit corporation, has insisted that it 
applies nonpartisan criteria to determine who is invited to the 
debates. The rules require that candidates have at least 15% support in 
national polls to qualify. None of the third-party candidates this year 
has met that hurdle.

Critics of the debate commission assert that it is little more than a 
front for the major parties. They note that the Democrats and the GOP 
issued a joint press release announcing the creation of the 
"bipartisan" commission and describing its purpose as facilitating 
debates between their "respective nominees." More recently, the 
commission has described itself as "nonpartisan," although its 
adherence to that standard remains in question.

Last month, a spokesman for the debate commission told the Sun that the 
panel could not comply with a provision in the agreement worked out 
between the Bush and Kerry campaigns that dictated the makeup of the 
audience for Friday's town meeting debate be one-half "soft" supporters 
of Mr. Bush and one-half "soft" supporters of Mr. Kerry. "We can't use 
soft Bush and soft Kerry supporters because we are a nonpartisan group, 
not a bipartisan group," said the commission spokesman, who asked not 
to be named. "We have said we'd use undecided voters."

In an interview with CNN last week, the editor in chief of Gallup, 
Frank Newport, said that more than 90% of those in the audience for 
Friday's debate had stated a "soft" preference for either Mr. Bush or 
Mr. Kerry. Mr. Newport did not indicate whether supporters of the 
independent candidate Ralph Nader or of Mr. Badnarik were considered 
for the audience.

In August, a federal judge in Washington sharply criticized the Federal 
Election Commission for ignoring evidence of bias on the part of the 
debate commission. Judge Henry Kennedy Jr. noted that in 2000 the 
debate commission gave security guards "facebooks" with pictures of 
third-party candidates and instructed the guards to prevent those in 
the photos from entering the debate venues, even with valid audience 
tickets. "The exclusion policy appears partisan on its face," Judge 
Kennedy wrote.

In a national poll taken in September, 57% of likely voters favored 
including presidential candidates other than the president and the 
Massachusetts senator in the debates. The survey, conducted by Zogby 
International, found 57% of likely voters in favor of adding Mr. Nader, 
and 44% in favor of including Mr. Badnarik.


See also http://www.commission-on-fake-presidential-debates.us/

--Apple-Mail-38--931058216--

'cause I dunno, I'm like havin' this mondo fall fever
of not doing homework, Bad Bad me- /me slaps hand - so
I dunno... I kinda saw Jonas BSP & got reeeeeeally
temped 2 ditch class 2 go 2 his happy hour @ Luna...
well.. needless 2 say that i did... LoL...

So i got 2 Luna around 6:30... Jonas was on the decks..
he was spinning Acid house... went in2 some Techie
kinda house w/ alota bleep bleeps.. Yum.. OK... then he
like went like Nuyorican Soul kinda 4 a few tracks if
notr like just 1 or 2.. then went back 2 like some just
Groovy Yummy House...I Loved it.. I danced alot!!

I dunno, it was kinda weird, I like totally went out
the 1st time & had a ciggy.. but I dunno.. I just had 2
B outside like I was told 2 go out there like something
inside me told me 2... so I'm chillin' outside 4 a lil'
bit during Jonas set... then some guy like totally
walks past me then walks back like in my face & says my
name... LoL.. it was 1 of my olkd Homies from back in
the day when Kryptyk threw Jungle weeklies there..
anywaze, his name is Mateo & Wow.. LoL.. that was Dope!

brought in a mellow vibe 2 the floor.. I mean.. he
played alota I dunno.. B Sides of the Disco-iiiie kinda
house he was spinning???   I dunno... but it was like
well.. I think in his (& kick my ass if I'm wrong)
words Jazzy Disco HOuse?  It was fun!!  Yeah.. I know
Andrew, I'll communicate w/ U if I hear or talk 2

OK... but this is what totally threw me in 4 like a
mondo loop & 1 of the main reasons whY I cut class

2 a year that I've seen him spin, well, i think that's
about it... but yeah.. when he got there, we just had
soooooo much 2 talk about & catch up on... yeah...
Groovy!

Then he got on the decks & like WOW.. spun well wait,,
he opened up w/ this really rough break beats track w/
this bouncy 2 note bassline.. it was Dope!!  But like
after that, he just went strait on full in2 mondo yummy
vocal house.. I LOVED IT!!  It was a nice long set &
his B-Boy Atire kinda threw off what kinda music U
would a thought he mighta spun... LoL... but he did
actually take an Eminem acapella & layed it over this
Groovy House track which was funny!!!

spinning) & they were all playing some Hip Hop then
busted out this yummy breakbeats track which coulda
been a Big Beat song (I just learned that 2night), but
Li said it wasn't!!  Oh Li.. Thanks 4 the drink!!!

leaving & well.. he barted in2 the City & him & I
enjoyed a ride 2gether on bart... yeah.. i dunno... I
was only gonna stay like a lil while longer, but I

week =3D)

Buck Murdock <buckmurdock@gmail.com> wrote:In my collective you gotta be a cute girl, play the hell outta your
cowbell and be willing to really explore the studio space.
 
if you haven't yet, you really need to hear what Dirty Gringos did with that skit. that track gets a reaction every time i drop it :)
 
as for "crews", i've always been against them on general principle unless they are actively throwing parties together. otherwise it seems to me like it's mostly ego stroking for people who like a lot of things in parentheses after their name. i wrote a long-winded rant about the proliferation of useless crews when i was in dallas and practically started a war, so i won't get into it all again here. 
 
i prefer to just include my current and/or past residencies after my name, and that's only if someone insists on the little blurb. however, if i were to start my own collective (in a parallel universe) skill, work ethic, and philosophy on throwing parties would matter to me a lot more than style/genre.
 
love,
mo
(proud to be independent)

Subject: [sfraves] Re: NRR: What to watch out for from Edwards tonight (humor)

On Wednesday, October 6, 2004, at 03:56  AM, J.C. wrote (in part):

>> 	As to fair and transparent elections, no one has more of an interest
>> in ensuring the integrity of the vote than alternative parties like 
>> the
>> Libertarians. Those not in control of the vote-counting process always
>> have more to worry about in terms of potential fraud than those who do
>> control that process. The more election monitors the better, as far as
>> I'm concerned, and I hope that lots of monitors from other countries
>> are watching the U.S. elections, not just a handful invited by
>> left-wing members of Congress or left-wing groups like Global 
>> Exchange.
>
> Are you implying that they might not be honest in their judgements?

	Would you be asking that question if we were speaking of international 
monitors invited by right-wing politicians and groups? Seems to me that 
it's in the interest of fair elections to have monitors brought in by 
people from a variety of political backgrounds, not just one (whatever 
that one may be).

>> 	Anyone who wants the vote results to be as transparent and free from
>> potential malfeasance as possible should be in favor of all voting
>> results immediately being released to the public and to the media as
>> soon as they are tallied, and I encourage people to call the SF DOE at
>> (415) 554-4375 to request that this be done.
>
> Even better yet is to continue the tradition of (generally highly
> accurate) exit polls.  Which unfortunately seem to have been dropped,
> since the recent voting machines don't seem to be so accurate for
> whatever reasons.

	Exit polls are all well and good, but official outcomes are determined 
based on tallied results, not exit polls, so you still want to make 
sure that there's no opportunity for anyone to tamper with the vote 
count.

I feel that too. I guess one of the resons I asked, is because having been
an independant, and only recently associated myself with a partner (thus
forming our wikkid two man crew, lol) I would like to perhaps find a
crew/collective that was likeminded. I could care less about trying to make
myself seem cooler by having stuff after my name, because not much could
make me cool, hehe. To me it's more of a "these are my people, we look out
for each other and want to bring you the best party experience we can" type
of thing.

*shrug*

here that isn't saturated in politics.

that skit. that track gets a reaction every time i drop it :)
>
> as for "crews", i've always been against them on general principle unless
they are actively throwing parties together. otherwise it seems to me like
it's mostly ego stroking for people who like a lot of things in parentheses
after their name. i wrote a long-winded rant about the proliferation of
useless crews when i was in dallas and practically started a war, so i won't
get into it all again here.
>
> i prefer to just include my current and/or past residencies after my name,
and that's only if someone insists on the little blurb. however, if i were
to start my own collective (in a parallel universe) skill, work ethic, and
philosophy on throwing parties would matter to me a lot more than
style/genre.

--part1_127.4cf46875.2e9ecf95_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Just wondering, knowing it's hard for smaller parties to get into the 
debates, would it make sense for all the small parties to have some kind of a primary 
among themselves to determine which person would be THE third-party 
candidate? 

I'd be interested in hearing another view besides Bush and Kerry ... I really 
would. However, with a limited amount of time, I don't think people want to 
see eight candidates on stage without any way to ask questions in any depth. 
Maybe if the third parties could list all their candidates and collectively 
vote, at primary time, on which candidate would have the best chance of 
challenging the Demo and Republican candidates. 

One fairly strong third-party candidate would have a lot more pull than eight 
or so minor candidates who deserve a chance but don't have one. I know it 
"doesn't work that way" but it's something i just thought of and i don't think 
it's a bad idea. 

--part1_127.4cf46875.2e9ecf95_boundary--

> On Wednesday, October 6, 2004, at 03:56  AM, J.C. wrote (in part):
>
> >> 	As to fair and transparent elections, no one has more of an interest
> >> in ensuring the integrity of the vote than alternative parties like
> >> the
> >> Libertarians. Those not in control of the vote-counting process always
> >> have more to worry about in terms of potential fraud than those who do
> >> control that process. The more election monitors the better, as far as
> >> I'm concerned, and I hope that lots of monitors from other countries
> >> are watching the U.S. elections, not just a handful invited by
> >> left-wing members of Congress or left-wing groups like Global
> >> Exchange.
> >
> > Are you implying that they might not be honest in their judgements?
>
> 	Would you be asking that question if we were speaking of international
> monitors invited by right-wing politicians and groups? Seems to me that
> it's in the interest of fair elections to have monitors brought in by
> people from a variety of political backgrounds, not just one (whatever
> that one may be).

Then have the other side bring in monitors too.  Fine from my view.

>
> >> 	Anyone who wants the vote results to be as transparent and free from
> >> potential malfeasance as possible should be in favor of all voting
> >> results immediately being released to the public and to the media as
> >> soon as they are tallied, and I encourage people to call the SF DOE at
> >> (415) 554-4375 to request that this be done.
> >
> > Even better yet is to continue the tradition of (generally highly
> > accurate) exit polls.  Which unfortunately seem to have been dropped,
> > since the recent voting machines don't seem to be so accurate for
> > whatever reasons.
>
> 	Exit polls are all well and good, but official outcomes are determined
> based on tallied results, not exit polls, so you still want to make
> sure that there's no opportunity for anyone to tamper with the vote
> count.

But they do act as an indicator of fowl play.  I believe their
elimination was a conscious effort to allow for that fowl play.

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 43115 invoked from network); 13 Oct 2004 19:37:47 -0000
Date: Wed, 13 Oct 2004 12:37:43 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20041013193743.GT465@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <127.4cf46875.2e9ecf95@aol.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <127.4cf46875.2e9ecf95@aol.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Re: [sfraves] Judge orders hearing ... What about ONE third party candidate?

quoth JonnyR@aol.com:
> Just wondering, knowing it's hard for smaller parties to get into the
> debates, would it make sense for all the small parties to have some
> kind of a primary among themselves to determine which person would be
> THE third-party candidate? 

Uhhh, no. :)

The minority parties, for the most part, represent very specific
positions on a wide array of issues. Libertarians, for instance, would
be unlikely to support the nomination of a Green party candidate because
their party stands in direct opposition to the regulation of industry
that the Green party advocates.

> Maybe if the third parties could list all their candidates and
> collectively vote, at primary time, on which candidate would have the
> best chance of challenging the Demo and Republican candidates. 

That's not the point though. Minority parties don't seek just to
challenge the major parties for the hell of it; rather, they have
specific policies that they want to push. Nominating a single third
party candidate doesn't accomplish this goal, so I doubt that any
minority parties would support doing so.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJ/COLLECTIVE question...

Gavin Varitech <nesound@hotmail.com> said...
> I rarely dance anymore because people tend not to play danceable music
> anymore.

No shit. That is and always has been my biggest complaint about some
of the underground scenes. They keep scheduling DJs because they're
friends even though those friends tend (over many instances) not to
generate dancing!

DJs who continually put out lackluster sets that are disconnected
from any crowd... that's just annoying loud music. I can go to
social scenes without that.

It's rocket science, and every DJ should aspire to it. How do you
make people dance? Learn it. It's not easy or obvious. But if you're
dedicated to it, you will get there.

And if you don't care if you make people dance, why the fuck are you
playing records at dance parties?

Sean

dumb.  Dancing is cool anyway!

Act. The text of S. 226 was included, in conference, as Section 608 of S. 
151, the PROTECT Act. See S. 151 for further action. (CR 4/10/2003 S5153)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Mobile phone 'ear tumours risk' 

--=====================_16663701==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Mobile phone 'ear tumours risk'

Using a mobile phone for 10 years or more increases the risk of ear tumours 
by four times, research suggests.

A 750-people study by Sweden's Karolinska Institute found the risk of 
acoustic neuroma rose by 3.9 times on the side of the head the phone is used.

There was no increase in risk on the other side of the head - giving an 
overall rise in risk of 1.9 times.

Acoustic neuroma is a benign tumour in the auditory nerve, which can cause 
brain and nerve damage.

It affects one in 100,000 people.

Those who had used mobile phones for less than 10 years were not at a 
greater risk, the team reported.

IOut of the 750 people who took part in the study, 150 had acoustic neuroma 
and of those one in 11 had used a mobile phone for at least a decade.

Professor Anders Ahlbom, from the Stockholm-based institute, told BBC News 
Online he was "surprised" by his team's findings.

"The results show there is a relatively substantial risk and we are hoping 
others will follow up our research.

"We do not know what is causing it but the risk certainly increases over 
time."

He said he would not go as far as warning people not to use mobile phones.

But he added: "If people are concerned the simple way to avoid risk is to 
use a hands-free kit.

"Our researched showed that the risk is only on the side of the head on 
which the mobile phone is used."

Risk

At the time of the study only analogue mobile phones had been in use for 
more than 10 years.

The majority of people now have digital (GSM) phones, which came on to the 
market in the mid to late 1990s.

Some of the people who took part in the study had used both analogue and 
digital phones. There was no evidence to suggest solely using digital 
phones for 10 years increased the risk.

Dr Michael Clarke, a spokesman for the National Radiological Protection 
Board, the UK's advisory group, said it was a "good study from a well 
respected institute".

He said: "It is suggestive rather than conclusive but we will obviously 
take it into account when we issue guidance in the future."

And a spokeswoman for the Mobile Operators Association said: "The mobile 
phone industry takes very seriously questions relating to the safety of its 
products and is committed to addressing public concern in an open and 
transparent manner."

But she added: "Individual studies must be seen in the light of the total 
research effort into mobile phone safety. There have been other recent 
studies that have failed to show any link between mobile phones and tumours."

Three quarters of adults in the UK own or use a mobile phone.

The mobile phone industry has always maintained there is no scientific 
evidence of negative effects from mobile phone use.

But over the last few years experts have remained divided over the question 
of risk.

A study by Finnish scientists in 2002 found electromagnetic radiation, 
which is emitted from mobile phones, affected human brain tissue.

But the UK government-commissioned Stewart report in 2000 concluded there 
was no evidence of harm associated with using mobile phones.

However, the report recommended a precautionary approach and said children 
should only use mobile phones in emergencies.
Story from BBC NEWS:
http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/2/hi/health/3742120.stm

Published: 2004/10/14 10:12:10 GMT




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] Wed Night review: Clandestine in SJ... woooooooohooooooo =)

So like over 2 months ago, my Jungle DJ Homie from LA,
DJ Primo, told me that he was gonna be up here spinning
@ a Jungle Club & ofcourse Hello 2Day, I said I was
down to support!!  Also, I was getting hella shit from
DJ Aphelion, who help runs Clandestine, to go and hang
out down there!=20=20

So the time finally came when Primo trekked up here
from SoCal & via public transportaion, I made the 3 1/2
hour voyage down 2 Johnny V in downtown SJ to finally
kick it @ Clandestine!!!  LoL

Wow... I had sooooo much fun there!!  It was a light
crowd that night (I was told), but man... the energy &
the vibe was So Dope!  Alota Groovy people were hangin'
out!!!  LoL.. saw hella people I ain't seen in 4ever
daze!!  LoL.. people were kinda shockled 2 C me down
there... LoL... Oh mY Goodness man... I finnaly hung
out w/ Proxy after heeeeeella long!!  LoL.. we had alot
2 talk about & stuff!!  YAY.. Love Proxy! =3D)

Totally kicked it w/ Aphelion after hella long also &
we had alooooot 2 talk about man!!  So Dope!!! =3D)

It was Rad 2 finally meet & hang out w/ Primo 'cause we
been like online Homies for a while now & he always
sends me CDs of his mixes & tracks he produces....
Primo is fukin' Sick man.. I swear.. & when this Dude
spun his set.. it was so Bad Ass!!!  He like totally
opened w/ this like 1/2 beat slowwer than Jungle tune
that totally pumped up the floor.. then BOOM.. he went
strait up w/ hella hard ass DNB like 2 minutes after
and kept it all the way through his set!!  It was
Sick... Loved it... totally Danced my Ass off!  It was
Groovy too 'cause like alota the hard tunes he played
had vocals & man... I was in Heaven!  Mondo Yum!  I
mean, Mondo bass/ tricky percussion driven tracks all
the way!

Before him was DJ ummm... Tommy Jeramy... Dope set
(well, he was on when I got there)... he was spinning
alota hard Jungle also in his set!!  It was sick 'cause
he was juggling @ one point during his set, then he
hella scratched alot, lol... he did 1 rewind... LoL...
Good Shit man... yeah, ummm, alot of his tracks were
like, in my description, like alota hard, screechy
Jungle!  But man, it was a totally Awesome way 2 get 2
the club, grab floor, and Groove right away... Dope
Dope So Dope DJ!  LoL.. it's funny, him & I like met
each other mondo months ago Bad Kitty over @ Anu &
haven't seen each other like since then...

After Primo, Aphelion hopped on the decks for a whlie!!
 LoL... I wasn't even looking @ the DJ booth @ that
time, lol, but as soon as I heard some Dub come on... I
knew it was him!!  Dope!!

Then after Aphelion, Roaland something from Sacramento
went on... his set was like well... it was like some
good nice DNB... like his set just like totally flowed
off the mini Dub set that Aphelion spun... it was a
gfood way 2 like mondo close the night...

Calndestine was So Dope!!  I'm so glad that I finally
made it out to SJ for this!!  Wow man.. LoL...
wooooooohooooooo 4 the South Bay Jungle!!!

Take Care,
Peace=3D-> O=A7bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] The "Lesbian Daughter" Card

Dick and Lynn Cheney slammed Kerry for mentioning their lesbian
daughter in the debate, calling it a "cheap shot". Isn't this much ado
about nothing?

Was it a political move to hurt Bush/Cheney? What's the point of
mentioning Cheney's lesbian daughter when just about everybody already
knew about it? Dick Cheney had made many public appearance with her
daughter in front of gay audiences, and he already admitted that he
disagrees with Bush's opinion on using consititutional amendment to
define marriage.

A right-wing religious voter would already know about all this, and
even if they really didn't know Cheney had a lesbian daughter, would
they instead vote for Kerry (who's pro-gay, pro-choice, supports
federal funding for abortion and against consitutional admendment on
marriage) because of it? Voters who believe being gay is not a shame
wouldn't find Kerry's comment inappropiate either -- it's not a shame,
and Dick Cheney has made his lesbian daughter more or less a visible
figure as anyone else in his family, so it's not an invasion of
privacy. So it doesn't matter how hard the Cheney family slams Kerry,
ultimately, the controversy itself won't even affect a single vote.

What I found particularly interesting is that Kerry was cold,
uncomfortable and almost shameful when he made that comment. This is a
striking contrast to Edwards' comments in the VP debate: he spoke of
Cheney's family in great deal of admiration and positivity, and Dick
Cheney returned a very warm "thank you".

Now why would a pro-gay Democratic senator from Massachusetts acted
the way he did when he said the word "lesiban"??? He knows the Cheney
family is very supportive of Mary, he knows being gay isn't a choice
and nothing to be ashamed of. It's all very "uncharacteristic" of him.

So it's in my opinion that he did it deliberately, to get a reaction.
When Edwards played it with respect, Cheney reacted in respect. When
Kerry played it with shame, Cheney reacted in shame. I really want to
believe it wasn't a calculated expression,  but I think Kerry
delivered the comment with some deliberation.

So what's the point of invoking a shameful reaction, when in reality
such reaction won't benefit Kerry among voters anyways?

What this deliberate "look of shame" generated is the Republican's
over-the-top reaction and focus on attacking Kerry's character, which
will probably go on for the next 2 weeks. Great for Kerry, because you
know how Karl Rove loves to use dirty tricks to attack his opponent's
character. And now Kerry somehow made the Republicans to focus their
ruthless personal attacks on Kerry on the basis of a comment revolve
around what they think is a dirty word -- "lesbian", rather than
something that would actually hurt him.

Brilliant.


- Jeff


-- 
"I don't go out to be seen,
 I don't go out to show off,
 I go out to be a part of something I believe in."
