Subject: RE: [sfraves] The "Lesbian Daughter" Card

The "Lesbian Daughter" card was indeed played well.. but perhaps we might 
assign too much credence to the Keery camp for playing it.. it was in fact a 
valid and forthright response to the constitutional amendment charge that 
defined marriage as a "right" between men and women, to the question of 
whether or not a gay person is to be defined by choice or nature.

The whole question was loaded to split the candidates futher apart, devide 
and concquer is the game now.. and it is disseminating from the media down.  
This is the real beast, for the democratic party is split amoung varying 
degrees of moderate and liberal views, while the republican party is holding 
the party line firmly.  If Kerry looses, it will be because the democrates 
have split their vote based on how far the division takes the democratic 
voters away from the moderate left.

This is the brilliant part.. and it is not in Kerry's favor.
Rove is an amazingly hateful mastermind indeed.

Anyone read the Vanity fair artical on the election 2000 smear campaigns?
This is super highly recommended reading***

Subject: [sfraves] The "Lesbian Daughter" Card
Date: Fri, 15 Oct 2004 05:23:00 -0700

Dick and Lynn Cheney slammed Kerry for mentioning their lesbian
daughter in the debate, calling it a "cheap shot". Isn't this much ado
about nothing?

Was it a political move to hurt Bush/Cheney? What's the point of
mentioning Cheney's lesbian daughter when just about everybody already
knew about it? Dick Cheney had made many public appearance with her
daughter in front of gay audiences, and he already admitted that he
disagrees with Bush's opinion on using consititutional amendment to
define marriage.

A right-wing religious voter would already know about all this, and
even if they really didn't know Cheney had a lesbian daughter, would
they instead vote for Kerry (who's pro-gay, pro-choice, supports
federal funding for abortion and against consitutional admendment on
marriage) because of it? Voters who believe being gay is not a shame
wouldn't find Kerry's comment inappropiate either -- it's not a shame,
and Dick Cheney has made his lesbian daughter more or less a visible
figure as anyone else in his family, so it's not an invasion of
privacy. So it doesn't matter how hard the Cheney family slams Kerry,
ultimately, the controversy itself won't even affect a single vote.

What I found particularly interesting is that Kerry was cold,
uncomfortable and almost shameful when he made that comment. This is a
striking contrast to Edwards' comments in the VP debate: he spoke of
Cheney's family in great deal of admiration and positivity, and Dick
Cheney returned a very warm "thank you".

Now why would a pro-gay Democratic senator from Massachusetts acted
the way he did when he said the word "lesiban"??? He knows the Cheney
family is very supportive of Mary, he knows being gay isn't a choice
and nothing to be ashamed of. It's all very "uncharacteristic" of him.

So it's in my opinion that he did it deliberately, to get a reaction.
When Edwards played it with respect, Cheney reacted in respect. When
Kerry played it with shame, Cheney reacted in shame. I really want to
believe it wasn't a calculated expression,  but I think Kerry
delivered the comment with some deliberation.

So what's the point of invoking a shameful reaction, when in reality
such reaction won't benefit Kerry among voters anyways?

What this deliberate "look of shame" generated is the Republican's
over-the-top reaction and focus on attacking Kerry's character, which
will probably go on for the next 2 weeks. Great for Kerry, because you
know how Karl Rove loves to use dirty tricks to attack his opponent's
character. And now Kerry somehow made the Republicans to focus their
ruthless personal attacks on Kerry on the basis of a comment revolve
around what they think is a dirty word -- "lesbian", rather than
something that would actually hurt him.

Brilliant.


- Jeff


--
"I don't go out to be seen,
  I don't go out to show off,
  I go out to be a part of something I believe in."

vote on our November 2nd election day.

"Take Your Clothes Off When You Dance."
Frank Zappa


There will come a time when everybody
Who is lonely will be free...
To sing & dance & love

There will come a time when every evil
That we know will be an evil...
That we can rise above

Who cares if hair is long or short
Or sprayed or partly grayed...
We know that hair ain't where it's at

(there will come a time when you won't
Even be ashamed if you are fat!)

Wah wah-wah wah

There will come a time when everybody
Who is lonely will be free...
To sing & dance & love (dance and love)

There will come a time when every evil
That we know will be an evil...
That we can rise above (rise above)

Who cares if you're so poor you can't afford
To buy a pair of mod a go-go stretch-elastic pants...
There will come a time when you can even
Take your clothes off when you dance
...




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_1216599==.ALT--

<br>

In reading through this DOJ, (full disclosure, they're a present
client), document I picked up an interesting sub-text, which is though
the werd 'problem' is used throughout, the description of said
'problems' make them out to be practically non-existent from the point
of view of a street level, beat cop.

That practically leaps off the page.

I think any good cop, and they are still the majority of those that
protect us Citizens from each other, will see right through the BS,
not that, when push does come to shove, they aren't going to not do
their sworn jobs and uphold The Law.

Even one as odious as this.

It's going to be a long struggle, but I believe that we will
ultimately prevail, though it may take 20 years and at the end of it
the United States will no longer exist as we know it today.

This will be a good thing.

nwa

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Mobile phone 'ear tumours risk'

Wow!  This looks _really_ dangerous, everybody!  Quick, let's all get
rid of our cellphones; that'll prevent EM-induced cancer, right?=20
Unless we were to get it from our television, radio, CRT, cordless
phone, microwave, Wifi network, satellite TV, or any of the myriad
public safety, military, and commercial sources of radio and
microwaves that emit electro-magnetic radiation in quantities and
intensities far greater than what's being kicked out by your
cellphone...

(no offense intended, Apollo... just putting the issue in perspective...)

On Thu, 14 Oct 2004 16:14:05 -0700, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> Mobile phone 'ear tumours risk'
>=20
> Using a mobile phone for 10 years or more increases the risk of ear tumou=
rs
> by four times, research suggests.
>=20
> A 750-people study by Sweden's Karolinska Institute found the risk of
> acoustic neuroma rose by 3.9 times on the side of the head the phone is u=
sed.
>=20
> There was no increase in risk on the other side of the head - giving an
> overall rise in risk of 1.9 times.
>=20
> Acoustic neuroma is a benign tumour in the auditory nerve, which can caus=
e
> brain and nerve damage.
>=20
> It affects one in 100,000 people.
>=20
> Those who had used mobile phones for less than 10 years were not at a
> greater risk, the team reported.
>=20
> IOut of the 750 people who took part in the study, 150 had acoustic neuro=
ma
> and of those one in 11 had used a mobile phone for at least a decade.
>=20
> Professor Anders Ahlbom, from the Stockholm-based institute, told BBC New=
s
> Online he was "surprised" by his team's findings.
>=20
> "The results show there is a relatively substantial risk and we are hopin=
g
> others will follow up our research.
>=20
> "We do not know what is causing it but the risk certainly increases over
> time."
>=20
> He said he would not go as far as warning people not to use mobile phones=
.
>=20
> But he added: "If people are concerned the simple way to avoid risk is to
> use a hands-free kit.
>=20
> "Our researched showed that the risk is only on the side of the head on
> which the mobile phone is used."
>=20
> Risk
>=20
> At the time of the study only analogue mobile phones had been in use for
> more than 10 years.
>=20
> The majority of people now have digital (GSM) phones, which came on to th=
e
> market in the mid to late 1990s.
>=20
> Some of the people who took part in the study had used both analogue and
> digital phones. There was no evidence to suggest solely using digital
> phones for 10 years increased the risk.
>=20
> Dr Michael Clarke, a spokesman for the National Radiological Protection
> Board, the UK's advisory group, said it was a "good study from a well
> respected institute".
>=20
> He said: "It is suggestive rather than conclusive but we will obviously
> take it into account when we issue guidance in the future."
>=20
> And a spokeswoman for the Mobile Operators Association said: "The mobile
> phone industry takes very seriously questions relating to the safety of i=
ts
> products and is committed to addressing public concern in an open and
> transparent manner."
>=20
> But she added: "Individual studies must be seen in the light of the total
> research effort into mobile phone safety. There have been other recent
> studies that have failed to show any link between mobile phones and tumou=
rs."
>=20
> Three quarters of adults in the UK own or use a mobile phone.
>=20
> The mobile phone industry has always maintained there is no scientific
> evidence of negative effects from mobile phone use.
>=20
> But over the last few years experts have remained divided over the questi=
on
> of risk.
>=20
> A study by Finnish scientists in 2002 found electromagnetic radiation,
> which is emitted from mobile phones, affected human brain tissue.
>=20
> But the UK government-commissioned Stewart report in 2000 concluded there
> was no evidence of harm associated with using mobile phones.
>=20
> However, the report recommended a precautionary approach and said childre=
n
> should only use mobile phones in emergencies.
> Story from BBC NEWS:
> http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/2/hi/health/3742120.stm
>=20
> Published: 2004/10/14 10:12:10 GMT
>=20

>=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] USDOJ Problem-Oriented Guides for Police Series: No. 14: Rave Parties

Dustin De Wynde <nwa420@gmail.com> said...
> In reading through this DOJ, (full disclosure, they're a present
> client), document I picked up an interesting sub-text, which is though
> the werd 'problem' is used throughout, the description of said
> 'problems' make them out to be practically non-existent from the point
> of view of a street level, beat cop.
> 
> That practically leaps off the page.
> 
> I think any good cop, and they are still the majority of those that
> protect us Citizens from each other, will see right through the BS,
> not that, when push does come to shove, they aren't going to not do
> their sworn jobs and uphold The Law.

This has generally been the case in my 11yr experience with the
SFPD. They are pretty laid back, compared with most of the other PDs
in the bay area, and don't seem to have a predilection to harass
people when there's not really a problem.

If you're well organized, have someone sober and competent to meet
the cops and offer to deal with things, there isn't teenage
drinking, and the situation doesn't look obviously unsafe, SFPD will
generally let you get on with it. Occasionally you'll get the cop
who's going to shut you down no matter what, and there's nothing you
can really do about that. But usually, they're pretty reasonable.

I've been at a party in Sausalito that was busted because people
were talking too loudly on a balcony in a private residence!
Perfectly safe, fun event. And the cops were complete assholes,
right to the core.

SF has it so easy that way. I love SF :) :) :).

Sean

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  DUB TRIBE SOUND SYSTEM Farewell TOUR

--=====================_14572143==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

DUB TRIBE SOUND SYSTEM Farewell TOUR
Sat October 23rd 9pm
Veterans building 846 Front St. Santa Cruz

Little John  & Strydah will be opening the show

  Now Then lets take a walk back in time to a  Friday night Come-Unity 
party in San Francisco in some
smoke filled club in 1994. Who are these wild haired freaks playing the 
dirtiest grooviest acid house and
breakbeat I had ever heard. No they were not playing records they were 
playing samplers, sequencers, keys
live percussion and singing about love, freedom, revolution, and Mother Earth.

  Well needless to say I was my doors were blown open, never to be shut 
again. It marked a new eara of music
and a turning point in my life.

  Their music was so inspirational, their message powerful, and the 
production top notch. Over the years I began
to know the people behind the music. And it made all that much more 
beautiful and powerful.

  I / We have been honored to host four Dub Tribe shows here in Santa Cruz 
over the years. The first of which was
supposed to be at our original location were we threw The Deep at the end 
of the pier in Santa Cruz ,but as a
twist of fate would have it, the party got moved at the last minute to a 
biker bar called Skinny Mcdoogles that no longer
exists.

  The next show was done proper, this was still The Deep but it was now 
home at Palookaville ,which also no longer exists.
Doc Martin was also on the bill, but could not attend due to an illness. So 
we had Carlos do the opening set,nobody complained
about Doc's absence.

   The third was up into San Lorenzo Valley at Don Quixote's in Felton. 
This was the most memorable for me. I don't know why but
they were on FIRE this night, and the crowd was full tilt vibration.

    The last time they were here  we were further up in the Valley At the 
Brookdale Lodge. On this tour they had a full production crew
sound, lighting, stage scene, huge disco ball, and a locker full of elves 
that set everything up for them. It seemed like they had moved
into a new phase and level of production.

Now fast forward to 2004. Sunshine and Moonbeam are the proud parents of a 
3 year old baby boy. They are ready to settle in and
let the next faze of their life unfold.

We are quite honored that Dub Tribe wants to do one of their final shows 
here in Santa Cruz. If you have not seen them in the past
this will be your one and only opportunity to catch these pioneers of 
conscious electronic dance music

more on DUB TRIBE go to http://www.dubtribe.com/





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_14572143==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] USDOJ Problem-Oriented Guides for Police Series: No. 14: Rave Parties

	SF cops damned sure ought to be cool. They have a good thing going on. 
When you make in the neighborhood of $70,000 a year from the taxpayers, 
plus overtime, plus generous pension and benefits, plus being hired at 
good rates for off-duty security work for clubs and events trying not 
to get shut down, plus presumably a bit of graft here and there in some 
cases, why rock the boat?

	It would sure be nice if they would uphold the law, as stated in the 
Constitution, the highest law of the land, but most of them, most of 
the time, will follow orders and do as their superiors instruct 
instead. That's true in SF as well as elsewhere, so I wouldn't say that 
the SF cops are good, I'd say that cops elsewhere are often even worse.

			<<< Starchild >>>


On Saturday, October 16, 2004, at 02:00  PM, Sean Casey wrote:

> Dustin De Wynde <nwa420@gmail.com> said...
>> In reading through this DOJ, (full disclosure, they're a present
>> client), document I picked up an interesting sub-text, which is though
>> the werd 'problem' is used throughout, the description of said
>> 'problems' make them out to be practically non-existent from the point
>> of view of a street level, beat cop.
>>
>> That practically leaps off the page.
>>
>> I think any good cop, and they are still the majority of those that
>> protect us Citizens from each other, will see right through the BS,
>> not that, when push does come to shove, they aren't going to not do
>> their sworn jobs and uphold The Law.
>
> This has generally been the case in my 11yr experience with the
> SFPD. They are pretty laid back, compared with most of the other PDs
> in the bay area, and don't seem to have a predilection to harass
> people when there's not really a problem.
>
> If you're well organized, have someone sober and competent to meet
> the cops and offer to deal with things, there isn't teenage
> drinking, and the situation doesn't look obviously unsafe, SFPD will
> generally let you get on with it. Occasionally you'll get the cop
> who's going to shut you down no matter what, and there's nothing you
> can really do about that. But usually, they're pretty reasonable.
>
> I've been at a party in Sausalito that was busted because people
> were talking too loudly on a balcony in a private residence!
> Perfectly safe, fun event. And the cops were complete assholes,
> right to the core.
>
> SF has it so easy that way. I love SF :) :) :).
>
> Sean

BlankThis shindig will be rockpants like whoa....

Evil Breaks presents: DIRTY
Wednesday October 20th, 2004

Featuring:
Chris Carter (TCR/Botchit & Scarper/Sober/London,UK)

Chris Carter is a world renowned dj and producer, and since 1997 he has =
been releasing a steady stream of tough but musical breaks on the =
international scene and has earned a reputation as a master of well =
crafted dance floor tunes.

Check out a mix from Chris Carter:
http://www.nubreaks.com/audio/ram/CCarter_DJMix_Feb03.ram

With local support from:

Breaks Room:

A:Dubl (Breakthru)
Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks/AaronJae.com/Ill Behavior)
M.O.D. (Evil Breaks)
Influence (Evil Breaks/In tha Mix)

Progressive Room:

Jeffrey Allen (Fastvibes, Twisted Family SF, LOST | LA)
Hoj (Opel, DjHoj.com)
David Gropper (rnd()/Satellite/Looq)
Thomas Kent (Ill Behavior/Modified)

This event will be taking place at the beautiful Luna Lounge(1192 Folsom =
@ 8th) between the hours of 9pm and 2 am for just $5. Please come =
prepared to dance, as this night will be filled with irresistable beats.

more information:
www.EvilBreaks.com

DjHoj.com)<BR>David=20

beautiful Luna=20

beats.<BR><BR>more information:<BR><A=20

I hear that, but you know what?

If these people, or anyone else wants to run my country, with my
permission, part of my vetting process is damn well going to be to see
just how well they treat their own.

That goes for everybody that wants to sit in the highest office in the
land, period.

Their treatment strikes me, and many, both gay and straight, as about
the shabbiest fucking thing you can do to your own flesh and blood.

No gay person I know picked that for themselves, that's who they are
as a person and the Cheney's argument takes on a lot of water pretty
quickly when you stop to consider that Mary Cheney is not in the
background, but is pulling down $100k to work for the Bush/Cheney
Team.

These people are so fucking **cheap** they can't even lay on a decent bribe.

Where was their outrage when fellow Republican Alan Keyes, who himself
has a bi/lesbian daughter,  fucking full on assaulted her by saying
she's "a 'selfish hedonist' because she is a lesbian," less than 2
months ago?

I didn't hear them stick up for her then, but oh, right, that would
have spoiled their lovely convention in New York City.

Jesus christ, don't you get it?

These people eat their own, with relish, and if that's how they treat
their family then I don't want them fucking running my country.

I can't make it any simpler than that, and i've only been a registered
Democrat for the last 7 days.

Thanks!

peace out motherfuckers,

nwa

you if you are, not my style.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] The "Lesbian Daughter" Card

But Dick Cheney brought the subject up himself throughout his entire 
campaign in 2000. Mary is out, Dick brought it to the public himself
previously.

And now it's "inappropiate" to bring up a fact about your opponent's
daughter? The opinion of whether it was "inappropiate" or not entirely
depends on whether you consider "lesbian" a dirty word or not.

What if the debate question was about disability instead of
homosexuality, and Mary were blind instead, and Kerry said...

"if you were to talk to Dick Cheney's daughter, who is blind..."

Would that have been "inappropiate"? Obviously not. But somehow "lesbian" is.



What the Cheneys are complaining is basically that:

1. It's our daughter to cash in on, not Kerry's

2. It was OK for us to cash in on her during the last campaign and
make it  public knowledge, when we pretended to be moderate,
conpassionate conservatives.

3. Now that we re-oriented to the far-right neoconservatives like we
really were in the first place, we consider her being a lesbian a
private issue

4. we can't even say the word "lesbian"

Ultimately, it still changes nothing. You can believe it was
"inappropiate" only if you think "lesbian" is a dirty word, or believe
it was a "privacy issue" only if you can overlook that they made it a
public knowledge during the last campaign and now try to bury it
because of ideological reasons. They can keep crying wolf about how
"insensitive" Kerry was, when in reality anyone who's sensitive about
gay rights at all would never touch the Bush Administration with a
10-foot pole, and woudn't consider "lesbian" a dirty word in the first
place.

The only thing Kerry's comment was insensitive about is the Bush
Administration's neo-conservative ideology.


- Jeff

--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:

> DUB TRIBE SOUND SYSTEM Farewell TOUR
> Sat October 23rd 9pm
> Veterans building 846 Front St. Santa Cruz
> 
> Little John  & Strydah will be opening the show
> 
>   Now Then lets take a walk back in time to a 
> Friday night Come-Unity 
> party in San Francisco in some
> smoke filled club in 1994. Who are these wild haired
> freaks playing the 
> dirtiest grooviest acid house and
> breakbeat I had ever heard. No they were not playing
> records they were 
> playing samplers, sequencers, keys
> live percussion and singing about love, freedom,
> revolution, and Mother Earth.
> 
>   Well needless to say I was my doors were blown
> open, never to be shut 
> again. It marked a new eara of music
> and a turning point in my life.
> 
>   Their music was so inspirational, their message
> powerful, and the 
> production top notch. Over the years I began
> to know the people behind the music. And it made all
> that much more 
> beautiful and powerful.
> 
>   I / We have been honored to host four Dub Tribe
> shows here in Santa Cruz 
> over the years. The first of which was
> supposed to be at our original location were we
> threw The Deep at the end 
> of the pier in Santa Cruz ,but as a
> twist of fate would have it, the party got moved at
> the last minute to a 
> biker bar called Skinny Mcdoogles that no longer
> exists.
> 
>   The next show was done proper, this was still The
> Deep but it was now 
> home at Palookaville ,which also no longer exists.
> Doc Martin was also on the bill, but could not
> attend due to an illness. So 
> we had Carlos do the opening set,nobody complained
> about Doc's absence.
> 
>    The third was up into San Lorenzo Valley at Don
> Quixote's in Felton. 
> This was the most memorable for me. I don't know why
> but
> they were on FIRE this night, and the crowd was full
> tilt vibration.
> 
>     The last time they were here  we were further up
> in the Valley At the 
> Brookdale Lodge. On this tour they had a full
> production crew
> sound, lighting, stage scene, huge disco ball, and a
> locker full of elves 
> that set everything up for them. It seemed like they
> had moved
> into a new phase and level of production.
> 
> Now fast forward to 2004. Sunshine and Moonbeam are
> the proud parents of a 
> 3 year old baby boy. They are ready to settle in and
> let the next faze of their life unfold.
> 
> We are quite honored that Dub Tribe wants to do one
> of their final shows 
> here in Santa Cruz. If you have not seen them in the
> past
> this will be your one and only opportunity to catch
> these pioneers of 
> conscious electronic dance music
> 
> more on DUB TRIBE go to http://www.dubtribe.com/
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> 
> House Music 101: 
>
http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> 
> "The government, which was designed for the people,
> has got into the hands 
> of the bosses and their employers, the special
> interests.  An invisible 
> empire has been set up above the forms of
> democracy."
> -Woodrow Wilson
> 
> "There are times when you have to obey a call which
> is the highest of all, 
> i.e. the voice of conscience even though such
> obedience may cost many a 
> bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends,
> from family, from the 
> state to which you may belong, from all that you
> have held as dear as life 
> itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
>    Gandhi

> organization are ahead of the 
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that
> will gradually become 
> visible."

like 7 oyster shooters & talked w/ this Awesome like

place was hella shwankie man...

I ended up getting like really drunk

Groovy people I kicked it w/ Thurs night... LoL

like totally planned on going 2gether... & Sat I got
dropped off @ his house... LoL.. Hello 2Day... Homeboy
has the fuckin' Dopest collection of vinyl & I swear
man... it was this mondo listening party we were havin'
@ his pad!!  So Dope! "We're the kids of America" :P

up, & vinyl mania, we went 2 TELIC 4 "Let There Be=20
Rave".... Oh yeah... SEcurity there is like way much
more better mondo Groovy now... LoL, well, alota them
are Raver Homies & they're all fuckin' CooL people!

up I guess.. but then, Oh My Goodness, Oh My Gosh
man... JUNGLE a la The Natural Disasters aka The Doctor
&  Reclipse.. Nice Nice Nice set!!!  Perfect way 2
start of the evening!!  Loved it!!  Their set was like
just a nice yummy hard jungle set, I feel like using
the term "Jump Up DNB", but I dunno if that's the
correct like term 'cause this past year  I been well..
la la la... but man.. I danced my ass off.. Loved it!
Oh Oh Oh Oh.. The Doctor was dancing.. So Dope!

The Nice Guys went on Next.. lol... these scary Dudes
who were wearing like rubber masks who ended up being
grrrr... who were they again??? Anywaze, Man, they
played this So Dope HHC set.. Yummy!

like Wow... another Yummy HHC set... Hello 2Day... he
spun 1 of my fave songs "Heart Of Gold" & I was soooooo
in Heaven!

OK... now Brisk went on.. YAY.. My UK Homie!!  LoL.. it
was a Dope set... he did alota switching off w/ his set
between HHC & Hardcore... Hello 2Day, he spun this like
Hardcore Remake of Queen "WE Will Rock You".. Loved
it!!  I mean.. all in all man.. I Loved his set & how
he just was in2 it man...LoL... I mean.. usual DJ like
behind the decks gestures, but this Dude's my Big Bro &
like I mean.. I Love watching all my Homeboys &
Homegirls rock it behind the decks 'cause it's like u
hella feed of their energy, ya know!!  Wait... that
goes w/ any DJ I guess, but more like funner when it's
some1 up there spinning who you're hella tight w/,
yeah... LoL!

I guess he had like alota studio tracks not on vinyl
yet stuff 'cause he played his whole set on CDs!  Fun
Fun =3D)

Then like Tronic went on after him.. it was strait
hardcore his whole set!  Dope!!  He did play a few like
Vocal hardcore tracks that I was mondo diggin'!

I mean.. after this point I was like kickin' it w/
Brisk most the whole time after his set... OK.. see,
like right now, I'm soooooo fuckin' mondo after party
high still 'cause well.. OK.. yeah.. I LOVED all the
music I Grooved 2, but OK.. so when i 1st like was
hangin' in the office w/ Brisk, OK... U know those like
big plastic red cups, right? Well, Homeboy fuckin'
poured me 2 & a 1/2 filled cups with Vodka, LoL, &
dared me to shoot them down w/in 30 seconds.. yeah...
that got me kinda toasted after that & it was funny!

OK.. &Y I totally have 2 share this 'cause this is like
part of the reason I'm like still hardcore afterglowin'
(no pun intented)... so like yeah, in the past few
times he came out 2 the Bay Area, we partied hard &
stuff, & we like always KIT on the computer, but man...
we had this mondo like Heart 2 Heart conversation
lastnight 'cause he told me that he always worries
about me & stuff & hopes I'm taking care of myself... I
mean... He fuckin' schooled me while we were drunk &
well... it was hella touching man 'cause like LoL... I
dunno... I"m still like kinda feelin' hella fluffy from
the whole thing still... LoL..

JonnyR was like right there 4 3/4ths of Brisk talkin' 2
me about this & that & stuff & Jonny... it means
soooooo much 2 me that U were there 4 that Dude!  Brisk
even told Jonny 2 look out 4 me & make sure I"m takin'
care of myself... LoL.. OK.. Hello 2Day.. I"m sooooo
"Emo" right now still from what happened!  LoL  It was
So Dope! So Dope! YAY!  Jonny, Thanks 4 Everything
Dude! =3D)

Oh oh oh.. OK... so like Val Spark's set was Dope!!=20
All Anthems & she played 1 of my Mondo fave HHC songs,
I think it's called "Til The Break Of Dawn"

OK.. I knowq this is getting long, so OK.. the Vibe was
Awesome.. I met soo many Groovy People!  Hung out w/
alota Bro's & Sistas! Decorations minimal as usual on
the walls w/ banners here & there & there &
lazers...Wow.. so much fun!  LoL

Take Care,

Subject: [sfraves] You have the right to vote!

- Are you registered, but your name is not on the voting list?
- Have you been told you went to the wrong precinct, but don't know how
to find your correct voting place?
- Has someone tried to stop you from going to the polls, or tried to
intimidate you?
- Has someone tried to help you fill out your ballot?
- Are you confused about the actual voting day?

Election Protection can help.  Election Protection is a nonpartisan
coalition of civil rights and civic organizations committed to
protecting your right to cast your ballot.  Their hotline,
1-866-OUR-VOTE (1-866-687-8683) is an immediate, on-the-spot resource
staffed by lawyers and law students trained to resolve your problem.
If you have ANY problems casting your ballot, call them.  They can help!



http://www.jcthedj.com
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

(I wrote this last night on the Rave Act and its general implications
to another list I'm on and it turned out better than I thought, so I'm
cross-posting it here...thanks!)

What I love is the selective enforcement that the Rave Act affords
our Powers That Be....

The President whined about steroid abuse in major league sports this
past January in his State of the Union Address and I'm like that is
such horse-hockey, you already have the Rave Act on the books, why not
apply it to, oh, say, the owner of the San Francisco Giants, if it
turns out that Barry Bonds was enhancing his performance that way?

Oh, right, that would really fuck your,
sedate-the-masses-with-your-modern-day-version-of-Bread-&-Circuses,
shit up

Or, better yet, throw George Steinbrenner in a Federal Gulag for 10-20
years, take the day's gate money, the team, and lay a hefty fine on
his ass, if it
turns out that he may have been "knowing or having reason to know" and
reasonably aware that his players were trying to get an edge and
resorted to using illegal and banned substances to help them keep
their multi-million dollar jobs.

Actually, that one would make a lot of New York Yankee fans and New
York Yankee haters both pretty fucking happy.

All kidding aside, once a society starts passing laws like the Rave
Act it's only a matter of time until that society starts lining people
of an artistic temperment, such as are found in our rave community, up
against the wall and shooting them.

That is after they've werked their way through their mentally ill,
alcoholic, addicted, homeless, infirm, elderly & chronically ailing
and otherwise disabled.

In 1930's Germany people in those categories were called "useless
eaters," and they were eliminated from their society by degree long
before they got around to slaughtering the Jewish People.

The modern day US equivalent of such language that you hear daily
would be "homeless crackhead," "dirty hippy," "welfare queen," or it
'*costs* too much' to help that person.'

Phrases like that get bandied about every day here on the web and
elsewhere in the US.

The genocide of the Jewish people was just the tail-end of a long,
on-going process.

We've already seen a large percentage of the United States's mentally
ill population freeze to death in our streets over the course of the
last 20 years, so, being that we've kinda run out of them to kill in
cold blood, and we're still very hungry for more blood, to the point
of being insatiable, we're going to move on to the elderly and infirm
next, if the Medicare Bill that passed last year is any indication of
where all this shit is heading.

They took out the Gypsies, probably that society's closest equivalent
of us Ravers, before they exterminated Jews and if there is any truth
to "the US has morphed into Naszi Germany" meme, then this set of Rave
Act laws and bills seems to be right on time, going off of that
schedule.

Pretty grim sounding I know.

My grandfather was a Preacher and he & others saw it coming and tried
to do something about it, which nearly cost him his life, but he knew
Russian and they at the time needed him more than he needed them, so
instead of short visit to his friendly, local, nieghborhood Death
Camp, he got to go to the Eastern Front and help them figure out
Stalin was up to.

He got really lucky, and now, 75 years or so later, as his grandkid, i
see the same shit happening here and I'm nowhere near as gifted and
connected, (Thomas Mann was a personal friend and he translated the
werks of Kirkegaard into German), as he was, nor do I have a position
of respect in the community as he did, nobody's coming down to *my*
Church this weekend, (where's the damned 'recessive gene theory' when
you really need it, huh?), and I despair of being able to do anything
like he did to push back the tide.

It's fucking hard enough for me to being taken seriously in this
milieu, the closest thing the US has to a 'bohemian intelligentsia,'
you should see how well I do in mainstream American Society.

:P

On the other hand, it is encouraging that so many people here in the
States *are* speaking out in a way that they just weren't doing in
that by-gone era, so there is that.

The future is not written.

Biggest issue around the Rave Act that's already been stealth-passed
as a rider to the Amber Bill, a year ago April, is that while protests
and rallies such as ROAR have their heart in the right place, they
aren't going to do a damned thing to get that law overturned.

That time has passed as soon as Bush signed it into Law.

In order for that to happen, somebody has to get ARRESTED and then
challenge it up the chain and have the US Supreme Court throw it out
as Unconstitutional.

Who wants to go first?

My guess is is that now that it's on the books it's going to take a
minimum of 20 years for this law to get overturned and some bad shit
is going to happen in the meantime, if things keep going the way they
are.

This is not to say that we should not fight the impending passage of
these new bills with every full measure of energy and devotion that we
can collectively muster.

So do what ROAR suggests, and if you can afford it, throw a few bucks
their way to help them help you out.

Bill O'Reilly isn't looking out for you, but they are.

Who knows, if we keep our eye on the ball from this point on, we might
be able to push back and reverse this shit before it becomes too late
for all of us.

But keep your bags packed just in case, and keep a low profile otherwise

nwa

(myself and my boyfriend) are strict vegetarians, Buddhist and share a room.=
 We=E2=80=99
re also both students (me- Neurobiology at Berkeley, my boyfriend- Industria=
l=20
Design at Academy of Art) so we=E2=80=99re very considerate of the need for=20=
a good=20
studying environment (as we would hope from you as well). However, we=E2=80=
=99re all also=20
really outgoing and enjoy each other=E2=80=99s company, so we=E2=80=99ve kno=
wn to have a=20
party every once and a while when it=E2=80=99s right for our schedules.


What we would love:

We=E2=80=99re hoping for someone who is vegetarian, student or has a steady=20=
job,=20
around our age and a good mix between sensible, responsible and considerate=20=
and=20
outgoing, unique, and open-minded. We=E2=80=99re also all really clean so th=
at=E2=80=99s a=20
must. We=E2=80=99ll take male or female, though I would love another female=20=
in the house=20
after living with three boys! We currently have a cat, two cockatiels, and s=
ome=20
sweet chickens (so expect fresh organic eggs every morning), thus we would=20
prefer someone without any pets, since we have so many already. However, it=20=
may=20
be negotiable depending upon how much we absolutely adore you and how much o=
f=20
an impact the animal will make on the house. Sorry, no cigarette smokers.

Rent is $500 a month, which includes garbage. The owners also pay 20% of our=
=20
water bill during the warmer months to help with the cost of maintaining the=
=20
outdoor areas.

E-mail me back if it sounds like you fit the bill and would enjoy living wit=
h=20
us so we can set up a time to meet. : )

Subject: [sfraves] News: KRS One Rebuttal To NY Daily News Article

--0-710776231-1098136472=:31179
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE


(ORIGINAL Daily News ARTICLE TEXT BELOW @ end of REBUTTAL)

KRS One Rebuttal To NY Daily News Article

Like everyone I was shocked to read that I and other African-Americans=20
actually "cheered when 911 happened" and that I have "declared my=20
solidarity with Al Qaeda". When I read my words taken out of context I was=
=20
shocked and disappointed that the Daily News would go this far to=20
assassinate my character and distort my views.

Such statements with no follow up explanation or interview from KRS-ONE as=
=20
to what he may have meant or even a complete quote of my point is simply=20
irresponsible journalism on the Daily News' part. I would never just say=20
something as crazy as "we cheered when 911 happened!" I was making an=20
objective point about how many Hiphoppas as well as the oppressed peoples=
=20
of the world felt that day.

I am a philosopher and a critical thinker, I speak truth and I urge people=
=20
to think critically about themselves and their environment. Yes, my words=
=20
are strong. Yes, my views are controversial. But to call me a terrorist is=
=20
simply wrong!

A young lady asked about what we can do beyond voting to change the=20
political state of things in our country? I responded not by irresponsibly=
=20
stating that "America has to commit suicide if the world is to be a better=
=20
place" and that's all. I am a poet and I speak poetically. My full=20
statement was "America has to commit suicide if the world is to be a=20
better place".

If you want to go beyond voting American interests must put a gun to its=20
head and commit suicide because as long as we are only interested in=20
American interests we go out and invade the rest of the world. The real=20
question is are you a citizen of the United States or are you a citizen of=
=20
the world? And so for me, I would say voting in a corrupt society adds=20
more corruption.

I was asked by the New Yorker magazine to discuss "different and personal=
=20
beliefs musicians hold and the contribution artists like myself can make=20
to the nation's political dialog". My views were indeed different and most=
=20
were personal. However, when I was asked about why Hiphop has not engaged=
=20
the current situation more (meaning 911) my responds was "because it does=
=20
not affect us, or at least we don't perceive that it effects us, 911=20
happened to them". I went on to say that "I am speaking for the culture=20
now; I am not speaking my personal opinion" I continued to say;" 911=20
effected them down the block; the rich, the powerful those that are=20
oppressing us as a culture. Sony, RCA or BMG, Universal, the radio=20
stations, Clear Channel, Viacom with BET and MTV, those are our oppressors=
=20
those are the people that we're trying to overcome in Hiphop everyday,=20
this is a daily thing. We cheered when 911 happened in New York and say=20
that proudly here. Because when we were down at the trade center we were=20
getting hit over the head by cops, told that we can't come in this=20
building, hustled down to the train station because of the way we dressed=
=20
and talked, and so on, we were racially profiled. So, when the planes hit=
=20
the building we were like; mmmm justice". And just as I began to say "now=
=20
of course a lot of our friends and family were lost there as well," but I=
=20
was interrupted.

My intent is never to demean or disrespect anyone's loss or gain; and of=20
course I did not literally "cheer when 911 happened". I made an objective=
=20
statement about the feelings of those who were oppressed by world trade=20
policies. I was just as saddened as everyone else on 911. However, for=20
many of us that were racially profiled and harassed by the World's Trade=20
Center's security and the police patrolling that area as well as the=20
thousands of American protesters that spoke out against the World Trade=20
Organization months before in Seattle, Washington there was a sense of=20
justice, a sense of change, a wake up call watching the twin towers fall.

These are not my views only; these views represent a popular truth that=20
few people are really ready to hear. No one wished death on anyone or just=
=20
sat and "cheered when 911 happened". But some of us can see through the=20
bullshit! America must change its approach to the world and its citizens.=
=20
This, I believe is what all Americans should be thinking about. How do we=
=20
make our country better?

For years my career has been one of promoting peace, love, unity and=20
having fun; such has always been Hiphop=92s cultural principles. So how all=
=20
of a sudden now can I be aligned with Al Qaeda? What happened to honest=20
debate and freedom of speech! I don't speak for the African American=20
community exclusively, I speak for HIPHOP! And let me be clear here; most=
=20
of the Hiphop community is against the war in Iraq! But to align me with=20
Al Qaeda is clearly an attempt by the Daily News to interrupt the street=20
voice of our Hiphop community, KRS-ONE's leadership and the increased=20
momentum of our Hiphop political movement.

I don't think Al Qaeda needs my solidarity nor did I ever offer it, so=20
what's the point. For a major news organization to now align KRS-ONE with=
=20
Al Qaeda shows the unwarranted contempt that such an organization has for=
=20
me. Such is grounds for a law suit!

Finally, no one should ever believe anything that the one-sided Daily News=
=20
has to say about the same Hiphop community that it (the Daily News) has=20
tried so desperately to undermine for years. The only thing the Daily News=
=20
seems to be interested in is scandal and controversy and for years I have=
=20
challenged the Daily News on its depictions of Rap artists and Hiphop as a=
=20
whole.

I know they don't like me. However, I don't give a ---- either! They never=
=20
cover our efforts toward peace and all the charitable work we do within=20
the Hiphop community. They never air our grievances or how we feel about=20
the state of the world, nor have they ever aired our views on America's=20
invasion of Iraq simply because they just don't want to hear them. The=20
Hiphop community forces America to look at itself; and no one likes to=20
take b.l.a.m.e. for their own for immaturity Because Looking At Me ain't=20
Easy!

For the record, I am an American philosopher. I speak and seek truth. If=20
the slander that the Daily News has printed regarding my political views=20
has disrespectfully offended anyone in any way I truly apologize. Again,=20
it was never my or Hiphop's intent to disregard, disrespect or demean the=
=20
tragedy of September 11th 2001 and those that died that day.

However, we do have a voice and a point of view and if you are not=20
prepared to hear what Hiphop has to say about its view of world events=20
then don't ask!

KRS-One

Original Article (Printed in the NY Daily News):

KRS-One: Blacks 'cheered when 9-11 happened'

Knight Ridder Newspapers
Oct. 14, 2004 03:08 PM

If Osama bin Laden ever buys a rap album, he'll probably start with a CD=20
by KRS-One.

The hip-hop anarchist has declared his solidarity with al-Qaida by=20
asserting that he and other African-Americans "cheered when 9-11=20
happened," reports the New York Daily News.

The rapper, real name Kris Parker, defiled the memory of those who died in=
=20
the terrorist attacks as he spouted off at a recent New Yorker Festival=20
panel discussion.

  "I say that proudly," the Boogie Down Productions founder went on,=20
insisting that, before the attack, security guards kept Blacks out of the=
=20
World Trade Center "because of the way we talk and dress.

"So when the planes hit the building, we were like, 'Mmmm - justice.' "

The atrocity of 9-11 "doesn't affect us the hip-hop community," he said.=20
"9-11 happened to them, not us," he added, explaining that by "them" he=20
meant "the rich ... those who are oppressing us. RCA or BMG, Universal,=20
the radio stations."

Parker also sneered at efforts by other rappers to get young people to=20
vote.

"Voting in a corrupt society adds more corruption," he added. "America has=
=20
to commit suicide if the world is to be a better place."

--=20

	boundary="=====================_11288181==.ALT"

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  All the Worlds a Stage: Bringing Hip-Hop to the Theater

--=====================_11288181==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



All the World's a Stage: Bringing Hip-Hop to the Theater




By Desiree Evans, WireTap
Posted on October 18, 2004, Printed on October 18, 2004


In the first act, the dancers' movements are slow, calculated. The lights 
focus in on the stage to highlight the sinuous muscles of the three men 
rising and turning in an avant-garde mix of movement over break beat. The 
textured lights follow a narrative of fluid motions that seem to mimic a 
ship at sea, a journey taken from break dancing to modern dance. The 
dancers, members of the Philadelphia-based 
<http://pennpat.org/artist_results.asp?id=149>olive Dance Theater, are 
performing a production of Olive, an original multimedia narrative. In this 
performance dance takes a fantastical journey through the art of b-boyin.'

When the lights come on, they shine on an audience that many may not 
consider your typical theater-going crowd. They are young (many are 
teenagers and under the age of 30) and primarily youth of color. After the 
show some gather outdoors in corners freestyling, while others comment on 
the performance.

Thus began the third Annual 
<http://www.hiphoptheaterfest.com/home.html>Hip-Hop Theater Festival in 
Washington, D.C. This festival, which was founded by 
<http://www.dannyhoch.com/>Danny Hoch, Kamilah Forbes and Clyde Valentin in 
New York in 2000 (then in in D.C three years ago and San Francisco last 
year), has evolved into the nation's most comprehensive and influential 
display of Hip-Hop aesthetics­showcasing solo and ensemble dance pieces and 
plays, as well as workshops and panels. According to critics, the 
festival's popularity with a younger crowd symbolizes Hip-Hop's movement 
from margin to center stage in contemporary theater.

Once a movement of the underground, "Hip-Hop Theater" has burst onto the 
stages of the mainstream, blurring the line between high and low cultur. As 
one of the organizations that has brought the movement to the forefront, 
the Hip-Hop Theater Festival's mission is to present and support live 
performances by artists who stretch, invent and combine a variety of 
theatrical forms, including dance, spoken word and live music sampling to 
express the diversity of the human experience through Hip-Hop culture. 
While supporting the production of Hip-Hop theater-based work, the festival 
also designs and implements programs that address the socio-political 
issues impacting their target audience­underserved urban youth spanning the 
ages of 12 to 35.

This year's artists mean business. Marc Bamuthi Joseph performs "Word 
Becomes Flesh," a series of performed letters to an unborn son in which he 
uses poetry, dance, live music and visual art to document nine months of 
pregnancy from a single father's perspective. This runs alongside 
<http://www.ayadeleon.com/>Aya de Leon's Hip-Hop feminist manifesto, 
"Thieves in the Temple." Her show is described as a battle cry for 
grassroots Hip-Hop consumers and creators, particularly women. Tackling 
similar, complex issues is Chad Boseman, the director of "Deep Azure," a 
play that addresses the concepts of abuse, brutality and redemption.

Then there's Full Circle Productions, a nonprofit entertainment company 
that graces the stage utilizing DJing, breakin', MCing, spoken word and 
dance, all infused in Latino and African American youth culture. Its 
founders, who worked their way from the outdoor performances of street 
shows, now reach large audiences touring internationally at festivals like 
this one.

Full Circle's artistic director, Gabriel "Kwikstep" Dionisio, says that not 
much has changed in how they approach their shows. "We're just street 
performing to stage," he says, adding that he was trained in an art that 
has been passed down through generations. "The social exchange is a village 
experience," says Kwikstep. "[You] go into cipher or circle and learn it."

Redefining Aesthetics

These Artists see Hip-Hop Theater as being at the center of a global youth 
culture. But this generation is not alone in calling for an aesthetics that 
encompasses their experience. When Danny Hoch called for "theater that is 
by, for, and about the Hip-Hop generation" he echoed the words of W.E.B. 
Dubois, who called for "theater by, for, about and near" African Americans 
in the 1920s. The revolutionary aesthetics of the Black Arts Movement (the 
artistic arm of the 60s Black Power Movement) created artistic work that 
took on the struggle for socioeconomic, racial, gender and sexual equality 
(inspiring artists such as Amiri Baraka, Sonia Sanchez, the Last Poets and 
Ntozake Shange). Many of these movements were in tangent with cultural and 
musical revolutions (August Wilson's plays were informed by the blues and 
Ntozake Shange's work was informed by jazz).

"We are not reinventing the wheel. Just look at our history," says Daniel 
Banks, a New York University drama professor who helped to create the 
educational parts of the Hip-hop Theater Festival.

The rituals today known as Hip-Hop were birthed in the post-60s climate of 
New York's inner city neighborhoods, sprouting from the lives of the people 
who lived there. A collage of art forms­graffiti, emceeing, break dancing, 
turntablism­reclaimed public spaces by turning inner city walls into art 
galleries, street corners and parks into dance clubs, and turntables into 
technological inversion as symphonic as any saxophone.

Hip-Hop Theater was shaped on the streets and then nurtured in community 
performing arts centers and on college campuses, outside of the modes of 
mainstream funders and foundations like the National Endowment for the 
Arts. But is goes back even further than that.

"We are rooted in music and are practitioners of an ancient tradition," 
says performer Marc Bamuthi Joseph.

The use of Hip-Hop aesthetics continues to define this cultural continuum. 
"[Hip-Hop] is just this generation's relation to sound­Black people and the 
drum. [We] move from sound to rhythm to text," says Joseph. "We move, 
speak, dance in folkloric traditions We are folkloric traditionsour art is 
interdisciplinary, a mythological method."

Playwright and actor Chad Boseman sees Hip-Hop Theater as ritual, as well. 
"We are taking it back to what it was in the beginning­a ritual, a 
reenacting of what is in front of you, a myth happening," Boseman says. He 
adds that you can't box Hip-Hop in because "when you do that it is no 
longer Hip-Hop."

"If our art is not evolving us, then it's oppressing us," Boseman 
maintains. "When an emcee is on stage, some people say its not theater. But 
it is. It's just not Western. We are griots; we are reclaiming this [art] 
in our indigenous forms. We want to take theater beyond what people 
normally see."

U.K.-based artist Benji Reid calls the work he does in Hip-Hop Theater the 
marriage between "movement and language and the power of storytelling." 
Reid tries to use the language of breakin' to signify emotion and to speak. 
"It is about how to tell stories of all the suffering in a new context to 
tell stories of suicide, redemption, rites of passage," Reid says.

"Hip-Hop Theater is the prose of Hip-Hop," says performer Aya de Leon. 
"Some of us have craved to tell the longer story. The stories of people 
trying to transform their circumstances."

De Leon also points out that women have a strong presence in Hip-Hop 
Theater, if not in other elements of Hip-Hop. But the combination of the 
two (Hip hop and theater) has created new spaces for women. "I felt like I 
was coming in the backdoor of Hip-Hop," she says.

She underscores that her work is about reexamining Hip-Hop. "I grew up on 
Hip-Hop and it's my voice. So now I can reclaim my voice and look at how 
sexism plays a role in discouraging voice," she says. She wants to be an 
example of Hip-Hop Theater for a new generation of women coming up. "There 
is a demand for women's voices not being filled in other media Hip-Hop 
Theater is a place for this."

Performing a Generation

The idea to call it "Hip-Hop Theater" came about in 1999, at the National 
Black Theater Festival in Winston-Salem, NC. Since then, these festivals 
have reached out to nontraditional theater audiences, such as young people 
who may not identify with the world of theater, but who do identity with 
Hip-Hop.

Kamilah Forbes, the festival's artistic director, sees the art form as an 
evolution of our generation speaking in a way they need to speak. "There is 
always contention about what Hip-Hop Theater is. It has an energy, a 
spirit, something transcendent," she says. The actress, director and 
playwright, adds that Hip-Hop Theater is "a growing aesthetic, defining and 
developing itself."

Although Hip-Hop Theater can trace its origins to the do-it-yourself 
mentality of this generation, its influence has hit the mainstream 
recently, winding its way into a steady flow of Broadway and off-Broadway 
productions. (Think of Sean "P. Diddy" Combs playing Walter Lee Younger in 
A Raisin in the Sun, Regina Taylor's Drowning Crow and MC/actor Mos Def in 
Suzan-Lori Parks's Pulitzer-winning Topdog/Underdog). Much of today's 
Hip-Hop Theater can find its origins in the spoken word movement that 
rocked coffee houses in the late 1990s. Russell Simmons' Tony-award winning 
Def Poetry Jam is one such influence. Spoken word champion and "Hip-Hop 
poet" Reg E. Gaines also introduced the Hip-Hop aesthetic to a vast 
mainstream audience in the early '90s when he penned the poetic phrases 
behind the Broadway hit, "Bring in da Noise, Bring in da Funk."

Hip-Hop theater artists often bring underrepresented voices to the stage, 
such as Danny Hoch (whose Jails, Hospitals and Hip-Hop combines 
beat-boxing, deejaying, spoken-word poetry and rap to tell the stories of 
multiple characters living in the inner-city) and Hanifah Walidah (whose 
"Straight Black Folks' Guide to Gay Black Folks" tackles sexuality in the 
Black community). Other artists make their impact in choreography, like 
Jonzi D and Rennie Harris (Puremovement of Philadelphia); in ensembles, 
such as Universes and I Was Born With Two Tongues; in solo acts, such as 
Danny Hoch, Sarah Jones, Will Power, Caridad de la Luz, Marc Bamuthi 
Joseph, Liza Colon-Zayas, Teo Castellanos and Mariposa; and in playwriting, 
like Ben Snyder, Kris Diaz, Eisa Davis, Chad Boseman, Candido Tirado and 
Kamilah Forbes.

"Harlem Renaissance writer James Weldon Johnson once said that history 
judges a race by the quality of its literature and art. If jazz and 
modernism are the formal legacies of his generation, Hip-Hop may be one of 
the formal legacies of ours. Content may never change, stories always stay 
the same, but new forms alter consciousness, actually change the way we 
imagine ourselves," playwright Eisa Davis said in an article for the 
Theater Communications Group.

Indeed, this generation of artists is a generation much like Hip-Hop itself 
­ one that reshapes, reflects and remixes the past and innovates toward the 
future. It is a generation that finds its voice in a variety of 
languages­visual, music, dance and poetry.

Kwikstep says Hip-Hop Theater is a start, but there will be a day to "just 
let go... it will not be Hip-Hop Theater anymore just theater."


© 2004 Independent Media Institute. All rights reserved.




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] Israel decriminalises ecstasy

Since drug war (in any country) should be important, and this is a 
club/rave drug.  I thought some of you might be interested.

-maz


http://www.inthemix.com.au/news/intl/18011/

Israel.s Justice Ministry announced this week that people caught in
possession of up to five ecstasy pills will no longer face prosecution,
and explained that the change is .a case of adapting legislation to meet
reality. (Ha'aretz, Jerusalem).

However, the Ministry stressed that possession of even one pill will still
be technically a crime and explained the new category of .personal use. is
designed to distinguished between users and suppliers.

The change coincided with the publication of a report in the UK by leading
civil liberties organisation Transform which predicted that all drugs will
be legalised in the UK by 2020.

"Drugs will be legalised in the not too distant future because prohibition
is an ongoing catastrophe Click Here of startling proportions," Transform
director Danny Kushlick said as he unveiled the report, titled .After the
War on Drugs, Options for Control', at a presentation at Britain.s Houses
Of Parliament.

"We need to consider more effective, just and humane options," he
continued. "In the UK, the prison population and property crime would be
halved, drug related prostitution would end, opportunities for organised
crime would reduce substantially, prohibition related corruption would
disappear and drug turf wars would end," he said.

The .drug policy road map report. was immediately dismissed by British
Home Office officials though was endorsed by a number of MPs and
influential Brits including former Times editor Simon Jenkins.

From sfraves-return-116528-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Oct 20 01:47:14 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-116528-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 56788 invoked by uid 1103); 20 Oct 2004 01:47:13 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 56767 invoked from network); 20 Oct 2004 01:47:12 -0000
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 2004 18:50:16 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v553)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-Id: <642793AE-223A-11D9-82AD-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Libertarian Party of San Francisco recommendations on local candidates & ballot measures

U.S. Representative, district 8: no recommendation.  There is no
Libertarian candidate in this race, though Republican Jennifer DePalma
sought our recommendation.  While there was wide feeling that her 
positions
on most economic and social issues were good, her support for the U.S.
military action in Iraq was considered unacceptable.  (DePalma: 2 
votes; no
recommendation: 8 votes.)

U.S. Representative, district 12: Libertarian candidate Harland Harrison
(unanimous endorsement).  Harland is a Libertarian activist for peace,
human rights, and civil liberties.  His top priorities in Congress 
include
ending the war in Iraq and bringing the troops home, dismantling the USA
PATRIOT Act, and reducing spending to balance the federal budget every 
year.

State Senate, district 3: Libertarian candidate David Rhodes (unanimous
endorsement).  Dave has been an active member of the Libertarian Party 
for
several years.  His top priorities are to reduce regulations on small
businesses, end the War on Drugs, and to balance the state budget.

State Assembly, district 12: Libertarian candidate Chris Maden 
(unanimous
endorsement).  A ten-year member of the Libertarian Party, and currently
Chair of the San Francisco party, Chris's top priorities in Sacramento 
are
a dollar-for-dollar tax credit to shift charity from a government 
function
to personal and community activity, and returning state government to 
the
hands of a part-time legislature.

State Assembly, district 13: Libertarian candidate Jonathan Scott Marvin
(unanimous endorsement).  Jonathan would work to decentralize state
government, move funding for state projects from taxation to fees, and
introduce tax cuts starting with the lowest tax brackets.

Board of Supervisors, district 5: Jim Siegel (recommendation).  In the
heart of San Francisco's so-called "progressive" district 5, there is 
one
candidate who understands that government is the enemy of progress.  
While
not completely libertarian, Jim, a small business owner and landlord, 
would
work to reduce government interference with property ownership and 
business
operation.  The chief reservation was with his fondness for using
historical preservation laws to save neighborhood character; however, he
also understands private approaches to preservation, and notably raised
private money to save the former site of the libertarian bookstore at 
1800
Market, now part of the LGBT Community Center.  (Siegel: 7 votes; none 
of
the above: 1 vote; no recommendation: 1 vote.)

[There was no recommendation for any other supervisory district, nor for
any other candidates in district 5.]

Board of Education: Libertarian candidate Starchild (unanimous
endorsement).  Starchild is perhaps the most well-known ambassador of
Libertarianism in San Francisco.  While we believe that the government
should not be in the education business, Starchild has an innovative
proposal to decentralize the school district's management and spark
competition between schools.  This should raise the quality of the
government schools and reduce the cost, while setting the stage for
conversion to a free-market educational system.

[There were no recommendations for any other Board of Education 
candidates,
nor for any Community College Board candidates.]

Proposition A: NO (unanimous recommendation).  Proposition A is a $200
million bond issue for building and renovating "affordable housing".  
Every
property tax increase worsens the housing situation in San
Francisco.  Imposing such a tax to help the housing situation is
oxymoronic; housing needs will be better served by reducing taxation and
regulation.

Proposition B: NO (unanimous recommendation).  Proposition B is a $60
million bond issue for protecting city-owned historical resources.  If 
the
resources are worth protecting, a fund-raising drive is the appropriate
means of restoring them; private foundations do very good work at this 
kind
of job.  In contrast, government tends to do a very poor job, and
Proposition B contains no guarantees as to which sites will get the 
money
from the bonds.

Proposition C: NO.  Proposition C sets up a separate City department to 
run
the Health Service System, taking it out of the hands of the Human
Resources Department.  This is essentially a change to enable extension 
of
City health benefits to city residents (Proposition G), which we also
oppose.  Growing the bureaucracy is bad, especially when it's to enable 
a
worse cause.  (NO: 7 votes; no recommendation: 3 votes.)

Proposition D: NO (unanimous recommendation).  Proposition D makes a 
number
of changes to the Board of Supervisors' operational rules, and also 
removes
the fixed number of aides each Supervisor may employ.  This is a Trojan
horse: the Supervisors constantly complain about having too much work to
do, and rather than run our lives less, they are certain to hire more 
staff
as soon as they are allowed.  Passage of this measure is sure to 
increase
the cost of City government.

Proposition E: NO (unanimous recommendation).  Proposition E increases 
the
survivor benefits for police officers or firefighters who die in the 
line
of duty.  The benefits were reduced effective in 1976, and any employee
hired since then has agreed to the current terms.  The middle of a 
budget
crisis is not the time to raise them back again.

Proposition F: YES.  Proposition F extends the right to vote for Board 
of
Education elections to non-citizen residents with children in the school
system.  Some felt that citizenship is not too high a hurdle to require;
others felt that the measure does not go far enough (non-citizen 
taxpayers
who fund the schools will have no say over the board).  But overall, it 
is
a step in the right direction.  (YES: 7 votes; NO: 1 vote; no
recommendation: 4 votes.)

Proposition G: NO (unanimous recommendation).  Proposition G would 
extend
the medical and dental plan currently administered by the City for its
employees and their dependents to all interested city residents.  The 
City
is not an insurance company and should not pretend to be one.

Proposition H: NO.  Proposition H would officially name Candlestick Park
and prevent the city from selling naming rights.  While Libertarians 
would
prefer that the city not run a sports stadium at all, hamstringing its
ability to make money is just senseless, especially during a budget
crisis.  (NO: 11 votes; no recommendation: 2 votes.)

Proposition I: NO.  Proposition I would require the Controller to 
produce
an economic analysis of proposed legislation as well as a long-term
Economic Development Plan.  While we support the principle of an 
economic
watchdog, creating yet another government agency to perform that 
function
is a case of the foxes watching the henhouse.  (NO: 9 votes; YES: 1 
vote.)

Proposition J: NO (unanimous recommendation).  Proposition J would raise
sales taxes to provide funding for a budget that assumes it will be
there.  The budget should be balanced by cutting spending back to
pre-dot-com days, not by raising taxes on an already-damaged economy.

Proposition K: NO (unanimous recommendation).  Proposition K would 
impose a
gross receipts tax on local businesses.  As with Proposition J, this is 
to
provide revenue already assumed in the current budget, which is 
dishonest
and poor budgeting.  Further, gross receipts taxes particularly punish
low-margin high-volume businesses like supermarkets, and would be 
imposed
on top of the payroll tax already in place.  San Francisco will never
thrive until it stops punishing businesses for locating here.

Proposition L: NO.  Proposition L allocates some of the 
currently-collected
hotel tax money to restore and preserve single-screen movie theaters.  
This
is so far from a legitimate function of government as to leave one 
stunned;
worse, it is narrowly tailored so that the allocated money can only go 
to a
non-profit organization established by the measure's sponsors.  (NO: 12
votes; no recommendation: 1 vote.)

[Proposition M was stricken from the ballot.]

Proposition N: YES.  Proposition N is a statement, on behalf of the 
City,
that the U.S. military action in Iraq should be ended.  While it is not
clear what exactly the measure will accomplish that hundreds of 
thousands
marching in the street did not, since it is on the ballot, it should be
passed.  (YES: 9 votes; no recommendation: 1 vote.)

Proposition O: NO.  Proposition O allocates the sales tax revenue that
would be collected if Proposition J passes.  As we oppose Proposition 
J, we
hope that Proposition O will be moot, but earmarking revenue by ballot
measures is a bad practice that tends to lead to future budget crises 
and
tax increases.  (NO: 9 votes; no recommendation: 4 votes.)
- --
Christopher R. Maden, Chair, Libertarian Party of San Francisco
The Party of Principle: individual freedom and personal responsibility
<URL: http://www.lpsf.org/ >  +1.415.775.LPSF
PGP Fingerprint: BBA6 4085 DED0 E176 D6D4  5DFC AC52 F825 AFEC 58DA

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Hugger-Mugger Tonight!

Sorry for the short notice folks... one of my guests cancelled on me at
the last minute and I've been trying to find a replacement all day. I
haven't found anyone, so my only guest for tonight is my friend Dres,
who shares my penchant for strange minimal techno and will be bringing
the bizarre beats from 10-11-ish. The rest of the night will be a
resident free-for-all featuring:

AndyW
Clairity
Forest Green
Li
Juan Segovia
and Shazbot

Hugger-Mugger takes place every Tuesday night from 9-2am at the Lit
Lounge, 6th & Mission in San Francisco. More info here:

<http://tech-on.com/huggermugger.html>

Although we like to call Hugger-Mugger a "techno" weekly, it's really
much more than that. We're constantly on the hunt for talented guests,
searching for local music afficionados with unique tastes. Techno is all
well and good, but there's a lot going on in other electronic music
circles: electro, (don't-call-it) IDM, breaks, drum and bass, abstract
hip-hop, dub and house all continue to evolve, often borrowing stylistic
cues from each other to create new sub-genres and distinct sounds. As
much as we'd like to stay on top of everything, it's just not possible.
Musical diversity makes our community stronger, and that's why we need
to bring in guests and give them the exposure they deserve.

So if you that sounds like something that you might want to be a part
of, come on by tonight with a CD and say hi. Even if you're not a DJ,
come down and have a drink. At the very least, you'll get a sneak peek
into what some of us are going to be throwing down at the OtherWorld
next weekend. :)

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

--=====================_29982482==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hacker Hits California University Computer

2 hours, 36 minutes ago

SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - A computer hacker accessed names and Social 
Security 
(<http://us.rd.yahoo.com/DailyNews/manual/*http://news.search.yahoo.com/search/news?fr=news-storylinks&p=%22Social%20Security%22&c=&n=20&yn=c&c=news&cs=nw>news 
- 
<http://us.rd.yahoo.com/DailyNews/manual/*http://search.yahoo.com/search?fr=web-storylinks&p=Social%20Security>web 
sites) numbers of about 1.4 million Californians after breaking into a 
University of California, Berkeley, computer system in perhaps the worst 
attack of its kind ever suffered by the school, officials said on Tuesday.

"The investigation is continuing but we have no idea if the (personal) 
information has been compromised," said Carlos Ramos, assistant secretary 
at the California Health and Human Services 
(<http://us.rd.yahoo.com/DailyNews/manual/*http://news.search.yahoo.com/search/news?fr=news-storylinks&p=%22Health%20and%20Human%0AServices%22&c=&n=20&yn=c&c=news&cs=nw>news 
- 
<http://us.rd.yahoo.com/DailyNews/manual/*http://search.yahoo.com/search?fr=web-storylinks&p=Health%20and%20Human%20Services>web 
sites) Agency.

He said state agencies and the Federal Bureau of Investigation were 
investigating but the hacker had not been found.

The names accessed by the hacker were being used by a UC Berkeley 
researcher who had collected data on elderly people and individuals who 
provide in-home care to seniors to study the impact of wages on in-home 
care, Ramos said.

The data, which included home addresses, telephone numbers and dates of 
birth, was being used at the state's authorization but without the consent 
of the individuals whose information was being used in the study.

Ramos said the state is authorized to share with researchers the personal 
information of individuals who participate in state programs administered 
by the state social services department.

George Strait, a university spokesman, confirmed the school's computer 
system had been penetrated in what he believed was the most significant 
hacking job the university had experienced.

The university detected its computer system had been broken into at the end 
of August, but did not notify the state until Sept. 27 after the school had 
done its own investigation with the FBI 
(<http://us.rd.yahoo.com/DailyNews/manual/*http://news.search.yahoo.com/search/news?fr=news-storylinks&p=%22FBI%22&c=&n=20&yn=c&c=news&cs=nw>news 
- 
<http://us.rd.yahoo.com/DailyNews/manual/*http://search.yahoo.com/search?fr=web-storylinks&p=FBI>web 
sites), Strait said.

From sfraves-return-116533-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Oct 20 17:41:55 2004
