Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_2419859==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Before Wicked, there was........ "Whoosh!"  

--=====================_2419859==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Before Wicked, there was........ Whoosh!"

Jeno and Markie bring you the return of the original
East London throwdown.

At the Blue Cube @ 34 Mason....San Francisco
   21+, full bar..... Only $5

With special guests TK Disko and Seven.

It's happening all over again.

Whoosh was an intimate (and intense) psychedelic party
that happened in an old anarchist bookstore, tucked
away in a derelict part of East London. Starting in
'89 and ending in '91, it wasn't a "rave", but instead
followed in the wake of the once vibrant and eclectic
warehouse party scene in North and East London that
had been pretty much destroyed by the arrival of "acid
house" and the resulting attention it received from
the authorities determined to stamp it out.
Fortunately the bookstore was off the beaten path and
therefore far enough away from the drama and busts
that were plaguing much of the London party scene at
the time. Not having to worry about get shut down
allowed us to have a night where rules were few and
far between and the atmosphere was very free and
hedonistic..

What also made it special was the mix of friends and
other eccentric characters who'd make it out to East
London to share the night with us. In fact if it
hadn't been for the help and support of people like Al
and Trish (of Wicked), the North London Posse, the
Brixton Posse, and also Greg Smith (now of Ultra
Magnetic) who brought the Turbo speakers, it would
never have been quite so memorable.

Jeno, Markie, Bones, Para, Ron Aslan, and other
occasional guests would throw down a heartfelt mix of
soulful grooves, acidic beats and other left field
musical treats. While Markie would blow minds with his
occasional 3 turntable mix-madness, some other dj's
didn't really mix at all. Often it just worked better
that way..

Although some of us worked with and/or were regulars
at the now legendary Tonka parties, the Whoosh parties
were quite separate, Markie being the only dj who
played at both. After helping Tonka get going and
throwing their first parties in London I realized I
wasn't going in the same direction they were taking,
and looked for creative outlets elsewhere, ending up
in the basement of the bookstore. The influence of the
Whoosh parties has never really been written about,
but it's where many of the ideas that we brought to SF
were fermented, and it's where many of the roots of
the Wicked party lie..





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_2419859==.ALT--

TRUE SKOOL ANNIVERSARY/AFRIKA BAMBAATAA RECORD RELEASE PARTY

For 5-years straight, True Skool has served as a platform for emerging
artists, turntablists, and legends. From our early days at a weekly
Friday at the former Storyville to our current status as one of the
top events in the Bay, True Skool has remained a leader of the underground
and home to like-minded music enthusiasts.

On Saturday (Oct. 23), we celebrate our 5-Year Anniversary at the DNA Lounge
with an exclusive 2-hour set by the Amen-Ra of Hip Hop Culture, 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219025&s=4448475>Afrika
Bambaataa on "The Millenium of the Electro Gods Album Tour" which
celebrates his recent release on 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219052&s=4448475>Tommy Boy Records, "Dark 
Matter Moving
At The Speed of Light."

Freestyle session with 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219023&s=4448475>Raashan Ahmad 
(<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2218996&s=4448475>Crown City Rockers), 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219036&s=4448475>Felonious, 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219060&s=4448475>Psychokinetics,
Spaztik Emcee, Won Way, 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219056&s=4448475>Prozack Turner (Foreign 
Legion) +more. Direct
from NYC a special performance by the 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219031&s=4448475>Real Live Show (feat. 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219061&s=4448475>Stimulus & Dionysus),
DJs: <http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2218995&s=4448475>J-Boogie, 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219030&s=4448475>Jah Yzer, Coop D'ville, 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219009&s=4448475>Platurn, 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219012&s=4448475>Mr. E, 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219037&s=4448475>Sake 1, and
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219005&s=4448475>Ren the Vinyl Archaeologist. 
Dance performance by Soul Sector/Headhunters.

This Anniversary party will go down in history, so don't miss it.
@ <http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219038&s=4448475>DNA Lounge, 375 11th St. (@ 
Harrison), SF. 9pm-4am, 21+, $15 before 10pm.
Buy tickets ($15): 
<http://rd.bcentral.com/?ID=2219002&s=4448475>http://www.ticketweb.com/user/?region=sfbay&query=detail&event=551108
Tix also available at Papalote, 3409 24th St. @ Valencia, SF.





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Important for California voters

You have the right to ask your election official, in your balloting
location, for a paper ballot instead of using a Diebold machine.  This
is California law, and a very good idea.  I suggest all of you do so!

See the bottom of:
  http://www.ss.ca.gov/elections/elections_w.htm

"In response to concerns about the security of touchscreen/DRE voting
systems, the Secretary of States office has required these systems to
meet 23 additional security measures before these systems can be used
in the November election. These additional security measures require:

That every voter be given the option of casting a paper ballot. If
you would prefer to use a paper ballot instead of a touchscreen/DRE,
you may request one when you sign in at the polls."



http://www.jcthedj.com

resume, cover letter, and a recent pic of you to the back office, ask for

>On Wed, 20 Oct 2004, Apollo wrote:
>
> > Before Wicked, there was........ Whoosh!"
> >
> > Jeno and Markie bring you the return of the original
> > East London throwdown.
> >
> > At the Blue Cube @ 34 Mason....San Francisco
> >    21+, full bar..... Only $5
> >
> > With special guests TK Disko and Seven.
> >
> > It's happening all over again.
> >
> > Whoosh was an intimate (and intense) psychedelic party
> > that happened in an old anarchist bookstore, tucked
> > away in a derelict part of East London. Starting in
> > '89 and ending in '91, it wasn't a "rave", but instead
> > followed in the wake of the once vibrant and eclectic
> > warehouse party scene in North and East London that
> > had been pretty much destroyed by the arrival of "acid
> > house" and the resulting attention it received from
> > the authorities determined to stamp it out.
> > Fortunately the bookstore was off the beaten path and
> > therefore far enough away from the drama and busts
> > that were plaguing much of the London party scene at
> > the time. Not having to worry about get shut down
> > allowed us to have a night where rules were few and
> > far between and the atmosphere was very free and
> > hedonistic..
> >
> > What also made it special was the mix of friends and
> > other eccentric characters who'd make it out to East
> > London to share the night with us. In fact if it
> > hadn't been for the help and support of people like Al
> > and Trish (of Wicked), the North London Posse, the
> > Brixton Posse, and also Greg Smith (now of Ultra
> > Magnetic) who brought the Turbo speakers, it would
> > never have been quite so memorable.
> >
> > Jeno, Markie, Bones, Para, Ron Aslan, and other
> > occasional guests would throw down a heartfelt mix of
> > soulful grooves, acidic beats and other left field
> > musical treats. While Markie would blow minds with his
> > occasional 3 turntable mix-madness, some other dj's
> > didn't really mix at all. Often it just worked better
> > that way..
> >
> > Although some of us worked with and/or were regulars
> > at the now legendary Tonka parties, the Whoosh parties
> > were quite separate, Markie being the only dj who
> > played at both. After helping Tonka get going and
> > throwing their first parties in London I realized I
> > wasn't going in the same direction they were taking,
> > and looked for creative outlets elsewhere, ending up
> > in the basement of the bookstore. The influence of the
> > Whoosh parties has never really been written about,
> > but it's where many of the ideas that we brought to SF
> > were fermented, and it's where many of the roots of
> > the Wicked party lie..
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> >
> > House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> >
> >
> > "The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands
> > of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible
> > empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
> > -Woodrow Wilson
> >
> > "There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all,
> > i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a
> > bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the
> > state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life
> > itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
> >   ­ Gandhi
> >
> > "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> > rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
> > visible."
> > -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> >
> >
> >



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

On Mon, 18 Oct 2004 14:54:32 -0700 (PDT), Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:
> 
> (ORIGINAL Daily News ARTICLE TEXT BELOW @ end of REBUTTAL)
> 
> KRS One Rebuttal To NY Daily News Article
> 
> Like everyone I was shocked to read that I and other African-Americans
> actually "cheered when 911 happened" and that I have "declared my
> solidarity with Al Qaeda". When I read my words taken out of context I was
> shocked and disappointed that the Daily News would go this far to
> assassinate my character and distort my views.
> 
> Such statements with no follow up explanation or interview from KRS-ONE as
> to what he may have meant or even a complete quote of my point is simply
> irresponsible journalism on the Daily News' part. I would never just say
> something as crazy as "we cheered when 911 happened!" I was making an
> objective point about how many Hiphoppas as well as the oppressed peoples
> of the world felt that day.
> 
> I am a philosopher and a critical thinker, I speak truth and I urge people
> to think critically about themselves and their environment. Yes, my words
> are strong. Yes, my views are controversial. But to call me a terrorist is
> simply wrong!
> 
> A young lady asked about what we can do beyond voting to change the
> political state of things in our country? I responded not by irresponsibly
> stating that "America has to commit suicide if the world is to be a better
> place" and that's all. I am a poet and I speak poetically. My full
> statement was "America has to commit suicide if the world is to be a
> better place".
> 
> If you want to go beyond voting American interests must put a gun to its
> head and commit suicide because as long as we are only interested in
> American interests we go out and invade the rest of the world. The real
> question is are you a citizen of the United States or are you a citizen of
> the world? And so for me, I would say voting in a corrupt society adds
> more corruption.
> 
> I was asked by the New Yorker magazine to discuss "different and personal
> beliefs musicians hold and the contribution artists like myself can make
> to the nation's political dialog". My views were indeed different and most
> were personal. However, when I was asked about why Hiphop has not engaged
> the current situation more (meaning 911) my responds was "because it does
> not affect us, or at least we don't perceive that it effects us, 911
> happened to them". I went on to say that "I am speaking for the culture
> now; I am not speaking my personal opinion" I continued to say;" 911
> effected them down the block; the rich, the powerful those that are
> oppressing us as a culture. Sony, RCA or BMG, Universal, the radio
> stations, Clear Channel, Viacom with BET and MTV, those are our oppressors
> those are the people that we're trying to overcome in Hiphop everyday,
> this is a daily thing. We cheered when 911 happened in New York and say
> that proudly here. Because when we were down at the trade center we were
> getting hit over the head by cops, told that we can't come in this
> building, hustled down to the train station because of the way we dressed
> and talked, and so on, we were racially profiled. So, when the planes hit
> the building we were like; mmmm justice". And just as I began to say "now
> of course a lot of our friends and family were lost there as well," but I
> was interrupted.
> 
> My intent is never to demean or disrespect anyone's loss or gain; and of
> course I did not literally "cheer when 911 happened". I made an objective
> statement about the feelings of those who were oppressed by world trade
> policies. I was just as saddened as everyone else on 911. However, for
> many of us that were racially profiled and harassed by the World's Trade
> Center's security and the police patrolling that area as well as the
> thousands of American protesters that spoke out against the World Trade
> Organization months before in Seattle, Washington there was a sense of
> justice, a sense of change, a wake up call watching the twin towers fall.
> 
> These are not my views only; these views represent a popular truth that
> few people are really ready to hear. No one wished death on anyone or just
> sat and "cheered when 911 happened". But some of us can see through the
> bullshit! America must change its approach to the world and its citizens.
> This, I believe is what all Americans should be thinking about. How do we
> make our country better?
> 
> For years my career has been one of promoting peace, love, unity and
> having fun; such has always been Hiphop's cultural principles. So how all
> of a sudden now can I be aligned with Al Qaeda? What happened to honest
> debate and freedom of speech! I don't speak for the African American
> community exclusively, I speak for HIPHOP! And let me be clear here; most
> of the Hiphop community is against the war in Iraq! But to align me with
> Al Qaeda is clearly an attempt by the Daily News to interrupt the street
> voice of our Hiphop community, KRS-ONE's leadership and the increased
> momentum of our Hiphop political movement.
> 
> I don't think Al Qaeda needs my solidarity nor did I ever offer it, so
> what's the point. For a major news organization to now align KRS-ONE with
> Al Qaeda shows the unwarranted contempt that such an organization has for
> me. Such is grounds for a law suit!
> 
> Finally, no one should ever believe anything that the one-sided Daily News
> has to say about the same Hiphop community that it (the Daily News) has
> tried so desperately to undermine for years. The only thing the Daily News
> seems to be interested in is scandal and controversy and for years I have
> challenged the Daily News on its depictions of Rap artists and Hiphop as a
> whole.
> 
> I know they don't like me. However, I don't give a ---- either! They never
> cover our efforts toward peace and all the charitable work we do within
> the Hiphop community. They never air our grievances or how we feel about
> the state of the world, nor have they ever aired our views on America's
> invasion of Iraq simply because they just don't want to hear them. The
> Hiphop community forces America to look at itself; and no one likes to
> take b.l.a.m.e. for their own for immaturity Because Looking At Me ain't
> Easy!
> 
> For the record, I am an American philosopher. I speak and seek truth. If
> the slander that the Daily News has printed regarding my political views
> has disrespectfully offended anyone in any way I truly apologize. Again,
> it was never my or Hiphop's intent to disregard, disrespect or demean the
> tragedy of September 11th 2001 and those that died that day.
> 
> However, we do have a voice and a point of view and if you are not
> prepared to hear what Hiphop has to say about its view of world events
> then don't ask!
> 
> KRS-One
> 
> Original Article (Printed in the NY Daily News):
> 
> KRS-One: Blacks 'cheered when 9-11 happened'
> 
> Knight Ridder Newspapers
> Oct. 14, 2004 03:08 PM
> 
> If Osama bin Laden ever buys a rap album, he'll probably start with a CD
> by KRS-One.
> 
> The hip-hop anarchist has declared his solidarity with al-Qaida by
> asserting that he and other African-Americans "cheered when 9-11
> happened," reports the New York Daily News.
> 
> The rapper, real name Kris Parker, defiled the memory of those who died in
> the terrorist attacks as he spouted off at a recent New Yorker Festival
> panel discussion.
> 
>   "I say that proudly," the Boogie Down Productions founder went on,
> insisting that, before the attack, security guards kept Blacks out of the
> World Trade Center "because of the way we talk and dress.
> 
> "So when the planes hit the building, we were like, 'Mmmm - justice.' "
> 
> The atrocity of 9-11 "doesn't affect us the hip-hop community," he said.
> "9-11 happened to them, not us," he added, explaining that by "them" he
> meant "the rich ... those who are oppressing us. RCA or BMG, Universal,
> the radio stations."
> 
> Parker also sneered at efforts by other rappers to get young people to
> vote.
> 
> "Voting in a corrupt society adds more corruption," he added. "America has
> to commit suicide if the world is to be a better place."
> 
> --
> **************************************************************
> ******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
> If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
> much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
> & in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
> -- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

>From: "sashakelly2000" <sashakelly2000@yahoo.com>
>To: arizona-raves@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [az-raves] DJ Rap's Gear Stolen!!! Need Help!
>Date: Wed, 20 Oct 2004 22:53:55 -0000
>
>
>Charissa (DJ Rap) asked me to post this:
>
>On Oct. 18 Josh NYNEX (Josh Atchley) from LA & Offworld Records broke
>into Charissa's studio/home in LA and took the following items. There
>is strong belief that they were sold to someone in AZ recently.
>
>The items are listed below:
>
>- 1 G4 Power Mac
>- 1 G4 Power Book
>- 1 Ipod
>- 1 17 inch plasma display
>- 1971 US Blond Fender Stratocaster Guitar (we feel he kept this item
>for himself)
>
>Now here is the big problem. All of Charissa's songs for her upcoming
>new album and lyrics she has been working on for both the new album
>and other projects were on these computers, along with a variety of
>personal items like photos, emails form family and friend and such.
>
>I'm not going into how low this action is for someone claiming to be
>a musician to steal from another is just shocking and repulsive.
>
>Anyone who can offer any information please contact me (see below)
>and I'll forward it on the Charissa. The fact that 4 years of her
>life and artistic creation has vanished which in turn may deprive us
>of ever hearing her new material is just sickening. She wouldn't be
>so upset if it just a computer with some emails on it but this is
>much more serious since those computer contained her blood, sweat and
>tears.
>
>I don't have to point out to some that this happened to BT a while
>ago twice. Once he lost several finished songs that we will never
>hear, however the second time someone returned all his items after
>posts were made all over the internet. So we have hope Josh and the
>person in possession of these items will do the right thing.
>
>Shame on you Josh! Serious... Musicians stick together as family with
>a unified mission.
>
>leads and info to these missing items please send emails to
>badjosh@dancingmice.net , it will be kept private at your request.
>
>PLEASE POST THIS EVERYWHERE POSSIBLE, ALERT ALL MUSICIANS, PAWNSHOPS,
>MUSIC STORES AND MUSIC WEBSITES (INCLUDING THOSE WHO HAVE
>MEMBERS/VIEWERS FROM THOSE STATES) IN CALIFORNIA AND ARIZONA,
>INCLUDING SURROUNDING STATES.
>Peace
>
>
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] Urbanology 2 This Friday Night (guesslist)



Urban Couture and Fresh Entertainment presents:

URBANOLOGY2

"One night fits all!"

Friday, October 22nd 2004

FASHION : ART : DANCE : MUSIC

Urbanology will feature a 3 hour fashion show on an extended cat walk with
over 10 hip west coast designers. There will also be two rooms of music, an
art show, a B-Boy showcases, comedian performances, and much more! Get ready
for a night of strutting, styling, schmoozing, shopping, and grooving. Doors
open at 8pm with shows throughout the night.

Henna Tattoo's:

This event will be held on the second floor in the beautiful Crown Plaza
Hotel @ 777 Bellew Drive in Milpitas CA.

Get $18 presales @ Groovetickets.com to ensure entry and so you don't end up
paying $35 at the door! Also, for $75: VIP tickets include: Reserved front
row fashion show seating, free clothes, cds, after party access, raffle
tickets, and much more.

We are always on the look-out for like-minded companies and individuals. If
you have questions, inquires, or would like to vend your goods @ Urbanology
or future events contact urbanology@sbcglobal.net

nice werk-around the space bar issue, osby.=20

i use the period.......trick too if i'm composing a web page that
won't let me use more than one blank space.....between letters, then I
change the text color of the periods to white so the periods become
invisible.

umm i think the archives are all zipped in some way so google's or
other search engines spiders can't read them so easily, Brian thought
of this long before google existed, which is why he's our fearless
leader and all

i'm on a linux box here and the last time i  cracked an sfraves
archive file i was on a windows box but that was a long time ago and I
forgot how I did it, but i'm sure you can figure it out from here or
someone else can help you over the part you're having issues with.

nwa

http://www.sfraves.org/archives/sfrlist/

This Year's archives:

http://www.sfraves.org/archives/sfrlist/2004/

http://www.sfraves.org/archives/sfrlist/2004/sfr.0410

view past archives of the list, you need a viewer that can decompress .gz=

files (like Winzip on Windows)...

know... I'd be happy to investigate it. Send a URL if you can...

Subject: [sfraves] RR News: Another USDOJ page (archive)

--0-2066742050-1098363217=:8484
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE

http://www.usdoj.gov/ndic/pubs/656/

Highlights:

"...
21 U.S.C. =A7 856
=A7 856 Establishment of Manufacturing Operations

(a) Except as authorized by this subchapter, it shall be unlawful to

     (1) Knowingly open or maintain any place for the purpose of=20
manufacturing, distributing, or using any controlled substance.

     (2) Manage or control any building, room, or enclosure, either as an=
=20
owner, lessee, agent, employee, or mortgagee, and knowingly and=20
intentionally rent, lease, or make available for use, with or without=20
compensation, the building, room, or enclosure for the purpose of=20
unlawfully manufacturing, storing, distributing, or using a controlled=20
substance.

(b) Any person who violates subsection (a) of this section shall be=20
sentenced to a term of imprisonment of not more than 20 years or a fine of=
=20
not more than $500,000, or both, or a fine of $2,000,000 for a person=20
other than an individual. ...

=2E..
The law enforcement agencies that participated in Operation Rave Review=20
developed a five-step process that might be employed effectively in other=
=20
areas experiencing high levels of rave activity, club drug overdoses, and=
=20
related emergency room visits. The process employed consisted of the=20
following steps:

     1. Identify rave promoters. Potential subjects for investigation=20
included all parties responsible for managing the production and promotion=
=20
of the raves, including the owners of the property where the event was=20
held.

     2. Compile emergency medical service (EMS) records. Records of medical=
=20
transports from the rave venue to local emergency rooms were collected.=20
Retrieval of medical records sometimes required grand jury or=20
administrative subpoenas or court orders.

     3. Conduct undercover operations inside the venue during rave events.=
=20
Undercover investigators purchased paraphernalia (chemical light sticks,=20
pacifiers, and drug test kits) at the venue and filmed ravers using drugs=
=20
and using the paraphernalia to enhance or manage the effects of the drugs.=
=20
Undercover investigators filmed drug purchases by undercover officers who=
=20
purchased drugs from as many different people as possible and as quickly=20
as possible to clearly demonstrate the availability of drugs at the venue.=
=20
Undercover investigators filmed the actions or inaction of security=20
personnel hired by the rave promoter, and they also filmed patrons being=20
treated or transported to local emergency rooms.

     4. Place an undercover officer. Undercover agents or officers posed as=
=20
job applicants for security positions and obtained interviews with the=20
rave promoter. The undercover officers asked for the promoter's general=20
expectations of security personnel and specific expectations of security=20
personnel observing drug use or distribution.

     5. Execute search warrants. Search warrants were executed at the rave=
=20
venue, at offsite offices, and at the home of the rave promoter. Officers=
=20
and agents seized all documents and items relating to the ownership,=20
advertisement, promotion, and operation of the rave venue, including but=20
not limited to purchase orders for rave paraphernalia, water, and other=20
stock. Officers and agents also seized employment records identifying=20
security personnel and any memoranda detailing their responsibilities,=20
correspondence or contracts with EMS services, and financial records that=
=20
detailed costs and profits associated with raves.

=2E..

=2E..

Conclusion

  Raves have developed over the past decade from a small subculture to the=
=20
highly commercialized and widespread exploitation of young people by=20
large-scale rave promoters. The growing awareness of the nature of rave=20
activity and the effects of club drug use have moved many communities to=20
action. In order to curtail rave activity, communities and law enforcement=
=20
agencies are enforcing existing fire codes, health and safety ordinances,=
=20
and liquor laws, and are establishing juvenile curfews and licensing=20
requirements for large public gatherings. They are requiring rave=20
promoters and club owners to pay for building or liquor licenses, medical=
=20
services, and security for their events, all in an effort to force rave=20
promoters to move or cease their operations.

=2E.."

--=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJ Rap's Gear Stolen!!! Need Help! 

I met DJ Rap when she spun at a party at Studio 54.  I
didn't realize who she was actually, until after she
had to run to the bathroom during her "pee record."  I
complemented her on her spinnign and then felt like a
doofus afterwards.  We were nominated for a Yahoo
Internet Life award and I was there to accept if we
won which unfortuantely we didn't. I was supposed to
be seated next to David Bowie actually, but he never
sat in his seat.  Martha Stewart was two seats over on
the other side, but she left after Amy Mann played.  
And Rick James spilled a cocktail on my partner at the
pre-party.  Ha ha!

DJ Rap got us into BT's gig at the Bowery Ballroom the
next night for free where she was opening.  That was
the night that our friend David P. was so drunk he
jumped out of a moving taxi cab in the middle of
Manhattan to walk off the spins for the second night
in a row.  Hey Dave you don't *HAVE* to drink those
free drinks at industry events...

DJ Rap is one of the niceest people I've met in the
dance music business and I really hope she gets her
gear back.

Peace,

Peter

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"

> Undercover investigators purchased paraphernalia (chemical light sticks, 
> pacifiers, and drug test kits) at the venue and filmed ravers using drugs 
> and using the paraphernalia to enhance or manage the effects of the drugs. 
> 

This made me want to say something. I take pics of light shows at parties. I 
take them 'cause they look cool, and people might want to see the pics when i 
post them. Normally, you can't see who's doing the light show in the pics, 
just the lights. However, if anybody feels uncomfortable being photographed, 
please tell me and I'll delete the picture right then. 

Also, sometimes people look f'd up in pics. Could just be because they 
blinked, and the half-closed eye makes them look wasted.  I avoid posting pics in 
which I think people look bad. I use red-eye correction to help. People can ask 
to see the pic after I take it, and zoom it in to see how they look. I'll 
delete it if they want. 

I take pics and post them so people who went to a party can have something to 
remember it by ... and so people who wanted to go can see what they missed. I 
would feel terrible if the pics were being used as evidence of illegal 
activity. 

That DOJ page is just SO morally wrong ... receipts for purchasing water are 
evidence of illegal activity? Emergency room and EMS records? fuck!!!!  

People have issues with cops all over the place, but at least in San 
Francisco, thanks to the SF Late Night Coalition and others, cops can't use 911 
emergency calls as evidence to shut clubs down. I've seen cops come into a party 
looking mainly for underage drinking and not hassle people over anything else ... 
maybe sometimes looking for people under 18 at an 18+ party  ... but not this 
knee-jerk attitude that the party is all wrong, every time. 

--part1_1d8.2e167724.2ea9537c_boundary--

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR News: Another USDOJ page (archive) & rave pics

I've struggled in dealing with this issue as well.  I've found it rather 
difficult to ask and/or beg people to leave their cameras and recorders 
at home.  Without fail, every time I make such a request on a BSP a 
flood of complaints is almost always guaranteed to follow.  I've had 
some success providing one on one directions/requests with people before 
they get to the party, but even then you get those people that have a 
hard time listening.  Next to cavity searches and kicking people out 
caught with them (both of which I frown upon), I have yet to have come 
up with some sort of solution.
I've seen first hand police and news agencies come into parties take 
pictures, pick up fliers and shoot video only later to see it pop up 
overly exaggerated on the news or in printed anti-rave literature.  I 
understand that drug use and certain drinking situations are against the 
law - but more often then not such material ends up being being used as 
propaganda or shady law enforcement tactics.

lmnt

Sean Casey wrote:
> JonnyR@aol.com <JonnyR@aol.com> said...

>>take them 'cause they look cool, and people might want to see the pics when i 
>>post them. Normally, you can't see who's doing the light show in the pics, 
>>just the lights. However, if anybody feels uncomfortable being photographed, 
>>please tell me and I'll delete the picture right then.

>>blinked, and the half-closed eye makes them look wasted.  I avoid posting pics in

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR News: Another USDOJ page (archive) & rave pics

I find this paragraph interesting for obvious reasons...

"Members of private drug education and drug testing organizations, called 
"harm reduction organizations," have appeared at raves over the past 10 
years. They attend rave events to test samples of illegal drugs so they can 
inform ravers of purity levels. Members of these organizations believe that 
they help reduce the number of overdoses by educating users on the physical 
effects of specific drugs. Conversely, many law enforcement agencies believe 
that the practices of harm reduction organizations encourage drug use, and 
they support their position with national statistics that show an increase 
in club drug overdoses as harm reduction organizations have become more 
active. "

Why do I find that last sentence the biggest cop out in history?

Not only can you truly draw no correlation between HR groups and drug OD's.. 
but since law enforcement themselves usually are the ones fighting to KEEP 
HR orgs out of parties..  isnt the evidence inherantly flawed anyway?

Next DOJ thing will probably read "Many fire fighting agencies believe that 
the practices of the boy scouts encourage forest fires, and they support 
their position with national statistics that show an increase in fires 
starting near camping areas as Boy Scout Troops have become more active"

-B

> sort of solution.

Subject: [sfraves] RR News Archives: The War Raves (on Drugs Is Terrorism) article

US: The War On Raves
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v02/n1269/a12.html
Newshawk: The War on Drugs IS Terrorism
Votes: 0
Pubdate: Wed, 03 Jul 2002
Source: SF Weekly (CA)
Contact: feedback@sfweekly.com
Copyright: 2002 New Times Inc
Website: http://www.sfweekly.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/812
Author: Dan Strachota
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm (Raves)

THE WAR ON RAVES

Forget Terrorists; Let's Fight The Dancers

You can dance if you want to -- well, no, you can't The government doesn't 
want you to dance.  Actually, the government doesn't want you to take 
drugs, and it thinks that getting you to stop dancing -- or buying plastic 
tubes of neon to wave in the air -- will cut down on your drug intake. 
Nothing, and I mean nothing, should ever stop you from exercising your 
right to wave a glow stick.  It's right there in the Constitution, sort 
of.

Let's backtrack a bit.  Last year, the Department of Justice sent out a 
painfully funny memo ( found at 
usdoj.gov/ndic/pubs/656">www.usdoj.gov/ndic/pubs/656 ) to law enforcement 
bodies throughout the country about raves and "club drugs." Among other 
incorrect assumptions, the missive suggested that rave organizers were 
condoning drug usage by providing free water, allowing on-site testing of 
Ecstasy purity, and making party fliers that emphasize the letter "e," 
which we all know spells trouble ( or at least helps spell it ).

But the least amusing part of the memo concerned a "methodology for the 
potential prosecution of rave promoters who [allow] open, unabated drug 
use." The bulletin explained how certain prosecutors were shutting down 
nightclubs by using a 1986 law designed to rid cities of crack houses. 
This statute says that any building manager with knowledge of drug use on 
the premises can be sent to prison for up to 20 years and/or fined 
$500,000.  In other words, if one guy's doing Ecstasy at a rave, the 
organizer of the party can be held responsible.  If this law had been in 
effect in the '60s, Bill Graham would've been up shit creek.

In 2001, federal prosecutors used the "crack house" law to arrest the 
owners of two dance clubs -- Club La Vela in Tallahassee and the State 
Palace Theater in New Orleans.  Neither case stuck: In Tallahassee the 
jury returned a not guilty verdict in only 75 minutes, while in New 
Orleans the feds merely got a plea bargain, which stipulated that glow 
sticks, pacifiers, and face masks would be forbidden in the State Palace 
Theater.  But the American Civil Liberties Union appealed the Louisiana 
case, and in February of this year, in what the ACLU called "a major 
victory" for free speech, U.S.  District Judge G.  Thomas Porteous ruled 
that "the government cannot ban inherently legal objects that are used in 
expressive communication because a few people use the same legal item to 
enhance the effects of an illegal substance."

But don't lace up your dancing shoes just yet.  Recently, federal 
lawmakers sneaked a little provision into the proposed bill HR 3782, the 
so-called "CLEAN-UP of Methamphetamines Act of 2002," that expresses 
similar ideas to the "crack house" statute.  Section 416A, a one-paragraph 
addition to the bill, says that a promoter who handles "any rave, dance, 
music, or other entertainment event ...  where the promoter knows or 
reasonably ought to know that a controlled substance will be used or 
distributed" can be fined or imprisoned for up to nine years.  The wording 
is incredibly vague, not to mention ridiculous.  As Turner Madden, general 
counsel for the International Association of Assembly Managers Inc., 
writes in a letter to the chairman of the House Committee on the 
Judiciary, Rep.  James Sensenbrenner ( R-Wisc.  ), "businesses are 
generally not liable for the criminal acts of third parties." To prove his 
point, he brings up a 1985 decision in which a judge ruled that a Los 
Angeles Dodgers fan who got mugged in the parking lot after a game 
couldn't hold the team financially responsible.

Not to be outdone, the California Narcotic Officers' Association is 
sponsoring a statewide anti-rave bill, AB 1941.  The legislation requires 
that promoters of raves -- defined as all-night parties where "repetitive 
electronic music" is played -- jump through extensive permit hoops, 
acknowledge in writing their sufficient knowledge of drugs ( what, show 
off their bongs? ), and promise cross-your-heart style not to condone 
violations of drug laws.  Both the ACLU and the Center for Policy Reform 
have submitted letters opposing the bill, on the grounds that it is 
discriminatory, arbitrary, and draconian.  Unfortunately, the California 
Assembly passed the measure by a vote of 79-0, so we may have to hope the 
courts will strike it down.  Still, it couldn't hurt to send your state 
senators a letter saying how strongly you oppose the legislation.  Maybe 
include a glow stick as well.

For more information on both bills, go to www.emdef.org .

--

& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.

Beats vs. Bush: A Dance Party

when: Wed 10.27 (7pm-2am)
where: Rickshaw Stop (155 Fell St, San Francisco, 415.861.2011)
price: $10-20 benefits MoveOn and John Kerry
info: Rickshaw Stop

The cream of San Francisco's crop of future-forward DJs come out for a 
night of groundbreaking beats to celebrate our groundbreaking candidate, 
John Kerry. Features Polywog (SisterSF), Jefrodesiac (Frisko Disco), 
TophOne (Red Wine), Matthew Africa (KALX), Philip Sherburne (Trouble), Dr. 
Dreary (Cat Five), and many more.

839cbe.jpg





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Passing almost without notice earlier this month, the public release of
The Civil Rights Record of the George W Bush Administration - the
official staff report prepared by the US Civil Rights Commission - whose
submission is required by federal law, was blocked by the Republican
commissioners. None the less, it was posted on the commission's website:
"This report finds that President Bush has neither exhibited leadership
on pressing civil rights issues, nor taken actions that matched his
words."

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  PROBLEMS VOTING -- CALL 1-866-OUR-VOTE

--=====================_2239019==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

1-866-OUR-VOTE is the hotline to report any incidents in
which voter's rights may be compromised from now on
through election day. The Election Protection Coalition
has put together a highly visual web-based voter based
monitoring system called the Election Incident Reporting
System (EIRS). The system tracks reports of voter
incidents on a color-coded map that rapidly identifies
locations where multiple complaints have occurred and
connects to a rapid response system where observers,
technical, and legal help can rapidly be sent out to
observe and record.

The brightly colored maps are drawn from information
collected by volunteers staffing hotlines.

The effort is funded through more than 60 voter watch
organizations. Volunteers can sign up through the site
to monitor polling locations for irregularities and help
with other implementation tasks.

Since its deployment on August 31, 2004 more than 1,000
incidents have been recorded and mapped.

More Info:

<https://voteprotect.org/>https://voteprotect.org/
https://vevo.verifiedvoting.org/eirs/
<http://www.wired.com/news/evote/0,2645,65215,00.html?tw=wn_2polihead>http://www.wired.com/news/evote/0,2645,65215,00.html?tw=wn_2polihead

===

a long, long time ago, far away on a completely different planet with a completely different atmosphere, food, water, general eco system, a planet with a completely different idea of what time it is, what day it was, and a planet where there was lots of cotton candy in a multitude of colors, there was a rainbow in a box under a floor board on a shelf, and it glowed and glowed, and it even made kind of a humming sound when there were lots of the kind of people that live on that planet who were kind of humming too. :)

empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."

i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

When you've got a major artery gushing blood you don't try to
reconstruct the entire area right then. You put a tourniquet on it.
John Kerry is that tourniquet.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

--=20
Main Entry: 1ta=C2=B7la=20
Pronunciation: 't=C3=A4-l&
Function: noun
Etymology: Sanskrit tAla, literally, hand-clapping
: one of the ancient traditional rhythmic patterns of Indian music --
compare RAGA

|--Begin BSP----

Secret Psychedelica v4.10 w/ guest Joti Sidhu (Psychaos - UK) >
     Mon.Oct.25

Silicon Valley's only psychedelic trance (& breaks!) night...
SECRET PSYCHEDELICA v4.10
4th Monday of every month

Monday, October 25th, 2004
version four.ten:
It's time for the Halloween edition of Secret Psychedelica v4 and what
better treat is there than a pioneer of psychedelic trance for a Monday
night scare? This month's guest not only helped shape the direction of
psychedelic trance but also works as groove consultant and programmer
with Dave Allen, producer of the Cure. He has numerous classic
releases on labels such as Blue Room, Transient, and Atomic Records as
well as current dancefloor stormers co-produced with Simon Posford of
Hallucinogen and Dino Psaras from Cydonia. Please help us welcome Spun
Records recording artist...
JOTI SIDHU aka Psychaos - UK

plus Secret Psychedelica resident DJs:
MICHAEL LIU
DUTCH
AEON
MUBALI

breaks room:
LI
AARON JAE
BERT
NATURAL HIGH
TAJ

Live Visuals Mixing by VIBERATION GRAPHICS
Special decor by PSYBERTRIBE and MUF!
Sound powered by S.W.A.T. and ATARAXIA

POWER HOUR -> 10pm to 11pm -> $1 draft beers!
Free CDs while supplies last

Music starts at 9pm
21+ ID required
$5 door

Located at the Savoy on 3546 Flora Vista Ave in Santa Clara CA

On the night of Secret Psychedelica v3.10, October 27th, 2003, Evan
Ilyana Liu was born into this world. Secret Psychedelica v4.10 is
dedicated to the brightest light to shine in our family. Happy Birthday
Evan!

Secret Psychedelica would like to thank you all for your continued
support and energy. Your ever faithful Monday night dancing has kept us
going strong for over three and half years! To say thanks, we've planned
and handful of special shows in 2005 starting with a live appearance from
Son Kite at v5.2! Mark your calendars now!

408.278.5211

www.illuminationrecords.com

<<ESCT>>

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Cast a spotlight on voter intimidation

I don't have a video phone, nor a camcorder.  But for those that do,
consider this effort.  And with early absentee voting efforts not having
the same rules and regulations that voting day does, I've heard of
intimidation coming from both sides (unfortunately.)
(http://www.VideoVoteVigil.org)

CAST A SPOTLIGHT ON VOTER INTIMIDATION

No right is more central to a functioning democracy than the right to vote.
Yet in this critical election newspapers are reporting daily on
anti-democratic efforts to suppress the vote. This must be stopped.

Working together we can do it. We are issuing a nation-wide call for
volunteer poll watchers armed with video cameras to document voter
intimidation efforts at polling places.

To support our efforts please contribute here:
http://texansfortruth.org/contribute.html

Texans for Truth is setting up a web site, http://www.VideoVoteVigil.org,
where citizens can post digital copies of their videos. We've prepared ahea=
d
of time to provide sufficient bandwidth and server space to make it easy fo=
r
volunteers to post their digitized videos. This site will be completed in
the next few days.

This year, when thugs raise their fists and phony felons lists to frighten
voters from the polls, they will be caught on camera and frozen in their
tracks.

We're looking for volunteers to film voter intimidation efforts wherever
they take place: highway road blocks, polling places, work sites, or
neighborhoods.

Attempted voter suppression will be exposed IMMEDIATELY =AD before they can
steal votes from our democracy. Working together, we can let would-be
intimidators know they cannot hide from the eyes of the world. We must
succeed in diminishing these voter intimidation efforts and providing
critical support to Americans trying to cast ballots in the 2004 election.

This year's effort has been well-documented by bloggers and the mainstream
press. Just Saturday, October 23, the New York Times described planned
efforts in Ohio to hire thugs to intimidate voters.

Daily Kos has a clearinghouse of information on voter intimidation and
TalkingPointsMemo has reported extensively on abuses here and here as have
many others.

Throughout the nation, in election after election, Republicans rely upon
voter intimidation and suppression strategies. As GOPer Webster Todd once
said after helping elect his sister, Christine Todd Whitman, as governor of
New Jersey, "That's where a lot of our effort went and a lot of our
planning, getting out the vote on one side and voter sup--and keeping the
vote light in other areas." Todd caught himself before finishing the word
"suppression."

In my 2004 book, The Politics of Deceit: Saving Freedom and Democracy from
Extinction, I make the case that the voter suppression effort is the most
under-reported political scandal of our time. Now, because of your support,
we are able to do something about it.

Bullies like to work in the dark. They like to hide. But with the help of
tens of thousands of volunteers, we can shine a light on these thugs. Join
us in this historic effort.

The thugs cannot escape a million righteous eyes.

thank you,
Glenn Smith
Texans for Truth



http://www.jcthedj.com
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

Message-Id: <6.1.2.0.2.20041025185233.029ccc48@localhost>
X-Sender: apollo@localhost
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.1.2.0
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 2004 19:48:13 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_5378904==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] TRUE SKOOL:   BAMBALICIOUS

--=====================_5378904==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I haven't been to the DNA since a horrible night at a Wicked party many 
moons ago.  My anti-big-club bias wasn't strong enough, however, to prevent 
me from attending True Skool's fifth anniversary party there on Saturday 
night.  Hell, I'd crawl on my hands and knees naked for ten miles in a snow 
storm to hear Afrika Bambaataa.

Further, I have become a big True Skool hip hop fan.  Been to a number of 
their parties and had a consistently good time.  TS attracts a crowd much 
like the early house/rave community did in the early nineties:  friendly, 
accepting, and very passionate about dance music.  Moving into a different 
musical subculture in this town can sometimes be a bumpy ride for a newbie, 
but even at my first TS event I felt like I was with family.

As you know, I have been feelin' the need for more funk and soul in my life 
and it is at these parties that I get my fix and more.

We arrived late as usual:  around 12:30, and the party started at 
nine.  Everyone seems to be getting to events earlier these days, and I'm 
still on the old NYC schedule.

I don't know if things have changed at the DNA, but for the TS party 
security was very chill.  Just an ID check at the door and no hassle with 
ins and outs.  They didn't even search my partner's camera bag.

The DNA was packed with the usual diverse and friendly TS crowd.  Very few 
if any clubber types.  No drama.  No aggression.   And it appeared from the 
lack of lines at the bar, very little drinking.

First thing we saw was a break dance performance by Soul 
Sector/Headhunters.  Impressive.   One guy spun like a top on his head, 
body perfectly straight, for several seconds.  Then Coop D'Ville came on 
with a live performance.  TS is an openly political collective with an 
agenda that harmonizes with my own beliefs, so it was refreshing to hear 
Coop rapping about our current political climate.

We spent some time in the smaller room dancing to hip hop, and then Bam 
arrived on the main floor.  Bam is a DJ like DJs used to be.  He plays a 
very eclectic and innovative set, and his musical experience goes back to 
the seventies.  I love and respect this man, and god did I enjoy his 
set.  So many extraordinary remixes of old school stuff -- and, what a 
happy surprise, he ended his set with "Respect."  Haven't danced to that in 
a club in decades.

As I was dancing with abandon to Bam a kid who didn't look a day older than 
21 comes up and suggests I go up on the stage with the breakdancers.  He 
said:  "I still had it goin'."  Well, the days of spinning on my head are 
gone, but it's cool to know one's display of love for the beat is still 
appreciated:)

True Skool is doing something very important for the dance music community 
in the Bay and is right in synch with my own musical direction these 
days.  In fact, it is the only party in town right now where I would 
really, really like to spin.  So I'm going to put together a demo for them 
when all my political work is finished in November.

This Friday another soulful party, a tribute to Stevie Wonder, is going 
down at Club Mighty with DJ Spinna and Bobbito.  This year I'm just burnt 
out on Halloween so I just may do my weekend celebration there.  No costume 
needed, and Sake-One from Local 1200 will also be performing.

Much love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_5378904==.ALT--

are willing to pay that much for the party they get in return.  Plus they 
gave the presale ticket buyers a break, so if you wanted to go that bad for 
cheaper you could have.  Plenty of other options on Halloween weekend anyway 
if that's not your cup of tea.

Subject: [sfraves] RIP John Peel

--=====================_895647==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


No matter your genre....heads that know will miss John Peel for the many 
years of dedicated enthusiasm as a true pioneer of progressive music....



"He became one of the first DJs to give exposure to punk, reggae and 
hip-hop, before they crossed over into the mainstream. "



------------------------------------------------



Legendary radio DJ John Peel dies

Veteran BBC broadcaster John Peel has died at the age of 65, while on 
holiday in Peru.

Peel, whose radio career spanned 40 years, was on a working holiday in the 
city of Cuzco with his wife Sheila when he suffered a heart attack.

He was BBC Radio 1's longest-serving DJ and in recent years had also 
presented Home Truths on Radio 4.

Radio 1 controller Andy Parfitt said Peel's contribution to modern music 
and culture was "immeasurable".

'Hugely missed'

He added: "John Peel was a broadcasting legend. I am deeply saddened by his 
death as are all who work at Radio 1. "John's influence has towered over 
the development of popular music for nearly four decades.



HAVE YOUR SAY

John Peel stayed true to what mattered most in music
Pete, Nottingham, UK

"Hopeful bands all over the world sent their demo tapes to John knowing 
that he really cared.

"His commitment and passion for new music only grew stronger over the 
years. In fact, when I last saw him he was engaged in a lively debate with 
his fellow DJs over the state of new music today

"He will be hugely missed."

Mr Parfitt told Radio 1's Newsbeat that Peel had been on a holiday of a 
lifetime when he died.

'Irreplaceable'

He added: "He had gone on holiday with Sheila to a place where he had 
always wanted to go."





BBC director general Mark Thompson said: "We are all very shocked and 
saddened by the news of John's death.

"He was one of the giants of radio and will be missed, not just by everyone 
at the BBC, but by millions of listeners of all ages."

Tony Blair's spokesman said the Prime Minister was "genuinely saddened by 
the news".

He added: "His view is that he was a unique voice in British broadcasting 
and used that voice to unearth new talent and different subjects and make 
them accessible to a much wider audience."

Radio 1 DJ Jo Whiley, who presented coverage of the Glastonbury Festival 
with Peel, paid tribute to her colleague and close friend.

She said: "John was simply one of my favourite men in the whole world - as 
a music fan and presenter he was simply an inspiration."

Mainstream music

Peel was born in Heswall, near Liverpool, and after completing his military 
service in Britain in 1962, went to the US where he began working for a 
radio station in Dallas.



It was because of him I got to hear some of the most obscure but 
influential music I ever heard
James Dean Bradfield, Manic Street Preachers

He joined Radio 1 at the launch in 1967, and established himself with the 
late night programme Top Gear.

He became one of the first DJs to give exposure to punk, reggae and 
hip-hop, before they crossed over into the mainstream.

Peel's programme built up a reputation around the world, and in addition to 
his Radio 1 programme, he could also be heard on the BBC's World Service.

James Dean Bradfield, lead singer of the Manic Street Preachers, paid 
tribute to Peel.

He told BBC News Online: "It was because of him I got to hear some of the 
most obscure but influential music I ever heard.

"He was a lifeline to hearing music I would never have heard otherwise. The 
service he provided was getting to hear music that you couldn't buy in 
Cardiff. He was a portal to a whole new world."



He always had his finger on the pulse of the music industry
Michael Bradley, Undertones

Blur lead singer Damon Albarn said John Peel's patronage was "one of the 
most significant things that happened to us in our careers".

"The world is going to be a poorer place with his sudden departure. I will 
miss him deeply," he added.

"I want to send my heartfelt sympathy to his lovely family. John's memory 
will never be forgotten because he had the spirit of music in him."

Favourite record

After announcing Peel's death on Radio 1, the station played his favourite 
song, Teenage Kicks, by the Undertones.

Michael Bradley, bass player for the Undertones, spoke of his shock on 
learning of Peel's death.

He said: "He was a very funny, very warm man and we will always be grateful 
for what he did for The Undertones.

"Personally, I find it incredible what he did for the band and we always 
got huge pride out of the fact that he said Teenage Kicks was his favourite 
single.

"He always had his finger on the pulse of the music industry and the fact 
that Radio 1 played the Undertones, the White Stripes and the Strokes today 
showed just how relevant he remained throughout his career."

Story from BBC NEWS:
http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/3955289.stm




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

basics again. I know it won't happen though because more and more SF is

On Tue, Oct 26, 2004 at 03:12:30PM -0700, innocentchild wrote:
> So what did I just say in my last email? MAKE THEM ALL THE SAME FUCKING 
> PRICE. And regardless - $30 for a fucking CLUB night that's going to be 

Tickets were cheaper because it helps the Thump crew to make plans when
you buy your tickets early.  So to incentivize you to buy them early
(thereby forgoing 1 month interest on that 25 bucks), you get them a few
dollars cheaper.  If you have a problem with the price, buy early.

If you have a personal problem with cheaper presales, then DON'T FUCKING
GO.  But for fuck's sake, quit whining about it.   You already said you
didn't want to go anyway.

> Now maybe if they brought in REAL top notch talent playing live like they 

Umm, it's a bit cocky of you to decide what REAL talent is.  Most everyone
who is into psytrance agrees that Simon is one of the VERY BEST producers
and musicians.  And not only do we get his new solo act, we get his
Shpongle act, too.  That's *REAL* talent.  

You may not think Simon is worth 20 or 30 bucks.  There are a couple
thousand other people who do, and we'll have a great time without you.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Thumpoween question

Naa man - I've got a gorgeous view in front of me right now and some great 
music in my headphones. My day is just peachy. I just could give a rats ass 
about psy trance. I know who the guy is. I know the other acts he performs 
under. I know this fucking area loves that shit. It's not for me. Now that's 
just me, and really I'm not ripping on psy trance here. I like it in small 
doses.

Beyond all of that I am getting more and more annoyed with the increasing 
prices of clubs these days. Thump I will give credit to actually putting 
effort into the production and for those of you into psy trance and the 
relevent artwork - you're stoked. To me when I have been I see it as *at 
least they actually put some effort into production with banners, string 
art, fire dancers outside, etc* and it ends there. I see people like Dax out 
there throwing parties in the D7 warehouse with people pissing in the sink 
and shitting in the shower with zero production, no effort and jacking up 
prices throughout the night just because people are stupid enough to pay. 
It's an overall trend in SF. Even *Walnut Creek* (LAUGH) is getting away 
with charging $10 cover for their stupid little clubs! I'm amazed that 
people pay out like that. I really wish that things hadn't taken such a 
business greed turn lately. I know things can be done better than what I've 
seen and for a lot less.

Hell it's gone so far that even my stupid high school reunion planner kids 
can't figure out how to throw an event for less than $75/head and that's not 
with an open bar! Oh and it's at the old Charlie Brown's in San Ramon.

:: bangs.head.against.desk ::

:: r ::

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Thumpoween question


innocentchild <innocentchild@hotmail.com> said...
> So what did I just say in my last email? MAKE THEM ALL THE SAME FUCKING 
> PRICE. And regardless - $30 for a fucking CLUB night that's going to be 
> fucking packed, have security, and charge club prices for drinks? Value 
> wise that's never going to be worth my money regardless of who is playing. 
> Now maybe if they brought in REAL top notch talent playing live like they 
> did years ago when Hybrid played Kelly's Mission Rock live I'd pay. It was 
> a miserable experience due to the overcrowding, but I got to meet the guys 
> and ask them questions so I got what I really wanted. But fuck man... I'm 
> really sick and tired of SF and its over priced and over hyped nightlife 
> industry. I can only hope that if//when I'm back in the area in the future 
> that all of this implodes, people stop supporting this shit and things get 
> back to basics again. I know it won't happen though because more and more 
> SF is posturing for a high-end lifestyle and it will only get worse.

Presales ease the budgeting process by getting money in sooner. I
think rewarding people who hand in their money sooner is reasonable.

Perhaps the wording should be: Tickets $30. Presale ticket buyers
get a $5 discount.

One should get a *whole lot* for $25 or $30, At that price point
collectives I've been associated with have thrown events with great
light shows, visuals, and artists. We've provided free-food, plenty
of porta-potties, smoothies, chai, earplugs, etc. We've provided
bust-proof venues with lots of room, friendly and professional
security, and EMTs too.

I'd be disappointed in a $30 party that didn't run till at least 7
or 8am, that was in a less than permitted location, that was
oversold, that had a disorganized crew, that wanted to sell me
bottled water, etc.

>> PRICE. And regardless - $30 for a fucking CLUB night that's going to be
>> fucking packed, have security, and charge club prices for drinks? Value
>> wise that's never going to be worth my money regardless of who is 
>> playing.
>> Now maybe if they brought in REAL top notch talent playing live like they
>> did years ago when Hybrid played Kelly's Mission Rock live I'd pay. It 
>> was
>> a miserable experience due to the overcrowding, but I got to meet the 
>> guys
>> and ask them questions so I got what I really wanted. But fuck man... I'm
>> really sick and tired of SF and its over priced and over hyped nightlife
>> industry. I can only hope that if//when I'm back in the area in the 
>> future
>> that all of this implodes, people stop supporting this shit and things 
>> get
>> back to basics again. I know it won't happen though because more and more
>> SF is posturing for a high-end lifestyle and it will only get worse.
>
> Presales ease the budgeting process by getting money in sooner. I
> think rewarding people who hand in their money sooner is reasonable.
>
> Perhaps the wording should be: Tickets $30. Presale ticket buyers
> get a $5 discount.
>
> One should get a *whole lot* for $25 or $30, At that price point
> collectives I've been associated with have thrown events with great
> light shows, visuals, and artists. We've provided free-food, plenty
> of porta-potties, smoothies, chai, earplugs, etc. We've provided
> bust-proof venues with lots of room, friendly and professional
> security, and EMTs too.
>
> I'd be disappointed in a $30 party that didn't run till at least 7
> or 8am, that was in a less than permitted location, that was
> oversold, that had a disorganized crew, that wanted to sell me
> bottled water, etc.
>

> I have this manpurse/fannypack hybrid. It's like a fanny pack that's
> flat, or maybe u can see it as a manpurse with a waist belt. I't's as
> practical as a genuine  fanny pack but with the contemporary styling
> of a proper manurpse.  LMAO  :)
>
> I used to never wear it cuz it's just, well.... a manpurse is a
> manpurse (and I had it for 4 years). Then I started wearing it a lot
> since I got an iPod: It carries the iPod, accessories, my PDA, my cell
> phone, etc. All in one place. I no longer have to check all 6-7
> cargo-pant pockets to find something.
>
> Manpurses are grate, I'm a believer now. Let's embrace the fashion
> victim in us all.  :)
>
>
>
> - Jeff
>
>
>
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Thumpoween question

I think the Bay Area has an extremely good mix of free, cheap, medium, and 
high priced parties, as well as a good mix of electronic music, and of 
bar/lounge, club, underground, and rave scenes...something for everyone.

Any industry will have some people that do it for the greed, some that do it 
for the love, and some that love it and are trying to make a living out of 
it.  I see plenty of people on both side of the fence in SF, but I'm glad I 
have options.

From sfraves-return-116664-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Oct 27 00:40:11 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-116664-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

X-No-Archive: yes

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 54989 invoked from network); 27 Oct 2004 00:40:10 -0000
Message-ID: <20041027003949.49113.qmail@web41011.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 26 Oct 2004 17:39:49 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jessica McMahan <ceridwen_ruad@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY2-F37gYBr4BvRnfv00031c1d@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Thumpoween question

I really hate to stick myself into this innane arguement, but I see the
business side of it - from the venue owner's point.

The rising cost of material to run the club rises every day. The more
people drink, the more supplies you have to buy to replace used/broken
material. Bars have to order new glassware every week, new janitorial
supplies, employees salaries, utilities, etc.

And because of the rising costs, they have to pass that along in their
rental costs and door charges. That's where WE come in - we have to pay
these rising costs, drink more, etc. to keep them in business.

Now when you add that in to the costs of running an event such as
Thump, there you get your $30 door tix, with the $5 off price if you
buy early. It's a deal for what you're getting for 7 hours of fun
times.

So honestly, I don't see why *anyone* is bitching - inflation & the
cost of living here is fucking high. I think we're LUCKY to only have
to spend $30 to see Simon & hear lots of other awesome acts and enjoy
the decor.

Anyway... have fun @ Thumpoween... I have to miss it for a family
funeral in Ohio.

Jessica

> that do it 
> for the love, and some that love it and are trying to make a living
> out of 
> it.  I see plenty of people on both side of the fence in SF, but I'm
> glad I 
> have options.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Thumpoween question

Jessica McMahan <ceridwen_ruad@yahoo.com> said...
> I really hate to stick myself into this innane arguement, but I see the
> business side of it - from the venue owner's point.
> 
> The rising cost of material to run the club rises every day. The more
> people drink, the more supplies you have to buy to replace used/broken
> material. Bars have to order new glassware every week, new janitorial
> supplies, employees salaries, utilities, etc.

> these rising costs, drink more, etc. to keep them in business.

Where does this information come from? Are you speculating? It
doesn't seem to jibe with anything I've seen or heard.

I've known many bar/club owners and none have ever complained about
breakage. If people are buying enough drinks to break a lot of
glasses, the bar is making BANK. Glasses cost *nothing* compared to
the markup on alcohol. *Nothing*.

If you want to see something interesting, look at both Thump's and
550 Barneveld's _actual_ budgets for that night.

Sean

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Howard Stern calls in and clashes with FCC Chairman. Check it!!!

Yup.. crazy indeed.  Michael is a very well spoken man.  Articulate, sharp,
thoughtful.. Essentially the quintessential lawyer turned FCC politician.
Howard came in a little frantic, and should have taken the two hours for
which he knew he was going to call and draft out some questions with his
lawyer.  Perhaps he did.. Perhaps they just don't have much of a position..
regardless.. Howard came out of that a little ruffled.  

Here is the wrap-up

1. Consolidation: Rules for spectrum allocation regarding consolidation by
conglomerates have tightened to restrict large firms from buying broad
market shares.
   
2. Indecency jurisdiction: The FTC governs commercial content, and that is
subject to protection under the first amendment, except in cases of
indecency in which the FCC was granted special power to impose fines and set
standards for indecency as determined by the Supreme Court and congress.

3. FCC Board constituents are non-partisan.. although some have expressed a
conservative and over-reaching desire to curb further indecent private
content.  To this Michael responded that he felt it was wrong to try and
restrict private content under first amendment rights and that the it was
the wrong direction for the governing body. 

Too bad nobody called to inquire about the free-radio bans in santa cruz and
elsewhere.. one caller was from santa cruz.. but the ass-wipe made the fatal
error of having his background radio on and it looped into the broadcast and
so was cut off.  I can't believe he friggin did that.. what a dork..  if you
are reading this.. better luck next time.. oh ya.. what next time.

Cheers!
Ranger

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Thumpoween question

That's the case for pretty much any after hours club, not just Thump.
People just don't down non-alcoholic drinks after 2am like they do booze
before 2am. So you have 4-6 hours of operating time where there bar isn't
doing much business. Most people don't get to a club til midnight, so that
leaves only 2, maybe 3 hours of drinking revenue. No wonder the cover for
most after hours clubs is so high. This is especially the case if you have
to pay for out of town big name DJs. The bar does help subsidize that
somewhat, but not like if it there were alcohol sales past 2am.


On Tue, 26 Oct 2004, Tim Hockin wrote:

> Also, I don't think Thump is exactly a windfall in the drinking area.
> Most Thumpers are otherwise engaged.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Thumpoween question

Just throw in my own twi bits on this one....

I have to agree with Ryan almost 100% on this one.  I don't so much 
have a problem with pre-sales being a bit cheaper.  I've even been 
known to pop out to the record store, myself, to score the el-cheapos 
to a party I know is getting jacked up.

But as far as ticket prices go, it seems that far too many promoters 
*STILL* haven't gotten it through their skulls that the dotcom boom is 
over, the economy's in the shitter despite what the talking monkey 
says, and we're NOT all swimming in money anymore.  I know *I* sure as 
hell can't drop $30 (JUST for the ticket, double or triple that for the 
whole night's expenses.) on a whim.  And I certainly WON'T for a club 
night at a skeezy place like 550 barnevald.

I wonder what the average pay-cut on SFRaves has been over the 
2000-2004 timeframe?  I'd guess it's been quite significant.  I know it 
has been throughout the Bay Area overall.  But are promoters lowering 
their prices accordingly?  A few are.  A few more never got the idea of 
making phat bank off  the rave scene in the first place, and have had 
reasonable prices since I first moved here.  And kudos to them.  But 
all too often, you see promoters still expecting to live the high life 
off of the scene, and still charging dotcom-era prices of $30 or more, 
with $4 water, and so on, for one night's worth of entertainment.

Hell, even Skills has dropped the price of their tickets!  The first 
Popsicle I went to, I think I paid $40 for my ticket.  The one coming 
up, I paid $22 including the record store's service fee!  And Skills is 
the "big commercial massive promoter" that everyone loves to hate!  
(Heh... bonus:  they've also finally figured out that telling people to 
go home at 2am is teh lame, otherwise I wouldn't be going even with the 
cheaper ticket price.)


cya,
john
